description:
OK let me start off by saying I was told to come to this restaurant by a buddy of mine who said it's the best sushi he's ever had in his entire life !!!!

so I thought what the hell that's pretty high praise and he has traveled Extensively so I figured well Dam those are pretty big words !

Not only did it live up to the hype it completely smashed it out of the park !

I would give this place 20 stars  if I could!!!!!!!
author: Azikiwee A.

description:
I got take out on Saturday afternoon. It was pretty good and would potentially go back, although I wasn't as impressed as I thought I'd be given the reviews.

I got the most expensive sushi platter that appeared to have a nice collection of fish that I liked. It was fine, and a few pieces were delicious, although overall I though it was just "better than average." They are lucky to get four stars from me as it probably deserves a 3, but I'm in the mood to support local business.
author: Oliver J.

description:
Oh man! When my girlfriend proposed this place for dinner I was hesitant as its so far away from the city, but I need to keep an open mind - after all Wako is somewhere nearby too. 
So we arrived here on Sunday night, at 7pm with no reservations - got seated at the bar.
There is omakase menu for $90 per person- 2 people minimum. Argh! I can't come back to dine alone, which I love! 
The special a la carts menu, the daily special menu. 
I got the wagyu tartar with the quail egg, and the wagyu dumpling with foie gras, bonito sashimi, Hotate sashimi, and ceviche. 
Mama Mia! So good! 
I can't wait to go back to San Francisco to eat here again. Reminded me a lot of dining in Tokyo with all the decadent rich dishes. 
The interior is unassuming, a bit crowded, service felt a bit rushed. 
But if you can close your eyes on that, and just come with a curiosity for the food - you will be delighted. At least I was :)
author: Anelya S.

description: The best sushi restaurant in town. Must must must try. Reasonably price with the best food.
author: Jim J.

description:
HIDDEN GEM. I'm even nervous to post this as I don't want people to know about this place but they deserve 5 stars. I had been here once a couple years ago for the omakase and thought at that time it was good already. I think I was really full which is why I never wrote a review. 

Came here recently on a Friday night - had called around 6pm to see if they had a table for 2 at 7pm...they did. Got there and was seated (people did try to walk-in and were told to a 30min to hour wait). 

Kabuto has a high quality fish and helpful service. We didn't did the omakase this time and decide to try all the things. The menu is pretty extensive but don't forget to look at the board above the chefs for the specials.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This unassuming little place elevates sushi to a contemporary, thoughtful art form. Innovative takes on tradition meets modern updates include the ceviche, pear hamachi, and crunchy sushi.

Everything is extremely fresh and delicious and I love that the wait staff gives not-so-gentle instructions to not use soy sauce on certain sushi creations. They are absolutely right - they deserve to be enjoyed unadulterated. 

Some reasonably priced sake options are on offer to accompany the delectable fish and rice.

All other SF sushi places pale by comparison. And even the sushi I tried in Tokyo a few weeks ago could not compete.
author: Carole B.

description: Best sushi in the city. Absolutely no complaints about this place. The staff is friendly and the sushi is INCREDIBLE. I recommend this place to everyone.
author: Ina S.

description: Holy amazing! Vegans here- We tried the Hijiki salad (which was quinoa and seaweed) and are now obsessed. Get the Nasu Dengaku (eggplant fried and grilled with miso) if you want to live a happier life. Also tried the tofu miso and avocado sushi roll which were both excellent. Thanks Kabuto!
author: Julia D.

description:
Let's talk about the sushi itself, probably this is one of the best traditional style sushi restaurant which you don't need reservation in San Francisco. Scale 1 to 10, I give theit 7.5 to 8 (10 is for Jiro only), if consider about the price, then maybe 7 to 7.5.
As a sushi lover who have been experienced several Michelin star sushi restaurants in both United States and Japan, I would say they got pretty great fish and solid skills, but a little bit overpriced. I say there are at least 2 more restaurants in sf I recommend more at this $100 per person price. (Please forget the crazy dragon roll or rainbow roll when we talk about serious sushi.) The old sushi chef is as cold(cool?) as most of these great sushi chef, as what he should be. 
The only thing I doubt is, why there is no hot towel before the meal? Come on, using hands is one of the sushi transition.
author: Louie Z.

description: An excellent surprise lunch!  We stumbled into Kabuto when the Thai Restaurant we were going to try was closed on July 4th.  Every piece of sushi was perfectly presented and executed.  Toro tartar, foie gras, hamachi pear, hirami ceviche, spider roll, Toro truffle caviar, akinmo!  Fresh grated wasabi too!  Will be back for more.
author: Mei L.

description:
I have proudly been supporting Kabuto for many years. Those of which were in my childhood. Originally located across the street, this staple Richmond district restaurant has been serving delectable Japanese fare.   I loved coming here when I was younger and today, I am still able to enjoy some of the same recipes and classic dishes. Some of my favorites include soft shell crab appetizer, spicy tuna handroll, and unagi nigiri. You can't go wrong with any of the futomaki rolls and of course their excellent choices of sashimi. I also love their miso soups. I always ask if there is any chutoro or otoro.

Recently visited and wanted a Hamachi Kama however they were sold out. Get there early if you want one!
author: Shannon M.

description: The quality of fish here leaves a lot to be desired.... avoid the uni here as they don't know how to properly assess its quality and are not going to admit to it.
author: Joshua L.

description: This place been around for a long time and I could never get enough of their sushi. I love their foie gras sushi and truffle toro. The portions are small and pricy but so worth it. My fav go to place for good fresh sushi.
author: Christy V.

description:
Sat at counter. I wouldn't call it sushi "bar" because the sushi chefs don't provide service directly.
Instead of putting your nigiri orders on the provided Sushi Geta(sushi plate typically where the chef places your nigiri) they bring out nigiri orders on many plates creating spacing issues. The Geta is right there. Why not use it for it's purpose? 

Food was pretty good but our order of nama kaki(raw oysters) that we ordered 15 minutes before the rest of our food, came out towards the middle of our meal. The oysters were not on the shell but 3 tiny oysters with 1 shiso leaf and a little daikon. I wasn't impressed for the price or taste
.
Sushi quality was good, very fresh without too much rice. They know how to do sushi well. 

Service was decent and friendly. Water was never offered even after having much sake. The wine list has several wines on their list but they only have 1 red and 1 white.


Nigiri is 4 stars. The rest is 3 stars
author: L D.

description:
How do you say delicious in Japanese?Oishi!
We had the grilled eggplant, seaweed salad, chicken katsu, pickles veggies, Udon noodles. Our waitress was Kaori, she was great!
author: Marian F.

description: Excellent quality fish.  Great service.  We go to this neighborhood gem regularly.  They have nice specials and a decent variety on their menu.
author: Kayvaan G.

description:
I'd been here once before and recalled liking it and when we arrived this time is was packed so that felt like a good sign too.

Sadly mistaken! The only good thing to report back about our dinner was the servers were very nice and efficient.
We ordered edamame, veggie tempura, spicy tuna, and fresh salmon and escolar sushi. It took us almost 1.5 hour to finish our dinner. The veggie tempura was overcooked and pretty nasty - first time I had overcooked tempura, didn't know it was possible but now I know it is.
The fresh sushi was okay - nothing to write home about but the prices were. My 2 pieces of king salmon (i'm guessing about 3 oz total) were $20.
I also ordered the grilled sea bass about 10 min into our meal. About 30 min later I assumed they forgot about it and we were ready to go, so I asked for the check. Then, 2 min later the sea bass comes out. It was clearly a frozen fish. Didn't finish it.
Overall, I'll never go back - we spent over $100 on a hugely disappointing meal.
author: Heather C.

description: Overall, it was pretty good.  The sushi rice is not very flavorful in my opinion.  At least, compared to other high end sushi places.  Also, Kobe + Foie Gras dumplings have a lot of going on them: uni, caviar, gold leaf.  I think their taste is lost, but looks really nice.
author: Pasha G.

description: This was my second time back to Kabuto since 3years ago. We had Chirashi and a few Nigiris. I was so surprised how good it was. All the fish were so fresh and great cuts - slices of nigiri sashimi portions were thick and big. They were really great. I usually prefer fancier sushi restaurants.  I will definitely come back!
author: Misa M.

description:
Initially thought we had the wrong place when we were walking in as the restaurant looks quite low key in contrast to trendier Japanese restaurants. However I much prefer this type of atmosphere where the focus is on the food. Only qualm, since the restaurant is so small, everyone is seated very closely together and personally I prefer some more space. It felt like I could hear everyone's conversations, especially pronounced when there were young children yelling.

We had the omakase for $80/person and for the price I thought that the amount and quality of food received were really superb. Standouts included the 1849 oyster, hamachi pear, toro caviar truffle sushi, and foie gras sushi. I was actually delaying swallowing the food because it tasted so good and I can still remember how it tastes now as I write this review. Presentation was beautifully done and the flavor was there to match it . Gold flakes were definitely extra but I don't have any complaints about that because I'm extra. All in all a really amazing meal that I'll be back for.
author: Annie D.

description: Low key place. Quiet, simple, clean. Great service. I was a little overwhelmed by the selection not because it was super numerous but mostly that so many things were unconventional
author: Kris F.

description:
Wonderful seafood and sushi. The hamachi kama is worth the visit alone. Also, the kobe sushi, yum!

This is a small place with non-existent decor. But you are here for food, not ambience, so focus on your ordering. 

The miso soup is on the salty side. I could live without the anago or unagi. But all things tuna are wonderful as was the seared black cod sushi.  

And as I mentioned above, the hamachi kama was a delight. Fresh and tender, huge, great with just a squeeze of lemon.
author: michelle l.

description: Best sushi in SF. Nothing fancy except for the quality of the sushi. Nice sushi bar or tables. The fish is fricking fantastic. Been going for years. I cross town for it. Ceviche sushi. Hard to go elsewhere even with other very good sushi around
author: Bored I.

description:
Really delicious Japanese meal. The 1849 oyster was exquisite,  and the scallop ngiri was divine. Honestly, everything was great, except the second ngiri we got, which we can't figure out what it was for the life of us, tasted borderline spoiled. What was it?? We remember everything we ordered, and feel like the bad ngiri wasn't part of our order. 

Overall a lovely experience still.
author: Grizzle J.

description:
From the outside this place looks sketch, but the food is ON POINT. We had the 1849 oysters, dumplings, kimiyaki, uni, wild buri, king salmon, hotate, amaebi, shima aji and matcha creme brulee. If you don't try anything else, you gotta try the oysters!! 

I can't wait to come back!!
author: Tiff L.

description:
My best friend took me to this restaurant for my birthday.

We had omakase for $80/person. Everything was fresh and tasty! We sat at the counter! I didn't mind at all. The place was clean and service was amazing!
author: Majileen C.

description: I really wanted to like this place. After having the omakase.. I wasn't too pleased. There were only a few good bites. The pear hamachi was gross. The sauce on top tasted like in n out special sauce. Very off putting to have in sushi. I recommend not ordering the omakase.
author: judy c.

description: Food was excellent but service was off putting. We were there for a birthday dinner and rather than feeling good about celebrating, we all felt stressed. There were two waitresses...One was patient while the other was impatient. I'm not sure I'd return as my husband is very particular about the politeness of the servers. Too bad really, as everything we had was wonderful. The eggplant nigiri, the scallop in the shell, the savory custard dish, the scallop nigiri...all top notch.
author: Gillian Dawson Y.

description:
Come here for an amazing and unique omakase without the fancy atmosphere and prices. I'm kind of over the pretentious fine dining scene so this was a refreshing change of pace.

My fiancé and I came here to celebrate a special occasion and I loved how simple and unassuming the restaurant looked. He even asked if this was the right place when we walked in.

Simple and small, but the food speaks volumes. I would so much rather come here than some of the $$$$ "hot and new" Japanese restaurants popping up in the city. We both went with the $90 omakase, and I feel like it was the way to go as we got a good variety of their best dishes.

Each dish came out quickly and there wasn't a lot of fanfare (the chefs kind of ignored us), but whatever, that's fine as long as our bellies are happy.

So, here's what we ate that night:

Uni and eggplant soup
Hamachi jalapeno
1849 oyster
Salmon tempura
Grilled scallop with a green tea & chardonnay sauce
Baby main lobster
Ceviche
Hamachi pear
Toro caviar truffle sushi
Foie gras sushi
4 pieces nigiri
2 desserts

It was the right amount of food for a starving 5'2 girl. I was caught off guard by the beautiful presentation unique and often odd combination of flavors and sauces, but they worked! For example, the hamachi sushi came with pear and a mustard sauce...and it was delicious. Every single dish was impressive, except for the salmon tempura and nigiri, which were pretty standard/lackluster. 

Highlights (i.e. dishes I can still taste in my mind) were the 1849 oyster (beautiful dish!), toro & truffle sushi, and foie gras sushi. 

Make a reservation, sit at the sushi bar, and prepare to have your mind blown!
author: Valerie L.

description: Everything is good here! The kobe beef and foi gras dumplings were my favorite. There is also some spicy tuna with tempura seaweed dish that was incredible. We will be back for sure!!
author: Rosee K.

description:
Amazing sushi, amazing service, amazing everything! From the outside kabuko just looks like a normal Japanese restaurant but as soon as you walk through the door you know it's a legit sushi joint. Make sure to make reservations because the place has very limited seating. 

My friend and I's first time so we ordered a lot!! 

-1849 oysters: the first oyster I've tried that I actually enjoyed! Comes with quail egg, uni, etc

-ceviche: was my favorite! Came on top of a sheet of crunchy sweet sea weed

-amaebi sweet shrimp: liked this one the least, tasted very oceany and the texture was gooey

-live scallop: must get! Scallop comes two ways, one raw sashimi style and the inner parts are cut up and served as a mini clam chowder. Amazing!

-sunrise: salmon sushi served with a raw quail egg on top, was good but the egg made it VERY rich tasting 

-hamachi jalapeño: beautifully presented, really good 

-Kobe beef
-kanpachi
-hon maguro 
-tako
-tamago
-tuna sampler
-unagi
-green tea creme brûlée 
-green tea & strawberry panna cotta: AMAZING get it. 

All together our bill was $180, pricey but definitely worth it! We each had one of everything and left full. We will be back!
author: Linz C.

description:
I literally can't say enough great things about Kabuto. This is BY FAR the best casual sushi restaurant I have EVER been to.

Sit at the bar for a better experience and definitely get the recommended sake.

Once you go Kabuto (yes, like the Pokemon), you won't go back.
author: Natalie D.

description:
Fish was fresh, service was too slow. 

My wife and i arrived at the restaurant at 5:55, our reservation was at 6. After ordering a few items we received part of our order rather slowly and the second part of our order we had to wait for over an hour. In the meantime, people that came after us and seemed to be "regulars" since they greeted the sushi chef had received their food before us. I noticed a a customer receive the same order that i had ordered brought to his table before us even though we ordered before this person arrived.
author: Dennis K.

description:
I absolutely love the design and crafting of each sushi piece. I have never seen such level of craftiness. We ordered the ceviche which was completely not what he had expected. Don't take it the wrong way but it was not the raw fish in a cup kinda thing.  The beauty and photos that came out absolutely stunning. 

We lyfted here because this place it was hard to find parking. 

Wow I'm not sure what to write. The fish was okay. I just loved the design and taking pictures of it.


The service was great. 5 STARS FOR SURE!
author: Amy Y.

description:
Over the years, I've passed by Kabuto countless times driving on Geary.  I've had Kabuto bookmarked for a while and finally made it out to give it a try. 

"A" and I ordered the omakase ($75/person), which consist of the following items:

Hamachi Jalapeno - fish was fresh, but otherwise nothing unique.  

Uni and Eggplant Soup - I'm normally not a fan of uni or eggplant, but the two ingredients paired well together.  Unfortunately for me, there was a hair in my soup, which made me lose my appetite.  

1849 Oyster - Tasted like the ocean.

Tempura - nothing special as you can't really mess up on tempura.  

Grilled Spicy Mussels 

Baby Maine Lobster 

Ceviche - It's a piece of nigiri, but I wouldn't consider this ceviche as I didn't taste the tart/acidic flavor.

Hamachi Pear 

Foie Gras Sushi - Of all the items we had, the foie gras sushi stood out the most.  It was our favorite of the night.  It was so good I wanted to order another!

Toro Caviar Truffle Sushi 

Today's Sushi - Chef's selection 4 pieces of  nigiri

Dessert

Matcha Panna Cotta 

Matcha Creme Brulee

Not your typical omakase menu, but the presentation was beautiful. In terms of the omakase menu, I think it's overpriced.  I've had better omakase elsewhere.  But I have to praise the chef for his innovative creations.
author: Candice H.

description:
4 stars for the food. 

Went here for dinner with my boyfriend. It was both of our first time here. We made reservations for the sushi bar and were seated promptly when we arrived. We opted for the omakase menu and were definitely not disappointed. Our favorite of the menu was of course the toro caviar truffle sushi. So delicious, so divine. 

Service could use a bit more work. Sitting at the bar, with omakase, I expected more interaction from the sushi chefs. Not once did they greet us or talk to us. Service is also a bit slow. We waited a long while after ordering to get our drinks--We got our food before our drinks and had to ask for them again. 

Overall, based on the food, I'd definitely come again. The presentation was beautiful. Flavors were pretty on point and impeccable. Mixing different flavors you wouldn't expect had our tastebuds extremely happy.
author: kathyy t.

description: Kabuto remains my favorite sushi place in the San Francisco area.  In fact this trip to the west coast  took me to Napa.  I made it a point to stop on my way to SFO.  The quality of their fish is unparalleled.  Their menu is innovative and food beautifully presented.  The chef has an uncanny way of pairing fruits and sauces to make a perfect marriage of sweet and salty.  I always get the hamachi pear, tuna and unagi with caviar is unmatched. It is a treat to try one of their daily specials.  The quiet atmosphere is a plus too.
author: Nancy A.

description: My absolute favorite Japanese restaurant in San Francisco. Nigiri has always been fresh and flavorful, and I have quite a few favorite specialty rolls. The recommendations from the staff have always been amazing as well and the waitresses are great. I'm glad to be living within walking distance of this place now.
author: ashley d.

description: Worst experience in years. Sorry to state, poor and rude service last night. Our party was barely serviced or acknowledged! Additionally, the sushi rice either changed and/or was very watery. Won't be returning unfortunately. Too bad, used to be a great, cozy spot with friendly, good service and good sushi. Time to search for new sushi restaurants.  :(
author: Aaa T.

description: This place has the best sashimi I've ever eaten, hands down! They serve the freshest fish I've ever tasted. The texture was perfect - soft, tender, easy to chew. You will not be disappointed. Also tried foie gras sushi for the first time and I think I'm hooked. I'm obsessed with green tea and the green tea creme brûlée did not disappoint. I will be returning to order all the same dishes and more.
author: Sonia T.

description: Excellent. Fresh sushi. Omikase lunch is a steal. Blue fin is awesome. Unique creations are special (look at these pics & judge for yourself.
author: ashton l.

description: One of my favorites in the City. Fish is fresh and the chef has some interesting creations like the Ceviche nigiri.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
By far our favorite sushi place in San Francisco. About 10 years ago we wandered in for the Chirashi and were impressed by the quality of the fish. On one of our next visits we tried the Omakase, which opened up a whole new world of delicacies. Now we go regularly and look forward to our favorite nigiri a la carte: Aji, New Zealand Salmon, Akamutsu, Ocean Trout, Kohada, and Sayori. And we also can't pass up their special sushi, especially Ce Vi Che, Hamachi Pear, Hirame Jerry, Katsunagi, and Kobe Beef Sushi. While we stick to our favorites,  we see many diners enjoying hot and cold dishes from the extensive menu. 
The staff is welcoming even when the restaurant is very busy. Chef Eric likes to take a break when he can to greet the diners. And if you are there celebrating a special occasion, don't be surprised is he brings  you a special treat fit for the occasion. All in all, Kabuto is a great restaurant run by wonderful hosts serving delicious food.
author: JA K.

description:
The sushi is fresh and tasty! They add little adornments which make their style pretty unique.

Service was average, though initially I felt like they were somewhat pushy. In the span of 5 minutes after being seated I was asked if I was ready to order 2 or 3 times, while still holding the menu and reading through everything.

Everything I ordered was amazing.

Prices are high, expect to pay at least $50 a person if you order anything off their specials.

They never refilled my tea, which I finished 1/2 way through my meal :(

I know they are busy, though wait time between dishes was REALLY long. From observation they make everything in batches. So if you don't order a lot of items. You will wait a bit.
author: Masa K.

description: The melt in your mouth type of sushi you've always been waiting for ! We always get the hamachi jalapeño appetizer and it never disappoints. My fiancé loves the exotic type of sashimi and thinks this place carries the freshest kind ! She had octopus, squid, uni etc every bite we take we make this hmmmmm. Sound and do a little dance in our chair. Would 5 star this place every time.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Called that Shabu shabu restaurant on 9th and Irving at 9 pm and asked how long it was the wait, they announced that it was 1 hour. Halu was our backup plan so I said, "don't assume. Let me call." He said, "It is 9 PM, how crowded could it be? I threw back a look at him, "It is 9 pm on Friday. That spot is right by Clement. Everyone would be out." He let me call. So I did. The voice on the other end said, "For two?" Pause. "One hour." So much for the backup plan.

No longer wanting to take any chances, we drove to Geary. Something has to give. Or not.

Was about to walk into the ramen shop, until he asked: "Can I show you this place?" I looked across the street and there it was. A sudden change of heart, we jaywalked across Geary and entered this restaurant, at 9:15 PM. Packed, but there was two counter space spots that just opened up. It had our names written all over it. 

Lucky find. Omakase menu looked enticing but required more time than allotted. Octopus salad and chicken karage to tie us over. Specialty roll and spicy hamachi roll. and monk fish liver nigiri. Bonito fish nigiri to finish because it is "our" fish. 

It would appear that this is a crowd pleaser joint. Menu consists of hot and cold appetizers, very pretty and innovative rolls, and nigiri selection is more than you'd expect at a small restaurant like this. Rice is a bit too mushy though he seemed to like it just fine (to be expected given that he's some miscellaneous white guy from the midwest, who has not, presumably, developed the discriminatory taste for that perfect white rice as I have). I did not order enough nigiri to make an educated assessment but the neighbors seemed to be doing the Omakase thing, so I was able to do a visual inspection by proximity. I was impressed enough to want to give it another try when it is not this late. 

He said that he'd often walk by here and found it to be too crowded to come in. So there we were, two hungry people, Friday night, eating, at this seemingly popular spot, finally. 

For an Asian (mostly Chinese, some Korean and a little bit of Japanese), the only things I know how to make are American or northern European food, with the occasional Indian curry (British style) thrown in. Have not figured out how to cook East Asian food, which consists of predominantly Chinese, Korean or Japanese. So much for my heritage food.

Therefore, my enthusiasm for Inner Richmond's Japanese abundance runs high. I liked it. He loved it. It's in his hood. Chances are, we may come back sooner than expected.
author: Victoria E.

description: The food is SO original. Honestly the best sushi I've had in SF! Kudos for making an original restaurant and menu.
author: Toby C.

description: Find this place in the city on Tuesday night as a lot of restaurants close today. Very small restaurant but kind of clean. The food is good but kind of pricy as 3 adults+2 kids spent $200 for a dinner.
author: Zhang A.

description: The fish here is among the freshest I've ever had -- I normally don't like raw fish, but I actually like it here! It's not super strong/fishy-tasty, and you could tell that it's really good quality, really fresh fish. Rolls are pretty simple here, so don't expect to find the usual assortment of baked/mayo-smothered rolls with multiple types of fish! And I think that the price is actually pretty cheap for the quality here.
author: Grace D.

description: I was told that this place has fancy really good sushi, but when I went there, the sushi was way way way overpriced and not that good. It cost us $75 per person and didn't even have a good dinner. The place is also very small and not impressive at all. Do not recommend it and will never go there again
author: Tamer M.

description:
4.4 stars. I don't want to round up my 4.5 ;). 

We had a 7:45 PM Wednesday reservation, which was good because this small place was busy. 

The food is really delicious. I especially loved the ceviche, hamachi pear, and oysters. (See my pics of everything we ordered. Hopefully they're helpful.) 

We appreciated the special menu. This shows, to me, the fish is fresh because they don't have the same 'ole on a daily basis, though there are staples. I also enjoy a treat off of the special menu sometimes. I'm not taking a star away because they were out of three items we wanted. I'm chalking this up to a focus on freshness also. 

I'm knocking off a star due to the service. Our waitress wasn't particularly engaging or helpful. She also ignored us for a while and forgot our water.
author: Paulina F.

description: Gone here on a few occasions and they have always been on point. I've had a la carte as well as their omakase and everything is really fresh, simple, and of great quality. My boyfriend and I went recently on a random night and were seated promptly at the bar. We had 4 cold Asahi beers, miso soup with tiny mushrooms, a sashimi assortment, 2 pieces of uni, and two pieces of foie gras. This definitely isn't your go to place if you want to pig out on sushi. Explore their chalkboard menu of specials and you won't be disappointed. Great meal every time.
author: Rana K.

description:
Kabuto is one of those places that I hesitate to Yelp about because I think it has managed to remain a hidden gem. But what the hell -- there are plenty of reviews out there.

Anyway, definition of hidden gem. Really high quality, fresh sushi served in novel ways.

Get the hamachi pear or else don't even go. It's served with a delicate dollop of this crazy mustard-curry sauce that you would, at first thought, not want anywhere near sushi. But it works. So well.

Other home-runs: harame green apple, tuna tartar, kobe berry, hamachi jalapeno. Bottom line, I trust the sushi chefs with my life and think you could order anything and be very satisfied.

It's a tiny restaurant and fills up quickly on weekend night, but they often take same-day reservations (or even same-night) if you just call ahead.
author: Elena K.

description: This is literally my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Been coming here since they first opened. If it's your first time, go for the tuna tartare, spicy tuna tartare, hamachi pear, and ceviche. I'm salivating just thinking about it...
author: Wes Y.

description: The best sushi restaurant in town. It is as good as anything I have tried in Japan in my more than two dozen trips there. Don't be fooled by unassuming decor and admittedly shabby exterior. Just step inside and let the food speak.
author: Eugene K.

description:
SF is blessed with a bounty of amazing sushi restaurants. Is Kabuto the number one absolute best ever? I can't say. But I can tell you what makes me love this place and what will keep me coming back. Fresh fish is the key to any good sushi. Kabuto has created some very creative flavor and texture combinations that are not only delicious but memorable. The service is humble and somehow the people remind me of my family. It's not fancy but does great food need to be? We used to live in the Richmond district back when we first moved to SF and to think we passed this gem every day makes me feel like I really missed out.

It is on the pricier side but I felt that it was fair and worth it. I don't like to eat big meals so we didn't have to order much for me to be satisfied and full. But I imagine most people could double what I am about to recommend. Omakase is probably your best bet then. The only thing that I didn't enjoy was the Sonoma duck special sushi. Wasabi overload.

Here is what we/I had and would get again.

- hojicha 
- hamachi pear 
- ceviche
- 1849 oyster 
- toro tartare
- salmon with uni + caviar
- matcha creme brûlée 

I forgot to ask about foie gras and live scallop but again I wasn't that hungry so maybe next time.
author: Sarah A.

description:
I came here with my girlfriends for a birthday celebration. We were actually very excited to try this place out because of all the good reviews on yelp. We walked in and told the server party of 3. She asked if we had reservation, we said yes but we were late to the reservation. The server directed us to one of the 4 empty tables ( this place is not a big restaurant, when I said 4 empty tables I meant there were only 3 occupied tablets with some scattered guest at the bar). Then an older server form the back stepped in and stopped the server who was sitting out party and spoke in Japanese about the fact that we were late and etc. We explained that we understand and asked if we can be seated as walk-in instead. Again, the older server kept saying we were late and they won't seat us. I mean, come on, less than half of the restaurant was full and they won't seat us? They said those tables were reserved but those guests just haven't showed up yet. So they told us to wait 20-30 minutes by the door and see if those guests will show up. (What? If those tables were reserved, the server won't direct us to seat there). Anyhow we got seated after waiting for about 10 min, we got seated at the table we were originally assigned. After we sat down and for the next 30 min, those tables were still empty!!! Did they want to discipline us for being late even if they have tables available and still not seat is? The first impression to this restaurant was bad! 

The server told us the Omakase set dinner was most popular($80/person). We didn't want to think which one to order individually so we just went with it. 

I am not going to comment each dish individually. But I have the say two dishes were worth mentioning 1) the seafood soup is plain miso soup with frozen seafood 2) oysters were not fresh!!! After I ate the oyster, I start to have some cramping, and after cramping for 15 minutes I had to run to the bathroom... (sorry)... bad diarrhea! 30 minutes after I had explosion, the rest of my friends each had to rush to the bathroom for the same reason. 

They kept rushing us to leave even if we still want to order more food ( that set dinner is not fulfilling at all). And once we finished the extra food we ordered, they rush to clean the table when we were still working on the dessert. Come on! It is not like we were just sitting there with empty plates or not eating. Can't they see there are still lots of dessert and we were very busy eating them?! 

The bill.... automatic gratuity 18%... for party of 3....  that was not mentioned on the menu nor anywhere else. We understand for large party, it is automatic... but for party of 3? I felt ripped off. The total bill came to almost $380 for 3 of us. We walked out and told ourselves we will not come back ever again! The food and service do not equal to its price. Food were not fresh and not tasty as it should be, not to mention its service. BONUS: everyone had diarrhea and cramping. 

Omakase on townsand street was a pleasant experience and worth for what I paid for.
author: Rebegi G.

description: Enjoyed dinner with a friend who took me to this place when I suggested to have sushi dinner. As advertised, this is a gem of a place. Unassuming, fairly small, but the sushi and sashimi are extremely fresh and flavorful.  Everything was excellent.  From sashimi combo to octopus sunomono and rolls with avocado.   Would love to be back.  The place is small, so it can be a wait time, if you don't have reservations.  Not cheap, by the way, but it is worth it!
author: Alex G.

description:
I first came to Kabuto about 5 years ago for my sister's birthday. We were a party of 10 in this small restaurant. Service was excellent and food was fresh and fast. It is quite pricey so if you're not willing to go all out and $$$$ splurge, you won't leave feeling full.

I made another trip out here over the summer and the designer sushi was as good as I remember, but the service wasn't. It's super fancy pants with foie gras sushi and wagyu beef involved. Toro caviar truffle sushi anybody? Yup, special and unique flavors! Treat yourself once in a while. ;) 

Service isn't always great, it's out of the way for me, and it's super pricey, thus deducting 1 star. SF has a lot of amazing sushi places so the competition is real!
author: Farrah N.

description: The most creative sushi I've ever had in the city. Great quality for the price. I only ordered from the special sushi menu--10 different things. Everything was amazing. They even tell you not to ruin it with soy sauce.
author: KC C.

description: Great dinner at Kabuto. First time. Everything was delicious & very fresh.  All the wait staff were friendly.  I  loved every bite.
author: Win C.

description: Amazing!! This place is amazing!! The food is so fresh and delicious. The best sushi i ever had. It taste like Japan! Great quality!
author: Anthony L.

description:
Think I just broke my record of most photos taken during a meal. Was too lazy to bother screening every yelp review to see what the must-eats were, so we ordered the omakase for two. #noregrets.

Food: 
In order of "don't want to brush my teeth so the flavor can linger until the morning":
1. Foie gras sushi - already planning my next meal here just for this. 
2. Toro caviar truffle sushi - money in yo mouth. 
3. 1849 oyster - every oyster should be born this way. 
4. Shrimp crab ball with edamame soup - just divine. 
5. Baby main lobster - perfectly seared, and soft meat. 
6. Scallop green tea Chardonnay - the sound of this dish was either going to be really good or really bad; it was really good!
7. Hamachi pear - the mustard aftertaste threw me off, felt like I had eaten a hotdog instead of a piece of sushi. 
8. Hamachi jalapeño - bit salty. 
9. Ceviche - plain. Wanted to dip in soy sauce but waitress had said "no soy sauce" with authority. 
10. Tempura - perfectly battered  
11. Chef's choice of 4 pieces of nigiri - sake was the only good one; the snapper, tuna, and hamachi wasn't anything spectacular. Feel like they should start off with this dish, as it becomes underwhelming after more flavorful ones. 
12. Green tea creme brûlée 
13. Gingerbread cake

Ambiance :
I'm a sucker for cozy Japanese  restaurants, just feels more authentic when your elbow is grazing a stranger's elbow at the bar - how you doin? ( Joey from Friends voice)

Total damage: $174
author: Bernice C.

description:
I was super disappointed at this place, especially after hearing all of the good things about it. The name of this restaurant brought up several times in an eater group, and someone even mentioned this is "the most memorable place in SF if she moved out of the city". After hearing a such high review, I decided to give it a try. 
We arrived on Sunday evening at 7pm. As we walked into the restaurant, all tables were full except the sushi bar. BUT, all customers were white. Not trying to be racist, but if you walk into an Asian restaurant and saw only non-Asian customers, it's not a good sign.
We sat down by the sushi bar, at this moment our eyes are at the same level as the glass fish storage thinging (not sure what to call that). The glass was foggy and dirty, which makes the fish look really unappetizing. Waitress then put down the menus, and the menus...were so old and wrinkled which almost tear apart. Omakase is $80/ppl and ONLY serve for 2+ people. My husband refused to order Omakase because the restaurant's appearance, so we made 3 individual sushi orders to try it out, and 2 seafood udon. 
After we tasted the 3 sushi we ordered, two were randomly picked from the Omakase menu, and one was Kobe beef slides. They were extremely heavy on the sauce, so heavy that I couldn't even taste the fish or the beef. The most Disappointment was the presentation, the plate was dirty, and you can even see finger prints around the plate, it was horrible and disgusting. Out of all of the sushi restaurants I've been tasted across the world, this presentation was the most disappointed one, especially under such high cost. Udon was salty, I couldn't finish mine.
The overall experience was so disappointed, I even wonder if this is the same restaurant that received such high review, or if we being serve the same food?
author: Huilin D.

description:
4.5 stars. This place's menu is incredible.  Any dish that you have ever seen in a japanese restaurant (other than ramen and yakitori) is covered here. The menu is 10 pages long, with special sushi menu of 2 more pages.  It's basically an encyclopedia of Japanese dishes. 

The menu is quite eclectic - some super authentic dishes mixed in with innovative concoction (without mayo which some restaurants tend to insert to appeal to the American palate).

The best ones on the menu:
- 1846 oyster: fresh oyster with uni and quail egg, and a bit of gold leaves on top, thus the name (year of California gold rush)

- uni sushi from japan. A bit pricey at $10/piece though

- live scallop. I actually like the scallop concoction inside the spoons better than scallop sashimi (there was a small sand particle in the sashimi, and scallop sushi just taste better than sashimi when the scallop is that tender, in my opinion)

Highly recommend:
Hamachi kama (yellowtail collar, grilled): very tender,  big portion

All of the sushi were really solid (saroyi, kanpachi, butterfish). Satoyi (a white fish with beautiful grey skin) was quite unusual - would recommend trying.

Ceviche: not what you think of ceviche.  More of an innovative halibut roll with a twist. Quite good.

Cucumber somonomo: refreshing. pretty good. More of an interlude between the important dishes

so-so (I would avoid)
Chawamushi: I hate carrots in chawamushi. And it lacked chicken and gingo nuts (my favorite ingredient in chawamushi)
moroyo (cucumber with moro-miso): simple. Just ok.
Mango ice cream: lackluster
author: Rebecca C.

description:
2.5 stars.

I don't think the price matches the quality of the fish. Some of the sushi we got were a bit stringy in texture :\ I now compare all sushi to Amami in San Bruno because they are just so fresh with the right price. This place didn't compare :( Also, their "special sushi" is super expensive at about $5-7 per PIECE. We didn't order it, but man, that stuff better be amazing for that price!

Pretty small place but we were able to get same-day reservations so that wasn't an issue.
author: Kathy L.

description:
comes here pretty often, around 2-4 times every month, because it's close to home and food quality is delicious every time I go. Street parking only, it's a small restaurant and always packed on weekends.
My favorite plates were their exotic oyster, hamachi pearl, baby lamb. The food plate design is very pretty, and the service lady is very nice ( always reminding everyone " no soy souce XD ).
author: Yilin Y.

description:
My favorite part of the meal was when the food moved my friend to exclaim, "This is challenging me!". I, on the other hand, like my food like I like my 70s dance jams: the funkier, the better. Bayyybeh!

(^_^) SHRIMP & CRAB TARTAR $6 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=aIdDirnv2zUyV3laJvsRJQ)
Texture-wise x taste-wise, my fave of the night.

(^_^) 1849 OYSTER $7/ea (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=gAnlw5reRaeW02VRrZQUdA)
There's gold on it. That's all you need to know. Get it.

(^_^) CEVICHE $6 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=xgtYr-ZJFT6Yu_GKSKcIJg)
Didn't get to try it; my friends really enjoyed it.

(^_^) ICED TEA $3 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=b0O4SdZ3MEJUkFyWFPGHig)
Mandatory.

(-_-) ONO GRAPE $6 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=CThiVr8CXKS23jbFFJkl7A)
Think I'd like it better as a smoothie. Not kidding.

(-_-) KATSUNAGI $6 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=c763c0sWLIer_IVJ5iDL3Q)
Fruitiness hid its sought-after savoriness.

(-_-) KIMIYAKI $6 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=UAb_P8JzjQQibks3D37t-Q)
I'm not into a ton of butter. If you are, you may like it.

(-_-) HAMACHI PEAR $6 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=Vs_AzY-1ipjJyREgnSk85Q)
Didn't get to try it; my friends said it was novel.

(-_-) SASHIMI TEISHOKU $25 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=FOFGQoDsQ1VZFiimpTTtXQ)
Didn't get to try it; seemed standard to my friends.

(v_v) SONOMA DUCK $6 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=cEHswuk0VRqSyYfozL9NDQ)
I love okra. I love duck. I don't love bland duck.

(v_v) EIHIRE NITSUKE $7 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=jaxa3kV_KOq1OtQtl3JZhQ)
Stingray. Only 2 small slices, though.

(v_v) SF TSUNAMI $6 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=2Xr5VxP55MrRtrDI0X39mg)
Visually memorable, taste-ally forgettable.

(?_?) KOTAKO $?
Couldn't order it because they ran out.

There's a $65 per person omakase with a substantial amount of food. I heart omakase. But, with a menu like this, I need strictly the oddest & craycrayest items, not a one-size-fits-all sampler.

Somewhere between 3 and 4 stars.
author: Dan B.

description:
This place is very easy to miss. You've probably passed by it a multiple of times not knowing what you've been missing. It's a small restaurant with amazing sushi. Their sushi has always been real fresh and they have very creative pieces.
I've eaten here a few times and each time my meal was exceptional and memorable.

Parking around the area is residential mixed with metered street parking.

The usual ones I order include (everything is off their special menu):
-1849 oyster shots- DELICIOUS. who could say no to an oyster topped with a quail egg, uni, and salmon roe. It's a medley of flavors and texture that's just amazzzingg and will wow your palate.
-the ceviche- refreshing and light. just delightful.
-hamachi pear- the pear brings a sweetness to the palate and compliments the hamachi very well. It also gives it a crispy texture to add onto the hamachi
-foie gras sushi- I used to always get it until california banned foie gras T_T..whyy!?!?!?
-scott handroll- spicy tuna hand roll topped with quail egg, yes as you can see i love quail eggs
-toro tar tar- also really good
-sunrise- beautiful presentation, it's salmon sashimi pieces wrapped around tobiko and topped with what else? but a quail egg :)

But you also can't go wrong with the regular sushi such as their sashimi, nigiri, and rolls.

This place is also real small, has a sushi bar and maybe 7 other tables? so you can imagine how busy it can get. I've always had a reservation each time I've eaten here. So I highly recommend making a reservation if you plan on eating here. If you decide on a whim to have Kabuto, you can test your luck!

You'll also be surprised how full you will get even though it seems like you didn't order much. I definitely want to try the omakase next time. I also thought the bill was going to be pretty high, but it wasn't that bad. Every time I've come here I've paid between $50-75 and I was stuffed!

Nothing can stop me from coming back here  XD
author: Stephanie L.

description:
What an great example to see another miracle happens in this country,

This kind of poor quality is a shame of 'Asian food'
author: Martin W.

description:
Ever single time I step into kabuto I'm thinking it's good but not the greatest. And then I get my first piece of sushi and it all comes rushing back to me. Holy Sh!! this is the BEST SUSHI in San Francisco bar none. These guys are constantly innovating with new rolls and flavors. If it doesn't work they drop it.  If it works they keep it. It's a simple philosophy and they keep surprising me with new flavors in an amuse bouche presentation. 

I recently had the toro truffle carpaccio with gold flakes and just about lost my mind with the explosion of flavor in my mouth. And the Foie gras nigiri is a must have.  My wife loves the toro nigiri.  I'm fine with whatever.  It's pricey but you get what you pay for and you always leave with a story of decadence that is unparalleled in San Francisco maybe the world.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Just bring one hundred dollars and some patience (for the wait time and service).

Let me preface this 4 star review by saying that I really would give this 3.5 stars if I could, but I'm feeling generous since I frequent this place often.

I thoroughly agree that the quality and service has gone down in the years...that's why I was debating on the 3 stars, but I still am a fan of this place, hence the 4 stars.

I feel that their fish and flavor profiles aren't as good as it used to be, and the service is always slow. 

The waitresses aren't old but they move like old grannies the last 3 times I've been here.

I really like their sashimi and special rolls menu.

Their tempura is okay, but I'm not a fan of their teriyaki chicken or beef. I feel that it's overcooked.

So I spend my time just ordering nigiri and sashimi...which can be done by the piece and not the pair. Usually about $3 to $4 a piece.

Munch, munch, chomp, chomp, and by the time you're halfway full it's about $100 dollars.

Oh and a charge of $4 for tea.

But, on Geary this is probably one of the better Japanese restaurants, so you'll trade your dollars and your time in exchange for some decent sushi.

P.S Save room for their Green Tea Creme Brûlée...it's one of my top 50 favorite foods...maybe another reason I'm giving this place 4 instead of 3 stars.
author: Jack R.

description: First things first! Lovely service! Now one of my new fave sushi spots in the city. Gold flakes on my sushi was icing on top of my !! Memorable specials include - Kobe Fois Gras Dumpling, Toro Caviar Truffle, Halibut Ceviche, Toro Uni...other items in my photo were delicious! Next time I would do the fairly priced and worth it Omakase since I ordered everything on that menu anyway! Can't wait to go back.
author: Quyen T.

description: The sushi is always fresh, the best quality, and prices are better than many of the other options in the bay area. The staff is so kind, polite and accommodating. Great for families and date nights.
author: Neli W.

description: Slightly dropping my review as my friend and I realized that really the best things here are the speciality items. The normal sushi doesn't deliver the same wow factor.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Can I just say, Kabuto is still my #1 sushi spot. Period. Don't get me wrong, I love traditional sushi, but the unique combinations they come up with here only enhance the flavors of the fish and take you to a whole new level of sushi experience.

Though the restaurant interior is nothing to take notice of, you can't help but take a moment to admire the fresh, beautifully decorated sushi that gets delivered to your table. I primarily order from their special sushi menu, but there are a few items from the regular menu that have become staples in my order.

Top items: 1849 oysters, Toro Tartar, Foie Gras (yes, it's back!), Ceviche, Sunrise, and Ono Grape
author: Kavita S.

description: GREAT unique sushi for the price. Love this place. Ambience is casual but the plates are displayed great and the sushi is so amazing for a low key place.
author: Rita Z.

description:
Just an amazing sushi spot. I passed by this place hundreds of times without noticing it at all, usually on my way to some other sushi spot. 

The place is clean, friendly service staff and great food. 
The sushi is always super fresh. Kabuto's sushi is traditional for the most part. The chef is very creative however, with tradition it is possible to stray from the common offerings and create something new inline with the tradition. 

That's one of the reasons I like this place so much, I find new and very pleasing items. The freshness of the fish is never compromised. I am a huge fan of the Okra Nigiri. The atmosphere is simple and personal, it's also family friendly.
author: Ben M.

description:
Amazing sushi - unique, amazing quality ingredients. The cooked meats didn't live up as much. It's also a tiny spot, very crowded inside.

SERVICE: We arrived & stood by the door for 15 minutes w/ no acknowledgement before I got a server's attention & we were sat. The servers were a bit hasty but efficient & did their job.

COST: ~$240 total for a filling dinner for 4 - everything below plus a lot of veggie rolls I didn't try.

MUST-HAVES: Aburi Toro (seared tuna belly), Agedashi Tofu, Hamachi Pear, Katsunagi (eel), Spicy Toro Tartar, Sun Rise (quail egg).
SKIP: Chawan Mushi (uni special), Lamb Apple, Live Uni, Sonoma Duck, Ume Yamaimo (potato).

Aburi Toro (Seared tuna. $19, 2pc) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#bOHQtSxs7u0DTLWVtG8_mQ
Excellent fatty & soft piece of tuna. Simple but the quality & freshness spoke for itself.

Agedashi Tofu (Deep fried tofu. $5) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#HEsqvB3K1v8sw8Xt3MLP5g
Great thin crisp skin, a simple broth. Delicous!

Ceviche (Halibut & salsa. $6, 2pc) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#rjAuBfcr_AOof-hjd0i5kQ
Good, not as amazing/memorable as the other items.

Chawan Mushi (special: steamed egg w/ uni. $6 each) - 2 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#P3phCETS03S7Dk3SYbnpzA
I'm an uni-lover & this was incredibly anticlimactic. This dish was very small, the steamed egg had just about zero flavor, & the texture was watery. The uni was overcooked, hard, & also flavorless.

Crunchy Sushi (Tempura halibut w/ curry sauce. $6, 2pc) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#SawElDvGrWIhlgIBsvxYdA
Amazing in its simplicity. The tempura was light, w/o too much crisp. but it tasted great, especially w/ the light, slightly sweet curry sauce.

Hamachi Pear (Yellowtail w/ pear & mustard. $6, 2pc) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#8I7WDJgnTuMSOR2xIa2ZuQ
One of my faves! Loved the crisp sweetness of the pear, the sharpness of the mustard, & the fatty fresh fish!

Hotapple (Seared scallop w/ apple & mustard. $8, 2pc) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#pQLmNjeHI9pPsAcHT5t8CQ
Beautifully presented. Loved that crunch & sharp mustard against the scallop (which was more seared, less raw).

Katsunagi (Eel, avocado, & shiso deep fried w/ raspberry miso sauce. $6, 2pc) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#OGhwhyI4S6XNShctOkpqcg
WOW! The crisp breading was fantastically crisped, yet soft. The sweet sauce was perfect (could easily have been overwhelming). I usually don't like eel but loved this!

Lamb Apple Sushi (lamb w/ apple & cherry balsamic sauce. $8) - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#q_rC_490IY3ZOUfouruF9g
Seemed more like a meat entree. Underwhelming. The lamb was overcooked, but it did have unique flavors.

Live Uni ($24, 4pc) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#PeK1ASt5KMOieoMl2kQniQ
Not as fresh as some other great live uni dishes I've had. The seaweed seemed a bit stale, hard to chew through.

Sonoma Duck (BBQ duck w/ Japanese spicy mustard. $6, 2pc) - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#9SXx1dtiYC-MbokY4hhCBg
Not very unique flavors, more like a teriyaki. The meat tasted overcooked.

Spicy Toro Tartar (tuna belly & avocado w/ tartar sauce. $5, 2pc) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#Ta2dEIfKbBkYZU4QVrLGXg
Amazing presentation, & eating it lived up. What a beautiful interplay of a lot of flavors (sweet fruit, spicy toro), & loved the perfectly tempura'ed wrap.

Sun Rise (seaweed w/ fresh salmon, roe, quail egg. $8, 2pc) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#erCTxsZZ8bvTbjoZqdN0Pw
Amazing!! You have to eat this whole thing in one bite. The way the thick runny yolk mixes w/ the salmon was like a mouth-gasm.

Ume Hirame (sour plum & halibut. $5 roll) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#_Os5NA4gq4-c6Ud7RN1gnw
My friend's go-to. This was good, but I'm not usually a fan so I'm not a good judge!

Ume Yamaimo (sour plum & mt. potato. $4 roll) - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tP-FwKAYo_6e_SrWxmwVOQ#CtULsLS9Ce4Cz2BDlnQ5eQ
Not very great.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
The sushi is always so incredibly fresh and they have some amazing different sushi as well, unlike some restaurants that just do different types of california rolls over and over again. My favorite have been the Hamachi Pear and the Katsunagi roll, though whatever random rolls I decide to try I have absolutely loved. You can tell that the sushi chef takes real pride in his work. 

Definitely my favorite sushi place so far. It's undeniable quality.
author: Kayla U.

description: Extremely overpriced, at least when you order anything off the specials menu. Be warned -- there is a reason why there are no prices listed! Do not be misled by the prices on the menu, because it is not a good gauge of what everything else will cost. If you're going to come DO NOT ORDER any of the chefs specials, do not ask the chef for recommendations, and stick to the $6-$9 for two piece nigiri vs $12 per individual piece ($24 for two)!!!!! If you're going to pay $150 for two people you might as well go to Kusakabe or do omakase at Akikos!!!!!!
author: Shirley L.

description: Very disappointing dinner at Kabuto. Horrible service. Waited over one hour for entrees. Having been here many times and experienced good service when ordering their dishes, we were surprised at the poor service. Service staff said that another big table came in but many other tables for two or four were being served just fine despite the fact they came in much later.  All we ordered were two simple rolls, two hand rolls and two sashimi dishes. Over one hour and then they were served over twenty minutes apart from each other while many other tables that came after we did were served promptly. Only explanation seemed that the expensive and more lucrative dishes were being served first because we saw all the tables around us being served those dishes in reasonable time.  However, the simple dishes we ordered were put on the back burner. Sad that this restaurant has chosen to put a hierarchy on its clients and does not treat all patrons equally regardless of what you order. We all deserve to be treated equally and not ignored or served last simply because we're not ordering the most expensive items on the menu.
author: Nadejda S.

description:
I just came back from a lunch at Kabuto, and I am glad to be close to a toilet. We used to go to that place for a very good sushi for years, but we have not been there for a while. It has changed dramatically. 

We made a reservation, but there was no need, as the place was nearly deserted. No wonder...The menu was all stained, dirty and crumpled. The food that came matched that. 
I had the chef's choice sashimi. The fish was old and like mush.  My date had a roll with eel, equally tired and old. The waitress behaved as if we intruded on her.  I promise that we will never do that again....
author: Julia A.

description:
I'm gonna give a shout out to my BFF for getting me a gift certificate for Kabuto. Because if it wasn't for her generosity, I'll never be able to afford this place.

And I would've missed out on so much.

Kabuto is legitimate. Awesome instagram pictures aside, the food here really really makes you tinge with satisfaction. I was eating their Ceviche and I tried to take smaller and smaller bites in a desperate attempt to prolong the sensational experience. My girlfriend was practically smiling after every bite. It made her look like a fatty, but it was too delicious so she didn't care anymore.

If you're in love with sushi, this is the place for you. If you dislike sushi, this place will change your mind. If you're a vegan, then please proceed to my other reviews.

I think everyone should try this place, even if you're not balling through your pants. Just budget yourself to several dishes (although that could easily clock you up to Benjamin territory) and get a taste of their sushi extraordinaire. If you're not full, don't worry. Save 10 bucks in your pocket and hit up Kowloon afterwards : )
author: Ringo M.

description:
Wow! This place rocks. We have been on a quest to find great Japanese food in SF and most of our encounters had left us bewildered- how can it be that so many Japanese places are missing the mark?  

We ordered at-least half of the items on the menu and everything was delightful!! The 1869, ceviche, Hamachi jalapeño, sea bass, tuna tartar, etc etc were delicious. This place is amazing and staff is wonderful. 

We didn't mention that we were celebrating of friend's birthday but somehow the owner heard us say it to our friend when we ordered desert and he warmly wished us and seeing our empty sake glasses, filled it up! It was just so endearing to see personalized attention when the restaurant was so busy.

We'll certainly will be back!
author: Sharika S.

description: The best sushi and service in SF! Great for everyone with an extensive menu vegans welcome! Would recommend the spicy salmon roll, salmon avocado roll/ Nasu dengaku
author: Campbell R.

description: We really enjoyed our meal but were a little put off by the loud table next to us. These guys were clearly celebrating but the quiet, close-quarters of the place made for a super uncomfortable experience. But we went for the food, I suppose. Hands down the best thing we had was the eggplant appetizer! I still dream about the creamy texture of the eggplant and the sweet, salty flavor of the miso sauce drizzled over it! Nomnomnom
author: Carlie D.

description:
Be careful judging this restaurant on the pictures alone. The pictures look great, real Instagram model pictures. There are way too many menus and menu items; think cheesecake factory.  

We ordered all the "appetizer" favorites that were reviewed well:
Ceviche
Kobe beef
Hamachi jalapeno
Foie gras sushi 
Toro caviar truffle sushi 

We then ordered quite a bit of sushi nigiri:
Hamachi
Blue fin
Toro
And a few others that the waitress recommended. 

Our waitress's breath smelled heavily of cigarette smoke, which blasted our palettes every time she came to us. The plates were too large for the table and the sushi, which were hurriedly dumped on us every time. 

The sushi was not fresh. The special appetizers that they do, the ones that involve hitting the sushi with a blow torch and/or dressing/masking the fish with a bunch of foie gras/caviar, are just ok; for two pieces of sushi nigiri, the caviar and foie gras appetizers were about $20 a piece. The kobe beef was good, but again, a lot of salt on top.
author: Ernest O.

description:
This is a long overdue review. I have been coming to this place for about 4 years and I still haven't gotten tired of it.

Food: Creative and delicious. The food here is Japanese fusion fine-dining quality for a very reasonable price. The portions are generous and the dishes are well presented. My favorites are the 1849 oyster, foie gras sushi, lobster sushi, and  jalapeño yellowtail. 

Service: The service is average. I think the waitress can be slightly more friendly and welcoming.

Atmosphere: The restaurant is casual but clean. Very typical family business type of setting.

Price: $200 for two dinner omakase; ~$90 a la carte for two.
author: Nawei C.

description:
Omakase $80 per person

Omakase includes premium menu items that are listed on their dry erase board. Everything was fresh and delicious and even kept me full.

Omakase included:

1. Shrimp crab ball and edamame soup: the shrimp crab ball was similar to that of a crab cake and complemented the soup well.
2. Hamachi jalapeño: fresh and flavorful 
3. 1849 oyster: raw oyster with uni, raw egg. Very delicious!
4. Tempura: battered fish. It's good very different than what you're use to at Japanese spots that make tempura
5. Scallop green tea ginger Chardonnay: grilled scallop with Chardonnay sauce. Scallop was well cooked.
6. Baby main lobster: fresh raw lobster served in a sushi form with empty lobster tail. The lobster was really fresh but just wish it wasn't so drenched in sauce. 
7. Ceviche: freshly served with rice and a large piece of seaweed for your own wrapping
8. Hamachi pear: fresh hamachi nigiri topped with pear
9. Toro caviar truffle sushi: my favorite one for the night. It just melts in your mouth. Well since its toro it better melt
10. Foie gras sushi: good sized foie nigiri very soft and flavorful
11. Today's sushi: 4 pieces of nigiri all fresh by chefs choice
12. Dessert: green tea brûlée was quite delicious

Overall a very good Omakase and especially for that price!
author: Joanne K.

description:
I've been to Kabuto twice now.  It may not look like much from the outside, but the second anything off their menu touches your taste buds... It's like being transported to a restaurant in heaven.  The most recent visit, we ordered a tasting menu that included the Toro with truffle and gold leaf, the famous oysters, the FABULOUS foie gras... all of which I have tried before, and it was lovely to be reacquainted.  But the surprise of the night was the delightfully rich Uni and eggplant soup!  I seriously could have had ten more servings of it.  

Can I just eat here every meal?
author: Haley G.

description:
Very disappointed. I used to come here a lot and I don't think I'm going back after today . 
Two of us ordered a lot . When the bill came there was an item I didn't know what it was so I asked the waitress she said to me it's tea! I was so surprised what kind of tea you charge for $3 a cup !?? Maybe she thought we had so many items on the bill and wouldn't noticed . I don't really care about the service but obviously it's getting worse. Oh well if they keep doing that to their customers they will lose them all !
author: Kiko W.

description: I hate to write bad reviews on a Japanese restaurant that has an omakase menu but my friend and I went there and both got the omakase menu ($80/person). It was the worst omakase experience we got. It felt like being in Chinese restaurant where you are being rushed out. Food was just dropped to you before you finish so you're forced to shove it in your mouth since there was no space. Food was ok...most memorable flavored dish is the nigiri itself and possibly the lobster sushi. Other than that, I can't remember much of the other menu. Maybe it's because we were forced to just shove it in our mouth rather than truly enjoying it. This is our second time here and might actually be our last. I would rather spend a bit more and go to Wako. Such a bummer as we were both looking forward to this dinner.
author: Amy T.

description:
This is now my favorite sushi restaurant in all of SF :) This tiny little restaurant on Geary is barely noticeable & doesn't look fancy at all. Their food quality is top notch. We ordered:
- Baby Main Lobster sushi
- Foie Gras sushi
- Toro tartar
- Abalone sushi
- Toro caviar sushi w/ gold flakes
- Hamachi
...and a couple more, I can't remember. But the above are my favorite absolutely delicious. Every plate has its own sauce with very fresh fish. This place can get very pricy but worth every dollar! Go early so you don't have to wait for a table
author: Cara N.

description:
Upon recommending Kabuto to a client today, I managed to come in also myself for dinner after ranting about them. 

This is one of my absolute favorite places to eat. Not just sushi but food in general. They treat you well here. VERY well. Although we came in late on a Saturday (30 mins before closing) they accommodated us and were so friendly. I'm quite particular about service and before I even noticed my tea was low I was met with another cup. Thorough explanation was given for our meal and advised on what to eat with soy sauce and what not to. 

Everyone checked up on us often and made sure it was good. Everything was awesome I cannot even emphasis that enough. Sushi chefs exuded confidence and care and waitress was so awesome and professional. 

Yay for Kabuto! :)
author: Chau N.

description:
Definitely some of the best sushi  I've ever had.
If you're looking for items you won't find elsewhere, this is the place.

Our favorites included the 'ceviche' the oysters and the foie gras. Even the miso soup was pretty amazing.
author: Flix N.

description: 4 and 1/2 might be more accurate, but regardless, I will be coming back to this place again and again. While the room is unassuming, the food is over-the-top good. Beautiful. high-quality, and brilliant execution. Whether it's kobe/foie gras dumplings with gold flakes, sauteed abalone in mushroom cream sauce (served on a spoon like an amuse-bouche), or the hamachi with pear and mustard, this place was full of surprises. Very small, so call ahead for any party beyond 4.
author: Jay N.

description:
Came here last night and the meal was excellent. Kudos to the Sonoma duck, foie gras & wagyu sushi, salmon uni with caviar and toro nigiri. Toro looked like thin slice of BACON! Fish bacon... yum....

We also got Chirashi, Jalapeno Hamachi which came in second to the above mentioned. Quite good and fresh too.

Got nasu dengaku (suggested by another yelper). I love eggplant and it was cooked very well (creamy) but I wasn't feeling the sweet miso.. it was heavy handed. But all else made up for this.

Come here for the sashimi. Their combination and execution of flavors is different and not quite like anywhere else and I love the unpretentious/homey atmosphere. 

Service was great actually. If you think the server is unfriendly, it's because she is serious about what they do there. I bet she knows as much about making the food there as the guys behind the counter.
author: S. S.

description: Bad service, food is bad. Our bill is $560 for 4, 4 omakasi, 1 bottle of sake, bring 1 on my own. The food they comby isn't bring out the main taste of the fish's freshness, it actually over come the main taste. The waitresses won't be able identify what's on the plate.
author: A X.

description: Best sushi I have had in my entire life. Most delicious. Here are some pictures. Friend of mine told me it was off the beaten track and they were right. Not very busy when I walked in but then it got really busy and big line and unbelievable food. Let the chef to the ordering for you.
author: Scott J.

description: Enjoyed the omakase menu here with so many dishes. I think the chef's choice nigiri course could use extra special fish instead of the common type.
author: S T N.

description:
Kabuto is one of my most favorites sushi joints in SF. Actually, it might even be my most favorite joints overall.   I came here with my friend around 6 p.m. last night and they have us two menus. One was for dinner, which had the grilled items and entrees, the other was the special sushi menu.  Being like the dorks that we are, we based our order upon the pictures that were posted on YELP.  Oh yelp,, how you complete us! Here's what we ordered

16-20 Kiss -. A sushi with shrimp, avocado and radish with a yogurt sauce. We ordered this, because it sounded interested, of course they worded it better then me.  It had a very soury lemon taste to it. We concluded that it tasted like a Vietnamese Spring roll.  

1949 Oyster-  It had a raw quail egg with tobiko, uni, salmon roe, oyster, and last by not least gold flakes.  You will have to slurp it up to eat this.  Who cares about being a lady or a gentleman.  When it comes to this dish you just need to devour it with all manners set aside. It was the perfect combo that went well with the fresh oysters. 

Ankimo sushi- Since the foie gras bans, anytime of pate is good.  The monkfish is as close is i can get to the foie gras. And this dish does justice, it just magically dissolves in your mouth. This will have to be one of my favorite dishes.   

Ceviche- This was recommended by the waitress. She said " did you see the pictures on yelp of our ceviche?"  She sure knows how to get to the minds of her customers.  This dish wasn't bad if you are into the citrus taste.  

Hamachi Pear- This was so delicous! The pear was sliced perfectly, not too thin not too thick, and it went well with the hamachi.  It provided a sweet juicy taste to each bite!

Shrimp and crab tartar sushi- This was not bad, it had a good amount of shrimp and crab mixed in.   It was pretty sweet and you can still taste the fresh sea flavors

Hamachi Kama- This was grilled well because it melts in your mouth.  The lemon juice more it more moist.  Watch out for bones

Uni- although i had a small bite of this. i can tell it was fresh. My friend loved it!! 

Save the best for last
Live Scallop-  If I'm ever stuck on a deserted island i will love to be stuck on it with the chef who made this dish!  words will not do justice, nor will the pictures! This is a MUST have dish!  The prepare it in two ways, The sushi scallops were so fresh.  But my favorite part of this dish was the portion that was served in a spoon.  You eat it like you will take a shot. There was surely a wild party in my mouth after that shot! Next time i am not going to share this dish! 

Desserts!
Macha Creme Brulee- This tasted a lot like the green tea cream puffs from bread papa.  It had a good amount of macha. 

Macha Cheesecake- Even if you are not a cheesecake lover, you will love this dish. It wasn't too sweet and they topped it off when red bean paste!  It was so good, i only wished the slice was bigger.  

Overall my taste buds and tummy had a great experience and the serve was really good.  I will highly recommend this place and I will recommend if you have a big party to make reservations.
author: Belinda C.

description:
OMG the Omakase.
The most delicious meal of my life so far. I was full for two hours after leaving and then immediately craved more. Everything was plated beautifully!
It is well worth the price, though definitely a splurge. My favorite was the Toro tuna with truffles and caviar, and the 1849 oysters.
author: Nicki H.

description:
They have two menus, one with regular items and one with "special" items, plus a specials of the day board. After eating a variety of items, I would recommend eating off of the special menu and board for a great experience. 

A little pricey in my opinion at $200 for two with no drinks.
author: Chuck R.

description: I have been coming here for years and it NEVER disappoints.  Freshest sashimi and always great specials.  B. Goldberg
author: Bruce G.

description: This place was very expensive, and really not special at all. I went in for lunch and had 5 single pieces of sushi and a small bowl of edemami and the bill was $27 ! (Note the prices listed on the menu are for a single piece of sushi, not the customary 2) To make it worse, my server, an older Japanese lady, was very brusque  and grabbed my plate as soon as I put the last piece in my mouth. I didn't even have a chance to eat the pickled cranberry garnish before the plate was whisked off. There are a lot of great sushi places in the Richmond, this is not one of them!
author: Lonna D.

description:
I don't know what happened over the years, but this place went WAYYYY downhill. I had the Omakase a year or two ago and thought that it was not bad...

Today, I went again at around 9pm. The place was completely empty. Red flag right there!!! Not going to go into details... But food was just very not fresh.
author: Betty T.

description: Unimpressive feature and decoration but impressive food. We ordered their special 1849 Oyster, and many other special sushi (sorry cannot remember the name). They are all pretty good! Surprised us! Will definitely recommend friends to come and try.
author: Angela C.

description:
Went here for lunch the other day. Almost got kicked out of there during lunch because there was no one else there. I got Sashimi combo or whatever for lunch. Sashimi was so DRY. That's like less than convenience-store quality in Japan. So bad. 

Service was not nice. I don't think the old waitress (Chinese or whatever she was) understood much English. Very rude. 

Not going back.  Sakesan bistro on Clement has WAY BETTER food and service. Plus Sakesan bistro is cheaper.

Not worth your time if you eat real sushi.
author: C M.

description:
MINUS 2 stars to the wife & another server (tall, skinny, and could've been the daughter) for their stinky & unfriendly service.  Let's just say the two times dining there (extremely fortunate hubby's Boss invited us), the bill surely exceeded the hundreds and both times, the wife doesn't understand the simple concept of good customer service; only her HUSBAND does. She has no shame charging you for everything rather than double checking with her husband when he personally came over offering us house special comps.  Is a shame cuz we won't be dining here again, so their lost!!

CeViche - Yum
Foie Gras - Super Yum
Mirugai - Super Fresh, crunchy,  and DELISH! 
Anago - Interesting and not bad.  I still prefer unagi more. 
Hamachi Jalapeño - Yum
Hamachi Pear - Delish
Fresh Prawns served in two ways - Yummmmm
Fatty Toro - Not bad cuz the one I ate was quite stringy.
Gyoza - Yum
Agi - Alright
Lobster - Yum 
Scallop served in two ways - Yum 
1849 Oyster - Alright
Uni - Fresh & Yum
Blue Fin - Nothing Special
Anikimo sashimi - Yum
Blue Bottle sake @ $135 each - Was not bad, but still the Green Bottle better. 
Green Tea Panna Cotta - Alright
author: Katy N.

description: Hands down, the best sushi we've had in San Francisco. The ambience is casual and comfortable, very welcoming. The relationships the chefs built with their customer speaks loudly on a different scale. It's noticeable that there are regulars around us, and it seems as if it's still their first time here. Overall, this place is recommended for everyone.
author: Connie Z.

description:
Okay, disregard the last review I made. I was young and naive and had no idea what good sushi was.

First time I tried Kabuto, it was more than 2 years ago, I was with my BFF, I wasn't a big fan of sushi and I was not impressed with Kabuto's sushi.

I tried it again with my boyfriend last week, this time I ordered the right things.

Foie gras roll - was amazing and I love foie gras! You can taste the yummy foie gras but it's also sushi. A mix of western and eastern.
Baby main lobster - very enjoyable and very fresh lobster
Ceviche - I thought I was gonna get mini shrimp on my sushi but not the case, it tasted more like sushi than ceviche.
Hot apple - The presentation of this was great! Scallops served on a clam shell.
Fire salmon roll - this roll comes with more than 2 pieces and the chef sets is ablaze.

Coming to Kabuto made me realize sushi, to me, is supposed to a snack not an entree.
