You order multiple sushi dishes but served in a couple of pieces, that way you can try different kinds of sushi and experience different flavors. Kabuto has fufilled my revelation wonderfully. The presentation of the sushi here is gorgeous as well. It's a hybrid between Gary Danko presentation and Japanese sushi.

Dining area is small and cramped and gets busy quickly! Come here early to beat the crowd.
author: Mabel Y.

description: They do not honor reservations. I reserved through Yelp but when I actually showed up they said they were fully booked and the wait was 45 minutes.
author: None I.

description:
So disappointing! Perhaps our expectations were too high. Since fois gras was now legal, we took the opportunity to try it. 
Everything from the decor, the seating layout, the noise level, the utensils, the freshness missed the mark. We should have known better when we saw the number of 'creative' rolls. The yosenabe's broth was rather unrefined and made me thirsty. Next time, we need to stick to our rule that we avoid Japanese restaurants with 'creative' rolls. So impure.

The best things we ate tonight were the oysters and the somen. There exists a restaurant nearby which is much more authentic and much higher quality. I leave it to the reader to figure out which one. 

While I love to try new restaurants, I am slowly learning that some oldies are really goodies. Here is a dish by dish rating:

Uni 3/5
Shima aji 3.5/5
Fois gras 3.5
Abalone 3.5
1849 oyster 4.5
Yosenabe 2
Somen noodle soup 4
Bathroom 3

Overall 3
author: Kathy L.

description:
Delightful food. Flavors range from fresh classic to gloriously innovative sushi.  Staff were very pleasant and attentive even though it was crazy busy.  Can't wait to return!

Agree with other reviewers - this place is small so do make RSVP to save yourself time.
author: Lev E.

description:
$75 per person omakase was excellent!!!! 

The fish was super fresh and tasty. They also manage to do innovative things (like adding homemade nontraditional tapenades or marinades) to the fish without having it seem gimmicky and without overpowering the delicate fish flavor. Great fusion dishes AND traditional nigiri.

Really happy with my meal. Also I felt full which is a wonderful feeling from a sushi-only meal.

It definitely is spare in terms of interior decoration and does not have date-night ambiance BUT if your date loves food, the sushi will be enough of an aphrodisiac.
author: Erin C.

description:
I love this neighbourhood Japanese restaurant and pay a visit when in San Francisco and craving something fresh and light.

The lunch time omakase is ludicrously good value at only $12.50 for a mini salad, miso and stomach-filling sushi and nigiri. At dinner, sit at the sushi bar and crack open the sake. Then, make your way through delicately flavoured items that are mostly prepared in front of your eyes my cheerful chefs. There's some interesting modern interpretations and fusion items that will excite the palate too.
author: Tresna L.

description:
I have never experienced sushi like I did at Kabuto.  Sushi here was AMAZING! I've uploaded a picture of every single dish we had because well, so I can look at the pictures again and reminisce the best sushi I've ever had lol. 

Dishes we had in order:

1. Foie Gras Roll - [http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/DjDyplmXctMI9gShywcvAg/l.jpg] goose liver. Never had it, thought "goose liver" was gross, but omg this was amazing. With the balsamic raspberry sauce and berry on top, it felt like I've never tasted authentic sushi until this. A must get.  It's popular on yelp, it was my favorite dish out of the 10 we got, so trust.

2. Hamachi Pear - [http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/AnaB8i-q_C30prEcV4btAw/l.jpg] this was also freakishly delicious, although it was difficult to pick up and eat. Again, the combination they choose to put in this tiny piece of roll, hamachi, pear, and a fruity mustard sauce, all went perfect together to kick in those taste buds and tell them, "wow, what have I been missing out of my whole life?!"

3. Live Scallop - [http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WD47kUUawSf0u2J_jHIluw/l.jpg] [http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/uDCgT-zr9_bo0qTh5XDqCQ/l.jpg] take it as a shot, or dip the roll in the sauce.  You won't believe how delicious this tastes!

4. Baby Main Lobster - [http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/AY6y3IpDCT3vD0edrgbP7A/l.jpg] they seared the lobster and made it a little burnt, but it still was good with the creamy sauce poured on top. Almost all the rolls were displayed beautifully, and this one especially with the lobster tail. 

5. Katsunagi - [http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ujlEj_PraST3JmL2xwyl6Q/l.jpg] unagi, avocado, and deep fried katsu.  This sauce was interesting, raspberry miso sauce. Not as sweet as the first in balsamic raspberry, but went well with this fried roll.

6. Sunrise - [http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/tCkMDvR6wslY15EfbciNGg/l.jpg] fish eggs and yolk.  You may want to add some soy sauce if you want if you want to add more flavor, but it was still good by itself. 

7. Five Salmon Roll - [http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/bqkliqSGFqfcmzSAEkgA7A/l.jpg] Bigger roll compared to everything else, and even tasted like the typical sushi rolls you would find in other japanese restaurants.  It was spicy with tiny jalapenos top of the salmon and a sprinkle of cavier.  An OK roll if you want to add a spicy roll.

8. 1849 oysters - [http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/-TZGgiLsl5dEELz8l1BK2Q/l.jpg] There's a party in my mouth!! There is so much going on with this oyster piece, egg yolk, edible gold, oyster, fish eggs, and cavier, all in one spoonful. Yum!

9.  Toro Tartar - [http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/5PZORXH688o1rkxcU0V8SQ/l.jpg] toro is "fat belly of tuna" (yes I looked it up haha) mixed with rakyo onion, avocado, and kabuto tartar sauce and a japanese mint (deep fried shiso).  Delicious as well.

10. Deep fried green tea ice cream - [http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Z1hobXIooqzNX8gmypQbig/l.jpg] so interesting!! It's pretty big so you can share. I've heard about this in many other places but never had it and can't compare, but it put the icing in the cake for our meal.  

I kid you not, this was one nice & fancy dinner my date took me to.  It was really amazing and a whole new experience of sushi.  Makes a girl feel special (hint hint for you men out there ;) 

The only reason why I gave it 4 instead of 5 was with the service and appearance of the menu.  The waitresses weren't patient and friendly at all.  If it's a fancy place, you have to have some hospitality and give people some time to look at the menu, eat, and talk! I also had to ask for a refill for my hot tea rather than them checking up on me to refill, not something I would expect at a nice restaurant like this.  Also, the menu was old, cheap, and dirty with some food stains on it.  Umm.. for the amount that you are charging for each sushi piece, I think you can afford nicer menus #imjustsayin. 

Overall, a must-go-to-sushi place when you're in SF. Prices are crazy, $10-14 bucks for 2 pieces of sushi, but I guess you get what you pay for.  Highly recommend Foie Gras, Hamachi Pear, and Live Scallop! Enjoy, and I hope my review helped :)
author: Raquel Y.

description: I almost always order from the 'special sushi' menu and am never disappointed. The presentation is beautiful, the sushi is delicious and the service is always professional. Pricier than the other neighborhood places but worth it.
author: Yuliya P.

description:
We went here for lunch just because. The food was just as good as we remembered. The parking was also as horrible as we remembered.
We enjoyed many of our old favorites, and tried a couple of new dishes. One of them was a live scallop special. Although it was nicely plated, the flavors were quite bland. There was a scallop served nigiri style and scallop that was chopped up and served in a creamy sauce. DH didn't think it was worth it for $19.
One special item recommended by our server was really good. DH remarked, "this was the favorite part of my meal." This was the sanma, an oily fish served nigiri style. The flavor was unique and it had a shiny skin much like mackerel, but without the super fishy flavor. This particular fish was $4.50 a piece.
We got an order of hot soba noodles with tempura. It's a good filler for nine dollars. Tempura was fresh and crispy, the noodles were fine, but nothing to write home about.
We also tried the saikyo sushi, which is a bite of grilled black cod in a yuzu kosho gravy, served in a soup spoon. The cod with nicely cooked with a light smoky flavor, however, we did not notice the distinct spicy & citrusy yuzu kosho flavor. Although this was also very nicely presented, it was not one of our favorites at $10 for two pieces.
We noticed that they now grate fresh wasbi at your table. This is only two dollars and well worth it!
The live prawn was also really good. It was sweet and the texture was crisp. The heads are served fried, much like amebi (sweet shrimp). Not a bad deal at six dollars a piece. And that is the update!
author: Kari C.

description:
Reserved two weeks in advance for two people and was told to be seated at the bar. We told them that we wanted a table and they said the tables were reserved. There were tables open at the time. We eventually got a table after our dissatisfaction with their offer at the bar. 

Service was not good at all. As we ordered the pre-set omakase and when we wanted to add additional food, the waitress said the omakase will be enough. It was rude to tell us how much we can eat, when we wanted to try their other dishes/sushi along with the omakase.

Some fish were good and some were ice cold. I expected better quality food for what it's worth. 

Not worth coming back.
author: Herrickson L.

description: Very fresh seafood, and the sushi is creative and flavorful! My fave was probably the 1849 oyster. I really liked the alcoholic tasting cranberries (I think) that were served with many of the dishes. Service was friendly and I noticed there were many regulars when I stopped by for dinner on a weekday. However, our oyster order was overlooked because I had to remind the waitress and they ended up giving us a free dish while we waited for the oysters to be put together. The items are pricey but you are paying for quality ingredients.
author: Maya S.

description:
We found this place via Yelp! on a Christmas Day, and are glad for it. 

Service: Professional and knowledgable. 

Rice on sushi: Very good/excellent. 

Proteins: Very fresh. 

Dessert: Get the Macha Cream Brûlée. 

We're looking forward to coming back here next Christmas!

Thank you for a wonderful experience. Merry Christmas!
author: Tien Y.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend and we pratically overwhelemed our waitress with our order, who was extremely friendly! Out of the 15+ orders we made, my personal favorites were the...

- 1849 Oysters (That quail egg though)
- Pear Hamachi (Who would've thought? Pear and Hamachi? NOM)
- Sunrise roll
- Toro TarTar
- CeViche (My NUMBER 1 FAVORITE, I highly reccommend)
- Foie Gras (A bit pricey but it's worth that 10 mouth watering seconds)
- Uni (Who doesn't love that slimy ooey goodness?)

Our entire meal was $160, but every dollar was worth every bite. A great sushi spot for those looking for fresh and buttery melts-in-your-mouth sashimi!
author: Betty P.

description:
First time being to this place, I thought they have pretty good food overall!  The place is not big, so a reservation is definitely recommended!  Price was not cheap as well, but heck the food was tasty!

We ordered mainly nigiris.  and for the night...
Hakkaku - delicious!
Kanpachi - this was okay, had better.
Tamago - the usual
Mirugai - very tasty! but quite expensive too...$10 a piece
Hokkaido Uni - nomnomnomnom tasty! but expensive as well... $10 a piece
Abalone - meh
Belt fish - cooked, pretty tasty too!
Salmon outside soft shell crab inside sushi roll - meh, rather plain for a roll, and felt too much rice around.
Sea bass - meh as well

The service was good, not exceptional, but decent.

I would give the nigiris 4, but others 3-3.5.  So I rounded up my 3.5 star experience here.
author: Johnston C.

description: I really enjoyed this restaurant. Beautiful inside, with white table linen, romantic, and simply nice!  The food was amazing. All sushi rolls had a very unique, special and surprising (in a good way) taste. Really enjoyed every piece!
author: Eleanor S.

description:
This place was ahhmazing!  I loved the fresh fish and the aburi toro was the best piece of fish I've tasted thus far.  

Highlights:
Aburi toro
Clam soup
Ceviche (delicious)
Tofu
author: Emily C.

description:
From what I'm hearing, Foie Gras is going to be banned in California in six months.  I never really had a problem with the process of making Foie Gras.  Actually veal, shark fin or any other food for my consumption.  My best friend is a (ahem) "animal reseacher" in fact.  And no, I don't own any pets.  Oh wait, I did have a Nemo (RIP).  But don't get me wrong, I love animals...

So coming to Kabuto, I was looking at the sushi options and they make Foie Gras sushi.  I thought to myself that I had to try it, who knows, maybe in six months this won't be available.  The menu definitely has unique sushi, here's what I ended up ordering:

Foie Gras sushi: Seared marinated goose liver served with balsamic raspberry sauce.  It's was delicious, too bad Arnold Schwarzenegger signed the ban of this item.  

Sonoma Duck sushi:  Duck served with Japanese Spicy Mustard.  This one was ok, don't think I'd order it again.

For nigiri I ordered Uni, Kanpachi-Yellow Jack , and Hon Maguro-Blue Fin Tuna.  These came in thick slices and very fresh.  I could eat the nigiri here all day.

Service was ok.  The presentation of the food was excellent. (see photos). I think  Kabuto is a great place for quality sushi.  Prepare to break bread here, 10 pieces came out to about $45.  But at least I can say I had Foie Gras sushi in California before this delicacy is outlawed.
author: Michael L.

description:
This is an incredibly authentic Japanese restaurant, probably my favorite so far in the city.  Their Omakase is reasonably priced and offers a ton of food:

Seared toro - Probably my favorite, just incredibly delicious

Baby lobster - Presentation and taste are top notch

Uni soup - First time having Uni in soup, it was fantastic

Monk fish liver - I actually thought this was just OK.  It tasted like egg yolk 

Overall, this place is better than Sushi Sam in San Mateo.  Highly recommended.
author: Peter Y.

description:
23 dishes for 3 people?  Yes indeed...

Two friends and I came here last Tuesday night around 8:30pm.  We were lucky to walk in when we did because there was either a table or three seats at the bar left. 

MUST TRY:
*Kani Kara (Deep Fried Softshell Crab)
*Live Shrimp 
*Spicy Scallop
*Asari Sakamushi (Steamed clams in broth) 

OKAY DISHES:
*Agedashi Tofu 
*Lamb Apple Sushi  
*Gyoza 
*Tako Nigiri  
*Chicken Karaage

PASS:
* Piri kara nasu (eggplant with spicy miso)

NOTE:
*Try some sushi out of the "Special Sushi" menu. Many may seem like oddly paired ingredients but they'll surprise you!
*Small dishes
*Most sushi orders are by pieces
*Prices are decently priced but if you see a coupon, buy it - our bill was $157 for 3 people,, but I had purchased a Yelp coupon so I saved some moolah

SERVICE:
Okay.  Our waitress basically took our order and that's it.  She didn't come around and check up on us regularly.  When we wanted to order additional dishes, we had to wave down her attention.  There was another woman working there who would clear our dishes.  She was friendly, cleared our dishes regularly and made sure we were okay.

PARKING:
Street metered parking.  If you're familiar with the area, you'd know that parking can be difficult at times here.
author: Nicole S.

description:
It had been a long time since my last visit to Kabuto. I had really great experience in my previous visits. I have raved about their sushi. I have recommended them to a lot of people. Unfortunately all good things must come to an end. It really pains me to say but restaurant is already passed its prime. 

While their menu and decor remained pretty much the same (probably shouldn't), the sushi is merely a shadow of their former glory. For one, the sushi rice served during early dinner time was already slightly dried out. That was quite noticeable even with all the sauce and garnish. Not excusable. 

The lamb on the lamb apple was tough. Sonoma Duck was underwhelming for reasons I can't comprehend. Sammy Roll, CeViChe, Shrimp and Crab Tartare and Ono Grape are still quite good. Valentine was interesting but could really use less sauce. Oh yes, the sashimi on the $20 chirashi really weren't that great in terms of both selection and quality. i would recommend just ordering from their special sushi roll menu. After all, that is what they are known for. 

What I really like about Kabuto is their creativity and how they could make all those odd elements work together and still capture the essence of authentic sushi. The menu has a lot of potential and I really hope they won't fade away.

Service was not good. The bill was presented to me without even asking if I want dessert. I was not happy. The sushi counter, tables and chairs look like they have seen much better days.
author: Mona W.

description:
My new favorite sushi restaurant in SF! 

Even though I had passed this restaurant many times over the years on Geary, I only tried it last week for the first time, and I was so pleasantly surprised.

First off, go right to the "special dish menu," which has a lineup of dishes that you just don't see in most sushi restaurants.  For example, the ceviche is outstanding, and truly unique in its presentation.

Second, the saki menu is very good.  I am not a connoisseur of saki, so I need a lot of help in making selections.  In addition to the menu, the server was really helpful in guiding me to some good choices.

And that brings me to my third point, which is the service is great.  Sometimes it is difficult in Asian restaurants to identify things that you will like but have never tried before.  The server made some great recommendations.

So, I highly recommend Kabuto.
author: Karl K.

description:
It's a well documented fact that having too many choices can trigger anxiety, especially if one tends to be a 'maximizer' and feels that she needs to get the most out of every experience. Hmm, sounds like a girl named Bubbles that I know. This is why I love ordering omakaze in Japanese restaurants. When I came to Kabuto I was determined to not be enabled by the sushi chefs and to choose from the extensive menu myself (well, my friend helped too.) 

It was a challenge; there were a lot of novel dishes and presentations, and two menus: one for dinner and one for 'special sushi.' Everything sounded delicious, and if you don't mind me tooting my own trumpet, I made some excellent choices. Look mom, no omakaze!

Amongst my favorites were the hirame yuzu topped with pickled shiso, and the stunning piri-kara nasu, which is fried and grilled eggplant with spicy miso. I chose to 'forget' that I'm slightly allergic to eggplant, and I am glad that I did so; that dish is amazing. The hamachi pear was unique but I'm not sure if I would order it again; it was a bit too sweet with the fruity mustard sauce on top. Fresh caught abalone should have been cleaned better, and it didn't taste too fresh. Dessert was a generously sized macha creme brulee-not bad. One choice that I enjoyed making was the tea; there are four to choose from and love a great cup of genmaicha with dinner. 

Kabuto is Japanese for helmet, in particular those wild helmets that samurais wore.  This makes sense when you experience the service; it is curt, rushed, and borderline antagonistic. I didn't mind though because it let me concentrate more on the task in front of me: enjoying innovative and gratifying Japanese food. 

Thanks, Yelp, for the deal! It definitely minimized my financial as well as my 'where to eat on Saturday night' anxiety.
author: Joanna M.

description: This might be the best experience for a good Japanese meal in SF now. It was Saturday night, and we were craving sushi and thought of this place but wasn't hopeful for seating because this is a popular place to go. So I call at 7pm and asked if we can get a table for 4 and they said YES, and I told them we will be there in 15 mins, and they said OKAY. The Omakase here is very very good, and reasonably priced at 80 dollars per person. We all did the Omakase and was very very pleased because the meal was fast and the service was great. Will be back soooooooon!
author: Q W.

description:
I would say that the sushi is DELICIOUS. Also, the oyster with gold flakes was definitely worth it, SO yummy. The first time I came in a group of 8, which it is completely necessary to make a reservation, otherwise a group of 8 is probably not gonna work. I would say a group of 2-4 is the best for non reservations. The parking is OK if you come at the right time and beat the dinner time traffic. 

The next time I came I sat at the bar with two others and it was really awkward. They didn't even say Hi or Bye to us. I guess you have to look like you have money for them to greet you properly ( -one star)
author: Lyra c.

description:
My dad and I came in for a late lunch around 2PM. The restaurant is pretty small and was empty when we arrived, so we received excellent, friendly service from both the waitress and sushi chef. However, the food did take a while to come to our table. They give you moist washcloths before your meal.

We shared red snapper and white tuna sashimi, which were both unbelievably fresh and delicious. Subtle, yet distinct, flavors between the two. They were presented beautifully on a bed of shredded radishes and with a few lemon slices and dried, zest-flavored cranberries on the side. Those extra sides show that the chef really took the time to decorate the plate so it's pleasing to the eye and that you can appreciate the food a lot more. My dad's sea bass was also presented nicely on a long plate with sweet egg and seaweed on the side. I had tempura udon, which was pipping hot and delicious on an unusual, yet usual, rainy summer day in SF. Noodles were a good, non-mushy texture and broth was flavorful.

To sum it all up: Clean restaurant. Clean bathroom. Friendly service. Fresh food. Expensive. But I will be back.
author: Priscilla W.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi restaurants in SF. Came here many times and brought my friend (new to the city) here for the first time and he loves this place. The service was awesome. We ordered most rolls from their special menu and the owner was taking care of us the whole time. I asked him to surprise us with special fish/rolls and he did an excellent job. I love the white butter fish because once I put it in my mouth, it melts and it's super smooth. The abalone spoon was great but it's actually sweet alone so I don't think it needs all the extra sauce. I'm glad the foie gras roll is back; haven't had it for a while. The seared toro and UNI roll is a must order item!! It's so good you'll want multiple orders. I will definitely come back more often and will recommend this place to my friends, coworkers, and clients.
author: Cindy W.

description:
They were so kind and welcoming at this spot. I really liked the infusion of so many types of fruit into their Sushi and usually I don't enjoy that. Like seriously, they really used fruit as an accent beautifully, they didn't just dump mango salsa on your roll and call it good like many places will.

I got a little apple pudding cup at the end and it was really sweet of them too.
author: Kendra S.

description: Excellent sushi and service. Make a reservation. Family friendly but mostly adults. Food is so fresh. Oysters a must. Tuna with jalapeño good. Spicy salmon roll a must. Very casual.
author: Marie A.

description: Kabuto is not fancy or trendy or hyped up, it's just reliably VERY VERY GOOD..I love this place for a weekday dinner in casual atmosphere, but without sacrificing the quality of the fish or the service.. I'm saddened to see the negative reviews, as this is one of my favorite and most visited places in the city. The omakase is a way to go here!
author: Julie M M.

description:
I really enjoy Kabuto. I used to work at a sushi restaurant and I know sushi. This is good sushi. Simple sushi that highlights the flavor of the fish, not disguise it with spicy sauces or deep frying it. I also like that you can order one piece at a time...gives you more options for trying new things. 

I took my parents to Kabuto for dinner one night and they loved it (my dad is the guy who likes to catch the fish off the boat and eat it that night). Small space, nothing fancy, just good food. 

Food = amazing
Service = average
Ambiance = nothing to brag about
author: Jenni S.

description:
We have been going here for years 
Every time we go elsewhere we are disappointed 
Don't expect fabulous service its spotty at best
If you can accept that ... You're in for a taste bud treat
Do expect innovative preparations and excellent quality product 
Signature dishes like ceviche and hamachi pear are unique and unrivaled 
Good sushi is expensive that's the bottom line
Eric Cho is a fabulous chef 
He's trained his chefs well and the quality is consistent year after year 
Kabuto isn't fancy or trendy 
It's just great sushi
author: Neira F.

description:
Fresh fish, daily fish specials, a visible sushi bar, these are the few basic essentials you can expect out of an ideal sushi restaurant. Kabuto has it all. We came in here on a Sunday night, just half an hour before their closing time. 

Overall, it was a pretty good experience with the sushi we ordered. They don't have much crazy fancy roll, so don't come in if you're looking for that. I usually like my sushi pretty straight and less gimmicky, so Kabuto is the place for me. Service is rather different. They will take your order, but they won't ask you what you'd like to drink. Some of us are very used to getting a cup of tea / water immediately after you sat down, but not here. So then after your food come, then you realized you don't have something to drink. So, remember to tell them what you'd like to drink. 

Price wise is a little above the standard, because remember, you are paying for quality. They also charge their nigiri per piece, so if you're dining yourself, it's perfect. You don't get stuck ordering an order of 2pc nigiri. Then quickly getting full with no chance of trying other fish. At the end of the meal, whether you order dessert or not, they will present a small bite of sweet treat for you. I got a little taster pudding.

Parking is super easy, plenty of meter and street parking on Geary Blvd and the avenues around. Given that it's in my neighborhood, I'll come back again.
author: Rika P.

description:
Sushi Ran quality at a bit lower price.  Good fish selection.

$18 for Alaska King Crab Cali Roll kinda high.
author: Kevin L.

description: Love this place! We've been coming here for years! Their sushi is top grade and they always have new and exciting specials each night!! Their Chef's Tasting Menu - is spectacular!! Great service, great sushi ..Love everything @ Kabuto Sushi!!
author: Dyna M.

description: The food is excellent.  Why the two stars?  The service is abysmal.  We sat at the sushi bar, and instead of the traditional, customary pleasant interaction and badinage with sushi chefs, they did not even look at us, and directly refused to take our order, referring us to the waitress.  The waitress was slow, brusque, and robotic.  In fact I was left to musing that robots would provide a superior dining experience.  (Well, I suppose I'll have to wait a couple of years for that dream to come true.)  In the meantime, if you want great food, served by soul-impaired automatons, this is a fine spot.
author: John O.

description:
So out of sadness for our previous experience and a huge hankering for some fish, I ventured back with a girl friend of mine to see if my last experience at Kabuto was just a fluke. While service isn't amazing, the weekend waitress is a lot more attentive and nice than the one we previously had. We made a reservation and our time in the restaurant was appropriate with having ordered two rounds of sushi. It was so delicious that we forwent the dessert to order more nigiri. Lol. We really appreciated that the waitress kept track of our individual orders and gave us separate bills at the end. 

The fish, omg, is amazing. My favorite was the salmon belly....drool! My friend had scallop and even ordered a second round. We definitely splurged on our meal but we didn't really care because it was so delicious. I definitely was glad to order by piece instead of the preset sushi meals but I wish I could order sashimi instead of nigiri (there's no where on the menu to order sashimi...it's all over rice/nigiri). 

The sushi chef was nice and talked to us a bit. We enjoyed watching him make all the fancy orders and look forward to ordering some of those next time.
author: Andy M.

description: Unfortunately under new management. Quality of fish has gone down significantly. Prices haven't changed making Kabuto's no longer worth it.
author: Brady K.

description: Consistently fantastic food. Toro tartar, pear hamachi, ceviche are all delicious. Unpretentious and cozy space.
author: Erik F.

description: Fantastic sushi in SF for reasonable prices. If you are looking for something small and intimate with authentic sushi cuisine, this is the place for you! Recommended would be the Poke - combine that with some white rice and you're golden. Stunning sushi; no doubt.
author: Dana W.

description: No ambiance, yet incredible creative sushi. This is a secret place. Ask the staff for their recommendations. The sushi was pricey yet it moved me to tears. So fresh and innovative. I ordered off the special sushi menu. The non-sushi items were also fabulous. The roasted eggplant was delicious.
author: A F.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night and was surprised it was pretty quiet. It took awhile for me to find street parking though.

The staffs were really nice and attentive despite I was a bit late to my reservation. The chef gave us a compliment small bite and dessert. 

The menu consisted of many things from cold and hot appetizers to noodles to rice to sushi etc etc. They also have one menu for their specialty sushi. I ordered sushi piece by piece--toro tartare, tamago, hamachi, smoke salmon, etc etc. The fish was pretty good and fresh. The toro tartare sushi was unique but you can't really taste the toro much since it was mixed with other stuff. I like how sushi I ordered were served out plate by plate even though I sat at the table.
author: Mandy C.

description: We went here recently for a date night dinner.  We ordered several Sushi dishes. Our favorites were the Foix Grasse sushi and the hamachi pear sushi.  Besides Sushi, they also have most of the other Japanese restaurant dishes such as Udon noodles and tempura.  Overall, this was a great place that we plan on returning to with the kids and the rest of the family.
author: John S.

description:
Our group decided to eat here from all the rave reviews... boy were we wrong about this place...

The food is amazingly fresh but my god, the service here is atrocious... we made reservations but they got it wrong so we had to wait an extra 30 minutes... apparently this happens alot as the group before us told us they got their reservations wrong as well... guess what happened to the people after us as well?

This place maybe nice for 2 but I definitely do not recommend this place for groups of more than 4... they're understaffed by a waiter and a sushi chef AT LEAST... our food came extremely slow as well as our sake... how on earth can sake take so long? you just pour it! We came to eat and drink... not wait for our sake to ferment... avoid this place! Warakabune on 15th and church is well worth the travel...
author: Nathan D.

description: I was very disappointed with the service. We were slightly late for the reservation and they told us we should wait for another 20 min to see if they can offer any seating. There were half the restaurant still available but they felt personal when we did not arrive on the reservation in time. After 5 min they decided to let us sit, 30 min after we were sat the restaurant was still half empty.
author: Kar Sui L.

description:
Poor customer service, 
Prices higher than comparable places. 
Sushi is good.
Place pretty dirty, they don't clean tables just place a paper on the table
author: Nick S.

description:
Kabuto is a tiny Japanese restaurant and a gem.   They have an exquisite and creative "special sushi" menu (I highly recommend) and daily specials (written on a blackboard).  From their special sushi menu I recommend the Foie Gras Sushi and Hamachi Pear.  And from their blackboard menu the 1849 (Oysters, Quail Eggs, Caviar, and Uni).  I haven't eaten much from their regular menu (though all of their sushi tastes fresh) I'm just a huge fan of their special sushi menu. 

If you order from their special sushi menu expect to experience explosions of flavor, not fullness.  It's pricey but well worth every satisfied taste bud.   It's a small place so you'll be closely and intimately seated near other patrons and will likely hear their conversations and vice versa.  Small and especially larger groups remember to grab reservations - wait time can be pretty long without them as they have limited seating (45mins - 1.5hrs)!  Bon appétit!
author: Bertina N.

description: Kabuto is an interesting sushi restaurant with a unique taste on sushi flavors.  Many pieces often pair raw rish with slices of fruit. I thought this was strange, but the flavors actually worked well together.  The hamachi pear was pretty good as well as the baby Maine lobster.  The seared salmon roll looked neat but not nearly as good as anticipated.  The ceviche was also another good choice. Be sure to come early or make reservations, especially on a Friday or Saturday night!
author: Nick A.

description:
Bottom line at the top: great sushi. 
--
Hamachi jalapeño. Damn. I haven't had yellowtail this good in a very very long time.

Enjoyed a bunch of other dishes like toro truffle tartare (topped with shaved black truffle, uni, caviar), albacore green onion roll, ume hirami, toro nigiri (had better in Japan but still good), but the star was the hamachi jalapeño. 

Service is good but slightly awkward (the chefs came out and checked on three specific tables (regulars? Large groups? Actually no because there were two couple that got checked on) and then they got checked on again and got different presents (samplings of sushi for the two groups and one of the couples, and then a dessert for the other couple). If the chefs made the hassle of coming out from behind the bar to say hi I think it would have also been better to check on/say hi to all the other patrons as well.
author: Dahlia S.

description: Welcome to inner Richmond. I recently relocated from NYC so my standards are HIGH to say the least. When you first walk into this place it doesn't look like a lot. This is where the term NEVER JUDGE A BOOK BY THE COVER COMES INTO PLAY. Service impeccable. Amazing choices across the board! I'm coming back for dinner!
author: Amavi D.

description:
I love this restaurant.  This review was for our 2nd visit on 4/3/15.  The food is amazing, and the sushi chefs are really nice (possibly more so than the wait staff - see below).  

We had a 7:15 reservation, and we were seated shortly after (not a big deal; we had to wait a few minutes as a couple patrons ahead of us were finishing up at the sushi bar).  Although, I was curious why we couldn't be seated at one table that was open and was not being used (which eventually WAS open to another couple).  

The bad:  After we had been seated, ordered, and settled in, we were asked to get up and move to another part of the bar to accommodate a larger party.  Actually, it sort of felt like we were being told to move instead of being asked politely.  The waitress was not the friendliest (we were waited on by 2 waitresses, this particular waitress was the older one).  When we moved and sat down, I think the sushi chef had noticed what happened... or maybe overheard me griping about it.

The good:  The food/sushi is amazing.  We had the Omakase menu ($75/person).  It's a little more expensive than the regular casual sushi dinner, but it is WELL WORTH IT.  Don't really want to get into all the details of the individual plates, but each one was delicious (including the desserts).  One of the items was an 8-piece nigiri plate... the fish was so fresh!  Some of the best that I've had.  

The great:  Back to the sushi chef... he was checking in on us throughout our meal, asking if we were okay and how the food tasted.  When we thought we were about to receive our dessert, the chef stopped the waitress and told him that we had 1 more plate coming out.  My gf and I ran through the Omakase menu and were confused because we had already tried everything on the menu.  The same waitress had brought out the last item which was on the house and the waitress had explained it was due to us having to move to the new seating area.    

I would have given a 4-star review, but the attentiveness from the sushi chef and the staff to go the extra mile puts them over the top.  We were very pleased with the food and that level of service.  We will definitely be coming back.
author: Matthew C.

description:
There ar sushi places....and then there are real-authentic-to-die-for-SUSHI places. We had heard about Kabuto prior to visiting, and it was on the top of our list when we visited San Francisco. 

We ordered the Omakase (Chef's selection) in order to get a full sampling of everything available. Sadly, after I took photos of our whole adventure- I lost my phone on the airplane later that evening.

The seafood was very fresh, sashimi melted in our mouths, and every dish served was more inventive than the first.

My absolutely favorite item? An Oyster special with two Oysters each with a raw quail egg, salmon roe, caviar, and a golf flake on top. Delicious, and I could have eaten 50 of them.
author: Meghan C.

description:
food: yum. It was my go to place out in the richmond. the lobster sushi (they torch the top) is great. foie gras sushi is good (guilty..). salmon with the quail egg on top. good. 

atmosphere: pretty chill, no thrills, normal nice folks. normal! what's wrong with that? nothing.
author: P L.

description:
Fish was extremely fresh. 

I ordered:
 - Oyster with Uni
 - Uni with shell
 - Toro
 - Assorted Sashimi (salmon, tekka, hamachi, etc

Everything is amazing. It is a small place and it gets packed, so get there early!!
author: Audrey S.

description:
BEST SUSHI IN THE BAY AREA I HAVE HAD.

I think that says a lot. 
I've tried so much here. The ceviche, the king salmon, the more simple rolls, the crunchy rolls, the salmon crepe and tuna crepe rolls, the pear, the lamb...no really, I fell like I've had it all. I LOVE this place. The flavor combinations on the sushi are fantastic. The sushi rice is DELICIOUS. Perfectly soft and tender, and with a vinegar-y ting that just makes your mouth water. The fish is very very fresh. I haven't been in a while because I've been off to college but I definitely want to come back soon. Staff is very nice and knew us after we went three times. 

10/10 would recommend.
author: alex d.

description:
When the 38 Muni bus hit Japantown, I thought, "OK, it won't be long now." Boy, was I wrong. This is quite a busy route and we must have paused at every bus stop along Geary Blvd. It took a good 40 minutes to get across town. 

Our party of 5 had a 7:00 pm reservation. My friends, who drove, arrived 10 minutes before 7:00 pm and were seated within minutes. I was last to arrive at 7:05 pm, just as we were served our first pot of tea. We sat for another 10 minutes with just the tea. We had no menus or wet towels. 

Everyone at our table was getting upset as the tables to either side of us were getting service. The servers were literally walking around our table. They were ignoring us like we were all wearing Harry Potter's cloak of invisibility or Frodo's Ring. TIP to servers, please make eye contact with your customers. A simple acknowledgement will go a long way to calming customers upset at the long wait.

At 7:15 pm, we had enough. A friend and I accosted a server as she finished taking still another party's order. As she started to walk away, we closed in on her from 2 sides. Trapped between the 2 of us, with the sushi bar on 3rd side and the table she just left on the 4th side, she couldn't escape. We asked for the menus she was holding and said we were ready to order. The first time food touched our lips wasn't until 45 minutes after we were seated. 

From the Special Sushi Menu:
lamb apple: grilled lamb topped with sliced apple & cherry balsamic sauce
hamachi pear: yellowtail sushi topped with pear & kabuto fruity mustard sauce
Sonoma duck: barbequed duck served with Japanese spicy mustard

From the Regular Sushi Menu:
aji: Spanish mackerel
asparagus roll
eggplant roll

From the Dinner Menu:
nasu dengaku: fried and grilled eggplant served with miso
edamame: Steamed and seasoned Japanese soy beans
chicken karaage: Japanese fried chicken nuggets

From the Dessert Menu:
ohagi: rice cake roll covered with sweet red bean paste

Fish was extremely fresh and pristine. However, a couple of pieces still had silver skin and a blood line. Their rice was cooked but it was also a bit firmer and drier than I like.

I tend to favor traditional sushi but I really enjoyed Kabuto's fusion cuisine. While the pairings didn't always work, I was pleasantly surprised at the kitchen staff's restraint. They showcased the fish rather than hiding it behind too many sauces and garnishes.

I also appreciated that we could order food by the piece. One of my friends was a sushi newbie and another is allergic to seafood. We were able to customize our meal and everybody got exactly what they wanted. 

The cooked plates were just as deftly cooked as the raw items. I loved the eggplant. Cooked in its skin until the flesh was mush, it was like a savory custard. The miso gave it a hint of salty sweetness. The lamb, chicken and duck were moist and juicy.

We were stuffed but we couldn't pass up dessert. Asian desserts are an acquired taste but Kabuto's version of ohagi is very approachable to the Western palate. Rice cake is usually heavy but this dessert was light, airy and delicate. Kudos to the pastry cook. 

I'm glad we persisted and didn't just walk out. The quality of the food went a long way to mitigating the service missteps. The food was worth 4.5 stars despite the long bus ride from downtown. 

The bill was also a lot more reasonable than I expected. Even with drinks, the bill was well under $100 each, tip included. However, because of the service glitches, I don't know if Kabuto will be a regular stop for us.

Conclusion: 4.5 stars for the food; however, I deducted 1 stars for the lackluster service. Final grade: 3.5 stars generously rounded up to 4 stars
author: Cece E.

description:
This place is amazing!!! The food is out of this world orgasmically good. My BF and I have come here quite a few times and each time the food is always consistantly stellar. I've brought a few friends to try this place out and they all said the same thing. Let me break things down:
- Service is quick, friendly and attentive 
- Reservations are recommended but you can still walk in but expect to wait on the weekends
- Restaurant is small and cozy
- Be prepared to spend some $$$
- Rec food.... I always order from their "special sushi menu" and I get (just off the top of my head): ceviche, hamachi pear, foie gras truffle sushi, toro tartare, ono grape, hot apple, and etc
- Other rec food... Sunrise sushi, japanese uni (if avail), tas. salmon and Buri (wild hamachi), 1849 oyster
author: Dee A.

description: Pricey sushi but tasty - the place is really unassuming, it is super casual. I had the okamase so had the chance to try a bunch of different ones and hands down my fave was the toro one. Soooo tasty! If you come here, get the toro!!! It has gold and truffle oil!
author: Foodeater F.

description:
I ordered the Omakase for $65, which came with:
# Uni and Eggplant Soup - fried and grilled eggplant served with uni
# Hamachi Jalapeño - sliced yellowtail served with yuzu sauce with marinated jalapeño
# 1849 Oyster - fresh oyster served with quail egg, fish eggs, and finishing 18k gold leaf
# Tempura - prawns and assorted veggie
# Grilled Spicy Mussel - green lip mussel served with spicy sauce
# Today's Sushi - chef's choice best 4 pcs nigiri
# Baby Main Lobster - seared lobster served with spicy sauce
# CeViChe - halibut and salsa wrapped with deep fried seaweed and served with lime and sea salt
# Hamachi Pear - yellowtail sushi topped with sliced pear and kabuto fruity mustard sauce
# Toro Tartar - chopped nevi toro and avocado mixed with kabuto tartar sauce served with deep fried ship, seaweed
# Aburi Toro - seared toro topped green onion served with lime and sea salt
# Desert - green tea panna cotta or macha creame brulee

* Things that could be cut out (and maybe the price could be cheaper... but then the meal probably would be less filling):
- Tempura. Fried. Average. It didn't fit with everything else
- Grilled Spicy Mussel. The spicy sauce was like an Italian vodka sauce.

* Amazing:
- EVERYTHING ELSE!

Interior is on the small side, but surprisingly they were able to accommodate a group of 12 people with a reservation.  Service was also still super fast.  The food didn't come out in the order that it was listed on the menu, but that's ok.

I think on my next visit, I might just get a couple orders of the 1849 Oyster.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
I was in my Japanese contemporary culture class one morning, and the topic was the traditional Japanese all-male theatre and all-female theatre, Kabuki and Takarazuka, respectively.

During a group discussion, I asked a groupmate "is Kabuto still popular in Japan?"  I received a funny look and I realized that I had just said the name of my favorite restaurant instead of "kabuki".  Obviously, I think about Kabuto all the time, without even realizing it.  

That's true love right there.
author: Vivian H.

description: So delicious. A great hole in the wall type place. Not pretentious at all. Just great sushi. And their "alt sushi" dishes are excellent too.
author: Louis K.

description: Very expensive for their omakase. Food looks good but not filling and very rushed when eating. Place is small a few tables and a few chairs at the sushi bar. Overall - not too impressed.
author: Allen L.

description:
$150 Preset Menu for two which includes the following: 
Hamachi Jalapeno, 1849 Oyster, Grilled Spicy Mussel, 8 pieces nigiri, Baby Main Lobster, Ceviche, Hamachi Pear, Toro Tartar, Foie Gras Sushi, Aburi Toro, & Green Tea Ice Cream

Expensive, but totally worth the experience.  Every single piece made my taste buds dance!!! I swear!!! Throughout the meal, there were moments of silence not because there wasn't anything to talk about, but simply because I was too busy savoring each bite slowly.  It was one of those "don't ever mess with a girl while she's eating" kind of moment.   

Each piece was: fresh, exquisite, divine, flavorful, extraordinary..the list goes on
 
Just know that you will not be disappointed.  I promise!  

BTW this place should be on the SF's Big Eat List of 100 Things To Eat Before You Die.  Just saying...
author: Therese F.

description:
Sushi is, without a doubt, my favorite food.  When I'm in Japan, I usually have it for both lunch and dinner.  So I tend to be extremely picky when it comes to my fish.  I usually just eat sashimi, so my perception of the fish is unencumbered by the rice, or what's in the maki.

Kabuto is currently my hands down favorite sushi place in San Francisco.  It is not cheap.  The restaurant is small, and often crowded.  But the fish is phenomenal, both in quality and selection.  The basic fish choices (maguro, sake, hotate, etc) are fresh and delicious.  But where Kabuto really shines is their special selections, like the Tasmanian salmon.  And they often have even more special fish which isn't on the board; though these tend to be extremely expensive, they are always worth the cost.

There is also a special menu with more haute-cuisine sushi interpretations, like the Hot Apple (hotate nigiri with a slice of apple, served warm).  These are also very expensive, but again very much worth the cost.  I usually get a couple of these, some special sashimi, rounded out with some standard fish.  I always leave happy, full, and not at all caring about how much money I just dropped.

Recommended to anyone who cares about their fish, with zero reservations.
author: Joey Y.

description:
Recently came back to try the delicate sushi again. Items not to miss include foie gras and live uni!! One will be banned in a few months while the other is seasonal.

Almost every item was as always mind-blowing sweet, nice and scrumptious. This is not something you casually eat just because, but something you want to spend an evening to enjoy to its fullest.

Other dishes that were beautifully prepared included 1849 oyster, albacore volcano
Toro with caviar and Wild buri (hamachi.)

The lovely dessert Zenzai was made with mochi wrapped red bean paste inside. It's actually quite similar to the Chinese dessert.

Service was always very nice and even the wait seemed to be forever, it's well worth it.
author: T L.

description: Mediocre at best.  We came here for lunch and it was less than 25% full.  Not a good sign already.  We proceeded to get the sashimi and sushi sets.  The slices of fish were thicker than they should be and not in a good way.  I'm not one who would ever get sick of sushi but halfway through I felt less and less eager to finish the next piece.  Maybe dinner is when they actually serve their better cuts?  With all the other stellar sushi joints in the area, I most likely won't find out.
author: Michele L.

description:
The best Japanese restaurant in San Francisco period! Although the price is on the high side but you get what you pay for! This place used to be packed on every night but I guess due to the economy not everyone is willing to pay for high quality Japanese food anymore. We came here on a friday night right after they open, by the time we left about 70 minutes later there are still tables left. We ordered the following dishes:

Kai Miso: miso soup with clams and they were very good! tho simple to make at home but Kabuto's Kai Miso is one of the best I have tasted so far.

Hijiki: AKA simmered black seaweed. Tastes good just like the ones we get at the Nijiya market in Japan town, I think they came from the same supplier so skip this and buy it at J town much cheaper and you get a lot more

Sanshu Moriawase: Sashimi combo, came with 2 thick slices of hamachi, 3 pieces of Tuna and 2 pieces of Sea bream. all are very fresh but again you can easily get these at 1/3 of the price at Nijiya market in J town

Oden: Japanese hotpot with fish cake, a bit too sweet and salty but totally reminded me of Japan.

Tamago Zousui: Egg and rice cooked in soup, kind like chinese porridge and it was great, big enough to share with 2

For sushi we ordered:

Uni, Ceviche, Tamago and Toro Tartar Sushi. THE BEST SUSHI ever! I love Tamago and Kabuto has the best Tamago in Bay Area! 

Grilled Lamb Ribs were also good

We ended our dinner with Chawan Mushi, Japanese style steamed egg with mushrooms shrimp and fish cake. It was not the best ever but pretty good.

Total for 2 of us (we were pretty hungry thats why so much food) were $88 dollars before tips. Overall a great time dinning here. Will be back for sure!
author: William C.

description: Simply the best. Low key joint that does amazing sushi and wonderful non fish dishes (delicate grilled chicken chicken sticks). Definitely high end in terms of the food.
author: Ian V.

description: Best sushi restaurant in San Francisco, everything is done to perfection starting with the miso soup to the amazing sushi and sashimi. Just amazing start forward Japanese food that melt in your mouth.
author: Zeev V.

description: Amazing experience, some of the beat sushi I have ever eaten.  Everything was perfect, highly recommend.
author: Christopher G.

description:
Over the years, I've driven by Kabuto countless times.  On some of those trips, I was even on my way to eat at other Japanese restaurants.  Places that can't even compare to Kabuto.  And to think, I wasted all that time and gas driving when really, I could have just pulled over, went inside, and eaten some of the best Japanese food I've found in SF.  Dummy!

So what did fellow Yelp buddy Jenny K. and I order?  Well, quite a bit.  Yet, amazingly, it still felt like it wasn't enough because I wanted to try so much more!

- Toro Tartare - with avocado, pickled radish (?) and a crisp shiso leaf.  I loved the creamy texture, and the flavors were spot on.  Toro is always good, but it wasn't the sole reason why I liked the tartare.  One of my faves of the night.
- Salmon Tartare - the toro was slightly better, but this one is still good.  If you love salmon, don't like toro, or just want to try both, get it.  For variety's sake though, no need to double up - get the Toro Tartare and enjoy!
- Ceviche - it's actually a piece of nigiri with a ceviche twist rather than just ceviche.  I liked how it had that tart/acidic flavor, but was mild enough to not be harsh.
- Sunrise - raw quail egg on a bed of tobiko over a disk of rice, wrapped with salmon.  Delicious, but be careful - it can break apart in your chopsticks, and you'll lose all the good stuff on the way to your mouth!
- Ankimo (monkfish liver) - good, but standard.  Not really a "must order" like some of the other dishes since you can find comparable quality at other places in SF.  Still, ankimo is always good.
- 1849 Oyster - "1849" because of the gold flakes on top (gold rush era), the oyster is topped with uni, quail egg, ikura, and tobiko.  Just look at the picture though...it's gorgeous!  Really good, but it's a splurge at $7 a pop.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7iiWJyo_N5rGz4agqe9EbA?select=u1oRuBEOvOVrsqZ30wrxuA

- Chawan Mushi (egg custard) - loaded with goodies, but it needed more of the sauce/broth.  Pretty solid but next time, I might spend the money on something else and get the chawan mushi at Tanuki instead.
- Live Scallop - came with two spoons of a scallop chowder, along with four pieces of scallop nigiri.  The bite of chowder was so flavorful, I wish they had given us a bowl of it instead.  I liked the nigiri, but the chowder was the star.
- Grilled Sea Bass - the only cooked dish we had, and it was terrific.  Perfectly cooked with that buttery flavor...it makes my mouth water just thinking about it.  I liked the "roll" of spinach on the dish too.
- Ono (Wahoo) Nigiri - I wanted to try it because I had never heard of Wahoo before.  It was nice - fresh with a subtle flavor.  Can't compare to a good cut of hamachi though.

As far as service goes, it was just as awesome as the food.  I really appreciated how the waitress took the time to explain the Live Scallop dish too.  The food can get pricey (we ended up paying about $50 each), but you certainly get what you pay for.  Now that I know what to get though, at least I can be a bit more efficient with what I order!  I just regret not getting on that Yelp deal they had a while ago.  Oh well...not like that is going to stop me from coming back again...soon.
author: Mike L.

description:
Nondescript, surprisingly good. 

I was really impressed with their nigiri quality, everything was oh so soft and the rice texture was perfect. Their seaweed salad wasn't great, but their gyoza and rolls made up for it. Though they don't have a ton of servers, the consistent trickle of our dishes kept our starving butts alive. The decor is of the "mom and pop" variety so don't except thumping music or designer furniture, though if you're hitting the Outer Richmond that probably wasn't your expectation anyways.

Full disclosure: At the time of this review Kabuto is a Yelp advertiser and I work at Yelp!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Although Kabuto is not exactly close to my house, I find myself going back for their extremely reasonably priced yet always super fresh toro!!

It is such a neighborhood sushi joint. Always packed with families and couples. 

I loveeee their toro Uni sushi and other fantastic creations. Sorry but the hamachi pear nigiri is not for me but I understand why some would love it. Fruit and hamachi for me just don't go!

Its been awhile since I visited Kabuto, Will write a more detailed review of my favorite dishes and will include pics! Stay tuned! :D
author: Amber S.

description:
I stumbled upon Kabuto while yelping a place for dinner tonight; it is now one of my favorite sushi restaurants. 

It's a pretty small place with about 8 seats at the sushi bar and 5 tables.  Luckily, my bf and I got there before the dinner rush and scored a couple seats at the sushi bar.

The service was sharp and our server was helpful and seemed to genuinely enjoy her job, which is always a plus.

The food was outstanding and the fish was some of the freshest I have ever had.  In addition to their dinner menu, they also have a menu called "Special Sushi" which contains a collection of their unique dishes.  And, in addition to that, there is a board above their sushi bar listing the evening's specials.  With so many choices and a limited stomach capacity, it was hard to know what to order.  We end up getting a sampling of their sashimi and "special sushi". 

You must try:
 - Hamachi Pear (yellowtail topped with sliced pear and a fruity mustard sauce)
 - Saikyo Sushi (grilled marinated black cod served with yuzu-kosho gravy)
 - Wahoo (Ono) sashimi
 - Tasmanian Salmon sashimi  

I cannot wait to go back and try more of their unique dishes and extremely fresh fish!
author: Juliana K.

description: This review is long over due!!! My boyfriend and his sister introduced me to this amazing little spot a couple years ago, and  this has become my most favorite sushi place EVER! Seriously, I've enjoyed sushi all over the Bay and this is by far the best! Eric the owner has created some amazing dishes ! Every time we go we order the must haves : ceviche, hamachi pear, tar tar, spicy tar tar , the "crispy", baby lobster, & the hamachi Kama, when ever they haven't sold out! If your in the inner Richmond it's a must try place!
author: Mary R.

description:
I wanted to like Kabuto more, it came highly recommended and the menu looked amazing.  It was really a 3.5 star experience for me.

Fish was fresh, but my fave bite is salmon and that was a chewy (I love when the salmon just melts).  I also got a clear soup with seafood and veggies and my wife got the veggie tempura and scallop dishes -- very satisfied with the food.

Service was not friendly.  We were never offered water, even when our drinks ran out.  We literally were eating with no liquid for at least 10 minutes until we flagged down a waitress and requested water.  Then she brought one glass for two people and quickly scurried away.  We had to flag down another waitress for the second water.  The restaurant was full and they brought our check before we even asked for it.

I'll be back because the place has potential, but I'm no hurry.
author: Steve K.

description:
Another great sushi place in SF! We were surprised at how delightful their dishes were, and had to come back and try more stuff in less than one week! 

Our favorites were the: Foie gras sushi (melts in your mouth with a raspberry balsamic vinagrette sauce that complements it well!), hamachi pear (generous slices of hamachi served with pear (refreshing taste), ceviche (tasty!), ankimo, toro tartare, and potato croquette (yummy, well fried!). The sashimi platter was delicious, served with fresh slices of hamachi, salmon, tuna, white tuna, and octopus.

The live scallop was okay.  It was fresh and sweet.  They cook the outsides and serve it on two spoons with some cream sauce though, which I didn't really like much.  The gyoza wasn't  bad ...with thin wrappers.  The sushi crepe was a little strange to me; it's basically what the name says it is... nothing spectacular though.  The tuna which was drizzled with what I believe was truffle oil was ok also! It was on the specials sign, but I didn't find it super special.  Also tried the soba noodles, which had a pretty good broth.  The salad they serve you with your meal is tiny.

The desert was good! Green tea tempura ice cream and matcha creme brulee!

Overall,  great experience.  They add a creative fusion touch to their dishes! Not very authentic though, but very fresh ingredients.  Average service & decor.  We'll definitely be back!
author: Tramy V.

description:
Go early or late. Late is better to enjoy slowly savoring the more than excellent and off-the-beaten path of Sushi fare. Toro Tartar. Hamachi Pear. Snapper in some sort of puff pastry type thing. There was just too much to remember. 

Lost but now a found.
author: Michael S.

description:
I gave a 5 star rating for the sushi at Kabuto.  I think it's the best sushi I've ever had--EVER.  That is saying something, when you consider that I lived in Japan for 15 years.  I lived in an area of Japan known for its fresh fish.  I've been eating sushi for a long time--way before it became popular in the U.S.  

We had an assortment of nigiri--yellowtail, several different kinds of tuna, salmon, toro, and a list of others.  It caught us by surprise.  We read the reviews on yelp and they were very good, but not "off-the-chart-good".  I was speechless for most of the meal, except for pleasurable groaning in between.

That said, the tempura udon my daughter ordered was not good.  The broth was way off, and the tempura was OK, nothing to talk about.

The miso soup was just OK, I've had better, and I make it at home better.

The service started out pretty bad.  We had reservations and they weren't ready for us.  We got stuck at a table where you could barely move.  But once I started eating the sushi, everything changed.  The waitress could have seated us on the sidewalk outside and I wouldn't have complained, as long as I was eating that sushi.

I can't speak for anything else on the menu except for the nigiri-style sushi.  If fresh sushi is your target, then you won't find better than this.  
My wife and I were talking about the sushi all the way home in the car, and then even when we got home, my wife was asking when are we going back.  Yeah, that's how good.
author: Darien R.

description: This place is amazing! The fish was of highest quality and the sushi was just perfect. I highly recommend the white tuna nigiris and the matcha cheesecake for dessert.. Will definitely come back when I'm in SF!
author: Alina A.

description:
I haven't been here in years but decided to make a last minute reservation last night when my usual place was booked for a private party. I made a last minute reservation for 4 at 7pm and when the reservation was confirmed, I was surprised to be able to get a last minute reservation. I called the restaurant and told them I made a reservation on Yelp and wanted to confirm. The guy who picked up the phone said the Yelp reservation isn't working but he would take my reservation over the phone. Is this Yelp's fault? I don't know.

We got there at 7 and saw an open table. The waitress sat us down but after 5 minutes she told us she sat us at the wrong table. It was actually reserved for a table of 5 and asked us to stay put and then move when the other table of 4 opened up. No problem. While we were all waiting (the table of 5 party was hovering over me and even rested his hands on our table and leaned on me). Weirdo. Anyway we moved over to the other table of 4 but they didn't change the paper that was covering the table linen. The couple that just sat there didn't leave a mess so I didn't say anything.

I was overwhelmed by the menu. I'm used to going to places and just throwing orders at the chef or leaving it to the chef. I remember when I came here years ago, they didn't have too many options. The four of us ordered Omakase and a bottle of sake. Everything was good and it was a good value. I didn't leave hungry or overly stuffed.

I won't go into details about the food since there are already so many reviews about it. 

I love that they have real wasabi. It's hard to find a place that serves real wasabi in SF and yes I totally judge a place by their wasabi and ginger. Everyone serves that nasty green colored horseradish.

The restaurant is small and some people sit around at the bar lingering but not eating anything. Reservation recommended.
author: x x.

description:
a very interesting take on sushi
I'm usually a classic nigiri/sashimi type of guy, but thankfully my friend helped with the ordering and choose some special things i typically would never think to get. I don't think we ordered anything 'standard' on the menu except for the grilled yellowtail collar and seaweed salad (which were both great) 
we had both the tuna and toro tartare - great. spicy scallop, great. fire salmon, great. crab/lobster mix with a grape, great. and finished with another amazing lobster plate. also the chef brings out a delicious suprise before the end of the meal.
author: Gordon C.

description:
Best sushi in SF ... currently for me at least. Had a Yelp deal for Kabuto that was expiring so I trekked my way from FIDI over to the Richmond district during my lunch break. If my boss is reading this, I was able to teleport (meaning MUNI of course) from FIDI to Richmond making it back for an hour lunch.

The sushi at Kabuto is really fresh. The combinations of their sweet and savory sushi is a great compliment for each other. At first I was thinking, hamachi pear ... really?  But after I finished the first piece I couldn't wait to finish the second. Also had a lot of other wonderful tasting dishes.

Go for their 1849 oysters. These things have a raw oyster, fresh uni, salmon roe, a quail egg, and to top it off, a gold flake. How much more extravagant can you get? You feel like you're eating a million bucks!

I like how the server was telling me which to eat without soy sauce. Made me feel like I was eating at the Tsukiji fish market again. I was able to ring up a tab of $66 by myself but I would do it all over again for the freshness of their ingredients.
author: Eric L.

description:
This resto seems not improving, but degrading. From the food and service quality.

I came around 2 weeks ago, greeted, seated right away.
It was in the evening and they just opened and wasn't very busy. 
Since I went here several times (but not recently) I know what I want to get.
The server didn't give me the warm towel. Ok.. I don't know what's going on in her mind. There were only 2 tables, and 2 ppl at the bar (me included), but still she seems busy around the kitchen area. 

I ordered :
- toro tartar - tasted superb as before, but where's the crispy seaweed that goes on the top?
- ceviche - ok this looked disappointing as the meat was very dry and the cut is very very thin, so thin it was separating. Also the seaweed seems to be soaked in too much oil and tasteless. It was a piece of blob. Yuck! 
- hamachi apple - good. 
- uni sushi - very good.
- hamachi served on the spoon (forgot the name) - OMG 1 of them is bad. Smelled rotten, that I decided to spit it up on the napkin.
After that, I am done! 

Another older lady server came after 30mins, but service is still too slow, it takes too long to get refill of my tea and when it came it was way too hot. 
Nobody came and ask how's the food or do a refill. I need to keep flagging them.

I'm not coming back. NOT RECOMMENDED. EVER!!!!
author: Icey M.

description:
I went to this place with my friends for the first time, it was good. Everything tastes wonderful, so I visit this place the second time and prepared to have a great dinner again.  It turns out to be the worst experience ever, we ordered 1849 oyster, sun rise, nigiri dinner set, tempura udon, gomae, and everything tastes totally different from the first time.  
Sun rise taste boring, oyster is not fresh, I left half of the nigiri dinner set untouched, and the udon is too salty no need to mention the gomae. 
Based onto two experiences that I have in this place, I'm give it a two star for their no standard on the food. If you happens to have a great experience then you got luck just like my first visit. 
Will I give this place another chance? NO!!!
author: Gabi F.

description: Went Kabuto for several times, I know the special menu but first time try Omakase. Their Omakase includes all the popular dishes. Dessert highlight the menu.
author: Cherry C.

description: Best sushi I've had in San Francisco. Sun, our waitress, basically told us what to eat, and was 100% business (telling us when to use soy sauce, etc), and made the experience delicious and memorable. Very, very highly recommended.
author: Nicholas S.

description: We really liked the raw fish here. The Alaskan king salmon, the kanpachi, mackerel, and toro were all really good. They had a special dish- salmon with a raw quail egg in the middle and that was so creamy and delicious. Ceviche was clean and refreshing but tamago and hamachi kama were disappointing (too dry). I would return and stick to their daily specials for raw fish on the board.
author: Allison S.

description: My favorite Sushi Restaurant in the country. Hands down. High Quality, diverse array of fish. Really creative dishes. Let's just say, if you are looking for rolls, go somewhere else.
author: Aaron S.

description:
When I first walked in, the first thing I noticed was a funky and unappetizing smell. This wasn't a great start to the meal. When you're eating something like raw fish, you want the sense that everything is very clean and food is stored properly. 

I ignored the smell and ordered a few things. The edamame was a bit old, not a nice green, but a darker almost browning green. They are served totally plain, no salt, nothing. 

Next was yellowtail with jalapeño and a small piece of apple. This was pretty good. 

After that was a series of sushi (nigiri): salmon, seared salmon belly, blue fin tuna, toro, yellowtail, and amberjack. I have never seen such strange cuts of fish for nigiri. They looked like they were pulled off the fish by hand and not cut skillfully and delicately with a knife like I'm sure you've seen at every other sushi joint. The cuts were much thicker than usual, which normally would be nice since you're getting more fish, but it was a strange balance and texture paired with the amount of rice. 

The actual quality of the fish was decent, not awful but certainly not top shelf. 

The waitresses were nice and the service was quick, but in a city like SF with hundreds of options for sushi, I won't be back.
author: Scott S.

description: Great sushi restaurant. Their omakase is very reasonably priced at $65 and you get quite a lot. Service is great as well.
author: Kai C.

description:
My expertise with sushi is limited, but If I am to qualify the type of aficionado that I am...well I won't.  All I know is that I like it raw. I like it fresh. I like the unique. 

Kabuto was one of those random finds. You know the kind you stumble upon when you are looking for a decent place to eat that's new to you and your date. 

The conversation went something like:
Me: Where are we eating?  
Them: Not sure, let's get in the car and drive.
Them: How about that place?
Me: Nah, we have tried that one before.
Them: That one? 
Me: We have been down Geary time and time again, you would think I would have it memorized.  Let's keep going.

followed with a horrible parking job and a "OOOH OOOH, let's try that one."

The joint gets busy, so go non peak hours.
Access to parking depends on the time of day, but if you are lucky you can score something close. 
It's a tiny, unsuspecting place...but don't let that fool you.

The sushi is fantastic. The rolls are "modern" and pretty.
Suffice to say every time they dropped off a fancy roll, it was accompanied with a "no sauce needed."

Exactly. 

Among the various rolls I ordered, I remember 2. 

Ceviche:
Halibut, salsa, and seaweed served with lime and sea salt. Simple, elegant, and I surely wanted more. 

Lamb Apple Sushi:
Grilled lamb topped with sliced apple and who knows what else. It was good.
 . 
And they were pretty, real pretty.  Pretty, like that  super model who needs an extra helping at dinner if you know what I mean.  Either way, I was happy with the flavors and simplicity. 

If you want awesome sushi, bring your wallet and your hunger.  This is no cheap joint, for the love of freaking SUSHI.
author: Flor D.

description: Service was great. Food came out quick. Every dish was a piece of heaven. One highlight was the tempura soba. The noodles were served warm in a nice light broth and the tempura veggies were lightly battered to perfection. Such simple yet tasty dish. Every sashimi or sushi tried melts in your mouth and oh so delicious. I will come back for the omakase very soon!
author: Kelly C.

description:
We made reservations (good call - there was a line started and a long line by the time we finished!) and were seated at the sushi bar as soon as we arrived.  We had to wait a while for our waitress and we wanted to order sake but they didn't give us a sake menu.... so we had to wait another long stretch after deciding what sake we wanted, so we hurried it up and ordered a bunch of sushi while we had her attention, but by then we were so hungry, we were noshing on the ginger just to sustain ourselves! 
Once we ordered, things came quickly.   Here is a recommendation:  skip the California rolls, the Dragon rolls - you can get those anywhere - focus on the Specials menu. Larger than average portions - maybe a little pricey, but totally worth it.
author: Maria C.

description:
Hidden treasure in the Inner Richmond!

I've always seen this place when I drive by Geary, and was put off by the exterior of the Restaurant, but I'm so glad I finally got to try this place, thanks to the bf for going out on our monthiversaries! 

- It's really small inside, no area to wait.  All the tables are really close to each other and there is no room to walk comfortably. And make reservations ahead of time! It will be hard!

- Their "special sushi" menu has all kinds of really creative sushi that works well together, that I don't think you can find anywhere else (both presentation and flavor wise) 

- What I recommend: 
  Kobe nigiri! Gosh, this was so good, we ordered 4. A must!
  1849 oysters!! Oysters with quail egg, gold flakes, uni, fish roe, and caviar.
   Hamachi Pear
   Toro nigiri/Toro tartar
   Live scallops
   Ceviche
   Hamachi belly
   Uni
   Scott handroll
   
But really, everything was really good here. Very well blended flavors and I would come back again when I would like to splurge a little more. Happy eating!
author: Isabel L.

description:
Kabuto is awesome.  It's small, but we've always managed to be seated every time we've gone here.

Why do we like it?

It's fairly close to him that we can walk here if we wanted (BTW, I'd recommend walking anyway because sometimes parking can be a real pain in the BEEhind.), everything we've tried here is super tasty, their fish is extremely fresh (Case in point, I am not an uni fan, but I tried their fresh uni and I actually thought it was good.), and it's not too too expensive.

I suggest you call first and get your name on the list, then head over and enjoy some great sushi!
author: Kris L.

description:
Kabuto i may have ate at with a j.  girl decades ago. the present location is across the street from it's old location. it's now a small place with less than 10 tables and sushi bar seating.

got a yelp voucher and had high expectations.

sampling:
-foie gras (goose) sushi (2/10)
first time for foie gras. didn't wow me
-toro tartar (2/5)
nice looking, didn't taste anything special
-baby maine lobster (2/14)
some lobster taste,
-hamachi pear (2/6)
nice sweet taste, 
*most special sushi recommended eating without soy, had own sauce
*flavors very subtle or didn't taste much.

-omakasse sashimi lunch special (14)
got 3 tuna, 2 sake, 2 hamachi, i rolled hirame, miso soup & salad.
sashimi fresh, looked like chirashi, not much variety
-blue fin tuna (2/7)
didn't taste like blue fin, darker hue, dense texture.  looked like toro 
-aji (spanish makeral, 2/7)
small slice, both nigiri's rice fall apart, rice lumpy

temaki:
-sushiman didn't look japanese nor korean, waitress was japanese. 
-service impeccable. every item came on separate plate.
-fish/sushi fresh but not exceptional
-each entree had bits of fruit on it....
-may try again with another voucher but not at regular prices. (not a value option).
author: Victor G.

description:
Radiation? Who cares!

Kabuto is a whole-in-the-wall restaurant that serves some of the freshest, move innovative sashimi I've ever had! I wouldn't have known what to order, had it not been for Kavita S. and Carmen L. My friends and I came here to celebrate a birthday. We were lucky enough to secure a reservation for 10, and pretty much took up half the restaurant. You can imagine, then, how small the establishment is. 

The menu is hard to follow, but here is exactly what you need to order:
+ Toro Tartare - delicious, interesting twist to a regular tuna tartare
+ CeViche - absolutely wonderful! 
+ Foie gras sushi - buttery with a sweet finish from the raspberry 
+ Unagi nigiri - you get a huge piece of unagi that melts in your mouth
+ Hamachi pear - just get it! Words can't describe!

Things I thought were pretty good:
- Sunset roll: must be eaten in one bite
- Crepe albacore: interesting tempura of albacore 
- Spicy scallop roll: ok
- 1848 oyster: I didn't have it but at $7.50 a pop, I didn't really want to. 

Overall, an EXTREMELY expensive sushi restaurant with creative and delicious morsels of food. Each plate only comes with 2 pieces but sometimes they'll do odd numbers for you if you come in a party of 3 or something. The bill can definitely rack up. We spent about $45-70 per person that night. Service is efficient and the waitresses are friendly. They may not refill your water at a timely manner but they get your food to you pretty quickly, take away your plates, and are always courteous. 

I can't wait to go back!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Make reservations, or you'll be waiting forever! Sushi is pretty good, and unique (not in the "douse-everything-with-sauce" manner).

Must get - and I recommend ending the meal on either one of these high notes:
Foie Gras Sushi - literally, whoa and orgasmic. $5 a piece.

1849 Oyster - so much swimming around in your mouth: oyster, quail egg, tobiko, gold foil, salmon roe, uni, chive). $7 each

Amebi - super fresh and legit to the point where they fry the head and serve it to you as well. Be careful when you get to the tail portion, it can be prickly. $3.50 a piece, decent price.

Okay - lacking in wow factor:

Futomaki - tamago egg was done right, that's about it
