Unimpressed items:
Hamachi pear - meh, wasn't the greatest cut
Fire Salmon roll - double meh, one of those "white" people rolls where it's doused in sauce
author: Vanessa K.

description:
My husband brought me here for my birthday. We both love sushi.. with a heavy emphasis on FRESH. 

The place is quaint and the sushi bar is quite comfortable to sit at. It was pretty busy for a Tuesday. 

Since we were ready to splurge, we ordered the omakase (chef's choice). It's been a while since I was there, so i don't remember every last dish we tried on the menu. The oysters and the hamachi were delicious. The rest of the dishes were a bit too fancy for my liking. I just want fresh fish without too much additives. Speaking of additives, this places adds a bit too much salt. We're already a low sodium family, so this really pushed us over the edge.  

I think I would give this place another try, but would not recommend the Chef's menu.
author: Winny F.

description: Sushi is excllent and they have a nice variety of hot dishes.  They have a nice variety of specials as well.  Their blue fin tuna is some of the best I've had at any sushi restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Mike L.

description: We came here for dinner 2 weeks ago and it was fantastic. We ordered a bunch of nigiri and everything was very fresh. I'm a fan of how lightly seasoned their sushi rice is, so that it doesn't overpower the fish. I liked the specials they had, including a few things I don't often see at sushi restaurants such as abalone. I also liked that you order nigiri by individual pieces, so you don't have to get 2 of everything. My particular favorites were the mirugai, amaebi, anago, and hirame. We also ordered the miso glazed grilled sea bass, which was really good.
author: Jessie L.

description:
A neighborhood gem!  Best (and freshest) fish I've had in San Francisco. 

-It's a very small restaurant so expect no privacy.  There was barely even walking room through "the aisle". 

-Service was great and fast.  Our waitress suggested about 6-7 things (along with about 3 things we picked ourselves) and none of them disappointed us.  It was plate after plate of buttery fresh fish served neatly. 

-Food. Again, it was delightful.  All 4 of us (the bf and his parents) agreed that the food was amazing and is the best japanese food we've had.  

-Accessibility, there's a parking garage closeby although I'd imagine that weekdays would offer quite a bit more street parking. We went Sunday night.

Ghellie and Alex
author: Ghellie P.

description: Do not order the omakase for dinner. Just had the omakase and it was overpriced. So disappointed as I have experienced better at Kabuto. They very little of the good stuff but the quality of "filler" entrees were just sad and miserable. We had one prawn tempura to share. Also, the waitress forgot some of the dishes so we had to remind her. So disappointed.
author: Jane W.

description:
This is a great sushi place for bold sushi connoisseurs.  The menu is scattered with tons of different, unique, and crazy combinations of nigiri and rolls.  I would really recommend this place for those who know great sushi and aren't afraid to try a roll with foie gras in it.  However, this may not be the best place if you are a sushi noob and trying to impress on a first date (go to sister restaurant Ariake, located half a block away).  

I'd recommend getting the unique rolls...you can't get them anywhere else!  It's difficult when you have a budget though...which is why you can't go wrong with a chirashi. The nigiris that I remember most are the ones with foie gras....so delicious and so special. They are always beautifully presented, ready to take a picture!

Service can be slow though, so my tip to you is go when they open so you can guarantee a seat. The service is also slow when you're eating, when they're taking your order or giving you food. But be patient, because it's worth it!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: The most amazing sushi in the city! Real sushi chefs and really good fish. I want it all the time so please stay away because the line is long already!
author: Elena N.

description:
Kabuto serves the best and the freshest fish in the city. A wide variety of rare sushi dishes that you can't get from other sushi places. 

Kabuto is a cozy space that is casual and mellow. The service is friendly.

Top favorites by far:

Foie Gras Sushi 
Sonoma Duck
Ankimo Sushi
Mirugai Sushi
The Lamb Ribs 

Kabuto is definitely one of my favorites!
author: Chloe B.

description:
I stopped in to dinner at Kabutos on a Friday night.   Made reservations through Yelp and got seated promptly.   The atmosphere was nice and not overly trendy like many other sushi places in the City.    I ordered sushi from the Specials menu, Fresh Nigiri sheet, and from the chalk board behind the bar.   I thought every was just ok.   I can see why a lot of people like this place.  The fish all tasted fresh.    The simple nigiri was great.   They are very creative and hits you with a lot of flavor profiles that usually aren't associated with sushi.   Oh, and lots of very friendly customers.   
    
The reason I was not a huge fan is probably because I'm more of a purist when it comes to sushi.    Everything at Kabuto was covered in thick sauces which smothered all the great quality fish.    With the majority of rolls that we had, you could not taste what each type of fish was.   If you drown the fish, what is the point of using high quality cuts of the fish?    Really, they could have substituted the great halibut, New Zealand King Salmon, albacore tuna, or any other fish for a piece of cheap talapia and the roll would have tasted the same.   There is a ceviche nigiri that was wonderful.  Nice piece of fish with a light salsa on it and that was delicious.   It did not drown out the fish.  If they could tone down their aggressive sauces, I would have enjoyed it much more.    I'm much more of a fan of a place like Sushi Sam's in San Mateo that can take high quality fish and honor the fish without overpowering it.
author: Duy N.

description:
Very authentic, fresh, creative. 

Prices are high but the quality & presentation of food is outstanding. The fish comes straight from Japan.

Make reservations. It's a small place!
author: Alysha K.

description:
All I can say is this place was overhyped... My evening started with a 75 minute wait for a table for three. That soured my mood AND my appetite. People rave about this place but I think it's overpriced and overrated. It failed to impress me! Will not be revisiting.

Why two stars you ask? I have to admit their fish was very fresh and they know how to prepare it. Otherwise it would have been a one-star AND would have qualified to be on my "Banned List"
author: Stephen Y.

description: ABSOLUTELY HORRIBLE! We are visiting SF for a short trip to see friends and family after we moved away a year ago. We wanted a special sushi meal to match our special trip. I made an online reservation (which was confirmed via email). Our party of 3 arrived 5 minutes before our 7:30 reservation and informed a "Host" we had reservations, the time and my name. He told us "wait a couple of minutes". A couple of minutes turned into 15. At 7:45, 2 separate groups arrived and shoved their way past us and proclaimed their 7:30 reservation. Tables and people were moved and THEY were seated and quickly accommodated. I spoke to the same gentlemen again and asked why they were seated before us and he said "they called". Calling and showing up late trumps a prior confirmed reservation? Uh, NO! I expressed my distain and was told to wait yet even more time. This is ABSOLUTELY no way to treat people that are ready to throw down a decent amount of cash. We left and found a place up the street that was warm, friendly and knew what customer service is. Has this town really gone completely to S#%T? NEVER going back nor recommending this disrespectful establishment to anyone; especially our local friends and family.
author: Mandy S.

description: Just ate here. I had amazing sushi. I ordered from the specialty section, 2 pieces each x 4 different types. This amount of order was plenty of food, as the prices are bigger than usual. Amazing parings of flavored, for instance curry with halibut. This is my second time here, one for lunch and one for dinner. Make this a must try when in SFO. Service very good. I wouldn't say come here for ambience, as the decor is meh, everything else amazing!
author: Jackie O.

description: Fish is fresh! My mouth was watering when I laid eyes on my aji. It melted in my mouth. It had been weeks maybe even months since I've an aji nigiri that yummy! I love the selection tai, medai, ono, toro and much more!  Even the surprising lamb apple sushi has me coming back. The way those flavors mingle in your mouth with the meaty taste of lamb, delicate sweetness of balsamic sauce, and the crunch of an apple ooowheeee!! Make a reservation or come early because the tables and bar fill up fast!
author: April L.

description: It's our first time trying Kabuto. After a day of strenuous city hike, we decided to reward ourselves with a nice pre-set courses that they provide. It's $65 per person, not cheap, but worthy. The nigiri sushi has the perfect ratio of fish and rice. Salmon is the best. 1849 oyster, bay Maine lobster, aburi toro and toro tartar are my favorites. I believe there are other wonderful dishes that we can try next time. The service is good too. Small place, not the fancy type. But it's a foodies' place.
author: Claire L.

description: Very so so. In particular, the rice on the sushi was too much and hard. The fish didn't knock my socks off. Very much a has-been kind of place. Also, lots of selection, but a lot of it was unappealing. I'd go to Sushi Bistro over this any day of the week.
author: Andrew K.

description:
They are one of the best sushi place.  Sashimi is always fresh.  The foie gras sushi was one of my favorite, of course it is banned in CA.

Keep in mind the place is small.  They fit less than 25 people.  Go there early or RSVP.

I wish they can work on the customer service.  The older Japanese waitress was very rude to us when I paid with a Yelp or Groupon deal (it was awhile ago).  It was funny the deal only cover 40% of the bill.  She sigh in my face, ask to see my ID, and grab my ID & credit card from me.  After this incident I stop going there for a while.  Maybe a year later I came here for a friend bday.  The same waitress still work there.
author: anita s.

description:
I can say this was was pretty darn good, 98% of the fish was really fresh especially Aji, Uni, hamachi, etc. The only thing that wasn't excellent was the butterfish, had a slight smell too it. 

The miso soup with clams was soooo good. A complementary dish was given which was some spicy tuna on top of this fried leaf. One word amazing, a little spicy :-). There were other dishes that I would definitely try next time.
author: Nhung T.

description:
First thing first : Mind blowing ceviche!!! Believe it!

Secondly: Ensure you have a reservation as we had to wait outside in the cold. You will have to write your name in a small book near the door if you have not made one. The place is small and sits about 26 in a slightly cramped area. 

I started with the Osuimono soup and K had the Miso Soup. My clear soup with clam and mushroom was a welcome hot starter in that cold blustery night. I was told that the Miso soup was delicious!

I started with the Sanshu Moriawase sashimi (a sample of three slices of kihada maguro, two slices of hamachi, and two slices of hirame sashimi) garnished with bright orange fish roe that was fresh and burst in your mouth with a slight acidic flavour.

I have no idea why, but K started with the mozzarella sushi which was essentially a melted mozzarella and rice concoction; it was ok --- as good as rice topped with melted cheese can ever aspire to be! Bleagh! heehee (I hope she's not reading this)

I didn't want to have anything to do with that ghastly mozzarella dish while she completely missed out on my amazing plate of sashimi.

We shared the rest.

The Ume hirame (Sour plum and Halibut) was pretty good but was nothing out of the ordinary which is not to say it was disappointing at all! Their "interpretation" sushi, the "Dragon Roll" made me turn my nose up at it on the first bite of the seared/cooked fish, but after I got past the blasphemy, I'd have to say it was pretty darn good!

We also had the special "fire salmon roll" which was fricking amazing. Again it was a slight interpretation as the salmon on top was seared with a blow torch and garnished with some creamy sauce that went very very well with the fish. It was topped with dabs of a spicy sauce, small rings of jalapeno and finished with black and red fish roes. It was so good we had to order seconds!

I missed out on the Hamachi Jalapeno which looked really really good and I must have that the next time I come here --- as should you, dear reader! 

Every dish we had were presented beautifully, the fish as fresh as fresh can be, and the refreshing interpretation as well as traditional dishes never failing to serenade our taste buds to the last morsel.

I am no sushi connoisseur, but Kabuto blew my expectations away!

Total damage: $93 (incl tax and tips)
author: Umesh T.

description:
I definitely had a mix feeling about this place.In terms of sushi quality it is a 5 star. In a scale of increasing tenderness and sweet lip: shima aji (amber jack), tai (red snapper), kanpachi (greater amberjack, and a personal all time favorite). Sophisticated sushi eaters deviate from Tuna eating seeking for the perfect texture. Note: albanoe was available on special menu

Diners are allowed to buy one piece of sashimi at a time - very affordable in this expensive restaurant. That makes Tai - red snapper $3 for a tasting / brief satisfaction.

And I got to try something very adventurous: Eihire nitsuke -  slowly boiled, simmered stingray 'arm'. Wow, what an experience. The cooking is extremely well executed: thick savory soup to mask the naturally fishy taste, slow cook allow the meat to soften, and the 'bone' was crunchy and edible. But yes, the natural fishy taste will keep me away for a while

That being said Kabuto has other more tangible creative dishes: specialty sushis that you can't find anywhere else. Everyone talks about Cerviche, it was perfectly executed, the halibut was extremely tender and soft, with perfect light flavor of lime and salt

I thought about ranking it 3 stars, because the restaurant is rather shabby looking. There is no ambiance for the $$$ you are paying.  The space is small and crammed, the wall bare except for a couple of odd decors. The waitresses are busy and less friendly, unlikely to engage in a passionate sushi discussion with us, because... maybe, and I strongly suggest so, it is the intensity trickling down from the sushi counter chefs. 

The hierarchy in the restaurant space is apparent. Sushi chefs are tense and serious, lack of smile or communication even to those sitting at the counter. That is zero words, zero interaction. That really killed one of the best part of the dining experience. If you come here alone, you will be alone forever.And if you come here with a group, the restaurant can barely accommodate. 

Very mixed feelings...
author: Dilys S.

description:
Decent enough, quite fresh sushi - hilariously bad service. The first time, the lady came too soon, and we needed more time. Fine. She came back, and said something like "OK, you should be ready now, right?" We were, but that's not something you say to a customer... Well it gets better. 

They had a special sushi of the day menu where they gave a list of fish and a price. Now, I knew this price was the price PER PIECE, this was NOT labeled and I had to infer it. Many other reviews here mention getting trapped by that ambiguity, expecting two pieces per order. Moral of the story: If it looks too good to be true ($3 for 2 pieces of nigiri), it probably is.

The worst thing about this ambiguity is that I think they expect you to get hooked by it. My goal was to sample 1 piece of everything new and interesting that I had never had before (and FYI, the listed selection of fish at this place is amazing. If you are trying to learn about many different kinds of sushi, this is the place for you.) So I ordered "one piece of aji". "One /order/?" says the lady, going in for the kill.  "No, one piece," I replied, and I guess that took her off guard. As I run through the specials menu ordering pieces here and there, some fish were not available (please tell me up front!), some fish could only be ordered in pairs (another hint that the ambiguity is intentional and you are never meant to order singles of anything.) The whole ordering experience was extremely curt and unpleasant.

My first order shows up - Aji, spanish mackerel, on its own plate (keep in mind that I had 3 other individual pieces in flight.) This took the service level from unpleasant to just strange. Why not deliver the aji with the three other pieces?

My girlfriend's first order shows up - "live scallop", which unbeknownst to us contains 4 pieces of scallop and two spoonfuls of some creamy-white wine-cooked version of the non-sushi bits of the scallop. Again, taken for a ride by the specials board, which merely listed the fish available, not the preparation or the cost of the dish.

After that everything was pretty smooth food wise, but then we saw one of the waitresses break a glass on the floor, and another one wiped out on a wet spot near the kitchen and nearly broke another glass she was carrying - bless her, it wasn't her fault, but these events took the service level from strange to hilarious.

We asked for the check and of course the price was not updated to reflect the Yelp Deals coupon we came in with, so we had to send it back. The waitress we asked had to ask her superior to do it, who after a while came by and just swiped the check up without a word. Took the service level from hilarious all the way back to unpleasant.

Food: We ordered Goma-ae, 2 nigiri combos (salmon, tuna, tobiko, hokkigai, ebi, mackerel, halibut, albacore, tekka maki), Chirashi-zushi, Aji, Shima-Aji, Amaebi, Kanpachi, Ankimo x2, Tai x2 and a small hot sake. All fish were very fresh but the shari was a little tough and tightly packed for my taste. Nothing in particular really stood out to me - you can have something equally good, if not better, for the same price at Okina Sushi just 10 blocks due back east from this place. And the service will be much better as well.

If I'm honest, the service was so crazy at this place that it was sort of hard to pay attention to the food. :(

Bottom line: The food rates a solid 3.5, and great service would have made it a 4 star overall. The dismal service we experienced brings the package down to 2 stars for me, especially considering the strong alternatives nearby.
author: Josh K.

description: Kama grilled fish is outstanding! Grilled eggplant with sweet miso sauce is ALWAYS on my order list. Spicy tartar is just phenomenal. Very creative and tremendously delicious restaurant. they just need more space. My favorite sushi place in San Francisco. Short and sweet - Awesome!
author: Xela H.

description:
Before my visit to Kabuto, I noticed that they had moved and downgraded to a smaller venue across the street.  The restaurant's outer appearance sure fooled me - I was never enticed to try it until YELP featured this place as their DEAL OF THE DAY.  Go YELP!  Goes to show that you shouldn't judge a book by its cover.

This was one of the best & freshest sushi/sashimi experiences I've ever encountered!!

Agedeshi Tofu - edges were not as crispy as the ones I had down the street at Ariake.

Hamachi Pear - hamachi sashimi topped with thinly sliced piece of pear, great compliments of each other & hamachi was very fresh - MUST TRY.

CeViChe - unique interpretation of ceviche, never would really expect to order ceviche at a japanese restaurant but this is goood!!  MUST TRY

Toro Tartar - the toro pieces melted in my mouth.  Made me wish I had also gotten the toro sashimi. 

Spicy Tuna - wowza, this was on fire!!  I thought I had a high tolerance for spicy foods, but boy was I wrong!  

Butter Fish - I wasn't dazzled by this dish like I was with the others - SKIP.

Hon Maguro (Blue Fin Tuna) - yum, yum, yum - BEST TUNA I EVER HAD.

Sake Chazuke - grilled salmon over rice in japanese tea, first time trying this.  Very interesting if you like soup - you should try.

The hostess/waitress was also very helpful because half of the dishes we ordered was not eaten with soy sauce and she always gave us a friendly reminder when she put the dish down.  Prices aren't too shabby but things sure added up.  Minus 1 star since our lunch alone was $60 (luckily for us we had a YELP DEAL), but for others coming to try this place for the first time - its not a cheap meal!
author: Steph L.

description:
Really don't understand the 4 and  5 star ratings. This place was terrible! 

When we entered the restaurant for dinner, there was only 2 people in the whole place. We sat down at the sushi bar and had our order placed in 5 minutes. about 10 minutes after that, the seats at the sushi bar filled up, and we still didn't have anything we ordered. On top of that, EVERY single person that sat down after us got all their sushi before we did, and we still had to wait almost 30 min to get our food! The waitresses were very cold and way too brash. Their sushi menu is extremely misleading, almost all special sushi's were only 2 pieces but neglect to say so on the menu and the quality wasn't even that great. 

Everything was WAY overpriced. After paying $70+ with tip for only 3 people, we all left the restaurant still hungry and completely unsatisfied. I don't get all the hype here on Yelp. Even the sushi restaurants on Fishermans Wharf were better than this place. Spend your money elsewhere.
author: James J.

description:
I have my reservations for giving this place 5 stars because that implies perfection (which is inherently a demarcation problem), but Kabuto is definitely a step above the other sushi bars I have been to as of late.  

We couldn't decide what to get, so we let the chefs decide.  We made the right choice.  The omakase was inventive.  Each piece of fish was fresh and delightfully presented.  I suppose it didn't hurt that I was with fantastic company..food tastes better with a smile on your face after all.

Highlights include everything...not very helpful but true.  Also, the live scallop was a winner too.
author: Ling C.

description: Second time the reservation I made meant nothing to them. Came in and was told the table was ready in three minutes and she then seated a group that came in after our group and told me they didn't have any tables. Done with this place.
author: J P.

description:
This is T-H-E place for sushi lovers. 
The fish is so fresh and yummy and they have different variations of sashimi.  Unfortunately the service could be better.  Our waitress wasn't very kind.
author: Yana A.

description:
Kabuto is one of my favorite restaurants. I miss the foie gras sushi but they created a substitute that is just as good. 

I highly recommend ordering: (All from the "Special" menu)

1849 Oyster
Ceviche Sushi
Toro Sushi
Live Scallop
Toro/Uni/Cavier Sushi
Fire Salmon roll
hamachi Jalepeno
and the Foie gras substitute thing. Sorry, I can't remember what it was called. The waitress told me about it.
author: Karen L.

description:
One of my favorite sushi spots in SF. They have fresh fish and unique creations, which you should definitely try. Every sushi dish I've ordered there melted in my mouth and was super scrumptious. Some of my favs include:
  - Foie Gras Sushi
  - Baby Main Lobster
  - Toro Tartar
  - Hamachi Jalepeno
  - Cruchy Sushi

Only drawbacks are that this place is quite pricey and small so be prepared to wait.
author: Nora Y.

description:
I have a friend who I've taken to some of the most famous and highly-regarded restaurants in the city, and everytime I ask for his review, he goes... "Meh, I prefer Pacific Catch." Blasphemous, right? 

Don't get me wrong, I like Pacific Catch but some things are just not "meh"-able, such as Philz or The House. I FINALLY got good feedback from my friend on this place. It could be the hot female sushi chef clouding his mind, or it could be the beautifully plated fresh sushi. Whatever your motive, Kabuto is the best, most affordable place for fresh, well-crafted Japanese food I've ever had.
author: Jess C.

description:
Fresh fish that melts on your tongue. (sense of oohhhh...ahhhhh)

My friend purchased a Yelp Deal of: Spend $50 of food for $25! We split it in half and got to the grubbing at this comfy Japanese restaurant.

Time:  6:30PM on a Tuesday
Ambiance: Quite cozy (maximum seating would be 40-50 people)
Waiter/Waitress Service:  Friendly, quick & efficient (Lost a star for rushing us right after we finished eating our dessert.....sadness...so close to a 5-star review.) 

Quality of Food:  Amazingly fresh and delicious! Their presentation is so artistic, colorful and pretty. Take a sneak peek here: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7iiWJyo_N5rGz4agqe9EbA?userid=ei6Z52YF1UyTVaMQOYubPw

We got 6 tasty different dishes to share. 

1) Hamachi Pear: Yellowtail sushi topped with sliced pear
and kabuto fruity mustard sauce
2) Foie Gras Sushi: Seared marinated goose liver served with balsamic raspberry sauce
3) Dragon Roll
4) Salmon with Soft Shell Crab Roll
5) Sukiyaki:  Beef broth, served with veggies in a hot central pot
6) CeViChe  Halibut and salsa wrapped with deep fried seaweed and served with lime and sea salt

We ended our scrumptious dinner with a sweet Green Tea Creme Brulee, which was a perfect palette cleanser. 

Overall, this place is amazing for great and fresh sushi.  Don't forget to either book a reservation or come before 6:30PM because it gets packed! 

Happy Yelping!
author: Deborah C.

description:
It's been a really long time since I sat down for some quality, top-notch sushi that goes beyond crazy and rice-filled rolls.  Kabuto not only provides a large selection of fresh fish, but it delivers it in a way that is unique and palate-satisfying.

A late weekday dinner with no wait, my mom, the Big F and I sat at the sushi bar.  This is what we tried:  

* CeViChe (Halibut and salsa wrapped with deep fried seaweed and served with lime and sea salt, eaten with no sauce.) $5 - My mom raved about this, and so we got it.  The deep-fried seaweed does indeed provide a different taste to it, along with the salsa mixture on top.

* Hamachi pear (Yellowtail sushi topped with sliced pear and kabuto fruity mustard sauce.) $6 - Very refreshing with the Asian pear slice on top and mustard sauce.

* Toro Tartar (Chopped Negi Toro and Avocado mixed with Kabuto Tartar sauce served with marinated Rakyo onion, deep fried shiso and seasoned seaweed.) $5 - This was my favorite of the bunch, definitely because of the seasoned seaweed and toro concoction.

* Sushi-Sashi Teishoku (Slices of assorted fish, assorted sushi and a roll of tekka maki.  Four slices of tuna, three slices of albacore, three slices of halibut, two slices of red snapper sashimi, tuna, ebi, salmon, hokkigai sushi, and tekka maki.) $23 This dinner entrée came with a house salad, miso soup, and a bowl of rice.  In retrospect, we should have skipped this and focused more on the unique sushi that Kabuto offers.

* Hamachi Kama (Yellowtail collar served with grated radish and ponzu sauce.) $8 - My mom devoured this, and usually the Big F really likes this too.  But I think he was preoccupied with the other good stuff we got.

* Dragon Roll (Unagi & Avocado on the outside, Tempura Shrimp on the inside) $10 - They did this roll well, very tight but quite typical.  Again, skip the regular stuff and order the unique things!

* Chawan Mushi (Steamed Japanese egg custard) $6 - A steamed egg dish that had shrimp, okra, and enoki mushrooms inside.  I didn't think it was that special.

* Salmon with Tobiko and a quail egg - This showcased the quality of the sake, the nice crunch of the tobiko and the egg mixing in with everything in your mouth.

 * 1849 oysters - The amount of time and effort that goes into doing this oyster explains its price.  A little bit of uni, ikura, tobiko, black caviar, chives, ponzu sauce and some gold flecks complete this lovely piece of artwork.

When it comes down to sushi and unusual accompaniments, Kabuto takes the cake.  The regular sashimi is okay, and the fish is fresh.  But the real winners are beyond the average sushi menu.

Our sushi chef, one of the few women working behind the sushi bars in SF, was amazing to watch as well.  Her precision and careful attention to detail showed how she really takes care of each piece of fish coming out from her end of the sushi bar.

The wait staff could use some improvement.  I had to ask for my water to be refilled each and every time, which is a pet peeve of mine.  

Overall, a solid 4.  (A true 4.5 for their really great stuff, but 3.5 for the average stuff.)  Next time I go, I'm going to focus on their special stuff only!

(Photos posted from our dinner!)
author: Teri C.

description:
Kabuto has very fresh seafood and great customer service.
Make a reservation...This is a small place, but it's worth the wait.
author: Margaret W.

description:
If you want "sushi" with crazy mayo sauces, two avocados, and more than 5 different types of fish, then please look again. You will be disappointed but not have diarrhea.

If you want specialty sushi that is both simple in form but complex in taste with nice quiet seating, then please do come to Kabuto. I have taken my girlfriend here countless times and have enjoyed the best sushi I have ever had. Hamachi pear/jalapeno, ceviche, toro tartare...oh DELICIOUS.
author: Jeff H.

description: I have been going to Kabuto for 10 years. The fish is consistently top notch and this is hands down my favorite sushi spot in the city. The hamachi pear nigiri is not to be missed!
author: San Fran G.

description:
5 star for the food, 3 star for the decoration...

Kabuto has very good quality and very creative sushi.  Unlike the most of the sushi place with tradition nigiri, sashimi, and rolls, Kabuto's special list is really special and truly outstanding!

My favorite is Hamachi Pear, CeViChe, Toro tatareand lamb sushi --yes sushi with lamb!!! No dipping sauce needed, all flavors are blended into the sushi already.

My friend said the way he usually judge a Japanese restaurant is the very basic California roll. So we tried it, simply california roll with real crab meat, very delicious!

It's not cheap, but definitely worth the price! Though I assumed this place would be a bit fancier, but it's pretty small and decoration is not as creative as their food :P
author: Chloé N.

description:
This place is one of my fave sushi places.  Their selection is good and a bit pricey but well worth it.  I have came here probably 4 total time in my lifetime and they had never had a dish that disappointed me.  

Must try's...

1849 oyster
Toro. Uni, Caviar sushi
Hamachi pear 
Live scallop
Kobe beef sushi 
All their fatty fishes that they have!! - toro, hamachi belly, etc.
author: Patrick C.

description:
This place was great. With the exception of the outstanding omakase at Zushi Puzzle, this is the best sushi restaurant I've tried so far in SF (given, I've tried quite a few that are noticeably sub-par).

If you are thinking of going, make reservations more than 3 hours in advance. We went at 8:30pm on a Tuesday (with reservations) and were really glad we had them, because there were about 10 people waiting outside to be seated (it's a small place with a few seats around the bar, and then only a few tables).

Between two of us, we ordered:
- Edamame ($4)
- Tuna Tartar ($5 for 2)
- CeViChe ($6 for 2)
- Sammy Roll ($10 for 6 pieces)
- Soft Shell Crab in a roll, covered by Tuna ($10 for 6 pieces)
- Hamachi Pear ($6 for 2 pieces)
- Foie Gras ($10 for 2 pieces)
- Vanilla Tempura Ice Cream ($5)
- Green Tea Creme Brulee ($6)

The SS Crab and the Sammy Roll were supposed to be fillers (so we could try all the special sushi dishes, but wouldn't leave hungry), but the Sammy Roll (Salmon-covered California Roll in a Curry Sauce) was surprisingly good. Strange / interesting to add Curry, but it worked.

If I were to come here again, I would pass on the Tuna Tartar and the CeViChe - while they weren't bad, they didn't live up to the reviews.

The Hamachi Pear was wonderful! The pear / mustard / yellowtail combination was scrumptious - I will order two of these next time! But the icing on the cake was the Foie Gras. I usually avoid Foie Gras, but the reviews were too compelling - and this dish blew every other one out of the water. The balsamic raspberry sauce and the fresh raspberry on top complimented the foie gras so well! Would highly recommend this.

A note on the service. It was perfect. Couldn't have been better.

Can't wait to return to Kabuto!


***

Returned to Kabuto on 6.15.2012. 

In addition to the above, we tried the sonoma duck, the ono grape, the saikyo sushi, and the baby lobster tail. We also-retried the hamachi pear and the foie gras. The hamachi pear remains my favorite (the fish is so fresh). The ono grape was also extremely fresh. I would definitely skip the sonoma duck next time (it had a whallop of a kick to it, but I'd prefer to have fish), and I'd skip the saikyo sushi as well. It had a slightly sour taste to it.

Again - highly recommend Kabuto. The omakase menu is actually a fantastic deal!
author: Helen D.

description:
I came here last night for dinner and I really don't understand all of the 5 star ratings.

My friend and I shared an order of gyoza, which was really good but they were more like Chinese pot stickers than gyoza.  I ordered udon, which was good, but the noodles weren't cooked thoroughly and a salmon avocado roll, which wasn't too bad either.  I guess what was grossing me out was the fish smell.  I know, I know, I was sitting at the counter where all of the raw fish is but it seriously smelt like a fish market. Eek.

The service is pretty bad.  There were only two waitresses and they had no system so it was seriously a free for all. We had to ask for everything, and if we didn't we'd probably still be there.
author: Marisa R.

description:
Kabuto did not fail to impress.  I would give it 4 stars for the tiny cramped space.  Atmosphere is also important.  We did have a reservation and found ourselves at the bar.  I enjoyed that, but I could tell he would have preferred to be at a table.  My date and I had trouble not getting constantly bumped into every few minutes.  The waitstaff were so polite and generous with their service, I never even had to ask for anything, they were so attentive.  
The menu was spectacular!  I appreciate that they show what is on the Omakase menu rather than surprising you.  It's a fun concept when you can surprise your dinner guest, assuming you like everything.   They use REAL Wasabi here!  So rare, and so delicious.  Hot towels so you can clean your hands before eating sushi rolls.  Many selections of delicious sakes.  ABSOLUTELY every cut of sushi was the highest quality, artistic presentation, SUPERB!! I used soy once, barely.  The foie gras sushi was something new, I adored the explosion of flavor.  Just go here!  You won't regret it!
author: Anna R.

description: Kabuto hands down one of the best Sushi spots in all of SF ..they have an amazing Civiche Nigiri there traditional and concept sushi is top notch. If you can only eat Sushi one night I'm SF make it a Kabuto night.
author: Ashley A.

description:
I'm still salivating over my meal here from 2 nights ago. 

If you are looking for fresh, melt in your mouth buttery fish, you found it.  If you are looking for traditional nigiri, you found it too.  If you are looking for aesthetically prepared sushi, you found it too.  

I have been living in the bay area for about 3 years now and I could not find a good sushi joint for the life of me.  Thank you to Kabuto for being around.  Sure, some of their rolls and sushi isn't exactly your authentic sushi but it's still to die for.  I personally don't like fancy rolls or fusion sushi of any sort but Kabuto has changed my mind.  

Since it was my first time here, I ordered the omakase, which is more or less what the chef wants to serve you.  In this order we were served:

"Hamachi Jalapeno"  (Fish was melt in your mouth fresh, but why would a sushi restaurant serve you something spicy to start with bewilders me.  Kills your taste buds a bit right off the bat)

"1849 Oysters" (consisted of your oyster, quail egg, ikura, uni, tobiko, and gold flakes...this was by far one of my favorites of the night.  It was an explosion of flavor.)

"Ceviche" (The roasted nori gave it a toasty taste and of course, the fish was fresh)

"Hamachi Pear"  (This was my least favorite dish.  I'm surprised that everyone raves about this nigiri.  The hamachi was super fresh, but the mustard sauce that was placed on top of the sushi tasted like sauce you would have on a burger and that to me ruined what could have been great)

"Baby Maine Lobster" (This was good but it doesn't really stand out in my mind)

"Live Scallop"  ( I liked the presentation on this dish.  And the scallop was sweet!)

"Foie Gras" (So rich! So creamy! Sooo good!)

"Toro Tartar"  (I liked the citrus taste in this one...and it again went well with the toasted nori)

"Abalone"  (No words needed...delicious)

"Aburi Toro" (My favorite of the night.  Citrusy, peppery, buttery, melt in your mouth fatty tuna.)

"Uni" (creamy...not fishy at all, melt in your mouth yummy goodness)

And that concludes my meal.  I can't say that the service was great but they were busy.  I did like that the waitresses tell you if you need soy sauce or not with each sushi.  Reminds me of Sushi Sasabune in Hawaii which is still the best sushi ever.  But Kabuto comes close.  I will definitely come back here again...and again...but next time, I will order everything ala carte instead of the omakase, doozo!
author: Amy L.

description:
I was sort of dragged here by a friend who insisted that this was the best Japanese restaurant in the city. Clearly I beg to differ but its good to know that nobu k. feels the same.

When I arrived it was barely past 5:00 PM so they had just opened and there were no customers inside. I was greeted and seated promptly. Up til this point I felt like things were going well, it's a very small restaurant, I've heard of the massive lines outside so I considered myself lucky. The waitress brought out menus but the bf and friend had to use the restroom / make a call, respectively, so I was the only one sitting at the table.

I think this means we're not ready to order. But this did not deter our waitress from coming back 3 times within 5 minutes to ask if we were ready to order. Ok, so I look over the menu and finally decide on a few dishes. To my surprise this place was actually quite pricey and I don't know that I quite like the fact that all of their nigiri or sushi come out very non-traditional with lots of fixings, sauce, and other compliments you would not normally see at a sushi place. Although it was good, it wasn't what I would call an authentic sushi experience. They should really make this place fusion instead. 

They also give you very little food. So quantity wise you won't be full and it's not the greatest meal so some may walk away grumbling a bit. The thing that really nailed this as a 3-star restaurant for me was that the waitress constantly came by and reached over us, under us, around us, and awkwardly in front of us to grab the plates AS SOON as we were done with it. Some were soooo ridiculous where she grabbed the plate right after my chopsticks picked up the nigiri but BEFORE it had entered my mouth!

Why?

Strange. I don't know that I'd go back.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Gosh, after reading all the wonderful Yelp reviews and building anticipation about this place, I was really disappointed. 

Lamb dish - dry and overcooked
Foie gras - also dry and overcooked
1849 oyster - I'm not too much of a raw oyster fan. I actually just tried it for the novelty. 
Hamachi jalapeno - actually pretty good
Toro nigiri - terrible. This was not good toro - wasn't very fresh and something seemed "off" about the flesh.

Maybe I'm spoiled by Jo's Sushi Bar in Pleasant Hill. Or maybe I came on an off day. I dunno.
author: Christine P.

description:
It's cold, it's damp, the power went out in our building at 7pm...what could possibly make me feel better? Dinner at Kabuto!

Have driven down Geary Street ample times and have always seen folks eating at Kabuto. When I saw the Yelp deal, it was a win-win situation.

We came to Kabuto on a Friday night and made reservations for 9pm. The restaurant is small and can fit about 30 or 40 patrons and while there was no wait, there weren't too many empty tables either.

We sampled about 10 dishes between 2 people of their special rolls. The major winners were the toro tartare and the hamachi pear, would definitely order those two again in a heartbeat. 

Some of the other things, miso eggplant, spicy tuna handroll, tempura curry sushi were definitely good but I would rather try something different the next time we come.

The best thing about this place is that it feels like omakase to order. Everything comes in a separate dish, separate presentation, and every bite is something special. Sushi tapas if you will because the way they present it makes you want to savor every bite.

The chef likes to use the blow torch and I gotta say, you can never get enough of that torch.

We are looking forward to coming back again and trying some of the other items on the menu!
author: Betty C.

description: A little gem in the richmond dist. kabuto is the spot to try sushi, they have special sushi rolls / fresh fish...I had dinner here saturday night 9/28 and the place was pack by 6:30pm,the staff is friendly servicw with a smile..But i felt that we were being rushed alittle since it's a small place..So one star docked off for that, but the food is good if your a raw fish eater then this is the place..But i still think ebisu on 9th ave is better p.s. my picture for the toro tartar is mispelled cuz of auto correct lolz
author: jonathan h.

description:
On the good side, Very fresh fish.  Creative special dishes with nice presentation.  enthusiastic servers.
On the ok side. Hit and miss presentation.  Nigiri presentation when you order just two pieces comes on a large white plate sometimes with some greens and a berry or two, sometimes not. They take reservations so if you are a walk in you can wait a very long time with several of their 8 tables sitting empty.  The first time we came we actually left after half and hour waiting with 3 tables sitting empty the whole time.
On the not so good side. the menu is near impossible to read for my old eyes.  The descriptions of the dishes are in light blue grey against white and no larger than a 6 font.  It was a hot evening so I did not have my jacket which held my reading glasses. Thankfully after attempting to use my iphone to read the menu, one of the waitress lent me a pair or reading glasses. I also felt rushed to order.  The atmosphere is very hectic and loud. I found our selection less than inspiring so for our last dish I ordered the grilled sea bass to give my taste buds a finishing treat as miso marinated sea bass is one of my favorite things in the world. No japanese restaurant has disappointed me until Kabuto.  It tasted old and salty.  
I was hoping to love this place, but because of the two less then stellar  experiences with the operation of the business, I will not rush to come back.  I am sure they will do great without me.
author: Jerry W.

description:
My friend and I had a second dinner to attend at 7pm and didn't want to fill our-self up. Really wanted to try this place, so we came here once when it opened at 530pm and ordered 5 dishes. 

Hamachi pear came with two pieces. Every single person in the restaurant ordered this as first course. 
Ceviche came with two pieces, on top of a deep fried seaweed.  Not your average bowl of ceviche.  
Live Scallop came with 4 pieces and two spoons with a piece of deep fried vegetable?! asparagus!?, topped with a temperature hot white sauce with chunks of scallop pieces?!  
Two rolls as filler, salmon avo and a spicy tuna roll.  

Sometimes it is cool to order off the walls and not know the price, but I don't think I will be doing that again,. The bill came out to 55 with tip. The only shocking part about the bill was ,.  the Live Scallop was half the bill, $18 SMH.  

This place is to expensive to turn into a regular dinner sushi spot, but it has pretty unique dishes and will recommend everyone to try at least once.
author: Chanel L.

description:
This was a great find!  I will go back, over and over!  I was meeting a friend who was coming from Palo Alto, and I was coming from Marin.  We looked at the Yelp reviews, and took a chance.  This place was great.

It is no frills, but the service was excellent, and attentive.  We ordered the gyoza, which arrived piping hot and delicious.  We also ordered the Hamachi with pear and it was very unusual and a delectable combination.  Other sushi and sashimi were also stellar.
 
It was very busy, yet my friend and I were not rushed out, and were able to continue to order food as we talked and caught up after not seeing each other for a year.  

The chef came over at one point to ask how we enjoyed the food.  I cannot remember getting such wonderful service even at a high end restaurant in a long time.

Kudos to the owners and chef!
author: Dr. W.

description: If you are looking for delicious, carefully prepared sushi, go here! I have been coming for years, and this is one of my favorite places in SF. For such an extensive menu, they do surprisingly well at a variety of things, and the fish quality is great. If you are looking for a sushi restaurant with upscale interior decor, this is probably not the top of my list, but the service and food quality render that irrelevant.
author: Jon S.

description:
I've written this around 9/25/2014 when I had a dinner there and left out while since I wanted to double check their entrance posted Michelin recommended sticker really. I've recently visited the area again and confirmed it was still posted and said Michelin recommended in 2013 and 2012, not 2014. And I've just realized why they didn't get it for 2014.
===== 

This is my first experience Michelin star didn't meet my expectations.

Firstly, the chefs are not Japanese, but Korean. From the name of the restaurant, 'Kabuto' which seems to be a word chosen by Japanese, 4 star reviews in yelp and one star of Michelin, I was totally deceived it's an authentic Japanese place. I should have searched through reviews carefully since many people had already pointed out this. But it's not the reason I give only two stars. Even if it's not authentic Japanese, the food could be much better for the price.

I tried Sushi-Sashimi Teishoku. 'Teishoku' normally means a set of various dishes in Japanese. Again, it's deceiving. It's just a plate of Sushi and Sashimi. Even rice bowl doesn't come with it. Miso soup came with it, but it's just tasteless. I don't think it's using enough broth nor traditional Japanese cooking skills. To be fair, it came with a small green salad which was good, but not super impressive.
 
The most important point is that the freshness of the fish doesn't definitely meet the expectation from the michelin star and at this price point.

I didn't try non-sushi menu, it might be very good, but judging from the freshness of sushi ingredients and the tasteless miso soup, I guess chances are not great.

As a typical sushi place run by non-Japanese, the portion is large with not-so-good quality of ingredients. Normally those type of restaurant priced very reasonably, but this place is not the case.

So, if you expect to get an authentic Japanese dishes and/or very fresh sushi/sashimi, this is not the place to go, sorry.

The service was quick and an average, I give two stars. It's really overpriced I think it's because of Zagat/Michelin reviews which I don't know how they got such a good review from them.
author: Toru M.

description:
The was definitely one of the best place for sashimi. The fish was fresh. The food there was just different, not the traditional Japanese restaurant. Everything I tried was great. 

Be prepared to spend more money than usual Japanese Restaurant. We paid about $80 for 2 people.
author: Donna M.

description: Went there for lunch .had the special which is your choice of noodle soup Plus dumplings and rice for around 12 dollars soup was lovely definitely a full meal waitress was very helpful with explaining the soups would go back ....the address is 5120  the restaurant as 2 parts to it
author: Kelly M.

description: In this unassuming, non-pretentious, hole-in-a-wall, ugly yellow box of a restaurant, you will find the most amazing culinary creations in the city. I've been here twice and had their omakase both times. Every piece is like an explosion of orgasmic flavors and textures. I don't often say this but after a meal here, I can die with no regrets. So worth the price. And just so you know, everyone working here is authentically Japanese (including the chefs of course) lol.
author: Philip T.

description: Mind blowingly delicious, melt-in-your-mouth, other-worldly experience! Hamachi pear and Tuna tartar were the major favorites.  Must try!
author: K M.

description:
Hmmmmm.........

Friend and I spent $50/person on little sushi on big plates... HMMMM....mmm...

I'm not really sure how I feel about that.  I mean, the sushi was GOOD, but....I think we paid for the artistic and creativity factors rather than for the food itself.  It's weird because the food is foo-foo looking, the prices are foo-foo, but the restaurant lacks in zee ...how to say...foo-foo feel.  Shrug.  

I'd rather have lots of  sushi for 50 bucks than pretty sushi.
author: Tokki M.

description:
I came, I ate, I think it's whatevs.

Tried it again with a second visit and I have decided that I probably won't be coming back anymore.... I really wanted to like this place but the food isn't that great..it looks like it would be but my taste buds and stomach & wallet just won't allow me.. I'm sorry..I would not recommend.
author: .I I.

description:
They have the best sushi in town. Is not a cheap place, but you will have the best sushi. Let them recommend you the best sellers, and best pieces of sushi. It is traditional with a fusion twist, which I particularly like a lot, as you try different flavours and sensations.
However, the atmosphere is very siple, so if you are expecting to getting dress up, on a friday night, and go o a fancy restaurant, this is probably not the restaurant to go. This place is simple, the best thing they have is an outstanding, excellent sushi. Expect to spend, probably 60 dollars per person.
author: Lucia C.

description:
Wow - this place is pretty amazing, and those who follow my reviews know I don't say that often about sushi.

The style here is modern - sauces and complex prepared dishes rule the day.  Their foie gras sushi ( get in before the ban if you can ) is actually well-conceived and delicious.  Especially a combination of foie and toro served as nigiri.

It being our first time here, we sat at the sushi bar ( you can reserve! ) and ordered their Omakase menu, which is actually mostly set.  It provided a good overview of what they offer and dishes were often shared between two diners.  Strangely, there did not seem to be a particular ordering to the meal, with dishes from the middle of the menu coming out first, and sometimes overlapping each other.  This was a little inconvenient in that it caused us to let the tempura course sit for a while as we finished something else, but generally everything worked well.  More strangely, sitting at the sushi bar, it seemed that we were still to order everything from the servers.

Platings were really beautiful - obviously they take time and care in the presentations.  And tastes - often problematically muddy in this modern style - were actually bright, clear and clean.  The omakase did include some traiditional nigiri - maybe just to prove that they can do normal things - and it was excellent in balance, flavor and texture.

We added a couple courses to our tasting, including the aforementioned foie/toro combination and an absolutely delicious live scallop preparation that we saw another patron enjoying - both so absolutely fresh and delicious that we were left wanting even more.

The sake list is both extensive and interesting, with a large number of things both familiar and new available by the glass.  Pours were a little variable in quantity, but mostly reasonable for the cost.  Admittedly, I skipped over a couple varieties I felt were excessively overpriced, and instead found some tasty things I had not tried before.

Prices may seem high to some, but are really reasonable given the quality - looking at the sushi case, it was obvious that we only scraped the surface of their fish selection, and we got out of there for somewhat less than we might have paid for similar quality and creativity elsewhere.  We will definitely be back.
author: Albert H.

description:
AVERAGE RATING
Ate dinner here this week , first visit.

**Wrong food - Most annoying:  the waitresses didn't serve our sushi choices to the person who ordered them.  As a result we weren't sure if we were eating what we ordered.  Example:  I didn't get to try the CeViChe although I ordered it, since it was served to my wife on the same plate as her order. Huh?  

Ordered sushi assortment plates + special sushi:  fair quality, I've had better in L.A.

Wait time: despite reservations, waited outside.
Parking: didn't need to feed the street parking meter since it was after 6:00 p.m., plenty of spots nearby.

Probably won't return.
author: NB A.

description:
I was so excited to try Kabuto... maybe because I've always seen a crowd of people waiting outside. Or maybe because one of my close friends eats here so often that the sushi chefs know him by name and he loves it. Or maybe it's because it currently has 4 stars on yelp. Or maybe it was all three of those combined that hyped it up.

To be honest, I didn't think Kabuto was all that. Don't get me wrong, it's still good and has some really interesting sushi combos, but it wasn't knock my socks off fantastic. things to note are: the oyster with uni, ikura, quail egg and a gold leaf on top, the ceviche roll was pretty good, the foie gras roll was good (get it while you can californians) and the tuna tartar one was pretty good also. 

Still haven't found a favorite japanese restaurant in the city for sushi, and it doesn't help that i've experienced sugarfish in LA because that is where i'm setting the bar for my sushi now. oh, and the prices at Kabuto are a bit pricey for what it really is seeing as I've had better quality sushi that costed less than what Kabuto charges.

c'mon san francisco, give me some amazing sushi already (suggestions are very welcome my fellow yelpers), that or Sugarfish open a location up here please!!
author: Kimberly F.

description: Love the fresh sushi here and it is kind of cozy romantic place for a date. It is small ,not too loud and the fish is just fresh. They also have great rolls.
author: P C.

description:
For having such delicious fish, it is surprisingly easy to get a table at Kabuto, which is a distinct advantage in San Francisco. 

The staff is often a bit harried, running between the kitchen and tables.  That said, they are very nice and friendly.  And I wonder if the lean staffing keeps the prices at a fairly reasonable level.

As to the food, I've enjoyed nearly everything that I've had.  Kabuto's special sushi tends to be interesting (and delicious).  In particular, the U.F.T. (ume fried tai) is one of my favorite dishes in my lifetime.  The Sonoma duck is also definitely worth trying. As to more straightforward sushi/sashimi, I've generally enjoyed sampling the daily specials listed on the blackboard.
author: S E.

description:
One if the best sushi places around. The first time I came here, I remember getting the foie gras sushi (so amazing). Can't remember what else we got.

The next time we returned here, we discovered the sushi sashi and that has been our go to dish since. It's the best deal, for $25 you get two pretty good size pieces of various types of fishes and a bowl of rice. It's totally filling and the fish is so fresh so wonderful. 

Other times we've also tried the unagi bowl (good), soft shell crab inside and salmon outside (also good).

If you're going to come here with a big group of friends (4 or more), you'll probably have a hard time getting a seat. The place is pretty small, but cozy. Everyone there is very nice.
author: Lang T.

description: 5 Star review every time we've been here.  Would be nice if the service slowed down a bit so we could take our time.  Other than that fish is always superb and service is very attentive.
author: Bonjing B.

description:
This place was delicious! my favorite dish was the mozarella (not sure about the spelling here?) sushi roll, which came out more like a risotto, but was good none the less.

For two of us, we spent $80 and had a good amount of food. Presentation of food is beautiful as well.
author: Pudgy G.

description:
I am in. love. With. This. Place.  Words cannot describe how much I enjoy Kabuto.  It's the only place where I can have tuna tartar without suffering.  I am beginning to believe that my stomach is tuna selective.  
Kabuto is totally worth every penny.  All the dishes were intricately prepared and every piece of sushi mouthwatering experience.  I enjoyed it so so so so much! Everything that we had ordered was great and exceeded my expectation.  I just wish I had the kind of $$ to support this kind of eating.
author: Shirley H.

description:
Went with the Omakase during dinner.  

Perhaps one of the top sushi places in the city.  I'm afraid you will just have to try it.
author: Steven C.

description: Eh, nothing special. Mostly overpriced sushi that is dressed with one two many sauces that overwhelm your palate. I prefer Koo. Simple, finer, cleaner servings.
author: Tammy T.

description:
My hubby and his friends took me here to initiate me into the wonderful world that is sushi and sake. Thank you, thank you, thank you!  What an incredible introduction into the delectable delicacies that sushi has to offer.

Loved the eel and tuna tartar and the uni melted in the mouth. There was something with Asian pear and a mustard/caviar blend that was very exciting and unexpected. The organic sake was a very tasty sip in between bites of buttery seafood. I'm a convert to sushi now!
author: Terrie C.

description: First time to this small unassuming sushi bar. Certainly it won't be the last!! Just amazing good food great quality and terrific sake!  Highly recommend this place!
author: JL B.

description:
there were way to many options on the menu that it overwhelmed us so we opted for the 65/pp pre fixe

set menu:
-shrimp and asparagus tempura: standard tempura
-grilled spicy mussel: liked that spicy kick
-hamachi jalapeno
-1849 oyster: plus quail egg, roe, uni, caviar, gold leaf! 
-baby main lobster
-ceviche
-hamachi pear
-chef's choice of 4 nigiri
-green tea pudding with strawberry sauce on top. served in a martini glass
..there were 2-3 other dishes served but i dont remember what they were..

everything was absolutely delicious and i can't wait to come back again soon
author: Raquel T.

description:
5 STARS

After trying several sushi places around the SF area, this is, by far, my all-time fave! 
Been back a few times and the sushi is on-par every time. 

This is not your modernized sushi bar like Sushi Bistro or traditional hole-in-the-wall sushi nazi joints like Tekka or Ino Sushi. This is in between traditional and modern. They have the quality and service of the traditional sushi bars but provides a fun twist in their dishes, like their Hamachi Pear or Foie Gras Sushi. 

It is definitely on the expensive side, even for sushi. However, the quality of fish is the best I've had in the SF area and the flavors are unique and fun. 

I've tried:
1. Hamachi Pear - BEST DISH EVER- MUST TRY
2. Daily special Hamachi Jalapeno (i love hamachi) - ALSO MUST TRY
3. Spicy Tuna and Scallops (raw scallops) rolls, which were more ordinary but still really good
4. The salmon kama came in a huge portion (enough for 3-4 ppl) and was really crunchy and juicy. However, I would definitely skip this next time and order more raw fish
5. Deep Fried Ice Cream - very lightly breaded green tea ice cream; so crispy and refreshing. 
6. Macha Brulee- who doesn't love Macha Brulee?? My two favorite things combined. 

Next time I come back, I want to try the Foie Gras Sushi and the 1849 Oysters. 

I would recommend Kabuto to anyone who wants a unique sushi experience with high quality fish, interesting flavors, and playful presentation. Also wouldn't hurt if you have over $50/person!
author: Lily S.

description:
Easy to get a RSVP there, sat at the sushi bar with my brother.  We took the advice from my friend and let the waitress pick whatever she wanted.  Everything was fresh from the live uni, tasmanian salmon and toro.  A little overpriced but good value overall.

Definitely would come back.
author: D A.

description:
Whenever I visit a Japanese restaurant, it's hard to not keep an eye on what I was eating and another on Kabuto due to an abundance of raving reviews about their culinary supremacy. The mystique has been seductively elusive to my wondering eyes and unabashed appetite for the most exquisite nigiri. Finally, I was able to stop by on New Year's eve and was pleasantly surprised to find immediate seating at the sushi bar. This was both a challenge and an opportunity to get up close and personal with what was supposed to be the best fish in the City, at least according to the reviews I've read. It was the perfect evening as the wind was calm in the Richmond District and the small interior was glowing with good lighting, great looking couples, and a clean, parsimonious décor. It was easy for me to keep my eyes on the prize as their sashimi display was the most colorful and sensitizing items in the house. There were three sushi chefs on duty while the kitchen appeared to be equally busy with servers rushing in and out to make sure the dishes were being delivered promptly to each table. My anticipation was running wild like never before.

I thought miso and the fresh green salad was quite a nice opener. Somehow the appetizer, lamb apple nigiri ($7) was served last, and came with redundant fresh greens with four dry pulpy pieces of lamb served with grilled apple, sushi rice, and cherry balsamic sauce. The concept was outstanding as the sweet tangy sauce and the apple nicely complemented the lamb, but the execution was off given the poor texture. With the size of the nigiri being so small, I spent more time enjoying the salad than the two nigiri bummers. It was definitely not worth the hype.

The Nigiri Ichinin-Mae ($19) arrived with tuna, albacore, shrimp, mackerel, halibut, salmon, hokkigai, smelt roe and tekka maki. I thought the taste was above average good with mackerel, hokkigai, and smelt roe really stood out. The fish was not mind-blowing super fresh like the ones at Sasabune and value-wise the fish selection was not as good as Ariake which included uni and ikura in a dish called "Love", which was only a dollar more.

My Scott handroll ($6) was a major highlight of the night with huge handroll with robust spicy tuna, smelt roe, and a quail egg yolk beautifully placed at the top. The taste was very delicious and memorable with good texture. This is one of the better spicy tuna I've had. Good portion and very nicely done.

They could easily have received a higher rating since this is one of the few sushi places that have an impressive list of desserts. However, the server brought the bill just right when I was getting ready for dessert, prompting an abrupt ending to the meal. Overall the server and the sushi chef were helpful, responsive, but distanced. The ending was not ideal and unsettling as I walked away with mixed feelings about the overall experience. Here's how they are rated:

1.) Quality and freshness: 4 stars
2.) Creativity and presentation: 5 stars 
3.) Quantity and substance: 3.5 stars
4.) Accessibility and affordability: 3 stars
5.) Service and ambiance: 3.5 stars

Rounding it up to a weak 4 stars rating with unanswered skepticism. This place might be over-hyped and somehow the experience led me to want to give Ariake another try.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Any ol' day: Kabuto.
Place to bring out-of-towner sushi fanatics: Kabuto. 
Birthday: Kabuto. 
Anniversary: Kabuto.
Last meal on earth: The foie gras sushi from Kabuto.

Foie gras sushi with the raspberry sauce is so, so YUM! The best thing I've ever had. I always order 4 pieces ($9 for 2 pieces): 3 for me, only 1 for the fiance. When it comes out warm topped with raspberry and chive drizzled with balsamic raspberry sauce, one word says it all: orgasmic. My eyes will roll back and I will make a moaning sound. If you're the person sitting at the table next me: I'm sorry you had to hear that. 

I usually come about once a month and the waitress recognizes me and knows that I will order multiple orders of my favorites. My fiance's favorite is toro tartar. Absolutely amazing as well. The crunchy leaflet of seaweed between the rice and toro tartar tops it off. 

Other favorites: 
- Ceviche ($5, 2 pieces): I love it because it's a soft hamachi fish topped with lime juice and sea salt. No sauce needed! It has enough flavor all by itself. Because I like sour flavors such as lime, lemon, and vinegar, I really love the flavor of this sushi.
- Baby Main Lobster ($12, 2 pieces): they use a torch to heat it up and make the "spicy" sauce, which is not spicy at all, SOOOO yummy! If you end up liking the sauce and you want more than just two pieces of lobster, you can opt for the "Fire Salmon Roll," (~$10) which is shrimp tempura rolled topped with salmon, torched with the yummy sauce and topped with small bits of jalapeno and tobiko.
- For fresh fish: uni, bonito, and ankimo are all really good! 
- Also, my oyster-loving friend LOVES their 1849 oysters which is topped with uni, tobiko, ikura, and gold flakes. If you love oysters, try this.

For dessert, their green-tea creme brulee was a favorite during my creme brulee obsession days.

Come for the special nigiri sushi and fresh fish. I've tried many other items on the menu and they're good but I come for the special sushi. Some may think the combinations sound weird and some may think, "this is NOT real sushi" but I don't care at this point. As long as it continues to create a party in my mouth! BUT there's a warning: this place may create a hole in your back pocket cause it's $$$. We usually order just from the special sushi menu and some fresh fish, no sake, and it's about $40-50 per person. 

FYI's:
- This is a cute, but casual place for dates. They always have a fresh flower in their vases. 
- Parking may suck, though. It IS in the Richmond district. 
- Come after 6:30pm on Friday or Saturday and you may have to wait for a seat. 
- Closed on Mondays.
- Take-out for special sushi not allowed because it has to be fresh when consumed.
author: Tina T.

description:
The sushi is exceptionally well-presented in this sushi restaurant. They make the sushi in an non-traditional way. Great presentation style with the French food and Japanese food .

Pros:

1: Great sushi quality

2: Sushi are well presented, great looking with the technique of combination of western food and Japanese food

3: Well prepared, overall high quality

Cons:

1: Environment is decent but nothing fancy, which I would think they should rent another bigger spot with better interior decoration to match its food design

2: Pricy, a major concern, I would not really go back if I am craving for sushi or just want a Japanese meal, other Japanese sushi stores serve with the same quality of sushi for lower price with more quantity

3: We want the menu to be more readable, at least with some pictures on the side. Or else I would just recommend the customers to order by pointing the pictures on yelp.

4: The wait time between they bring you different plates.


Overall I would still recommend this great place for a romantic date or occasional friends gathering, especially if you want to try Japanese sushi in a different way.

For satisfying your Japanese sushi craving, go for another restaurant.
author: Jay J.

description: straying from sushi norm...mix of fusion, flavors and creativity...gulp of large sapporo...wiping hands with hot towel and ready to begin...mix of sushi orders...amaebi fresh and heads fried to crispy perfection...toro little dry and not melting...slivers of fish flavored sweet and some tangy...table overwhelmed by each sushi pair served on individual large plating...pair of dried cranberries on each sushi plate...feeling a bit rushed to swallow to make room for more plates...a sushi break and sampling udon from a non-sushi eater...decent large pot of noodles...chicken teriyaki overcooked dry...washing down with beer...roughly $fifty per person for a forgettable sushi dinner...
author: Hen A.

description:
FOIE GRAS!!!! Who can resist that artery clogging goodness?!?!?! Not me...

Last Tuesday was my most recent visit, and my gf and I ordered the following:

*Foie Gras Sushi (MUST ORDER): The BEST tasting bite EVER! The foie gras is perfectly seared and served Nigiri style. As soon as you sink your teeth into the foie gras, it melts into your mouth like butter. MmMmm, the accompanying balsamic raspberry sauce adds a great tanginess to the foie gras to balance out the richness. 

*Sunrise (MUST ORDER): Two thick slices of Sake wrapped around a quail egg. The sake itself is already buttery, but the quail egg adds an additional layer of creamy goodness. *drool*

*1849 Oysters (MUST ORDER): 2 Oysters on a half shell topped w/ quail egg, uni, salmon roe, ponzu sauce, and gold paper. Oh My!!!! All the ingredients were super FRESH. It's one of those things that you have to try for yourself because it's too hard to put into words how MIND BLOWING it is. Rich, creamy, buttery, salty, sweet, tangy...

*Hamachi Pear Nigiri: A generous slice of hamachi (very fresh) topped with sliced pear and a fruity mustard sauce. Very interesting flavor combos, but it all works in harmony giving you a tangy, savory, and sweet flavor.

*Ceviche: Chopped halibut and salsa on top of fried seaweed. The halibut was fresh and the fried seaweed was very crispy and held up well to the ceviche. The saltiness from the seaweed gave the halibut enough flavor that there was no need for any soy sauce. 

*Dragon Roll: This was more of a filler than anything. There was nothing special about it. Do note that Kabuto's rolls are half the size of other restaurant's rolls although they charge the price of a whole roll. So, I would veer away from ordering rolls here. 

*Spicy Hamachi: Another filler...the spiciness came from the roll topped with Sriracha. I would have rather had it blended into the fish. 

*Tempura Ice Cream: Crispy, warm, rich, sweet but not too sweet; everything that a dessert should be. The vanilla ice cream was tempura battered and came out warm. The tempura was light and crispy, but the ice cream was still very hard. Despite this, it was a great ending to a good meal.

*Anmitsu: Gelatin with fruit cocktail, green tea ice cream and sweet red bean paste. I could have passed on this. There were too many things going on and the ingredients didn't work well together. The fruit cocktail syrup + green tea ice cream + red bean paste made for sugar overload.

*Ginjo-shu sake: Filtered and slightly sweet. After 5 shots = BUZZED!

SERVICE: The only reason why Kabuto is not deserving of 5 stars is their service. The times I've been there, the waitresses were not attentive and you always have to wave your arms in their air to get their attention. Despite that it's always packed, the food does come in decent timing; about 15 minutes for the first dish, and then another 5 min for accompanying orders.

AMBIANCE/DÉCOR: Simple; wooden table and chairs. It's a SMALL restaurant; with max seating at around 30. So, if you're coming on the weekends, make sure to make reservations; otherwise, expect a wait. 

Overall, Kabuto is a great place to try creative and flavorful sushi combinations. Stick with the menu specials and the special sushi and AVOID their rolls b/c they're blah and not worth the price. Despite their inattentive service, I expect to come here time and time again b/c their sushi is that good!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Nice selection of fish.  Make sure to call first to check if they are open.  I've tried to just drop in on a few occasions and found that they were closed.

This place is ridiculously expensive, but worth the splurge if you're in the Richmond District.  I stop in a few times a year mainly for the ono.  The amberjack was out of this world last time I had it.  The jalepeno hamachi is one of my faves.  Oh and save room for dessert:  I had the mango mochi and it was delish.

Be forewarned that noise level can be really high, since the space is so small.  This is not a first date place...the ambiance quite frankly sucks.  When the environment matters, go to Sushi Groove or Blowfish.  When you want to try a variety of fish not usually found on most sushi menus, then stop in here.
author: Sam S.

description: Japanese restaurant with a fancier menu. Had the crab salad, seafood salad, sashimi, California roll, spicy tuna, spicy California, shrimp tempura roll, and soft-shelled crab roll. Nice restaurant.
author: Denise C.

description:
VERY VERY SOLID 4 STARS (maybe even a bit more)

Note:  The seafood here are sooo fresh.  They keep it at a perfect temperature, not too cold, so it brings out the sweetness of the seafood even more.  Brilliant.
At the end of the night, you really get what you pay for here...if not more.  Definitely a place I will go back.


NOTABLE DISHES / MUST HAVE:

-- HAMACHI NIGIRI with slice of pear and fresh mustard on top --
you will definitely be surprised how well the flavors work together.  I'm usually not a fan of mustard...but you i would not have this dish any other way

-- TORO --
Have it any way you want.  It's fantastic.  This is the only place in the bay that I am satisfied with their toro.

-- LIVE SCALLOPS --
Absolutely amazing.  Perfect temperature.  You can't go wrong with this dish

-- 1849 OYSTER --
All those raw oyster fans, this is the dish to get.  Oysters, with uni, scallions, ponzu sauce, and ikura.  Amazing dish.

-- ANKIMO NIGIRI --     *MUST HAVE**MUST HAVE*
If you are down for some monkfish liver, this is the best place to get it. I don't know how they do it, but it really melts in your mouth.  Hands down the most memorable dish of the night.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Creative sushi rolls that are full of flavor and deliciousness.  I would highly recommend giving this place a try if you're adventurous enough to try combinations of different ingredients in your roll. 

Out of the 11 rolls/items we tried, there wasn't a single thing that we did not like.  Though it's a little pricier  than your typical sushi joints, I absolutely think it's worth the splurge.

For pictures with more details, check out my blog post.

http://winendinesarahstyle.blogspot.com/2012/09/kabuto-restaurant.html
author: Sarah F.

description: Kabuto is a hidden treasure. Great service. Great fish. Great no traditional fancy sushi and cooked items (like eel? Like fried food? Get the Katsunagi).
author: Johannes C.

description: This restaurant increased my credit card charge after I signed to increase the tip amount to 22%.  I just discovered it from my statement.  I am not sure if this is legal but it's dishonest to me.
author: Cherry L.

description:
Kiji near my house used to be my favorite restaurant, but now I'm all about Kabuto. Oh Kabuto. I remember reading about it years ago in Zagat, but being all the way out in the Richmond I had not yet eaten there. 

Then my friend who lives nearby suggested we go there for dinner. He said it was usually crowded. Here's the thing, though, it was blistering cold that day and while that might not have stopped a New Yorker it kept a San Franciscan in doors. This worked out to my advantage. 

With a sushi bar and some plain tables and chairs lined up against the wall, Kabuto is not one of those hyper spa relax my dear but I'll fuck you in the ass when the bill comes kind of places. It's unpretentious and cozy. (Not to say that you won't feel fucked in the ass when the bill comes, but at least you can see the fresh fish from the bar easily. You know what you're paying for. They're not tricking you.) And when I mean cozy, I think that this is one of it's best qualities, on top of how good the food is. Having recently gone on a sushi kick which I don't think will be ending anytime soon, I found this place to be the most cozy and romantic. No metal walls with heinous black berry rings pulsating around the room, and the chitter chatter of people who had too much sake. You'd take your parents here. And your date. 

We sat at the bar, and started out with a sashimi plate that most definitely had my favorite, hamachi. Incredible, buttery, life affirming, fresh. We kept ordering more. Live scallop, the lobster roll, a salmon skin roll. It was fresh and full of flavor. I didn't want to de-virginize it with my heavy soy wasabi mixture. It was good plain. Everything was delicious, but if I had had it my way, I would have eaten sashimi throughout the night. Kabuto's cuts are very superior to many other places I've been, and you just can't go wrong with tasting the real thing unaltered by rice and all that fancy jazz.

Speaking of fancy jazz though, there is one other thing I want to order next time I'm there. The foie gras. So though I am a sashimi girl, Kabuto has all these crazy sushi dishes in ADDITION to a classic menu. I would like to try some of these dishes next time, including the foie gras of course. There is also a Hamachi Pear roll on the menu now which is Hamachi with sliced pear covered with fruity mustard sauce.  Um, yum! Lord do I look forward to my next visit.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
Oh My Gosh ... !  This is my favorite place for sushi in San Francisco.  There are so many sub-par sushi places in this town who don't even try to give you something great, this is not one of them.   I have been here many times and have never had a bad experience, I have a favorite waitress there who has never done me wrong when I ask for her recommendation.  She also tells you how the item should be eaten (with or without soy sauce, etc ... ) which is very helpful.  The food and fish is always very fresh, and is visually as pleasing as it is to eat.  My two favorite non-sushi/sashimi/roll items there are the Chawan Mushi and the Hamachi Kama, also like the miso soup with Manila clams as a starter to warm my belly.
