It gets busy quickly and is small so I always try to go early to avoid the crowds and wait. It is also not the cheapest  sushi (see my reference to sub par places above) but I feel it is priced appropriately for the quality.  I only wish it was in my neighborhood so I would go more often!
author: Arthur M.

description:
For a few years, the gf has been saying she wants to eat here when we pass by it on Geary.  She mentioned that it was a pricey place and I'm like really?  From the outside it looks like another diner on Geary st and even when you go inside you may be thinking is this place going to be any good.  When we walked in there was no one besides two sushi chefs (both Japanese) and a waitress.  We sat down and the waitress came back quickly and said are you ready to order.  We had to ask her to come back a couple of times because we weren't sure what to get.  We ordered an assortment of food from something that you don't usually get such as foie gras sushi, toro tartare, live scallop, butterfish to something more ordinary such as sake chazuke (salmon, rice with green tea), omakase sushi set and age dashi tofu.

Let's start off with the negatives.  Age dashi tofu, salmon rice with green tea and the 7 piece nigiri omakase were a disappointment.  Tofu was bland, not enough sauce and portion was small.  Salmon rice, over priced.  Nigiri omakase set; it's as if the sushi chef thought this was not good enough dish for him to present it nicely that he just sliced the fish nonchalantly and put it over the rice.  That was a combined $30 that I could have had another foie or toro tartare.

Now onto the good stuff.  Foie gras sushi.  $5 a piece, not a bad price considering the amount of work they put into it.  Rice, foie, sauce and a piece of raspberry to balance out the flavor.; excellent.  Butterfish and hamachi belly were both very fatty and delicious.  The toro tartare at $2.50 per piece is a good deal.  Very well put together, it is rice at the bottom with a slice of nori and on top of that toro tartare and a piece of shiso.  There was also the oyster shots that had oyster, uni, ikura, caviar, golf flake all in an oyster shell eaten as an oyster shot.  

Service was cold in the beginning but once we ordered food and ordered an abundant of food, the waitress quickly became friendly.  The tea for whatever reason wasn't warm enough but other than that it was a good experience.

Why am I giving this four stars and not 3.5 or 3?  Kabuto isn't a place you go in for teriyaki beef or tekka maki.  It's a place where you try various different fishes and nigiris where you can't get at your regular Japanese restaurant.  Yes it is pricier and yes their hot food and regular lunch special isn't that great but that's not what they're about.  They excel in the spots where you can't find in other restaurants and that is why I am giving it four stars and why I'll be coming back.
author: Pierre L.

description: This place is disgusting! The fish is not fresh and has no taste. The cut is very thick and uneven--sloppy. The rice is very hard. I had to force myself to finish everything on the table and almost barfed!
author: Cindy C.

description: Halfway through my dinner and I have the sudden urge to write this review...this is by far the best sushi in the bay!!!
author: David A.

description:
This place is distinguished mostly by the unusual and interesting nigiri sushi they make.  It was about a week ago and we tried the 16-20 Kiss, Pear Hamachi, and Ceviche rolls.  Had never had any sushi like these before. They've really mastered the art of presentation and all of these were very tasty.  The regular spicy tuna roll was pretty good too.

The novelty comes at a price so I wouldn't recommend kabuto as a place to fill up on sushi but if you want to try unique flavor combinations in sushi form this is the place for you!
author: Alan S.

description:
It was OKAY, but nothing that great for the price tag. We opted for a variety of different things, and the bill came out to $100 for two!!! (before tax & tip).  Oy, expensive sushi much?

1) 2 Oysters - average
2) Fire salmon sushi - average
3) Seared Foie Gras Nigiri - different, but nothing special. Average
4) Ahi Tuna Nigiri - again, average
5) Jalapeno Hamachi - very good! I recommend this dish.  Very fresh Hamachi.
6) chicken kabob - alright.  I needed to order the kabobs & a bowl of rice to fill up for the night. 

Overall, it's a bit different from the typical Japanese Sushi.  But pretty pricey for the meager portions.
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
It was not too bad, spent 152.30 for two.
However, I wouldn't recommend the 1849 Oysters(2) for 28 bucks. Ouch! I know it has gold leaf in it but tbh dont made the taste better. 

Though, I will recommended the Hamachi Tartar, and don't try the jalapeno Hamachi for 17 bucks not worth it. Do try the akimo, very tasty. Hamachi Pear is good. (I love hamachi haha).

Besides the two items, oyster and jalapeno hamachi, everything else is well worth the price. 

I do want to comment that the their food presentation is very inviting and pretty. It is a good place to dine in except there is a long wait, so do call and reserve a table. Service is decent, not great, u often have to hold ur own plates to make room when dishes arrived lol. Maybe we ordered too much too ahha. anyways, I will recommended to try the place out.
author: Fish Y.

description:
Soft shell crab : 2/5
Eggplant : 3/5
Hamachi pear thing : 5:5
Sea bass: 5/5
Foi gra toro: 5/5
Saba :5/5
1849 oyster: 5/5
Scallop: 5/5
Spoon of soupish thing: 3/5 tasted like lobster bisque
Monkfish liver: 3/5 meh
Clams on rice : 3/5 I wouldn't order again just try!

$54/person? not bad
author: Cindy L.

description:
When I want sushi for a special occasion, I come to Kabuto.  Fresh, savory sushi made with a twist.  They keep their sushi interesting by serving it with unconventional ingredients, such as fruit, cheese and chocolate. Wait a minute, Is that even JAPANESE? Their selection of nigiri is larger than your typical sushi establishment.  And their non-sushi items are great also.  It is a bit pricey and they attract large crowds, so come early! 

Bring your date and she won't be disappointed. =)
author: Leeseuh K.

description:
I love Kabuto, it is my favorite spot for sushi in the entire city. While I'm normally a traditionalist about sushi (and usually judge a place, not in a good way, if they serve crazy rolls), my favorites are off their Special Sushi menu. The Crunchy Sushi is probably my favorite, followed closely by Ceviche and Toro Tartar. 

It's not accurate to call it a hole in the wall, but it is a very small restaurant that is decorated very simply. This just makes it seem more authentically Japanese to me. It's not glamorous, just delicious. Perfect for 2-4 people to have a somewhat quick but very enjoyable meal. As far as service, it's totally fine and the servers do a good job, but it's the kind of place where the food shines more than anything. If you have reservations (which are actually quite easy to get), you should probably give yourself extra time to find parking.
author: Amy K.

description: This is the best Japanese Restaurant in SF.  Be prepared to be blown away!  Everything has a very unique taste, that is very balanced. Orders are usually 2 pieces, that way you can pick and choose between the foods you like. Better for small groups of 2-4. I wouldn't recommend large parties. My mouth still waters when i think about the sweet tartness of the raspberry complementing the buttery richness of the fois gras served over a raspberry reduction.
author: Edward N.

description:
Kabuto is hands down my favorite SF sushi spot.   I have been here a few times now and I'm writing this as I'm calling to makes reservations for my next visit. 

Ever time I've have been here I've gotten the prefix and ever time I'm blown away.  I won't go into the food  as that has been done to death on there already but just know that its amazing. 

I really want to give Kabuto 5 stars but I have to hold back just a little.  There is always a toss away course on the prefix, usually the tempura.  And for the price I'm always left a little wanting on the services, its not bad its just not good. 

Go! get the prefix you will love it!
author: Ryan S.

description: Best sushi in SF the 1849 oysters are the bomb also the toro with caviar and uni.  This place is a must go if you are a sushi lover
author: Will L.

description:
I never yelp....but this was the BEST SUSHI I have eaten in SF. I have eaten in over 15 different sushi restaurants in the city and this was the best. I mean you can't beat Okina on Arguello and Carbillo for the price, but if you want to treat yourself come here.

I ordered:
Spicy Scallop roll
Blue Fin Tuna Nigiri
Hamachi (Yellow Tail) Nigiri
Albacore Nigiri

What I got:

HUGE pieces of fresh, perfectly cut fish. Only the best parts of the fish. I can't say enough about this place. The only downfall to this place will be the hit to your wallet by eating here 5x a week!

Enjoy
author: Neal R.

description:
Great fish selection.  Good service.  Prices were expected for a fresh variety of fish.  
I was a little disappointed w/ the presentation - 1 star knocked off.  I had a random piece of tobiko on a piece of sushi, the seaweed wasn't cut straight or wrapped tightly.  Food was fresh but definitely doesn't top my fave.
author: Meredith K.

description:
In a city where sushi joints turn up just about each city block like a Starbucks, its hard to pick out which ones to go to.   Sure there are the a variety of sushi places with additional specialties, take for instance, Kitaro.  Kitaro doesn't thrive off of creative sushi rolls or glorious fresh fish, it's more known for the bento boxes and chicken teriyaki.  

And for true fresh sashimi and perhaps one with a thrill for exploring different kinds of fishes, theres Zushi Puzzle.  And if you like your down to earth salmon and hamachi, trust in the hard to enter, Tekka.  

But where creative meats freshness and where different kinds of flavors meld in ways you probably wouldn't imagine, there's Kabuto.  Almost similar in the grade of Sushi Ran (although Sushi Ran, I must admit has the exotic fish like Zushi Puzzle, yet finds itself developing new flavors in the curing process to bring out natural flavors over others), Kabuto delivers just the tiny thrill of new flavors with a few of your recognizable ingredients.

Before selecting the what to order, the three of us acted like ADD children in a toy shop not being able to focus on a selective few items, but going all over the place.  Luckily, some of our choices overlapped and found itself sitting smiling at us on the Omakase.  Thus, the easy choice was right there.  And to accompany the fine meal, we had a dry chalo sake, which was a bit dry but perfectly sweetened to go with the sushi pieces that came.  

Dinner was delicious.  Although a little bit on the pricey end, it was fairly justified in the satisfaction of the meal and taking in some of the unique selections and flavors of the sushi.  We had the following:

-Tempura - average, probably not the smartest thing to get here as its just like the ones anywhere else
-Tasmania salmon - A personal favorite, it definitely didn't dissapoint
-Foie gras Sushi - In the last moments of this dying breed, I'd take it and enjoy every moment I could.
-Hamachi Pear - While simple, it was a merry mix of sweetness on the plump texture of the hamachi.
-1849 shot - The shot not nearly heard around the world, but definitely heard amongst SF resides in this pretty roe and quail egg mixture
-Waloo - another one of my newly found sashimi of chioce.  It's also known as butterfish.
-Hamachi Toro - when you have toro from that of a well flavored and tender fish as hamachi, need I say more?

Will I come back?  Perhaps...but not certain.
author: Vincent K.

description: Very good sushi. Fish was really fresh and a nice selection. Combinations were very creative. The service was good, they even explain what to eat with soy sauce or with just wasabi. The wasabi was hand made and really delicious. We tried six or seven of their nigiri specials and all were fantastic. Will definitely be back! This week
author: Rita L.

description:
4++ stars, maybe 5--we'll see on next visit. First time here was a treat, and I let those familiar order away: Asparagus roll; CeViChe, Crunchy Sushi, Fire Salmon Roll, Hamachi Jalapeno, Hamachi Pear, Scott Handroll, Shiro Maguro sashimi, Sunzauri (marbled yellowtail), Shishitou peppers (yum), Kai Miso soup.
These above items are time-tested by a local who eats here 3 times a week for years. Get 'em and you'll be in heaven. Cheers!
author: Brian J.

description: Love this sushi place. It's hands down the best in the Richmond area. The wait is really long and the service is terrible but I come back because the fish is so effing delicious.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
If your goal is to eat good sushi, come here!  I went here for lunch and ordered the following nigiri:

yellowtail, salmon, big eye tuna, yellow fin tuna, hamachi belly, king mackerel, fluke and wahoo.  I wanted to order some others like pencil fish and sea shad, but they didn't have it as it's out of season.  

The fish was very fresh which is the most important thing to me when I eat sushi.  It was the freshest I've had in a long time, and luckily, the cuts were slightly bigger than average.  Next really important thing to me is the sushi rice which was also wonderful.  They have some unique fish on the menu, much more unique than most sushi bars where I usually just see the same things (salmon, tuna, yellowtail etc).  

There were 3 sushi chefs and one waitress.  I'm surprised they had more than 2 chefs considering how tiny the place is.  You can hear everyone's conversation very clearly so I don't think this is an ideal date spot.  My only gripe about this place was the service.  All the employees are Japanese including the waitress.  Unfortunately, their English is understandably limited so my waitress came off as terse and cold.  I can't be too harsh on her for that though.  

If I'm back in town and just want some good, fresh sushi, this would be one of my first considerations :)
author: Steve l.

description: THE best sushi in town! I am absolutely addicted to Kabuto and must have it at least once a week - it has actually become a household rule! The fish in incredible and they are so creative with their creations. Every piece is butter and clean taste, and the service is excellent. This is my favorite place and I bring everyone here, and so far every person has been beyond impressed. I am a major sushi lover and need plenty of a good thing without being financially ruined. Kabuto is my dream come true!
author: Yuan N.

description:
This is the best sushi restaurant I've found in San Francisco.

Very fresh fish and great service.  Make a reservation or get there early ... the place fills up fast.

Hamachi Jalapeno, 1849 oysters, nasu dengaku, ono grape, and the saba are my favorites.  Oh, the Scott handroll is good too!
author: T T.

description:
My taste buds are still spinning from dining here over the weekend!  I came with a few friends and we got: 

*salmon dumplings - deep fried wonton wrappers w/ a salmon mixture stuffed inside...meh
*seaweed salad - they use the wider, darker seaweed instead of the thinner, crunchier, greener seaweed you're probably used to...nothing special
*sun rise - salmon wrapped around sushi rice, topped with raw quail egg and tobiko - delicious but wish it were easier to eat in 1 bite
*anikmo nigiri - AMAZING w/ ponzu and shaved green onion
*toro foie gras - I wish there were some rice to balance the fattiness, but still melt-in-your-mouth delicious
*1849 oysters - MIND-BLOWINGLY DELICIOUS!  Oyster, uni, quail egg, tobiko, salmon roe AND gold flakes?  This is the stuff dreams are made of!

It was pretty empty during the Saturday lunch period.  Not sure why it isn't packed as they serve creative, fresh sushi at great prices!  Would definitely come back =)
author: Jen Y.

description: I am never disappointed when I eat here. The selection of sashimi and sushi is amazing. Fresh fish and quick service. The staff are all very kind and tentative. We always order off of the special menu and they serve it letting you know whether you should eat it as is or provide dipping sauce. If you are not adventurous I would not recommend this place for you. Their dishes are very specific!
author: Jinnie L.

description:
When ever I'm in SF I come to Kabuto. Its very special. As many others have noted , its quite small; decor is minimal; Itamae a bit frosty; menus a bit worn out. But ... sushi and sashimi are 1st rank, and the fusion menu is unique.

Favorites from the "special menu": hamachi/pear, a unique combination of textures; ono grape, out of this world mix of grape fruit and wahoo; katsunagi, you will never find a combo like this anywhere else, of unagi/avo/shiso that's fried; any of the Tartar sushi are worth exploring for the unique presentation; scott hand roll is pure indulgence; like wise oysters 49.

Don't limit your self to the special menu. I very much enjoyed abalone, and standards from the regular menu such as aji, saba, toro, tai, uni and daily special fish etc are of very high quality and beautifully presented. Also, sake variety is good, and well priced.

If you go this route the $$ can add up, but this quality will be expensive any where in the world. If you eat carefully and avoid budget busters like toro, you can still eat very well and escape with an intact wallet.
author: Mark M.

description:
Hands down the best sushi in the Bay Area . Seriously this could be my favorite place to eat in America . 

It's small, and slightly expensive , but what you get is the highest quality sushi you can find. Don't let the shabby exterior fool you. These guys produce legendary food .
author: Will O.

description:
If you're not in a hurry, this place will serve you FAN-TAS-TIC sushi!  And I mean fish that is delicious, carefully prepared, and combined with all varieties of creative roll combinations.  

I loved their: 
Inari (2 huge pieces)
Hamachi Negi Roll
Spicy Hamachi Roll 
Dragon Roll

I liked: 
Sonoma Duck (2 pcs)
16-20 Kiss (2pcs)
Tazuna Roll 
Tamago (2 pcs)

They have two menus - one "special sushi" and one "dinner menu".  While the special sushi was imaginative and different, I enjoyed their take on traditional rolls the most.  For example, their tamago is less sweet and has more texture than I'm used to.  And it works.  

The service is slow, and the restaurant probably doesn't seat more than 40 (this includes the bar), but it's well worth your patience.  

I suggest checking out their menu online before going there, to get your order in faster as the menu can be a bit overwhelming the first time around.  

I just love Kabuto.  

P.S. "kabuto" is a samurai helmet!
author: Cora L.

description: I like to go to Kabuto sometimes, though it is not in my neighborhood.  The reason?  Excellent nigiri including maguro, shiro maguro, tasmanian salmon, ikura, and uni.  Try the special Japanese uni, which is a real treat.  Friendly staff and good service.
author: Adam T.

description: This place has super fresh fish and big pieces! I came here with my sisters to celebrate our birthdays! It was a great experience. We had uni shooters which my sister enjoyed and said was good. It was my first experience so I was kind of shocked by the taste. We had a the chef's selection of fish. It was super enjoyable. They also gave us a complimentary dessert with a candle to celebrate our birthdays! It was a really great dining experience. It gets crowded and reservations are highly recommended.
author: Annie P.

description:
Really interesting menu here.  Not your run-of-the-mill rolls.  I really liked the foie gras and ceviche a lot.  Expensive, but unique and flavorful.  Definitely worth trying at least once.

I was a little disappointed in the size of the shiro maguro and sake nigiri, and there was too much wasabi gluing the fish to the rice, but the fish was fresh.  The negi hamachi and negi shiro maguro rolls were okay; size was as expected; didn't expect to taste wasabi in the rolls though (dislike).  I don't use wasabi at all when I eat sushi because the flavor is distasteful to me.  I don't like using soy sauce with sushi either, not because the flavor is distasteful; com'on, I'm Asian, so I love soy sauce!  I just want to be able to taste the subtleties of the fish when I eat sushi, and soy sauce/wasabi crush those subtleties.

Dessert was okay.  I had the anmitsu, and there were still chunks of ice in the green tea ice cream.  The sweet red bean paste was yummy, but the little fruit bits were drowning in the thin liquid at the bottom - some type of sauce that was unnecessary and abundant.

I was one of 3 parties in the restaurant, so there were about 4 waitresses I could call on at any time.  They were all friendly and attentive.  The sushi chefs kept to themselves and weren't talkative, so there was no ordering from them when you sit at the bar, but they did say hello and goodbye to everyone.

For the amount of money I ended up spending here, I expected better.
author: Barbara T.

description: Absolutely loved this place! For a small hidden place, the fish was amazingly fresh and the choices from special sushi menu - a total hit with all of us! Order oysters from the bar menu - amazing dish.
author: Taty S.

description: This must be one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Kabuto is located a good drive away from the downtown, nevertheless it tends to be busy for dinner. Still, I never had to wait too long to be seated (this time we made a reservation through Yelp SeatMe, just in case). Their menu changes regularly and each time there are new interesting items. Alas, some interesting items also go away. This time we went for the Omakase for two. It included some familiar treats (hamachi jalapeno - a must try) and some new discoveries (grilled spicy mussel - interesting but messy). Toro caviar truffle with sushi was the high point of the flight, competing with the foie gras in balsamic raspberry sauce. The attention paid to the presentation makes even the simplest items mouthwatering. The staff is very friendly and helpful. My only gripe is that the different courses were brought with too little time in between, however with a twelve-course tasting flight this is not surprising. I look froward to going back!
author: Vladimir P.

description:
This place is SOLID.. Such creative rolls, fish was soo fresh. Why am I just discovering Kabuto?

Foie gras nigiri was FANTASTIC! It was combined with a berry.. I loved it
The hamachi with pear and mustard was such an interesting combination. So unexpected, great!
ceviche was like a fresh fish taco, must order!
Toro tartar - fresh, delicious
Ono Nigiri - WOW, like butter

Thank you Yelp for the Yelp deal to this place, it allowed us to keep ordering more and more.. I'll definitely come back for MORE..
author: Monica S.

description: The most aesthetically pleasing sushi I have ever had. This review is long overdue. I dined here when they had the foie gras sushi which was phenomenal. I'm more of a sashimi, nigiri, kind of girl. Although I do love a good spicy  tuna roll. Everything is fresh, fresh, fresh. Service was great.
author: Sabrina M.

description: 3.5 - Went here on saturday for lunch with one of my friends. I think it might have been because we just got the sashimi lunch omakase and nothing from the special menu but wasn't super impressed. The omakase was nice though for $14. It comes with a salad and miso soup. You get 5 different types of sushi which is pretty good. We went at around 1 so the restaurant was pretty empty. Service was quick and they were very nice. The cuts were pretty decent size too. Very fresh tasting.
author: Tao Tao W.

description: Amazing sushi and very creative. I recommend making reservations because it is hard to get in without.
author: Vanessa B.

description:
This restaurant seem to always be busy, especially now that for some time they have been located at this smaller space instead of their old location across the street.

Anyway, I came late this past Saturday night to limit my wait time for a seat.  I came for the foie gras they had on the menu, which was served nigiri style.  It was tasty, albeit I can definitely taste the fat as well (not good for my cholesterol level for which I'm already on medication for).  I figured it could very well be my last taste of it before the California ban starting after the end of the month.

The sushi and sashimi here is also always reliable.  Overall very friendly staff.  They can get short occasionally but then I remind myself of how busy and hectic things are for those ladies.
author: H K.

description:
Love this place.  I started going here in 1986 when I was in grad school and lived out in the Avenues.  It was near my apartment, and I would go on Saturday nights, with the Sunday NYT crossword puzzle, and sit for a couple of hours, dawdling and watching what other folks were ordering.  Always awesome sushi, and I had moved here from Manhattan where the sushi isn't so shabby either. 

So I went back a bit ago to take a family friend there.  They had moved, but--wow!--the menu had gotten a lot more varied and, I guess, exotic. Very creative takes on sushi and sashimi without losing the essence of the main attraction: The fish.  

(The only reason I don't give it 5 stars is that, because I now live in Marin, my main go-to sushi place is Sushi Ran in Sausalito, which, to me, is the gold standard.)
author: David W.

description:
I'm usually not a big fan of fusion Sushi but I can never say NO to Kabuto. The flavor combination of their creative nigiris are just amazing! I've probably tried everything on their Special Menu and my favorites so far areTuna Tartar, Sonoma Duck, Foir Gras, and Crunchy... I mean, where else in San Francisco can you find a  nigiri topped with duck liver?! (and still taste good)... Their appetizers and side dishes are great too... my favorite is their 1849 Oysters... it's a fresh shot of oyster topped with uni, tobiko, caviar, and quail egg... can't get any better!!! I wouldn't come here for super fresh sashimi and traditional Japanese food, but their unique sushis are definitely worth a try... For dessert, I really liked their Green Tea Cream Brulee. The green tea flavor is very intense and rich. Every time I come here, I leave the place STUFFED (and broke)!!!

There's usually a line during peak hours, so reservation recommended!
author: tiannaaah J.

description:
Whenever I feel like nontraditional sushi, I go here. There's so many different kinds of sushi, but with a little kick to it. 
I could write a list of what I have tried and liked or disliked, but honestly....I've tried almost everything and every other review here has it down already. :)

ps. at least try the 1984 oyster
author: Cha C.

description: The fish is always fresh.  Sushi chef takes numerous creative liberties, most of which work out really well.  A bit expensive but it's not crazy.
author: Charles W.

description: The fish is good, fresh, they offer varieties I do not always see other places.  Props on the Walu! The place is so tiny tho and a little too much madness inside because of it's popularity, so take out!!
author: Chelsey G.

description:
After eating at Kabuto a few times, every other sushi place I go to just doesn't seem to cut it anymore.  Everything I have eaten here screams quality and freshness.  They serve traditional sushi as well as the chef's creations like hamachi pear and seared duck.

It's a small place with an intimate yet casual atmosphere- be at ease and get lost in conversation.  It's also fun to sit at the bar and watch the chefs work, "Jiro Dreams of Sushi" style.  This place will work equally well for dates, small groups, special occasions or just a night out whenever.
author: Chris T.

description:
I've heard rave reviews and was very excited to finally try Kabuto.  Boy was I disappointed.  We ordered the tasting menu because it looked like a good deal and had both the oyster and foie gras sushi.  Those were the only two good dishes.  The sashimi was not fresh at all.  

Service was good, but I would not drive the distance for mediocre sushi. The restaurant itself could use some updating as well.
author: K V.

description:
Oh dear, what did I just eat? 

That was the recurring theme of last Friday's dinner.  The nine of us decided that we're done with Prospect, after doing a supposed Happy Hour that stretched into three.  

The breakdown of the group was as follows:
1) Half of us have been starving since 6
2) The other half were slightly tipsy
3) Luckily one of us had the foresight and made the executive decision to call Kabuto for a 9.15PM reservation (SUCCESS - they were wiling to accommodate our big and rowdy party)

So we trawled across town on the long-ass stretch that is Geary, past gazillion traffic lights and 25 mph speed limit, and after what felt like an eternity, we arrived at the restaurant. 

As I was in between the first and second sub-group, I initially took an interest in trying to order.  But their extensive menu (http://www.kabutosushi.com/special_sushi.html) was almost too much for my dumbed-down brain.  So my usually control-freakish self decided to defer to one of my friends' judgment and eat basically whatever's put on the table. 

I hardly ever was that hungry such that I would pop something in my mouth and try to find out what it was after the fact, so thankfully everything was nothing short of amazing.  Pretty-looking and delicious tasting sushi came right out, one after another, with no noticeable wait in between (I guess being one of the last parties to be seated did help).  I barely noticed the hardworking server feverishly attempting to tell everybody to not eat certain sushi with soy sauce.

All the sushi pieces were gone as soon as they hit the table.  My favorite was the egg-celent fat slimy fresh oyster topped with uni and four kinds of eggs: ikura, tobiko, caviar and quail eggs.  Following close behind were the seared foie gras sushi with raspberry sauce and crunchy sushi (tempura halibut with curry sauce).

And since we always had room for dessert, we shared a couple of servings of green tea cheesecake and green tea crème brûlée, which hit the spot.  

The whole thing did come with a sticker shock (especially given how modest and assuming the place was) - the bill came out to be $65 per person.  All I can tell you, though, is that it was worth every penny.
author: Ange L.

description:
I am giving this place 5 stars only because it won't let me give them more, which I truly believe they deserve. This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco and my favorite sushi restaurant in all of America probably. 

It doesn't look like much from the outside but it is absolutely amazing. The crunchy sushi is my favorite, it is tempura halibut with the best curry sauce topping that I have ever had! Honestly though, you cannot go wrong with anything on the menu. It is a bit expensive but it is worth every penny. I promise that you will not be disappointed!
author: Emma G.

description:
I decided to bring my BF to Kabuto because I know how much he loves Japanese food.  I truly think it's the closest authentic sushi restaurant in the city. 

What makes this place so memorable is the creativity of each dish and its fun, extensive menu.

I had the CeViche that was gone within seconds, Hamachi Pear that was absolutely so fresh that I gobble within a jiffy as well, Hamachi Kama, can never go wrong with this dish, Valentine, a bit too sweet for my tooth but still enjoy every bit of it, and the Toro tuna that definitely fulled our stomachs.

This place definitely hits the spot, until we meet again.
author: Sophia S.

description:
soooo pretty and yummy. but it'd probably cost me $300 to get full. Tip: try everything on the sushi specials. 

the foie gras sushi....

o
m
g
.
author: kim w.

description:
I've dined often at Kabuto, but tonight I had what was -- quite possibly -- one of the most exquisitely simple and unfussy sushi meals I can recall.

Our party of four was rather disappointed that they had already sold out of the live scallops (we always get their "two-ways" scallops) and the ivory king salmon, but after a slow start of merely average Manilla clams and a slightly-smaller-than-usual 1849 oyster, we moved straight into the nigiri.

The escolar, one of my favorites, was first and should have been an obvious sign that this was going to be more than an average night of seafood. Bright, with just enough bite to the flesh, and a beautifully subtle taste like a fresh sea breeze: it was a stunning piece of fish. Our ikura and uni were also excellent, though the uni seemed a little bigger and had more depth than ones I've had in the past. One of our diners has a bigger appetite than the rest of us so he decided to tack on a fiery salmon roll and a dragon roll. I'm not usually one for rolls, but the quality of fish in these was so excellent and the sauces weren't what you normally expect when you think of typical sushi rolls. Rather than a gooey, overly sweet/salty drizzling that is better suited to patching tires than seasoning seafood, the sauces were light and complemented the rolls perfectly.

The $$$ price rating is pretty accurate, but Kabuto is a great place to just let loose and try a million different things. The size of their nigiri is just right (Goldilocks would very rightly agree that they're not too big, not too small), the rice is very well seasoned, and they know well enough to not slap an over-sized blob of wasabi between the two.

But the king of the night was the toro. I've had toro at Kabuto before and though many will tell you to get the tartare, all you really need is toro as nigiri or even sashimi if you like. The cut was perfect and -- moreso than any piece that I've ever had -- the fish was perfectly marbled. In the mouth it had a deceptively meaty bite before the intermingling layers of muscle and fat completely yielded to my tongue and spread all over my mouth. We made the mistake of ordering a few more pieces of nigiri afterwards. I say mistake only because if I had known better beforehand, I would have absolutely wanted that perfectly fatty piece of toro as my last bite of the meal.

Oh well. Guess that just means I'll have to go back again. What a shame.
author: Marcus L.

description: Great food and presentation, totally love the hamachi jalapeno and the spicy tuna tartar. Best Japanese  restaurant around.
author: Alvaro I.

description: Very deserving of a 5 star for the fish. Each time I have come, I have been amazed by the quality of the nigiri served. Especially considering there usually is no egregious wait time. They sell delicacies such as needle fish and live uni and scallop. The live scallop from here has been hands-down the best I've had in the bay. (Maybe it was a good day?) I will say that they have a lot of unique specialty dishes that really won't leave a true sushi snob impressed, such as the Hamachi pear. My boyfriend disliked the omakase for this reason.  A little too experimental for our taste. I would suggest ordering off the white board menu and sitting at the bar. The service and ambiance aren't to boast either.
author: Cassie C.

description:
It's pretty good here.  They have a few specialty items, but mostly, they have a HUGE menu.  Service is not the best but they get the job done.  I wouldn't hesitate to bring an out of towner here.

I'm a fan of their uni nigiri, foie gras sushi, and stingray dish.
author: Erika C.

description:
Been wanting to eat at this sushi restaurant for a while, and finally got a chance to give it a try on Saturday.

We came here 10 minutes before it close for lunch hours.  The restaurant is very small and petite.  I could have drove past this place hundreds of time and still don't see it.  

We sat at the sushi bar and start ordering what was recommended on yelp:

1. Ceviche - Good -  a splash of citrus taste with mustard, the fish melt in my mouth 

2. Sunrise - Normal - Salmon wrap around rice with topiko & quail egg on top.  The ingredients are very fresh, no doubt, but is a little too big for the mouth to consume. 

3. Foie Gra nigri - Good-  Perfectly cook foie gra with vinaigrette sauce 

4. tuna tar tar - Normal- had the same plate in many sushi places, and this place have done it like every one of them

5. Spicy tuna hand roll with quail egg on top - Normal - the quantity of tuna they put in the roll is a lot 

6. Saba Nigri - Normal - nothing to say, the fish is not too fresh.  I assumed not too many customer order this type of fish 

7. Salmon Nigri- Normal - not too fresh

8. 1987 or 89 Oyster - not sure what the exact name is: This plate is half shell oyster with salmon roe, yellow topiko, orange topiko, small slice of uni, and top it off with quail egg and gold leaf - (NORMAL) I have so much expectation on this plate, it was a bit disappointed.  The taste of all the other ingredients overpower the natural taste of the oyster, and each of those side ingredient doesn't match with each other... in another word, "too much"


We have couple other plates, and not too much surprises.

I don't think i will go back again, is a little too pricey for the the quality and taste.  Each person have to cough up around $60 for 5 orders.
author: Wasabi L.

description:
I've been spoiled by great sushi places in New York and Los Angeles. I know SF has an abundance of "good" sushi places, you can pretty much eat any where and be complacent. Kabuto takes sushi up a notch SF and is my go to place for sushi when I want to spend a little more than average (around 50 per person). 

I consider this place the missing link between traditional sushi and the "specialty" sushi. This is the place where I bring friends that are apprehensive about sushi/ novices to try the traditional things (uni, scallops, snapper, etc) and sandwich in between the nontraditional stuff (Hamachi pear, tuna tartare, foie gras). They generally come out sushi fans. 

The food is well prepared and high quality. The chef and staff always know what to recommend. I was introduced to akamutsu here and it has become my favorite fish.

Excellent staff, service, reasonable prices and very good fish!
author: Nam L.

description: Best Sushi place in SF. If you never eaten here before I strongly recommend getting the preset menu so you can try items you wouldn't normally order. All of it is amazing.
author: Eugene Z.

description:
My favorite place to get sushi.  
Seems like there are things on the menu that others on Yelp aren't too impressed with but everything that I order is always awesome.
The Ono Grape is a favorite.  I usually order off the specialty menu and love that they tell you which ones not to put in soy sauce.
author: John W.

description: This place is the bomb for some delicious sushi during lunch! Yes, I do admit that the dishes are pricey, but that does not mean that the quality is any worse than how much they are charged. I love ordering the Dragon Roll and Kabuto makes the rolls very crunchy and flavorful, along with their special sauce that they drizzle over the rolls! I also had the Nabe Udon, which was pretty good but you need to add the spice in order to make the soup taste a bit more flavorful. The soup base tastes a bit bland but I like how it is very refreshing and that I can adjust the flavor with the spice. Definitely will be coming back again!! :)
author: Nathan C.

description: Wonderfully awesome! We eat a lot of sushi and I was just telling the hubby today I was getting sick of it since it alway seems to be the same... well just hold on there this has to be my most favorite sushi spot I have ever eaten! Now let me tell you this place is a hole in a wall, but still nice but not super fancy! What I like is a place you are going for the food! Not just hype or status! Inventive and delicious! The waitress was a Jem she was sweet kind and welcoming! Thanks for great sushi!
author: Nick N Parker S.

description: Best sushi in San Francisco. Every piece is like a great work of art.
author: Susanna S.

description: This post is almost 6 months ago, wow.  We decided to go to Kabuto Sushi in the Richmond one February weekend, and lo and behold they had their Valentine's Day menu.  OK, it really was not that surprising, since it was the weekend after Valentine's Day, but still, big yay!  I had been here eons ago, and had always wanted to come back, but Lingon and I are so lazy that we rarely get out of our immediate neighbourhood to get some good grub.  The dishes were not served in the same order as the menu, so I reorganized the photos and made them match the menu, but I thought that was really weird.  I thought the food was very innovative and delish.  I would DEFINITELY go back, but if only it was not so far away...  I want to say this cost about $80ish/person before tax (just the food, we didn't get anything to drink except maybe tea), really good price for so much food.  So innovative, and the ingredients were pretty amazing!
author: Michelle L.

description:
one of the best sushi restaurants ive been to in SF! a pretty extensive menu with a lot of creative items

if you're someone that wants a good sushi roll place, then kabuto is not the place for you. it specializes mostly in nigiri style sushi specials

my favorites of the night (in no particular order)

toro tartare - im a huge fan of fish tartare and these little bites of chopped up toro with avocado and onion served over rice nd seaweed were an absolute treat. good amount of flavor too

toro with caviar - pricey ($10/each) but it was delicious! perfectly seared toro topped with what i believe is uni and caviar (my first time having caviar! i feel so fancyyy) if i had a money tree in my backyard, i would have ordered a whole plate full of these. 

foie gras sushi - it sounds a little weird - foie gras with raspberry and balsamic sauce, but it was a wonderful combination. nothing was overpowering. another item thats a little pricey ($10/pair) but definitely worth a try

hamachi pear sushi - another weird sounding combination but it was also really good. the pear adds a very light and refreshing sweet taste to the hamachi

sunrise roll - salmon is one of my favorite types of fish and this particular roll had three fatty pieces wrapped around rice and topped with quail egg. i peeled one piece to eat alone with soy and wasabi and the rest with one big bite with the egg. the egg adds such a wonderful creaminess to the around soft fish.

saba (mackerel) - i always had a bad impression of mackerel. it was always way too fishy to my liking but the saba here was delicious! very fresh and not fishy all

salmon kama - two huge tender pieces for just $5! one of the best sushi deals ive ever came across. just beware of a lot of bones

soo soo items

butterfish nigiri - it was okay, nothing special. a very bland fish. to me, butterfish is better seared/cooked

hamachi jalapeno - thinly sliced hamachi in a ponzu type sauce topped with jalapeno. i think the flower in the middle is chrysanthemum and i swear parts of the fish was infused with it

sonoma duck sushi - i read good reviews on it but it was nothing special. just tasted like a small piece of bbq meat ontop of rice

the two disappointing items were the tazuna roll and the fire salmon roll. lesson learned.

the past couple of times i drove by here, it always looked pack so i recommend making reservations because its a very small restaurant. our waitress was incredibly nice and sweet. all the special sushi comes in pairs but since we were a party of 3 she offered to charge us by individual pieces. sadly, i cant afford to eat here on a normal basis, but i highly recommend this place to everyone and will be back myself sometime in the future
author: Katherine C.

description:
When it comes to sushi restaurants, there are particular things i am particular about:

1. the grade of the sushi (which can be observed by sitting at the bar)
2. the size of the restaurant (i find smaller ones provide better hand produced, innovative food)
3. nothing against other races, but Japanese people still do sushi best for how its presented and served (or those with heavy Japanese ties)
4. the sake selection

With that said, Kabuto provides for all four...for me. Sushi grade is choice, the size is small so of course you're going to have to wait at times, the staff are pretty much all Japanese and speak it as well and the sake selection is fairly extensive (which can add the bill nonetheless). 

We got seated with a reservation and good thing we had the Yelp deal a while back. Ordered the Hamachi pear, Crunchy sushi (ordered it again after the first order), Sonoma pear, Scott handroll, Salmon skin handroll, Hot Apple, an order of Toro, Japanese scallops served 2 ways, Ama-ebi (with heads fried),  Miso albacore, ceviche and a bottle of daiginjo for like $70...what would've came out to about $200 ended up being $140. I'd say I was elated after all that. Will definitely come back again.
author: Nick V.

description: This is the best sushi I have ever had! Try the hamachi pear. It's amazing! The tuna sashimi sampler melts in your mouth. This place has ruined me for any other sushi restaurant.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
WOW talk about a new take on sushi. The rolls are super innovative and the flavors leaves a lasting impression. This is what I had:

Foie Gras Sushi -  Seared marinated goose liver served with balsamic raspberry sauce. It was okay the raspberry sauce complimented the foie gras tho.

Hamachi Pear  Yellowtail sushi topped with sliced pear and kabuto fruity mustard sauce. OMG this was the BEST!!!! I had like 3 of these lol...when the waitress brought it out she speciafically told us "don't dip it with soy sauce". I was going to do the exact opposite, but I'm glad I listened to her and didn't. The mustard sauce made the nigiri taste soooo delish. Who would've thought those ingredients blended so well together.

16-20 Kiss - Black Tiger Shrimp sushi with avocado wrapped with thin slice marinated radish served with kabuto chocolate sauce. This was good, but kind of small.

Sushi Mozarella was gross. 

Toro Tartar - Chopped Negi Toro and Avocado mixed with Kabuto Tartar sauce served with marinated Rakyo onion, deep fried shiso and seasoned seaweed. This is my second favorite!!! I had 2 or 3 of these as well! Just the right amount of tartar to keep you craving more.

I also had one sake and beer, sake maki roll, beef kushiyaki, and tempura. This place is good, but it's super expensive so my bill came out to $100! It was worth it though, first time for everything. It won't be the last time either. And word of advice this place gets filled up fast since it's kind of small so make reservations ahead of time cuz that's what I did!
author: Diane L.

description:
I've been coming here at least once a month for the past 3-4 years, so the least I could do is write a raving review for them.  It's my favorite go-to sushi place in the city, especially if I do a drive-by at Tekka only to see that it's packed.  Eric and the crew there are fantastic.  They do a great job making really fresh sushi taste even better with their creativity.  Now I'm usually a sushi traditionalist, but I really enjoy what Kabuto does with their fish.  It's kinda like choosing Sushi Gari over Sushi Yasuda in New York, sometimes you just want some flair.  I pretty much order the same dishes every time I come here:

- Hamachi Pear (great textures, delicate and mustard adds a nice kick)
- Ceviche (no soy sauce!  awesome flavors)
- Toro Tartare (love the fried shiso leaf)
- Baby lobster roll (the seared baby lobster is sweet and tender and the sauce is divine)
- Shrimp and Crab Tartare (sweet but satisfying, love the slice of ono grape)
- Scott Handroll (best. spicy. tuna. ever. with the quail egg mixed in, fugettaboutit)
- 1849 Oyster (all i have to say is party in your mouth)
- Ankimo appetizer (Japanese foie gras anyone?)
- Chawan mushi (nice warm egg custard soothes the soul)

On top of that I usually order some more nigiri like the tasmanian salmon, uni, toro, etc.  All of the nigiri and sashimi is very fresh and tasty.

I just made myself hungry.  DAMMIT!
author: Dave L.

description:
I tried Kabuto tonight for the first time and left feeling angry and extremely disappointed.  For my overpriced 50 dollar meal (no sake or drinks and still not full) i would have preferred a peanut butter and jelly sandwich and the tiniest bit of respect.

The food was average or slightly better but they are a complete rip off!

I had a couple different things including their smoked black cod which comes cooked on top of a bit of rice on a spoon.  The menu says "$5 (1 piece)".  I told the waitress that i wanted to try the black cod.  Amongst the other things in front of me i didn't realize that when it arrived there were two of these spoons on the plate meaning 2 pieces.

When i got my bill after my OK but not particularly good meal i saw that i was charged for 2 orders or 2 pieces of the black cod.  Nowhere on the menu (i asked after looking) does it say that there is a minimum 2 piece order.  I was never told this either.

So i complained and said that i had only wanted one and wouldn't have tried it if i had known that i must order 2 or more.  My waitress wouldn't accept this of course.  After about a minute or two a manager was nearby and overheard our conversation.  He gave me the same run around saying it was my fault basically.  He said "i understand, you got 2 pieces and only want to pay for one" and things like that which i felt was EXTREMELY rude.  The only thing either of them said that made any sense was that i should have been told before i ordered that there was a 2 piece minimum.

Finally they took it off when they realized i wasn't going to budge.  After they left i gave a not very loud snort of disgust to myself.  At that point the sushi chef in front of me locked eyes with me in very rude manner when i looked up at him.  

I was tempted to give them 2 stars because when i left in my frustration i accidentally left my card behind.  My waitress caught me outside the door and gave it to me.  As she handed it to me and started to walk away i said "hey wait" because i wanted to up my tip from the crappy 10% i had given.  She pretended (i'm pretty sure) to not hear me and kept on walking.  

After a bit of thought though they get only 1 star.  Any place i will never go back to after only one visit, and leave feeling that unhappy gets one star.
author: Brian J.

description: Sushi, ok really everything is awesome!!!! This is the best sushi in SF!!!!  Great unique choices every week. Just great!!
author: Jaime P.

description: This place seriously went downhill; came here on a Thursday night and we were the only ones there. Usually this place is packed. Food really tasted bland and not very fresh.
author: David Z.

description:
Delicious traditional Japanese food.
You must follow the chefs orders when to use soy-sauce. Many outrageous sushi items that are so tasty, you will be coming back for more.
You must try the Ceviche sushi...
author: TVAT T.

description:
Pros:
Amazing sushi where they actually take some risks!  They do interesting things blending interesting techniques with fish.  First place on the west coast to remind me of my beloved Oishii in Boston/Chestnut Hill.  5 stars.

Cons:
Slow to fill your water.

Fun:
They have a "special menu"--rather than ordering one or two items off there, just order everything from it!  Here's what we ordered: Baby Main Lobster is amazing, Katsunagi, Ceviche, Hamachi Pear, Crunchy Sushi, Saba, Hamachi
author: Mike G.

description: This is really a 4.5 star review. My favorite sushi/sashimi spot in the city. My favorites are the ceviche, lobster, and fresh scallops. I'm just sad we can no longer have foie gras in California because their foie gras nigiri was to die for. My only bad recommendation is that you can probably pass on the greentea creme brulee. Also, there's a mean lady that works here, but I don't mind. I just come mostly for the food.
author: Elisa M.

description:
I've experienced waaaayyyyyy better. Should have waited to go to Ariake a block up. Walked in and was seated immediately at the bar. Points for that. Apparently is reservation only, and they thought we had just called so we were seated. Afterwards we were told to scoot down to the end of the bar to make room for a reserved couple that never showed up. Miso soup was good. The 10$ roll that I got (tuna outside softshell crab inside) came apart as i tried to pick it up. I am very experienced at eating asian food that requires chopsticks/ hashi.  so my skills are up to date. The roll however fell apart. Very unimpressive presentation. Very plain. After spending 50$ there, I walked out scratching my head wondering what I had paid for. Crappy maki rolls but they pay lots of attention to their fancy rolls. I didn't have any of their fancy rolls, just their regular 10 and 12$ rolls. If Zagat has  rated this place, you would think they would step their game up on their non fancy rolls. 
Service was good except for the complimentary red bean pastry they give you seems like a nice treat, but all it really gives you and your pretty girlfriend, are some of the worst rotten egg farts. So if you want to get sexy with you significant other later on, don't eat the red bean pastry. ( could of been the undercooked shrimp too)

I forgot to mention, they barely give u any wasabi. The wasabi wasn't even hot. I like my wasabi spicy, this stuff was bland and no spice, whats the point then.
author: Max m.

description:
I'm updating this review of Kabuto just to re-emphasize how incredible this restaurant is. I came here again with a couple of friends and the sushi was just as delicious as I remembered it during my first time -- which means that its quality, even after a good few months, has not gone down and that it's still consistently good.

We ordered my favorites again: Toro Tartare special sushi, Foie gras special sushi, and the Ceviche special sushi. All just as good as I remember -- the foie gras is my personal favorite. We also ordered some new ones, including: (1) Monkfish liver special sushi (SO DAMN GOOD -- I've never had monkfish liver before and it's definitely up there with the best of the best), (2) Hamachi belly sushi (very tender and tasty), (3) Salmon with quail egg and tomiko (very good as well), and (4) Unagi nigiri (prob the best eel I've had in years). 

Of all the Japanese restaurants I've had in my life, Kabuto ranks up there with having some of the most unique and fresh sushi creations I've ever experienced. Make a reservation... NOW.
author: Roy C.

description:
I lived in Japan for 2 years and Kabuto is the best sushi in the WORLD.  

Cozy, friendly, artistic, delicious, amazing... sushi.  Yes, there can be a wait, yes it is impossible to get a seat for more then 4 people (but you wouldn't want to pay for more then 4 people anyway) it's simply the best sushi (period)

P.S. if your favorite Sushi is California roll "or anything cooked", save yourself $100 and go to Blue Fin on 19th and Clement
author: Sara L.

description:
love the innovative fusion twist of this place.
interesting menu and good fresh seafood.
author: Katie K.

description:
I LOVED Kabuto, and kudos to THE Jessica T for the find. Delicate, intensely good sushi in a small, comfortable, sweet setting. 

Must orders: 

The miso eggplant dish (bury me in it)
Green Tea (heal me, baby)
Miso soup (mini mushroom caps: swoon)
Edamame (standard, albeit necessary)
Tempura veggies (mmmmm)
Aforementioned foie gras (experience alone, leave ethics at door)
Hamachi Pear (foodgasm)
Tempura Vanilla ice cream: (sighhhhhhhhhhhh, love)
Green tea creme brulee (crunchety, crackly fantasmo)

Small, quaint. Seriously sushi love. Mmmm. 

Ok, I ate foie gras. It's been BANNED in Chicago (since repealed, but the stigma stands), so I flew to San Francisco to eat it. And it was good, and I don't feel bad about it, so...there. 

Because honestly, if anyone is disgusted with foie gras, then you best be a total and complete VEGAN, or I don't want to hear it!
author: Colleen C.

description:
This place had high hopes of getting the coveted 5 star rating but here's why it didn't. The food is pretentious. You are going to be tapping into your kid's college fund for a few itty bitty pieces of sashimi. I mean I felt like they prepared the fish in front of me and then zapped it with "honey I shrunk the kids" shrink ray. I'm pretty sure Rick Moranis was working behind the counter top. My girl and I also waited for like 30 minutes for a refill of hot tea.  Actually we didn't even get a refill. We had one single serving each of hot tea. Errrr You take so much pride in creating your tasty over-priced confections but don't stop and give me a refill of ocha? Especially, when we had two different waitresses say, "i'll be right back with your hot tea". 

....

.....

A good tip is to show up right before the kitchen's closing. We went late enough without a reservation and were seated within 2 minutes. Don't go during rush hour. The best time to eat good food is during off-peak.  They do put caviar on everything. If you can handle the crappy service, and have money to splurge on itty bitty cuts of fish then go here.
author: Jon H.

description:
I've come back to Kabuto twice now and have decided that its the best sushi I've had in both SF and L.A. I have literally had every single sushi listed on their "specialty" menu and there were only about 3 that weren't a complete homerun hit. I would eat here every week if I could afford it.

They still need to expand, though, and either get a bigger space or find some way to have a waiting area. I'm growing tired of all of the people waiting by the entrance and opening the door constantly, bringing in the Richmond breeze.
author: Logan The H.

description: This place is a small place but they serve THE BEST SUSHI in Geary St.  A little pricy but very good.. Uni! a must try, also their dragon roll...
author: Karren N.

description: Still amazing. I've been enjoying the sushi here over a number of years, and the variety and quality of the fish is always fantastic.  The interior is cozy but not cramped, and the staff are great. Dining options also include a number of great non-sushi items too.
author: Albert L.

description:
Sushi addict here and I've found some new raw crack to fill my addiction.  And it's all at Kabuto Sushi.  Now this may be the best sushi I've found in SF (sorry bout that Ryoko).  I came here with 5 of my coworkers and 48 hours later we're still raving and raving about the sushi at Kabuto.

Everything was absolutely yelptastic, but a few standouts from the event:
Foie Gras sushi: Both my dad and my hometown (chicago) are anti foie gras so this was my first experience with it and I don't think it will be my last (sorry dad/chicago!)
Hamachi Pear: Oh so flavorful
Miso Eggplant: I don't even like eggplant and I've been craving more of this ever since first eating it
Tempura Vanilla Ice Cream: Does it get much better than fried ice cream?
Green Tea Creme Brulee: Yes, apparently it does get better than fried ice cream when it comes to the green tea creme brulee!

The atmosphere and service weren't anything special, but who cares when the sushi is this incredible! Go, go, go! And you'll probably catch me there dining on my foie gras sushi during my next visit to SF. Thanks to fellow yelper/coworker Jessica T for introducing me to this gem...

PS: And yes, this was my 1200th review if you're counting!
author: Andrea R.

description:
I decided to treat my boyfriend out to sushi. After much yelping Kabuto seem to have the best review for "fresh fish" which is my bf's favorite type of sushi, unfortunately. With much anxiety, me being a raw fish hater, we sat down. It was 7pm on a rainy friday night, the place seemed rather slow. We got seats right away and started to order. 
We got 
6 - salmon
3-  hamachi
3- wild hamachi
2 - live oysters
2 - uni
1 - dragon roll
1 - sf tsunami
2 - tamago
1 - halibut with salmon and quail egg roll
2 - foie gras sushi

that's about it, i think? My favorite is of course the only completely cooked sushi "dragon roll".  but i must say, their fish is as fresh as it can be. I usually HATE raw fish, but Kabuto makes it heck of a better experience. Everything was extremely fresh and tasty. The SF tsunami was OKAY, nothing special. One warning to all, I felt super guilty eating foie gras sushi after finding out what it was. That in some farm, they force feed the geese in order to make their livers fatter. Hopefully, Kabuto uses organic geese, but there's no guarantee. So beware of eating foie gras sushi! 

The wild hamachi is a lot more fatty and buttery than the regular hamachi. You can really taste the difference. The live oyster is a MUST TRY, it came with a very creamy oyster sauce. (although they look very much like scallops)very delicious. The tamago here aren't as great. they were very cold and i could barely taste all the flavors in the tamago. 

Overall, the place is pretty neat! Their sushi is creative, fresh, and tasty. But good sushi comes with a very expensive price. The sushi are mostly sold by pieces, and the regular "fish sushi" avg about 2-3 dollars a piece. The special sushi, which comes in 2, avg around 6-8 dollars. Our total bill came out to be 108 dollars (excluding tip), and that's only TWO PEOPLE. Well, we did order a lot. . . This place really need more attention for their awesome sushi! I would definitely go back in the far future when i can afford it. haha.
author: Winne L.

description:
If you didn't take advantage of the Yelp Groupon, you're a fool. Which just means that instead of getting a decadent meal of foie gras, lobster, monkfish liver, lamb, uni, and tuna on the cheap, you'll pay a lot but still get your money's worth.

Obviously, this isn't traditional sushi, but it's not your typical fusion sushi joint with 100s of different rolls all with the same basic ingredients.

They really are adventurous with their innovative combinations, all of which work at a basic level, some of which worked really well. Service is great, and the food is brought out very quickly.

Just go
author: Mark A.

description: This place is disgusting.  Chef added so much extra sauce that covers the original taste of fish.  And BTW if you are looking for a "Japanese sushi" place, I don't recommend kabuto because all chefs and waitresses are Korean lol
author: Ashley J.

description:
Our current go-to sushi place in our hood. Solid assortment of fresh fish plus a variety of tasty yet interesting specials when you feel like venturing beyond nigiri. 

Service is nice but can be a bit rough around the edges at times. I do wish we could order from the sushi chef directly (we usually sit at the bar) but that's not how it's done here. Still, we'll keep coming back for the fish.
author: Christina L.

description:
Finally cashed in on the yelp deal- 25$ for 50$ worth of food- expecting to go well over the 50$ (we were starving), but the bill came out to about 56$! I read all the positive reviews before going, and I still was not disappointed.

The fish was delicious & fresh. Would definitely suggest getting an order of the toro tartar- actually scratch that- get several orders! Unfortunately, I didn't and I'm still thinking about it! 

Service was surprisingly great! I'm a poor student, so I try to cash in on all the deals/coupons I can. I was half expecting the slightly frosty attitude that often comes with the presentation of a coupon, but the waitress was very friendly. The food was brought out right away!

The restaurant was small and cozy. Parking was okay at around 5:30, but I imagine it gets worse later in the day.

And now my mouth is watering...
author: Alannah N.

description:
This place offers fresh, uncomplicated sushi. They have more of a simplistic approach to their dishes that make it still pop. Don't expect any fancy frou frou rolls here.

A little on the pricy end for the quantity given. The lunch sashimi special may be more worth than ordering separate rolls. 

Spicy tuna roll is excellent, the shiso was a great surprise! Lunch menu was a little limited, mb dinner is better?
author: Ly T.

description:
Reading all these negative yelp reviews because of the yelp certificate makes me feel really bad for Kabuto.  This place is already ridiculously popular for dinner (I saw people wait more than an hour for a table), so all these new complaints about supposedly bad service.. blah blah, I think is way harsh.  It's definitely not easy to suddenly have a higher inflow of customers, so cut the waitresses some slack.  If you're one of those people who go to a restaurant in large groups and takes freaking forever to order and eat your food and then stay another 30 something minutes to chat, then you remember that you're adding to the "bad service" by making it impossible for the waitresses to turnover tables.  Just sayin'

My experience at Kabuto was wonderful!  All the waitresses came by to ask how our food was and to refill our tea throughout our meal.  Whenever a waitress saw that we had finished a dish, they would come by to clear our plates even though they weren't assigned to our table.  

Everything I tried was delicious except I didn't like the hotapple, which was apple + scallop.  The combo was strange to me.  

Definitely try the potato croquettes.  Best I've ever had for sure.  I think they put carrots and zucchini inside for textural contrast, and the crust on the outside was so good.  

Foie Gras sushi is honestly amazing.  If you like the buttery taste of Uni, then you can imagine how freaking buttery Foie must be with rice.  I will definitely order that again.

In terms of fish, I think their salmon was really really good, so you can't go wrong with that.  Same with Toro. 

This place is too crowded and on a Friday night, it's overfilling with yuppie couples going on double dates.  But it's cool.  Just be smart and make a reservation!
author: Anna T.

description:
I finally got to use my yelp coupon for a superb lunch!

I ordered myself a great big helping of their specials and am not ashamed to say that my nom nom belly got bigger after the meal.

Hamachi Pear: I wondered how I was going to eat this in a bite, but where there was hunger, there was a way. The sweetness of the pear and the fruity spice of the mustard blended well with the yellowtail.

Toro Tartar: I basically am a toro whore, so anything toro will make me happy.  This roll was also kinda big, but the tartar mix of the toro and avocado, onions, shiso was awesome. I love the seasoned seawed for that bit of extra flavor that you savor at the top of your tongue.  

Foie Gras Sushi: I've only eaten foie gras twice in my lifetime, so this third should complete the trilogy. I love the balsamic raspberry sauce over the foie gras. The sweet sauce and the richness of the liver flavor just melted together so well.  

Katsunagi:   I love this roll...I'd have this over again and again. The unagi, Avocado, and deep fried Shiso sauced with their housemade Raspberry Miso was DA BOMB!!! The fried cripsy flavors and the unagi flavor just socks you in the face and makes you drool bite after bite. I wish there were more than 2 on my plate, but I made it worth my time...Savor it people...it was yummers.

Dragon Roll: The tempura ebi was light and crispy...it was excellent, the unagi was fresh and the avocado was perfect. The teriyaki sauce covered the roll just enough to make me sublimely happy. 

Finally I ended my Kabuto affair with a macha creme brulee. The green tea cream was light and the caramel glaze coating had that nice crunch when you tap it. It wasn't heavy and it was a good note ender to a worthy lunch.

The service was attentive, and since I was the first one in, I never felt like everyone was hovering over me. Parking is street and there's 2 hour free ones a block away if you can find some. Also meters around too. 

Looks like I"m going to have to grab some of my outer Richmond foodies to come and gorge here again!
author: Pauline L.

description:
Management did not honor Yelp! Coupon. 
Bought the Yelp! Coupon ($50 for $25). Met a friend who also bought the coupon. The manager came to our table and told us that we can't use both coupons. "only one per person and one per table. You should have received an email about it". Not only was there no email, but it was not what the coupon said and IT MAKES NO FINANCIAL SENSE! Did i really need to move to another table? It also displays bad service. I will never return to this place.
author: Oren R.

description: They serve quite bad toro here.  But, the other sushi and sashimi are good.  I will come back here and not order bad toro.  Line is kind of long and they foldable tables and chairs.  If you order from the special menu, it's hard to go wrong.
author: Byron L.

description: Good sushi, but expensive. I like to order their specials of the day. They also offer some unique, successful combinations on their special sushi menu, but for only 2 pieces, they're a little pricey and not very filling. Like their dragon roll as well, with the crispy char on the unagi. Some of their sushi chefs are more skilled and experienced than others. Some sushi is not rolled as tightly or sliced as evenly. Their rolls tend to be heavy on the rice too.
author: Sophia B.

description: Just went back for my taste of tuna fish butter...their tuna toro just is better than everywhere.  it just melts in your mouth.  And ankimo nigiri.  too bad no more foie gras sushi, but they have a few new ones with ankimo.
author: ray l.

description: Sushi are good and creative, but a long wait for table just in sometimes. Recommended for reserve table will be easier. Dessert are not bad also, love this place. Will go back in sometimes.
author: adrienne t.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night and it was packed!  Even with reservation, we had to wait 20 minutes for a spot at the sushi bar.  

The food was amazing!  I had probably the best monkfish liver I've ever tasted there.  The hamachi pear was interesting a new flavor combination for me.  The ceviche was inventive and fun to eat. The uni was extremely fresh as well.  

But probably the most memorable dish was a simple grilled eggplant dish topped with miso.  The eggplant was sooooo divinely creamy that I could just spoon it up and eat it with white rice.  I found out that it was called Nasu Dengaku and I tried to make it at home recently (http://www.slowfoodfastcook.com/2009/03/15/nasu-dengaku-broiled-eggplant-with-white-miso/).  It was delicious!

Go try it at Kabuto, but just don't go on a Saturday night!
author: Edda S.

description:
I LOVE KABUTO.

I love to go to kabuto and thanks to yelp's great deals, I have had the chance to go there more often! 

I am a big sashimi lover, and the fish there is always fresh.  It is the kind of fish where you dont need soysauce and wasabi and you can totally taste the freshness of it.  Simplicity.

One of my favorites is the oyster with uni, quail egg, and roe.  It is SO good I find myself drooling while thinking about it.  Also, the raw salmon wrapped around a small piece of sushi rice with a quail egg in the middle (I forget what it is called) is so delicious too!  Ankimo is a must have also.

I LOVE KABUTO!  It's a small place, so you might want to make rezzies or call ahead.
author: Ali C.

description:
Hmmm by the first glance, I wasn't impressed. 

Random dinner night!

As we sat down by the corner perusing through the menu, we decided to go with the prefix menu.

I have to say one of the most phenomenal sushi places that I've been to.  I though every dish on the pre-fix was yummy


Oyster shooter - TO DIE FOR!!
Foie gras - Pretty amazing
Red Snapper - Fresh and citrusyyy
Nigiri pieces - Fresh, but not unique
Lobster with grilled pear
Shrimp tempura- typical
Mussels- Not a fan
ans a few others. If I didn't list it, I'm not crazy about it.  :)

My favorite was the oyster shooter.  The best that I've ever had in my life.   We finished off with green tea ice cream with fruit chunks and a puree (can't remember the flavor). 

I would definitely go back for the oyster shooters.

hahaha, just realized, never judge a book by its cover.
author: Jessica P.

description:
If you order just the right dishes, you'll look forward to going back to Kabuto soon.  If you don't, you could walk away wondering what the fuss was about because, as much as I love the great ones, there are a few very average ones.  

Things that are great:

-Foie Gras Sushi: Holy heavenly fattened goose liver on rice. Balsamic rasberry sauce is perfect.
-Hamachi Jalapeno: Yellowtail sashimi in a light ponzu sauce topped with jalapeno (not on the regular menu, so ask for it)
-Ceviche: Halibut with fresh salsa and lime wrapped in fried seaweed paper. 
-Crunchy sushi: Tempura halibut in curry sauce and the perfect mix of texture and flavor

Things that are good:

-Hamachi Pear: The hamachi nigiri and mustard sauce are really good together.
-Fire Salmon Roll: Shrimp tempura topped with salmon and jalapeno then torched.  Not sure if it would be as good without the 'show' of torching it.
-Scallop Ginger Chardonnay: Better with more ginger.

Things that were okay, but I wouldn't order a second time:

-Lamb Apple Sushi: Not bad, but not a stand-out
-Wave Tsunami: Tuna cooked w/ ginger wrapped in egg (crepe style) in sauce. Bland.
-Sunrise: Thick salmon sashimi around rice with raw quail egg and tobiko roe. Fresh and creamy and I know it's all about texture, but I thought it was bland. Could be personal pref. 

Things that are not okay:

-Seaweed Salad: It's actually just a spring salad with a little seaweed. 
-Sushi Mozzarella: White fish, simmered in mild broth with rice baked with mild cheese.  Disclaimer: someone else in our party ordered it.  It doesn't even sound interesting and it wasn't. 

Gentlemen/Boys on Dates: the sushi bar is mirrored in such a way that if you sit at it with your date next to you, you might spend the evening staring at your date's chest.

Ladies on Dates: see above.
author: P J.

description:
So I got one of those yelp deals.... pay 25 for 50.  

BUYERS BEWARE:  a deal is not always what you may think.

First time diners there, and were initially offered the 'special' sushi, of which we ordered: 

ceviche
genmaicha
Foie Gras sushi
sonoma duck

The sushi was tasty, however, they failed to mention to us that they charged PER PEICE.... they also didnt mention that it came in pairs, without even warning or asking us how many it was we wanted.  Meaning, each item was at least 2-5 per peice of sushi served.  I personally spent $40 just for 10 peices of sushi.  In my opinion, the fish was just OK, but quite overpriced for the food.  I've had MUCH better.

Based on 10 peices of sushi, we continued to order the fire salmon roll, grilled sea bass ( came out the size of our palms), and Tuna and soft shell crab roll, and NY steak terriyaki.  

YES, we ate all that - I couldnt say we were even that full.  Total bill came out to be $104!!! With the $50, already having paid $25, I ended up spending a total of $75.00 with tip for the meal.  I have had AMAZING sushi at Tomodachi in Hayward, of which we normally spend $100/ visit, however, their sushi melts in your mouth like butter.  I couldnt say the same for Kabuto, and as a matter of fact, my husband thought it was a little fishy.

Would I come back?  Heck no, not even if I got 50% off the menu.  It definately wasnt worth the drive, and not worth the palette.  Ive tried one too many sushi restaurants that outshine this place, irregardless of price.
author: Ricaa W.

description: One of the best sushi places in my opinion. Authentic, simple and fresh. Chef's choice is great, but it can certainly add up in the pocket... But good sushi is not cheap, right?! Go there!
author: Paula L.

description:
Love sushi and especially love Kabuto. They have an innovative and extensive menu for sushi. The plating is clean and artistic. The service is top-notch and they are very personable. 

I recommend the Hot Apple. The sauce they put on that dish was amazing. I literally fingered (sorry for the lack of a less perverted sounding word) it all off the plate. I thought that the Kobe (Salmon) was one of the freshest I have had in the Bay.

Awesome place. A delight.

*Tip* Try out creations for dessert down the street *
author: Richard K.

description:
This is one of the best sushi restaurants in the city.  The ingredients are really fresh and the sushi specials are innovative and delicious - like the Hamachi Pear, Sonoma Duck (with a mustard sauce), and Toro Tartar.

The staff is really nice but make sure you make a reservation ahead of time unless you are fine with waiting!
author: Nan L.

description: What a disappointment! Very anti-climactic. Waited 35-45 minutes in the chill of the night while there were 3 empty tables (reservation).  No one greets you. You're told to write down your name on a list and wait outside. How long you wait is anybody's guess. But after reading the stellar reviews on Yelp we knew it'd be worth it. NOT! Some of the appetizers we had: gyoza, miso soup with clam, spicy mussels. Gyoza not good, soup a little bland, and spicy mussels tasted like mussels with BBQ sauce. I had sashimi. Good but nothing special. Will say it tasted fresh. Someone else in our party had tempura. It was not light and crunchy but rather flat and tasteless.  And yes, service needs improvement.  We won't be back. It's unfortunate because we were really hoping this would be our "go to" spot.
author: R C.

description:
I believe a 3.5 star rating is most appropriate for my experience, but I bet if I went back (now armed with some experience), I would have a solid 4 star time.

Kabuto is a cozy space that is casual and inviting.  The service is really friendly, however, English is not the best language of communication (but who cares? Just keep it simple).

I would give 3 stars for the negi maguro sushi (it was blah, just nori, rice, maguro) and 3.5 stars for the hirame "jerry" nigiri.  It had ponzu jelly on top of a slab of halibut plus a tiny square of japanese clover.  The ponzu jelly was too subtle in my opinion and the overall effect was admirable but more avant garde than tasty.

However, the halibut "ceviche" was HEAVEN in my mouth.  Halibut over rice topped with "salsa" (more like finely diced tomato with a kick and some tang) served over a sheet of seasoned (deep fried?) nori.  You just roll the nori around the fish and chomp.  SO GOOD!

We also got agedashi tofu (bon!), sauteed burdock root (fine), soup with enoki tofu and a clam (forgettable), and mochi (mocha mochi rocks!).  The menu is pretty extensive so it can be overwhelming, but hey, I like choices.
author: Priscilla T.

description: This is a restaurant worth coming to for a completely satisfying experience.  Kabuto is warm and welcoming the moment you open the door.  The seafood is fresh and flavorful making an order of traditional sashimi enjoyable and making their unique combinations of fish & fruits exceptional.  And I can't forget to mention the clam miso soup  - YUM!  They take pride in their menu and it shows both in presentation and service.  When asked "What is your favorite sushi place in SF?"  Kabuto is always first on my list.
author: Rachel G.

description:
