I live in Oakland. A schlep to the outer Richmond is indeed, a schlep. I drove, I found parking (miraculously after only 25 minutes of searching) and met our out of town friends. 

We had made a reservation, because it's Saturday night and you do that. 
Didn't seem to matter, though. A table of our size, with a reservation AFTER ours, was seated promptly. Yet we stood, and stood and stood and waited and waited and waited. For 50 minutes we waited, standing at the door, TOUCHING the back of the chairs of the poor people seated nearest the door. This place is a tight squeeze. 

ONE HOUR after our reservation we were seated and finally got drinks. We tried and tried to order a bottle of sake, but we couldn't. The waitress had no idea what was actually in stock, until we would decide on that bottle, only for her to disappear into the back and return with 'we don't have that'. We couldn't figure out what they actually did have in stock, and whatever was, wasn't actually on the menu.

The service was, and I don't say this lightly, the most LAUGHABLY BAD SERVICE I've had in years, maybe ever. It was terrible. 

The food? Well, it looked like there was a bunch of creative, beautiful stuff coming out from behind the sushi bar, but no server ever explained to us what any of it was, so we just defaulted to sort of standard fare. We did order a few things from the 'special' menu, only to be told there's a MINIMUM ORDER for some of them. Luckily we met that need, but come ON. You must order two. Is the price listed for two? No, that's for one. WHAT? ARE YOU PEOPLE TAKING CRAZY PILLS??

Back to the food. The fish was good, and beautifully plated. The creative dishes we had were okay. Good, even. Worth the wait? Nope. I was furious, and still am. The servers made no effort to make us feel better about our wait. 

THE shining glory in our Kabuto experience was when the chef came out to our table with a bottle of the sake we did not buy (because it was $60) and filled glasses for us. Thanked us for waiting, apologized for the wait. THANK YOU, sushi chef. YOU were the bright spot in an otherwise cramped, rude, late evening.

Kabuto is a place where they play the Opposite Game- we have menus, but why bother with them? We take reservations, but don't actually respect them! We have servers, but why would they know what we have or anything about sushi? NO place is good enough to have crap service like that. Kabuto, pull it together.

People we met at the bar across the street recommended we go to Sakura, on 26th/Clement. Maybe we should have taken that advice?
author: Amani Ellen L.

description:
I have had sushi at countless restaurants, and this is my ultimate favorite. The flavors are so original. you must try the Hamachi Pear.
Each roll is roughly $5, but they add up quick. Be prepared to dish out at lease $50 for two people.
author: Tina C.

description: Can't add a lot but suffice to say, I think this is a top 5 Bay Area sushi restaurant.   Innovative sushi and extremely fresh fish.  I have been going there over 15 years which says a lot.  Hamachi and jalapeño is last supper worthy.   Make reservation.
author: mike s.

description:
Cute, small, hole-in-the-wall place. Try the sushi specials. You must be a sushi/sashimi lover for this place though as it lacks quality on the staple Japanese dishes. They have a good mix of authentic and creative dishes, mostly all made from raw fish. Had my favorite escolar here. 

Small neighborhood place that has a lot of regulars. It's a bit out there in terms of location though.
author: Yue Z.

description: I am a fan of sushi and this place is great. The food was on point. The place is very small and always packed.
author: Kevin W.

description:
I have to update because I got an email with apologies and with refund from Yelp. I really respect Yelp for making the best of the situation, I think THIS is a good service! 5* for Yelp! 

And to people saying that some of us were too harsh on the place because of the deal,  I did mentioned that food was fine, and I wouldn't even mind the service (if they are so busy all the time, this means they should be used to it, no?) Anyhow, we were a small group and we didn't stay for chatting... we didn't appreciate getting yelled and phrases like: "this is how you want this?!". So, sorry, I'm usually really generous and not that picky and annoying customer (BTW, we left a nice tip), but I do not appreciate being treated as a annoying person, when all I wanted was a nice evening in a nice company.
author: Nastia R.

description:
In short: tiny space, fresh fish, big pieces of sashimi, cool rolls, slow service. 

To elaborate:
I guess you can call me somewhat of a sushi purist given my Japanese background and foodie father who crammed into my head what good Japanese food should look and taste like since I was a little girl. Therefore, I cringe at the taste of cream cheese in my rolls, get disappointed when the servers or sushi chefs do not speak any Japanese, and sigh a little under my breath when people douse their sushi with wasabi and soy sauce. 

Now that I got that off my chest, Kabuto didn't really meet any of the requirements in my book to be considered a good sushi restaurant. 

There are tons of specialty rolls which is a cool 'American' concept and if executed well, could be very good. However, Kabuto's rolls didn't really wow me. I tried their hamachi jalapeno, sunrise roll, foie gras nigiri, sashimi plate, and tuna tar tar nigiri. None of them really made me want to order another plate. I do give them props for originality and presentation. I can see why it would be considered people's go to sushi place in the area. 

After five dishes and a small bottle of organic sake, the bill came out to be around $95.00 without tip. Not bad for the amount of fish I ate but I don't think I'll be coming back.
author: Stephanie O.

description:
This place is really fantastic!

The place holds about 50 people and does not seem to take reservations,s o you maybe inf or a wait. But it did seem to clear out a bit after 9 pm, so a late dinner may be your best bet.

The food and fish is extremely fresh and flavorful. Everything we had was tender and the flavor of the fish really came through - from milky and buttery to tangy and sweet. The Unagi was easy the best I have ever had. If you think BBQ unagi is supposed to be covered in teriyaki and a bit tough, you have been robbed. We all have,

Artistry is very simple and while they do offer mayonnaise based sauces, it's not to the level of something like Mikuni or Sushi to Dai for you feel like having a heart bypass afterwards.

Onlhy draw back is some of the waitresses can be a bot tough to understand. On the plus side is that they care enough about the sushi where they'll tell you not to use soy sauce on a serving. They really care about their food and art and how you experience it.
author: Jon M.

description:
I hesitate to write this review because I don't want to droves of people flocking to this amazing sushi spot.  

That said, the quality of the fish is outstanding and the sushi chefs are as brilliant as the delectable dishes they consistently create.  Favorites: 1849 oyster, sweet shrimp with fried heads, foie gras sushi (if they still have it).  

Unfortunately, the space is pretty drab and has harsh lighting, which makes convincing my fiancé to go with me difficult at times.
author: Blake G.

description:
4.5 stars. 

If you come here, you need to order just from their sushi menu, special sushi menu or from their daily specials on the white board. Move the dinner entree menu to the side.

I've had sushi in Japan and this place comes really close to the premium sashimi you find in Japan. REALLY close.

I've been here a few times and this is the sushi place I usually recommend to my out-of-towners for GOOD sushi. 

Some of my favorites are the following:
Hamachi Pear with fruity mustard sauce
Ceviche (halibut with deep fried seaweed with sea salt)
Ono Grape (Wahoo sushi)
Toro Tartar
Spicy scallop

Of course a lot of other sushi items and their changing daily specials are always good too. 

This evening, I felt the normal awesome ceviche fell short on the citrus flavor and the toro tartar was a bit flavorless. On the other hand, the salmon was SUPER fresh and melted like butter. They must have gotten a really good delivery of fresh salmon from Japan this morning. 

Overall, I think Kabuto is still one of my favorite sushi restaurants in the Bay Area. Highly recommend!!!

Quick tip: Come on a Tuesday. Barely anyone at the restaurant. Parking was easy too. 
Another tip: Try to avoid using soy sauce with the sushi. You may miss the natural flavor of the fish.
author: Molly T.

description:
So, yesterday was my first time dining at Kabuto.  When it comes to sushi in San Francisco, I'm often quite conflicted.  I've not really had my best sushi experiences here in SF.  The ones that I have enjoyed have cost an arm AND a leg (or promise of my firstborn child...go ask my mom, those restaurants shouldn't be holding their breath for repayment on that one...). 

So, what did I think of Kabuto?

Very good, solid, high quality sushi.  I appreciated the CLEANLINESS of the flavors.  This is NOT a place that will WAOW you with modern ambiance or crazy inventive rolls.  Yet, it is also NOT overly stuffy or overly traditional.  There are some innovative and interesting rolls to try here, so those that feel the need to experiment have room to play.

I categorize this as = MODERATELY priced (although, I did not pay the bill that night), solid sushi.  I read here that it is sushi for the gai-jin...well...as long as it is fresh and tasty, why not? ;-)

I find the service ABRUPT BORDERING ON BRUSQUE.  (I would give the service only 3 stars), BUT, with that typed, this was my first visit and I've seen a LOT worse at other restaurants.  Perhaps the FLURRY of the servers has more to do with LIMITED SEATING?  At times, I felt that the service was RUSHED.  Just my opinion.

The experience started off with the traditional warm hand-towels for prep, which I LOVE.

For a table of FOUR, we ordered quite a bit.  I cannot recall EVERYTHING in detail  (and as I said, I did not pay, so I do not have the receipt), yet, I will try to describe some of the more memorable dishes:

Hamachi Pear  ( hamachi nigiri topped with a slice of pair and dijon mustard). Very petite, bite sized portion with very fresh fish.  Not quite my favorite, but the fish was very fresh.  I'm not so sure if I really cared for the pear and dijon mixed with this choice of fish.


CeViChe  Very interesting presentation with halibut and salsa wrapped with deep fried seaweed and served with lime
and sea salt.  There is NOT your traditional presentation of Ceviche.  I liked the flavor of the ceviche itself, but the oily seaweed detracted from the experience.

Foie Gras Sushi   This seared, marinated goose liver served
with balsamic raspberry and sauce was actually one of my favorite.  It was an interesting combination that played  well with TEXTURE, FLAVOR and CONCEPT for sushi.

Gomae  how can you go wrong with SPINACH and sesame soy dressing *LOL*...

I think that we got the hirame...something... *LOL*...It was really good.

The seaweed salad VERY disappointing.  More of salad than traditional wakame salad...

Hmmm...we also got 2 orders of chirashi sushi (mixture of several different sashimi)...very fresh and good.

Oh...and dessert...the green tea mochi ice-cream was eh...  the green tea cheesecake = very good.

All in all -- food = good experience...service= fair

parking= hard to find (had to walk quite a ways)
author: Hiromi N.

description:
This is a gem in the Richmond District!  Always fresh  - never fails to have quality sushi, sashimi, and oysters!

We've never even gotten to the hot meals because ordering all the sushi would be more than enough for us!
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
The sushi at Kabuto are quite creative, even though it can be a bit pricey. For the special sushi, the Ceviche (halibut) and Foie Gras (goose liver) were just memorable with an outstanding artistic presentation. It's like making food into a masterpiece work of art.
Tasmanian salmon is the best salmon I have ever eaten... sadly not many places have it. It was super fresh, sweet, and literally melts in your mouth. Kanpachi aka yellow jack was also my favorite, it was succulent and firmer than hamachi.  
Even though the green tea cheesecake was not impressive, but the tempura ice cream was amazing. The tempura batter was hot, thin and crunchy with freezing cold ice cream inside. Service was good. I enjoy the hot towels they give you before you start your meal.
author: Cece Y.

description: I would say this is the BEST Japanese restaurant. Very dedicated, the food is innovative and yummy. You can't judge from the appearance of the restaurant, which looks like a fast food shop. Really good.
author: Piggy P.

description:
WOW! I don't know what else to say... Absolutely THE most exciting Japanese restaurant I've been to in SF....
If you haven't tried this restaurant yet- definitely make the effort to drop in...!
You can pretty much order anything and WON'T go wrong...!! Yes, it's THAT good!
author: Alex T.

description:
Authentic, delicious.  Cons: Long wait

Seared toro - Probably my favorite, just great

Uni soup - First time having Uni in soup, it was fantastic
author: boston U.

description:
I really enjoy the food here, but wish the customer service was a bit better.  I've had one of the waitresses a few times and she's kind of gruff.

hmmm, I dream of foie gras nigiri!!
author: Kel E.

description: Very creative sushi. If you want sushi but you don't want the ordinary sushi most restaurants have, then then you'll want to com to Kabuto.
author: MexicanHulk M.

description:
What can I say about this restaurant that 400 other reviews have not already written....................... Let me try.

This place would've gotten a 5 star easily if the spicy tuna, agadashi tofu, spicy california, and the their interpretation of a caterpillar roll didn't show up to the table.   

The rest of the food however was PHENOMENAL.  My God..............the foie gras sushi with balsamic raspberry reduction was ridiculously incredible, their version of a deconstructed toro and avocado tartar sushi was different and great, cerviche, and scallops were fantastic. The 1849 oysters were probably the most expensive at 14 dollars a piece(or for 2). The oysters were incredible though..........it came with uni, ponzu, quail egg, salmon roe, and this gold paper. If I knew the gold paper was the reason why it was this expensive I would've told them to take it out because you really can't taste it. These items are off the menu, their special. If we just stuck to these orders.........the food itself is easily 5 stars. Stick with the specials.........all of the other stuff is average to even sub par. We had other items as well but not worth mentioning. 

4 solid stars
author: jason g.

description:
i'm glad the foie gras sushi lived up to the hype.
i came knowing this place isn't for sushi purists
(to me, rice is a bit dry.)  but i enjoyed it and focused on the special sushi menu, which they excel.
so, back to the foie gras sushi, perfectly seared, and the raspberry onion on top with balsamic raspberry sauce paired just like when you have it at new american style restaurants.  very tasty.
also tried toro tartar, baby main lobster, hamachi pear, live scallop, hamachi jalapeno, alaskan king salmon, aburi toro (seared but wish it wasn't), overall presentation nice, quality good, menu is actually quite extensive.
i recommend coming for their foie gras sushi, which is the highlight.
author: Rob C.

description: My every year Valentine's date! Love this expensive exotic little thing so much!
author: Terra G.

description: i love this place!  walked in without reservations at around 6 and got seated quickly. the ankimo, uni and foie gras were just sooo delish!!! service was great!
author: she q.

description:
Small. Crowded. Long wait. No parking. Why the hell come here?

They have the freshest fish, the most exotic sashimi dishes, and very attentive service. That's why. 

I went here for the first time on a date. We got here at 730pm. I found parking right in front. Good parking kharma. No wait. We got super lucky. Although I did make reservations. We were seated at a table with a very attentive waitress. We decided on a couple of plates, but left the rest up to the chef to choose. Let me tell you, that is THE WAY to go. Let them pick as they know what they are doing. 

7-8 dishes later, a very happy Katie Anne.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
One of the few places that does both new style and old school Japanese very well. 

The special rolls are what keeps calling me back. The combination of flavors in your mouth awakens your taste buds so that you're often experiencing 3 to 5 of the 5 taste sensations at once. Some of my favorites are the ceviche and ono grape although all are good. The traditional sushi are also well prepared with a good ratio of rice to fish. If available, you must try the escolar. 

A year ago, this place would've rated 5 stars. On my latest visit, although still good, the fish was a little less fresh and the flavors were a little flatter than usual.
author: Judy C.

description:
We came out here for dinner last night and the food was delicious. We ordered the baby main lobster roll, crunch sushi roll, katsunagi roll, negi hamachi roll, negi toro roll, and the sammy roll.  The rolls here were very unique and tasty here. Then we finished off with some green tea ice cream. The ice cream had a strong green tea flavor was was great.

As for the service, they were very slow to seat us as well as serve us. We got very slow service from the sushi chefs even though we sat at the sushi bar.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Kabuto has been THE place to go for sushi in SF for the past 3 or 4 years since I've discovered them in their new location (across the street from the old location).

I find each visit super-consistent.  I can always count on extremely fresh fish (second only to the great Nozawa, in my experience).  Plus, they serve a progressive faire as well, both in terms of asian-fusion and presentation.  My favorite for the non-nigiri meals are the Jalapeno Yellowtail and 1849 Oysters.  The 1849 has oysters, quail eggs, uni, salmon roe, ikura and an interesting flake of gold to top it off.  Quite amazing.

On my last visit, I noticed that one of my favorite waitresses was not waitressing anymore.  Instead, she was promoted behind the counter preparing dishes!  If you've noticed a dearth of female sushi chefs in the Bay Area (or sushi restaurants in general), you'll be supremely impressed by Kabuto's continually non-traditional way of business.  For the non raw fish eating contingent, there are an array of cooked Japanese foods that are equally as yummy.  Yes, I said "yummy"...
author: Michael W.

description:
I always believe don't judge the book by it cover.  Awesome sushi joint, very very fresh and carefully made.  At the price that they are charging, this will be my first pick at the moment for sushi.

not need to say more, will come back from time to time.
author: Alan T.

description:
Our cousin highly recommended this restaurant. We were mesmerized by some of the creations from the website and decided to try in before a show in the city. I made a reservation at 6pm on Saturday and showed up promptly to a full house. Our table was ready at 6:05. By 7pm, the line was out the door with several people hovering right by the entrance to make sure people were not loitering at their tables. 

Kabuto has a fine selection of fresh fishes. Some of our favorites including shima aji and bonito were available. 

We ordered the foie gras and lobster sushi to start. The foie gras is absolutely decadent. In retrospect, we probably should have saved it for last since the favors were so rich and overwhelming. The lobster was quite good but really how can you go wrong with lobster. 

We then proceeded to order a selection of bonito, shima aji, kanpachi, Spanish mackerel, the tuna sashimi and a Scott hand roll. Everything was well seasoned and tasted fresh. I would definitely recommend the Scott roll if you like spicy tuna. It has a wonderful delicate mix of spices and flavors.

On my second visit, I would probably would not have ordered the tuna sashimi again, it was just too much tuna.
author: John C.

description:
Pro: Foie gras sushi, and hamachi pear.
Cons: Cramped seating. Sticky and worn out menus. Uninspiring decor. Shotty service.
author: b p.

description:
4.5 stars

Leslie was really good.  Salmon avo marinated lemon
Crunchy - tempura halibut w curry sauce super good
Oden - good but a little too salty i like broth more mild
Udon Nabeyaki - one of the best all time
author: Sage S.

description: Kabuto is our favorite sushi restaurant in the city! The selections are always super fresh, and the chefs are artisans - I often find myself snapping photos of the dishes as they hit our table - many of them are like miniature works of art.
author: Tom C.

description:
Oh man. I'd like to give this place 4.5 stars. I'm not sure what I'm reserving my five star ratings for...but this place comes close on the sushi scale.

Let me begin by saying that I'd been here once before several years ago, loved it, but then for some reason just didn't get back. Probably because my laziness generally kicks in and I order from the place near my house that delivers. That said, Kabuto is outstanding and worth the 8 block walk from my house.

The sushi is SO fresh, presented so beautifully and accented with the most complementary flavors (by way of delicate sauce and garnish).

My favorite of the night was definitely the ceviche - a hamachi that was served on a flat piece of seaweed with a bit of fresh tomato and jalapeno. You roll it like a "taco" and eat it without soy sauce. We ended up ordering four orders of it. It was truly to die for.

That said, there wasn't one thing we ordered that we didn't like. Another standout: the foie gras with fresh raspberry. OMG. It's like sushi dessert.

We had some kind of a seared salmon that was just mouth watering good, some fatty tuna that melted like butter and many other specials that rocked our worlds.

I was drinking sake that night and at $11 a glass was expecting a ginormous bill at the end of the evening - but even with everything we ordered, the damage wasn't so bad! I've spent far more eating far less in many "average" restaurants.

I recommend Kabuto wholeheartedly. Y-U-M.
author: Carrie S.

description:
Kabuto is on top of my list for Japanese cuisines in the City. There aren't many places I would go for a satisfying meal - as a matter of fact, I just went there a few nights ago and it hardly disappoint.

All nigiri sushi's are above average, if not great. I found their special plates quite unique in this area, and most of them are delicately prepared with great flavors. The daily special menu offers great selections such as Hamachi Jalapeno, 1849 Oysters, and so forth. I can't speak more to praise their effort in preparing their specials.

Cooked food is okay, but can be skipped. If you want to stuff yourself, then I'd recommend get couple orders. After all, sushi's are the best feature in this restaurant.
author: Edmund L.

description:
Been here before and enjoyed the sushi, came back Tuesday and was not disappointed. We ordered:

Toro Tartare Nigiri $5 a piece
- chopped negi toro and avacado, deep fried shiso leaf + seaweed on top, marinated Rakkyōzuke onion and a reddish tartare sauce
Very refreshing combination. The tartare sauce had a hint of spice, added depth to the taste and cut through the creaminess of the toro.

Saba Nigiri
- the sushi chef served this with a thinly shaved sheet of Kombu, an added dimension/connection to the ocean, also a clever and sensitive combination. Saba was top grade, soft creamy texture without being too vinegar-y. Mikey rated it A.

Amaebi $2 a piece with fried head
- nothing to complain about

Unagi
- THE biggest piece of unagi on nigiri i've ever seen in my whole life. A little more charred than the usual ones but I welcome the crispy brown parts.

Tamago Zousui $5 may be $6
- egg and rice in chicken broth with napa cabbage, some Kamaboko fish cake (the ones with PINK "rind") served in a small Agemono nabe pot. A very simple and satisfying dish, a filler, if you may.

Overall very satifying experience, above standard sushi with some inventive new ideas.
author: DANIEL T.

description: Love love love their fresh buttery sashimi that just melts in your mouth.  I would go here more often if I didn't mind dropping over $100 for my meal... but because I do, this place is my go to place for special days.  Everything that I have tried was delicious and the service is great too.
author: Mary W.

description: Dirty and underwhelming. Come here if you enjoy the charm of lousy service, moderate food, and unexciting food. Go just about anywhere else if you don't... Try Blowfish in Mission. MUCH better. It think people have fond memories of what this place may have once been... But no longer is.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Rolled in here on a Thursday night with the Hilo Wrecking Co. and immediately went for the for the good stuff: toro, hamachi, jalapeño hamachi, baby main lobster, 1849 oysters, and the fresh uni. 

I'm a huge uni fan and had been eyeing the fresh uni as soon as we walked in. It was being served at almost every table. The presentation of the fresh uni was pretty cool, it comes served inside the actual urchin shell. This dish ended up being amazing! Nice and fatty, melted in my mouth. The oysters were also great, eye catching presentation and lots of flavor. 

The others items were a let down though, not very fresh and overpriced. That brought down the overall rating.
author: Rich C.

description:
Been craving sushi, so I dragged Mr to Kabuto. It's his first. Kabuto probably accomodates 50 people, it's tiny. So you would understand there's a line everytime you come to eat & that's one of the reason I didn't give them 5 stars.

Past Saturday, got there at 6:15 PM, no reservation. Eventhough were the first name on the list, we waited for 20 minutes. 

Finally, at 6:50 PM, we got seated by the bar. The staff were great, they apologize for the long wait and they took our order right away.  

We ordered (4 pieces of each) Bachi Maguro,, Hamachi, Kotako, Mahi Mahi, Miso TORO Asparagus, Sake, Toro-Fatty Tuna & Yosenabe. 

For drinks Mr had Asahi & I had a glass of Kubota Hekiju ($24 for a glass) $110 for a bottle. But, LOVE that SAKE, it was little sweeth stong and smooth.

Since we ordered so much sushi, we didn't had a chance to finish our Yosenabe.  Our waitress accidentally spilled our soup when she was putting in a to go box so they ended up giving us a new soup. 

Total damage including tip $128.00. Also to avoid the line or wait, make a reservation.
author: jubi l.

description:
I have to say, this is my favorite Japanese restaurant in the city. It's a tiny place in inner richmond with minimal decor but I care more about the food than then place. The specialty sushi that they have are unique and flavorful. The chef really knows what he is doing by mixing those flavors together. I tried most of the specialty menu and my favorites are the foie gras sushi and the ceveche. The raw oyster is also one of my favorites too. They add quail egg, fish roe, uni, and edible gold shred on top. Every bite is like a party in your mouth. 

The food is simple, yet refined, That's what Japanese food is about. Folks, it doesn't get any fresher or better than this.
author: Jack S.

description: Heard that "Beggars can't be choosers"- not always true. Been here many times. Each time $50-60 easily for 1 person. Once took my sister's family and spent $300 for 1 dinner. My sister wasn't even impressed about the food. Today, I gently asked if I may order 1/2 bottle of small sake, since I can never finish 1 bottle by myself. Was told NO without any reason. Walked out and happily fed in the neighbor restaurant Ariake. Yes, they are ok with my peculiar request of 1/2 bottle of sake. Thumbs up to Ariake!! I may not even try the 1/2 bottle next time since it left me some desire for more. Dear Kabuto, sorry you are not the only J-restaurant in town. Are you out of your mind to let go a perfectly good business over 1/2 bottle of small sake on a chilly night when most of your tables were unseated?
author: SpaDoll H.

description:
The last visit here was so good that I had to update my review from 2007! Still 5 out of 5 stars but I just had more say!

Every time we come here, we are flabbergasted about how insanely good everything is.  EVERYTHING. The fish is superb, the sushi is so creative and just...perfect. The hamachi pear, the esoclar, the oysters, the eggplant! We have probably tried every single thing on their specialty sushi menu and each item is the best thing I have ever eaten...how can that be? I dont know, it just is. It just is.
author: Nilu r.

description:
My mind is blown by anyone who gave them 1 star!  Someone said they spent $50 didn't have sake and left hungry.  You sir, are a pig who should eat fast food then.  My boyfriend and I both like to eat and aren't light eaters.  We can get out of here for $50-60 per person for a fantastic meal and sake.  Sure that's not cheap, but their fish is one of the best in the city so it's worth it.  I don't really want to eat bargain sushi.  I don't have a $50-60 meal every day...but when I want awesome sushi, this is the spot.

Favorite sushi spot in the city.
author: McKenzie M.

description:
It was delicious, but the portions were so small! 

I don't know. I'm torn. Great quality sushi, but I wasn't even full when I left the restaurant.
author: A C.

description:
We used to live around the corner from this place... SO GOOD.

It's not a big space so it's important to arrive early or come on a weeknight when things aren't too crazy.

This was my first intro to sushi and it made me an avid fan. :)  and mochi is yummy.
author: Libbi J.

description:
I would rate this restaurant as just ok, especially given it's price..

Some of our rolls fell apart picking them up.
Some of the sushi pieces - could only taste the wasabi
We had asked for no avocado's on my wife's roll and specified that I liked avocado's on everything else.. apparently that meant no avocado's on anything.. 

Overall, might come back. but there's better places nearby.
author: mark r.

description: Treat yourself to some of the most imaginative, fresh, delicious sushi you'll find anywhere in the Bay Area.  Expensive.
author: Chris K.

description:
WOW. Foie Gras. Ceviche. Spicy Tuna. A few years back, I had paid Kabuto a visit, but it was with a group of people and I don't think I was yelping back then but thank goodness I am now so I can share my LOVE of this place.  

This place is really tiny - so if there's a wait, don't fret - go some where and get a snack so you don't feel like you are starving yourself - I promise the wait is sooo worth it.  

The fish is fresh, the roles are innovative, and the staff is so friendly!!  

Be adventurous and order from their "special menu" or from the items on the white board.  Also, be sure to listen to them when they give you your rolls - if they say NO SOY SAUCE NEEDED - listen to them and don't drench those specified rolls in soy sauce.  Trust, they know what they are talking about.
author: Cherlyn M.

description:
I love sushi and have heard so many great things about this place, so I FINALLY came in to give it a try.  It's a small place with simple decor.  

I actually did not do any research on the food before I came, so I was a little thrown off when I saw how many non-traditional sushis they offered.  I was very surprised that I enjoyed all of the creative/unique sushi.  I'm usually skeptical because not every place can pull it off.  Its either too saucy or bland, etc.  Theirs was the perfect balance.  

I highly recommend the ceviche, toro tartar, and baby main lobster.
author: Sandy J.

description:
I had dinner here a few years ago, and I am finally getting to the review.  Better late than never I say.  Luckily this restaurant left me with a good enough impression to recall all of the wonderful sushi that I had.  I love that there are a lot of items on the menu to choose from.

The most memorable sushi that I had here was the Scott Handtroo.  I really like spicy tuna hand rolls.  But when you throw in a quail egg...forget about it.  I loved this hand roll a lot.

The Foie Gras Sushi was also unique and tasty.  I love foie gras a lot.  So when you incorporate it into sushi and add raspberry sauce, it just leaves a memorable taste in your mouth.

I also had other sushi, such as Uni Nigiri, Sayori (Pencil Fish), Akamutsu (Black Throat), and the Chirashi-Zushi dinner.  All were good, but I remember not being too impressed with the Akamutsu and the Sayori.  I love ordering Chirashi when I go to a Japanese restaurant.  The Chirashi here was very tasty.  It is one of my favorite Japanese meals.

The reason that I didn't give it five stars was because of a few things...

One, our waitress was not all that nice.  She wasn't totally rude, but it seemed like she could care less whether we were happy or not.  It didn't matter to me so much because I was really into the food.

Two, as good as Kabuto was, I recently had a meal at Sushi Ran and I love that place!  To me, Sushi Ran is the best Japanese Restaurant in the Bay Area, and Kabuto comes in second.  When I compare the two, everything about Sushi Ran is just a little better than Kabuto.  So how could I possibly give Kabuto the same exact score as Sushi Ran.

Either way, if you end up at Kabuto, you won't be disappointed at all.  I can't wait to get a chance to go back to Kabuto and retry the dishes that I have fond memories of.  Hopefully I get to do that soon.
author: Jesus R.

description:
I've been wanting to come here since FOREVER. I was really pleased with everything we ordered, except for the spicy tuna roll (which I have to order EVERYWHERE!) because they placed mint (?) in the roll. The flavor of the mint overpowers the tuna and makes it unappetizing, this is the second place I've been to that does this, I don't know why?

I was really happy with my tuna tekka don, I have never seen tuna so rich in color and fresh! They also had a tuna sampler of different kinds of tuna sashimi on their menu that I was thinking about ordering instead, maybe next time. I didn't try any of their specialty rolls, it would have been too much food. But I'll definitely try the ceviche roll when I return. 

I was pleased with the food and quick service, but the restaurant itself is tiny and cramped. The table next to us was extremely close, I heard everything they talked about all night.
author: Stella C.

description:
1849 oysters- raw oyster with quail egg, uni, various roe topped with gold leaf. Was good to try but too much stuff and couldn't taste it all. Wouldn't order again. 14/pair 

Hirame green apple- hirame with green apple, rolled together with a green leaf of some sort. All the flavors stood out, def would order again! 12/4 pcs

Medai(butterfish) nigiri-cooked butterfish is def better. Couldn't really tell it was a butterfish. 7.5/pair

Toro nigiri- buttery and melts in your mouth. Mmmmmmm. 14/pair

Toro tartare-speaks for itself 5/pair

Valentine- goose liver with unagi and Kabuto chocolate sauce served in a martini glass. Very unique and creative dish. 9

Ceviche-SO SO good. Tastes like cerviche but on top of rice with seaweed. 6/pair

Sammy roll - salmon on the outside, cali roll inside with curry sauce.  Roll with a bit small. 10.

Foie Gras sushi - a bit deceiving, it's not foie gras.  Says goose liver which it may very well be but not foie gras.

In a nutshell, Cerviche, Hirame, Toro tartare were our favs.

Got really crowded after 7pm on a Sat night.
author: Will I A m.

description:
Sushi chef drinks beer all night. You know what that means? He's gooooood. 

Seriously though - really creative dishes, all of which are awesomely tasty. The aburi toro is the best - it's like a party involving explosions of fat on your palate. Fatsplosion.
author: Kevin L.

description: came back here for a 2nd try.  I wanted to try some of their other specials.  this time I tried the albacore'02, hot apple, hamachi miso tartar, and of course, the foie gras sushi in addition to some I tried previously.  my favorite by far is the foie gras sushi, seared marinated goose liver served with balsamic raspberry sauce.  now what kind of mad scientist thought up this concoction.  I was debating between 4 or 5 stars and decided to settle for 4 since I gave them 5 last time around.  this is only because I wanted to try different sushi from last time.  I guess I ordered all the good stuff the first time.  I still want to try their 1849 oysters but I'll have to save up to pay $14 for 2 oysters.
author: Samson M.

description:
We had some guests coming into town and wanted to show them an outstanding sushi experience, and since we had heard amazing things about Kabuto, we made that our destination. 

With 4 weeks' advance notice of our friends' visit to San Francisco, we decided that it would be prudent to book a reservation. I called Kabuto and did so, and they took down our name and number. When we became aware of a slight change of schedule a few weeks later, I called back to adjust our reservation by 15 minutes and add one person. No problem, they said, and made the adjustment.

Fast forward to the Friday evening of our reservation. We arrived at 8:15 to find a completely full restaurant (always a good sign!), but the restaurant staff appeared confused when we told them of our reservation. In response to our queries, they bustled around and seemed to be trying to expedite other dining guests' dinners to accommodate us, but none of the staff actually communicated to us that they knew that we had a reservation and were doing something to get us seated quickly. We started growing a bit agitated by 8:45, at which point I asked them point-blank what was going on. One server told me that "our restaurant doesn't accept reservations", which was clearly inaccurate and was also clearly the wrong answer for a large group that had been waiting more than 1/2 hour past its reservation time. A more senior staffer intervened and told me that they were working to clear a table for us quickly. Hot sake arrived, gratis, and this smoothed things over a bit, but our visiting guests were clearly hungry. 15 minutes later, we were finally seated.

Just as we were seated, a young Japanese/Caucasian couple that had also been waiting the same amount of time that we were finally lost their patience and left the restaurant abruptly, slamming the door behind them and inadvertently shattering the glass. This created some unwelcome drama for everyone and clearly added to the evening's stress (and cost) for the restaurant owners. 

After that point, the evening improved dramatically. Service was impeccable, and the food was equally amazing. Honestly, this is some of the best sushi that my partner and I have had in either San Francisco or Los Angeles, and our guests concurred. It was extremely fresh, elegantly prepared and simply delicious. Wow!

If we had experienced only the food and not the unprepared staff, we would give Kabuto a "5" with no reservations. When they seemed to forget our reservation, then told us that they don't accept reservations, and then seated us finally a full 45 minutes late (9pm), that merited an extremely poor customer service score... perhaps a "2". We'll net out both scoring dimensions and give them a "3" overall. 

We will definitely try Kabuto again, as their amazing food quality overcomes our concerns about the shoddy service experience repeating itself. Hopefully the staff took note of the disastrous way that they handled us (and the couple who left), and will work to improve their reservation handing experience and wait times. If they can get the service dimension right, we'll gladly give them the "5" that their food deserves.
author: Lao Z.

description:
Wow, thank you so much Yelp for turning me onto this place.  I adore sushi, and this place serves some of the best fish and flavor combinations I've had.  It would get 5 stars for the sushi, but we made the mistake of ordering a couple non-sushi items that were subpar, so for that I must sadly dock a star.  

So to get the bad out of the way...the agedashi tofu was really not good.  And for dessert the green tea creme brulee was fine, but the flavor was a little off.  This place is clearly a sushi restaurant.  

But now for the good...we got a ngiri sampler.  Pretty standard options, but boy was the fish fresh and melt-in-your-mouth.  Very nice. We also went for the roll filled with soft shell crab but wrapped in tuna.  Again, very nice, but I think I wouldn't order it if I came back.  Great to try, but not one of the standouts.  I also got a spicy hamachi roll (I usually only see tuna or scallops with a spicy option, so this was kind of fun) and the flavor was really nice, and yes it left my mouth burning a little.  It was great. 

And now for the truly phenomenal...the special rolls.  We only got the ceviche and the toro tartar, but next time I will want to order as many of these specialties as possible.  The flavors and textures were amazing.  The only downside is that at only two items per order, if you've got a big appetite like me, you can wrack up quite a bill, so I suppose I would suggest also ordering some of the non-special rolls that include several pieces of sushi instead of just two.  

This place makes impressive sushi.  Come here for a treat for your palate, but maybe snack beforehand if you plan to stick to a budget.
author: Anne Marie B.

description: I'm a regular at Kabuto.  I am a big fan of their specialty nigiri sushi.  I always order the tuna tartar,hirami yuzu, Scott hand roll, ceviche, and I've recently discovered their toro kama.  It's fattier than hamachi kama, but I love the buttery taste.  Sometimes I will start a convo with the customers next to our table & suggest our favorite dishes. Try to make reservations because you can wait up to 45mins if you go during their busy hours.
author: Jessica L.

description:
update 10-27-2006: 
this is NOT the house that Sachio Kojima built anymore. I sat at the sushi bar on a Friday night. not much eye contact from the chef and nothing in the way of service. I placed my sushi order with the waitress and waited for the sushi dining experience to unfold.
the proper way to serve and eat sushi is from light fish to heavier and more oily fish. just like a wine tasting from white to reds to dessert wine. your palate will appreciate the graduation of flavors. well, not only did I wait 15 minutes for my first nigiri to be handed to me by the old sushi man standing in front of me; it was the hamachi and unagi (eel with sweet teriyaki sauce slathered on top). next plate 5 minutes later was the chu toro (oily fatty blue fin tuna belly). and after another 10 minutes and i receive my remaining white fish sushi (ono, akamutsu, kanpachi).
sushi served completely backwards
the quality of fish was good. not great. especially for these prices. 
I remember as a business student at SFSU coming to Kabuto after night class on regular basis for incredibly fresh sushi crafted by a skilled sushi master with ninja like quickness.
I may have to make a five hour drive to the Mount Shasta area to seek out this master sushi chef's restaurant as a homage to the art and craft of sushi.
Sachio -san you are missed.
http://www.vivifyshasta.com/top.html

*************

in memory of sachio kojima 's wonderful work over the years in the SF sushi community. 5 stars. I haven't been here since he left.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Authentic Japanese style food.
The place is kinda small but very brightly lit and lively. 

try all the little dishes. they are delish
author: Alyssa K.

description:
The best damned sushi I've had with one exception. There's a fishing town in Japan called "Wajima", on the Noto Peninsula that gets freshly caught fish, "right off the boat." That's better than Kabuto. 

But since I don't get out to Wajima that often (!) Kabuto's my go-to place. Kirala in Berkeley is good, too, although it's farther for me. Other than that, I don't really eat sushi around here.

I get whatever is on the fresh list. Never been disappointed. There's raw fish, and then there's sushi--this is the real deal and leaves me feeling great.

Oh, also I go either early or late so I've managed to miss the lines. Did I mention that the prices are very reasonable?
==========
2009 Update: I seem to come here on my birthday--you know, go to the place you really like the most?

Also, I'll let you in on a secret. When I eat here, the fish is so good that I almost cry. But I don't let on to the sushi guys because it's kakkou-warui to cry at the counter.
===========
2010 update: sushi is the drug of choice for M and I. $2.50 for a piece of the most amazing hamachi ever? You've got to be kidding me. Yes I'll have another.

Did I mention that they have fresh home-made ohagi and zen-zai? crazy.
author: Paul K.

description:
A couple of years ago I would have given Kabuto 5 stars. Now I'd say it's just a solid 3.5 stars after the original owner/chef moved to Shasta (http://www.yelp.com/biz/vivify-mt-shasta#hrid:sLfiJ7S2SDXOSBKvKNEVHw).

Still quite tasty, but doesn't seem to have quite the same pop as it once did. That's a bad description . . . maybe it was watching the chef (whose name escapes me now . . .) bounce around like he was on speed or something, maybe it was how the spicy tuna handroll was now assembled vs. before, maybe it was that one piece of nigiri that was a bit off when everything used to be perfect before. Whatever it is, it's just not the same.

I don't think it's just nostalgia. My friends who used to frequent Kabuto with me agree. Above average sushi (with well above average prices), but not the greatness that once was Kabuto.
author: Andrew C.

description: My girlfriend took me to Kabuto for my birthday and I love every dish I tried. THe food is fresh and their creativity on the dish is very different. Many variety of sushi and sashimi and can't find anywhere like it. I have to take pictures on the phone so I know how to order next time when I go back. I went back 3 times already and love it even more each time. You'll not be disappointed.
author: Connie W.

description:
Highly recommended by locals and off the beaten path.  A true "fusion" style sushi house.  

Loved it.  Ceviche was "off the charts" good.

Get there early, it gets busy.  You will like this different style of sushi.  Four stars!!
author: Paul M.

description:
If I had to describe Kabuto in one word - "Amazing". I've always been a fan of sushi and sashimi but eating at Kabuto escalates it to a whole new level. When I visited Kabuto for the first time, I ordered the Ceviche Roll and it rocked my world. I had to be sure it was the sushi and not my hunger that was the exaggerating the superior taste, so I ordered another one at the end of dinner. And sure enough, BOOM! I was officially addicted and still to this day. Writing this review makes me want to go back....  

Bottom Line: 
- Kabuto is Amazing and Ceviche Roll is a must (be prepared to be rocked!)
author: Ryan F.

description:
We ordered a little over $100 worth of food for 2 people. Good thing we had a Yelp deal. 

We ordered: 

uni (sea urchin) - very fresh and perfectly prepared

Masago (smelt roe) - my favorite. Always good. 

Ikura (salmon roe) - the bf liked it

tuna tataki -Basically sashimi with sauce.Huge cuts of fish. Perfect sauce.

ceviche sushi - Different and unique. I liked it but it wasn't as good as I expected.

toro tartar - pretty good but doesn't live up to its hype. Toro is better served nigiri or sashimi style.

Aji sashimi (Spanish mackerel) sashimi - order thish nigiri style.They cut the fish into small pieces for some reason...would've been better as one piece.

Kanpachi sashimi (yellow jack) - it was very fresh but it wasn't to my liking (personal preference)

Akamutsu sashimi (black throat) - We had to try this because we've never seen it at a sushi restaurant before. I recall not liking it. I guess that's what happens when you experiment though.

1849 oysters - As you can see through pics others have posted, this one is a must. The best thing we ordered. BUT...we ordered 6 of them not knowing that they cost $7 EACH. Oh well....can't put a price on bliss right?? This one is not on the menu. Just hope that it's listed on their "specials" board.

Next time, I'll come here and order the usual dishes. Didn't really have much luck experimenting here.

Prices are pretty average for the usual items you always see (i.e. tekka maki, california roll, tataki, poke,etc.). Specials are on the pricey side. This is a good place to go if you really want to experiment with unique dishes and are not a picky eater. Well....then again...you can always go the safe route and order the usual dishes here as well. Either way, everything is very fresh.
author: Angelica P.

description:
Hello sushi! You know I love to see you once a week. I seek you out in various placed and will even randevu  with you when I know I shouldn't. (Like a "pizza and sushi" restaurant in Italy where the staff were Chinese and didn't speak English, Japanese or Italian. Seriously.) 

This place was a wonderfully unique change that tantalized my taste buds while exploring my inner joy sensors. I like trying new things and this, my friends, was a different experience. My first reaction to the first piece of nigiri was,  "What is this jelly like substance? Oh, it's interestingly good is what it is" 

I  like lists-easy to write, easy to read: 
1) Small Place, simple/ nice decor
2) All Japanese staff. All friendly and attentive 
3) Fish was fantastic! 
4) From those of us who love our rolls and to those who are "true" sushi fans, (whatever, I like me my rolls), will enjoy the unique creations this place produces. 
5) Price is on the upper side, but hey, you are paying for the above mentioned. 
6) GREAT date place especially if you are boring, you can talk about the food. 

Note to anyone going to Milan: Don't ever go to a "sushi/pizza place" no matter how desperate you are. Not only did they inform us "we are defrosting the fish" but my friends swore a roach ran across my plate when I was in the bano. I didn't believe them until the little bugger came back to see if our fish was served yet.
author: Kat M.

description:
pretty creative sushi.  the menu is extensive, so it took me a while to decide, but since it was my first time here, i stuck w/ some popular items.  we primarily came for the foie sushi, but i also tried many other interesting items.  i had the hamachi pear, the foie sushi, the ceVIChe, shrimp and crab tartare, the toro tartare, and a special roll that had tempura fish and cucumber inside and a torched salmon on the outside.  each order (other than the roll) came w/ 2 pcs each, and i shared all it w/ a friend.  

2 of our other friends got the $65 omakase, which i didn't think was worth it, because there weren't that many more things than ordering off menu.  i was full from my order, and i only ended up paying $30, including tax and tip.
author: Helen T.

description:
Tiny space but great sushi nonetheless!

We ordered a good amount of food since a friend of mine had a $50 coupon from Yelp.

Foie gras sushi: I wasn't sure about this but it worked. Savory and sweet, although the portions are tiny. It could be a dessert sushi with the raspberry sauce and fresh raspberry on top.

Gomaae: Boiled spinach with sesame dressing.

Osuimono: Soup with enoki mushrooms, clams and tofu.

Shiro maguro

Escolar

Chirashi

1849 oysters: raw oysters topped with caviar and a quail egg, dusted with gold flakes. 

Tuna sampler

Grilled sea bass

All of the items were delicious minus some of the pieces from the tuna sampler.

However, this will not deter me from coming back. There are so many other dishes I would like to try.

Kabuto lands right on my list of favorite sushi places right behind Tataki!
author: Bernadette A.

description:
thanks to yelp for yet another great sushi find. we took the parents here for dinner tonite and they absolutely enjoyed it as much as we did. 

our favorites were:
(*) hamachi pear (we ordered 4 orders of this dish since each order only has 2 pieces)
(*) sake chazuke (grilled salmon on rice mixed with japanese tea broth)
(*) asari sakamushi (steamed asari clams in clear soup and sake)
(*) ankimo sushi
(*) katsunagi (unagi, avocado, and shiso deep fried as katsu served
with kabuto raspberry miso sauce)
(*) kanpachi kama (grilled baby hamachi collar)

we ordered tons more dishes and sake, and the bill only came out less than $35 per person. we will be back!
author: Helen Y.

description:
First impressions are quite important. That said, we ended up waiting 40 minutes to be seated and before that there were 2 Japanese people that were seated before us even though we had reservations. That was actually quite rude if I may say.

The only reason I would come back is for the Foie Gras Sushi because it's one of the only places that has this. When there are other Japanese restaurants with Foie Gras Sushi, I would try them as well.
author: Eric A.

description:
Artistic approach to sushi.  Interesting combos--some work better than other--but they get an A for effort.

I am also a fan of their traditional sushi.  Overall--great quality!

Favorites:
Kasunagi
Ceviche
Toro tartar

Yum approved!
author: Kim C.

description:
I would sell my soul for good food, especially sushi. I would stand on the corner of the street and ask for money while wearing beaten up tattered used clothes. Hey, most of the panhandlers use the money for things that are not food and shelter, why can't I use it for sushi?

When people that help run yelp, like Jessica T. write about how out of this world a place to eat is, I suggest, run don't walk to them. Her taste is impeccable. 

I have had Kabuto saved in my bookmarks to try for over a year, but since the economy dropped and we've now all been working like dirty whores for a dollar, sushi has now turned into an extravagance, instead of a four times a week dinner.

Kabuto on Geary, in my hood actually, is innovative, fresh, amazing.....their food surpasses my dream of sushi. And get this, they have a female sushi chef as well who works to the side of the owner, which is amazing. In Japan, women aren't usually sushi chefs as "their hands are warmer" which isn't ideal for serving fresh cooled fish. She is amazing, with a slight smile she serves us sushi we only dream of when outside of NYC or Vegas. The rolls aren't rolls, they're utter perfection that happen to contain fish and rice. 

Pear and hamachi? Toro and spicy cilantro with fried shiso? You HAVE to be kidding me! Japanese pumpkin delicately fried and placed on amazing rice with perfect seaweed. Their gyoza are homemade, lightly pan fried and are light, flavorful and to DIE FOR!

I almost didn't want to write this because when I go back I don't want some huge wait in this tiny place because everyone in SF now knows about it. See how selfless I am? Im giving up my secret...that's how much I love you...

RUN and don't walk to this place, I don't care if you don't have the money, steal it if you have to. Commandeer a car, take two peoples wallets, and give Kabuto your money. It's worth it, and remember, there's a no chase law in San Francisco, so just speed.
author: Danielle S.

description: Love the sushi at this place.  Always fresh.
author: Lily L.

description: Just moved to the Presidio and found this gem in the area. I lucked out with seating - timing was impeccable because we got seated immediately. Soon after, there was a line out the door! I enjoyed their rolls (hamachi pear, salmon with soft shell crab and unagi with spicy tuna) and must come back to try 1849 oysters and other delectables on the menu!
author: Kit S.

description:
I don't normally like sushi, especially raw stuff, but this is the ONLY place I will eat raw sushi! I never liked wasabi, but I'll only have it here. This is place is LEGIT sushi. Most other sushi restaurants these days only make rolls, but thats the americanized version of real japanese sushi. 

Yes the price is a bit over the top and they sell sushi by the piece, but it's like paying for food-orgasm and beautiful work of art at the same time. Plus I got full off like 8-9 pieces so it was well worth it.
author: Shelly U.

description: One of the better sushi restaurants in SF.  Still a little pricey, but I guess I'm just spoiled by Asia.
author: Jerry W.

description:
table ordered a ton. some of the more memorable dishes:
ceviche - nice citrusy lime flavor, but i actually prefer real ceviche to this sushi version
foie gras - eh...
hamachi pear - hamachi was good, but crunchy pear texture didn't go well
toro - as toro should be
1984 oyster - crazy concoction of oyster, roe, caviar, and urchin; not for the faint heart or weak stomach
salmon crepe sushi - actually surprisingly good, very savory

overall, this place is creative, but i prefer the traditional stuff

service isn't the best either. it took forever to order and get our check. the waitress had a very heavy difficult to understand accent and was completely unapologetic about it. had a few orders missed and a few extra orders brought. yea, like i said.. not the best. she's just lucky we had a table of pretty easy going diners.
author: Debbie Chiou S.

description:
It's shocking that the 2 best sushi places in the city are within a block of each other (Ariake being the other). I waited to yelp Kabuto until I had a chance to go back a few times, because I was in a slight state of shock at just how good it is. 

First of all, the fish. I dare you, challenge you, look at pity upon, anyone who says they can find better tasting fish. The quality, and absurd freshness of the fish is something to try this place for alone. I could happily just eat Nigiri/Sashimi here until my stomach exploded. But if you did that you would be missing out on some of the most creative sushi "dishes" that you will find. 

And no I'm not talking about traditional "wild rolls" (I'm really over rolls in general at this point). But just insanely creative dishes. The ceviche "roll" comes as 2 pieces of halibut topped with "salsa" on rice, sitting on a large piece of seaweed (which you use as a "wrapper" to eat the dish), and is fantastic. Really amazing flavors. Most of their "rolls" on the special sushi menu come prepared in a similar fashion, 2 pieces that are just fantastic. Try the Hot Apple, Toro Tartare & Hamachi Pear. 

Sit at the Sushi Bar and watch a true master at work. Initially put off by my first visit to the Sushi Bar, because of the annoyed looks we got when asking "what is that (with an Ooh, and Aaahh)", on subsequent trips I realized that it is like disturbing a master painter who is mid stroke and asking "so what is that going to be". Just sit back and enjoy watching them work. 

Though you can get out of here without breaking the bank, it is very easy to do so as well. Be forewarned, for just o'girl and I, I have paid upwards of $200 for a meal. As the sake flows, and your taste buds drown out the part of your mind adding up the cost, it is easy to get carried away. If you walk in knowing that, you won't walk out pissed. 

I cannot recommend a place higher. Simple as that.
author: Andrew M.

description: I ate plenty of sushi and in Kabuto, what stands out the most for me is their foie gras sushi, hamachi pear, and most definitely 1849 oyster. It is amazing how they combine all the ingredients and make it blend into a magnificent taste without one overpowering the other too much. I'll definitely be coming back to this place soon!
author: Philip T.

description:
What can i say about this place except that its so good I've become a frequent flyer at Kabuto. I come here so often the waitress knows my basic order (foie gras, 1849 oysters) by heart. I'm always greeted by an enthusiastic, "hi! how are you!" With that said, service is always awesome. 

As for the food: Kabuto is like no other place in the city. Where else would you have oysters topped with salmon roe, tobiko, uni, and edible gold? I kid you not. When I have the 1849 oysters, it takes me to a happy place and my dining companions know not to disturb me. I could write an essay on the 1849 oysters but I'll make it simple, the sweetness of the uni compliaments the oyster so that the oyster is sweet. The popping of the tobiko and salmon roe in your mouth makes the consumption experience full of surprises and fun. And the edible gold just makes things look pretty. All my senses are challenged at every corner with this dish. The foie gras sushi is simply fantastic when augmented by the lovely raspberry sauce. 

Other honorable mentions: toro tartare, ceviche (listen to the waitress and DONT put soy sauce on this-or it will defeat the purpose of it being called 'the ceviche'), the valentine (foie gras + unagi), baby maine lobster roll, sunrise (tobiko wrapped with fresh salmon topped with a quail egg), bonito tuna and anything on the nigiri specials board is great. The fish are fresh.  There are some things like the uni or ankimo where I've had better but it is still superb here. Plus I'm a bit of a uni snob so I've got insane expectations for my uni.

I don't recommend that you order the plain 'ol rolls or else you'd just be wasting the experience and your yelp complaining about lame things like how bad the parking is that don't pertain to the dining experience.  I also don't reccomend the sonoma duck sushi unless you're in love with wasabi. Wasabi's awesome but damn that one really suprised me with the insensity of the wasabi. I think it may have opened up new sinuses that anatomically do not exist. Also, yes it is pricy but fair (typically a piece of foie gras cost bank at any other restaurant for something much smaller than what they offer at kabuto). So it is reasonable for the quantity and quality of the food. One more thing, notice that there's 1,2,3 dollar signs so you were fore-warned.

In conclusion: give this place a try if you like innovation and want something more than the over-saturated with mayo rolls at the typical sushi place. It has, has to say the least, become my friends and I's monthly (sometimes bi-weekly) guilty pleasure.
author: Wendy L.

description: Has grown to become my favorite sushi spot in the city. Great service and prices, and high quality fish. Begin with a few hamachi pear nigiri's and steamed seaweeds and branch out from there.
author: Nick C.

description:
Great selection of fresh fish. The restaurant is small, so make reservations ahead of time. One of the few japanese restaurants that are 
creative, inventive, and combines fusion of flavors and techniques to a dish. A MUST TRY! Ask and see what the specials are and try the different combinations!
author: Foodie F.

description: When I walked in, I worried that the place would be mediocre at best.  The decor, the lighting, the storefront, all were very stripped-down - almost unattractive.  The food was amazing, and the service was spectacular.  My only criticism is that their sake and wine prices were high.  The sushi itself was the best and most creative I have ever had.
author: K. M.

description:
Yes this place deserves the 4 star rating! Unfortunately, I can't give it the 5 star rating because it is rather pricey. Yes - I know you get what you pay for yada yada....but seriously you can really eat yourself into bankruptcy if you're not paying attention. 

I make no bones about it that when I am hungry - I can seriously eat a lot. For those of you who are heavy eaters - my advice is to eat something before you go here and after you leave. The sushi tends to be on the small size but I do understand it's more for looks and the experience. I call these type of restaurants "appetizer" restaurants. 

Ok so onto what we had: Sunrise, Ceviche, Toro Tartare, Foie Gras sushi, and the Hamachi Pear. Was it good? Mostly. The Foie Gras sushi does live up to all the high praises by my fellow yelpers. Same goes for the Toro Tartare and the Hamachi with pear. I would skip the Sunrise dish. The salmon was fresh but I think the egg yolks on top were a little too much for my palate. 

I would definitely go back but only on special occasions. I could easily go broke eating here too often. Betcha you are wondering if we went out for dinner after Kabuto huh? Answer is ....yes we did...
author: Cris H.

description:
This place is pretty pricey, but worth it if someone else is paying for you. The place is small, and they seriously need to hire more staff. I had called and made reservations, but looks like there is no such thing as reservations here. The wait was almost half an hour...

The foie gras sushi here is TO DIE FOR.  The sashimi is fresh, and the other specials are pretty tasty, like hamachi pear. But really...its all about the foie gras sushi. 

If you know the owner or someone on staff, you get hook ups. A couple that came in before us knew someone, and got seated before us. ROWR.
author: Carol L.

description:
I'm not a sushi expert, as I don't eat fish, but the sushi lovers I've eaten with here have loved it.

It's also great for a non-sushi lover. The nabeyaki udon is delicious, as are the tamago and avocado roll and agedashi tofu. None of the non-fish items are necessarily too spicy or vinegary.

A bit pricey but not outrageous. Come early (5:00-6:00 PM) to avoid long waits. You can also make reservations.
author: Al Y.

description: Not your typical Japanese restaurant. Very creative and fresh sushi. The presentation and service are good too. We have been there a few times and absolutely love the food there! Quite possibly our favorite sushi place in the city.
author: Elaine B.

description:
The best sushi in San Francisco! It might look like a whole in the wall type of restaurant from outside, but the food and the presentation are amazing! 

My favorites are Hamachi Pear and Ceviche. 

I grew up in Japan, so you can really trust me on this one! Don't go there and expect to get a Chicken teri or California roll. Their food is authentic, yet very unique and sophisticated!

 *MAKE A RESERVATION!*
author: meri o.

description: Didn't think to make reservations since it was a Sunday night but couldn't be more wrong the place was packed, after waiting outside in the cold for 30 min we were seated, mainly because we were a party of 2. The wait was worth it, delicious, fresh, and out of the box. My mom used to own a Japanese restaurant so the bar is set pretty high, I really enjoyed this place.. You gotta try it..
author: Linda Z.

description:
Last night I had meant to go to Old Shanghai, one of my staple Chinese restaurants in San Francisco.  Unfortunately, they are closed on Tuesdays, so I figure I'd try Kabuto a few doors down.  I always see a lot of people, and I have heard good things about it.  So I thought, why not?

The decor is a bit nicer inside than I thought it would be, which I suppose is a plus.  I looked through the menu and really didn't find that much to be excited about.  I hadn't read the Yelp reviews before going, so I didn't know what they were known for.  Now that I have read other reviews, I'm feel a little cheated since many of those items seemed to be available yesterday.  Maybe I'll go back one day, but here is why it probably it won't happen:

1) We ordered a sushi dinner, the sea bass, the chicken karaage and a seaweed salad for two moderately hungry women.  I asked if that sounded like an appropriate amount for us, and she gave me a condescending look.  Unappreciated...
2) The fish was okay, but really not that fresh at all.  It looked like something I could have gotten at some third-rate sushi place...  It was fresh enough that I wouldn't get sick, but that's about it.
3) Prices are really unreasonable given the freshness.  I may have order the sushi dinner, so it won't be as fresh as a la carte orders, but I still paid $19 for what should have been a $13 set dinner.  I didn't think anyone else's fish looking that much fresher anyway.
4) Seaweed salad was Asian fusion in a bad way.  Mixed greens, with same seaweed that they use in the miso soup, with little to no vinaigrette.  Not my idea of a tasty Japanese treat.

We had enough to eat, and the bill came out to about $45-$50 for two people.  Totally not worth it.  I like fusion as much as the next person, but I expect top quality fish for the price.
author: Fontane L.

description:
I've been recently coming back to this place, so it's time for an update...

Creativity: 5 stars.  Granted, most of the food here is fusion, not traditional sushi, but they do things with sushi I've never seen anywhere else, and they pull it off almost every time.

Quality: 4 stars (based an sashimi/nigiri).  This doesn't necessarily mean quality has suffered since my first post 4 years ago- it probably just means I've had better cuts to compare it to.  BTW, The monkfish liver was excellent.  

Some things I wasn't impressed with: the tuna carpaccio special- the cuts were the thickest I've seen for a dish like this, and the olive oil was so pungent that it distracted from the fish instead of blending with it.  The hand roll with the quail egg was really messy.  I also wasn't impressed with the crab nigiri.

Not that this changes the rating, but I love it when the sake menu shows the labels.  :)
author: Rego S.

description:
Pros: 
They have a large menu so plenty to choose from. 
Great sushi and presentation. 
Servers are attentive. 
Unique combination of flavors in their creations. 

Cons: 
Pricey. 
Sushi bar chefs has zero interaction with customers. 
Small place. 
Hard to find street parking. 

Bottom line is the food is good so if you want good sushi, give them a try.
author: Elaine L.

description:
I was taken here by some friends this week and was oh so pleasantly surprised. The rolls are served in 2 piece portions, so the bill can be a little steep in the end, but ohhhhhh, its worth it! The freshest fish I have tried and such unique presentation and classic, clean, and perfectly balanced flavor combinations. I think it is probably the closest thing I have tried that reminds me of actually being in Japan. I will be back as soon as I can afford it!
Note: The parking is atrocious, so plan to arrive 20 minutes early. circling & circling & circling...
author: Brittany T.

description:
We gorged ourselves here over dinner for under $50/pp. For sushi that's pretty damn amazing. Came with a regular who ordered what seemed like everything on the menu, I'll try to list it all here:
Ceviche: Delicious, with just a hint of citrus
Crepe Sushi Salmon: Gross, but I don't like cream cheese in my rolls. Everyone else loved it.
Hirame Jerry: Not a fan of the Ponzu Jelly but everything else about this roll was great. If I had to choose between this and Yuzu though, Yuzu wins.
Hirame Yuzu: Great roll with a very spicy kick to it. Beware!
Toro Tartar: One of my favorite rolls, but it's Toro how could you not love it?
Salmon Skin Roll: Meh, decided that I officially don't like salmon skin.
Spicy Tuna Roll: Nothing special, solid spicy tuna roll.
Tazuna Roll: The mackerel was way too fishy for me, I had a hard time even finishing 1 piece.
New York Steak: Can't eat this but everyone at the table loved it
Soba Noodles: meh, found this a little disappointing compared to everything else. I think it was the only dish we didn't finish.
Escolar: This was DELICIOUS. Except, I just googled Escolar to find that it's been banned in Japan and Italy and is considered "toxic". That explains the stomach pain after dinner. Won't be eating that again!
Agedashi tofu: SO DELICIOUS, I wish I had more than 1 bite of this. The tofu tastes amazing in this broth, if you go, order this!
Tempura Ice Cream in Vanilla & Green Tea: Yummy!

Loved the tea that was served throughout dinner, I think we went through at least 6 pots of it. Solid restaurant with a lot of great unique dishes. Would definitely come back and try the other half of the menu!
author: Joy B.

description:
A friend recently introduced me to Kabuto, specifically for the foie gras sushi.  OMG YUMMMM!! Definitely one of the BEST things I have ever eaten.  Salty and Sweet at it's best!! So many flavors that just keep coming.  Everything on their menu is DELICIOUS.  Kabuto has jumped to the top of list.  Instantly became one of my favorite restaurants.  So good, I went back a few day later and ate almost the same things.
The sashimi is fresh and delicious.  The specials are AMAZING!! The favors are complex and extraordinary.  
Most of the time you find a restaurant that does fusion well OR sashimi well.  Kabuto takes it to a new level.  Their traditional foods are delicious, their fusion/ New Japanese(?) is EXTRAORDINARY.

A little pricey, but WORTH EVERY PENNY!!
author: Tim W.

description: EVerytime this place just make my night. its great becasue they are open pretty late. I stay until midnight sometimes. Making reservations is defiantly a must if you plan on going here, the wait wont be to bad. But trust me. The sushi here has a very good quality, taste fresh, clean, flavorful. The dishes are presented very well.
author: David T.

description:
Kabuto received a 14/20 from Gayot, and I was in the mood for a top-of-the-line sushi bar that I had not already visited, so I tried it out for lunch today.  The interior is simple and welcoming with its yellow walls.  A chorus of "irrashaimase!" greeted us, which is always encouraging.

The waitress was very pleasant, and while the two itamae were friendly 'enough,' they weren't nearly as charming or gregarious as Tommy, Suzuki, or Isa over at Ebisu.  Guess I'm just spoiled by the best and the brightest.

Unfortunately, one of the first impressions of the place was the tiring and inauthentic practice of involving a waitress to take the order when I am sitting only three feet from the itamae.  This trend is horrible and must be killed!

I told the waitress that I wanted the chef to serve sashimi omakase style, but that I did not want the plate to include bluefin tuna.  "It's a fixed plate," she said.  I told her that I still didn't want any bluefin tuna on the plate, so she suggested that I choose from the a la carte side of the menu, which is practically the opposite of omakase.

Finally, the sushi chef intervened, and from that moment on, my experience improved dramatically (why couldn't we have just started this way?!?).  He asked me questions, I and my boyfriend asked him questions, and we were off to the fresh-fish races!

About the menu.  There were all kinds of fish I had never heard of, which is pretty exciting for a sushi lover.  Items like akamutsu (black throat seaperch) and bachi maguro (big-eye tuna).  Eric, the younger of the two itamae, served us plates with sashimi cuts of shiro maguro, sunazuri, hirame, something called Tasmanian salmon, which was a soft, succulent variation on ordinary sake, and shima aji (confusing, since the menu says it's amberjack, right next to kampachi, which is the traditional name for...amberjack).

About the fish.  The coolers were stocked with lots of fish, which is a good sign, as it suggests that they have a high-volume business and fish won' t sit around for very long at all.  Everything except the big-eye and escolar popped with freshness, and all slices were served at the proper temperature -- not too cold.  Particularly excellent was the hamachi belly, the Tasmanian salmon, and the shima aji.  I've had better shiro maguro, but Kabuto's was good.  Unfortunately, they were out of ono (which I've never had) and kohada.

About the service.  Service was excellent.  I drink tons of water during a meal -- the waitress was all over it.  I didn't care to receive a Western lettuce salad, lukewarm miso, and rice *before* my first bite of fish, so I ignored them.  While waiting for my sashimi, I poured a bit of soy sauce into its little bowl.  Within seconds, the waitress snatched the bowl away and replaced it with another, filled with an identical liquid. "Sashimi soy sauce," she said, and marched away.  I learned later that sashimi soy sauce has more salt and more of a soy flavoring.  I did notice that it was saltier, but I wonder why this is desirable, whether it's traditional, and why I had never encountered this odd sauce anywhere else?

I give it only 3 stars because I need to go back for another meal before I can consider upping that score to 4 or 5.  I think it's a tribute to the promise of Kabuto that I am very interested in eating there again.
author: Andrew L.

description: Top 5 sushi I've had in New York, San Francisco, Philly and LA.  We're lucky enough to live 2 blocks from this spot.  I cannot recommend it highly enough.  Incredibly fresh, inventive and unique sushi and desserts that take it a few steps above your typical sushi spot.  Service is really quick, not overly friendly (they turn tables over pretty fast because it gets so busy) but we really don't care.  We're just there to indulge in amazingness.
author: Sarah S.

description: Awesome meal! We will definitely be back soon. I thought that the caviar/truffle sushi was my favorite bite of the night, but the foie gras piece was the highlight for my husband. The sashimi was perfect as well.  Great neighborhood spot with fantastic service and excellent cuisine.
author: Sara C.

description:
Not bad. Better than I expected. A few things I didn't like: 
1) sushi chef doesn't talk to you / take your order... The waitress does at the sushi bar
2) I ordered chefs choice sashimi and sushi. Whatever he thought was good that day. Sashimi and sushi came out in an order I wasn't expecting. Usually it's from light to heavier tastes. 

Fairly good sake selection. Had "mu" and was very easy to drink. Even for a sake amateur like myself.
author: Lucy A.

description:
no better way to celebrate the end of foie gras in california than here

preparation//
street parking! and MAKE RESERVATIONS or you'll have to wait like all the other starving fools!

ambiance//**
good for small groups and casual dining

service//***
for how busy they are, the waitstaff is very efficient
but slightly brash when they set dishes down and say "don't add soy sauce!!!"
sillie people, traditonalists would know to leave the ponzu sauce alone and the n00bs will just ignore and eat it the way they like anyway xD

food//****
very creative in all their sushis...half our table ordered a number of their rolls from ceviche to hamachi pear...and the other half had omakase (a STEAL @ $65/person!)

omakase ranged from the traditional nigiri and hirame sashimi to the creative foie gras nigiri & 1849 oyster (fresh oyster + roe + quail egg + caviar + gold flakes = DECADENCE?!?)

definitely try their a la carte desserts!
tempura ice cream is skillfully fried...there's no thick battered crust ...just the simple scoop of vanilla in a golden crispy shell~

zenzai is a traditional dessert w/ rice cakes served in read bean soup =9

~*~
i would give 3.5 *twinkles* if i could~
even though the foie gras nigiri is n/a, the other stuff is yummy~ ;p

*bonus* you never know who you'll run into here! i had a pleasant encounter w/ an old acquaintance!^^
author: Donna S.
