description: This is what you get when you have chefs that are not traditionally trained in sushi/Japanese buy a Nobu's cookbook and try imitating it.  They don't know the first thing about delicate tastes and plaster thick sauces all over fish of all kinds.  Had the omakase menu.
author: woojin k.

description:
I used to go to this Japanese Restaurant about 10 years ago because it had the best variety and freshest fish.  Unfortunately, I stopped visiting San Francisco and had a long hiatus.  I returned a couple of weeks ago, not remembering the name but sort of remember the location.  We drove up Geary looking for it on the right hand side of the road -- I was sure I would recognize it.  Ultimately, while continuous searching Yelp for local Japanese restaurants I remembered the name (omoidashimashita) but the restaurant was on the other side of the street.  My confusion, I thought, but soon learned that they moved about eight years ago.

Well, I wasn't disappointed.  The sashimi was as good as I remembered.  Interesting cuts of fish and definitely fresh.  I even had a discussion with the the itamae about the quality of uni (my favorite), having thought that uni from San Diego was the best (I'm from San Diego).  To my surprise he convinced me that it isn't as good as it used to be!

In any case, I highly recommend this place if you are an aficionado.
author: Louis R.

description:
I think this is the best sushi I've ever had in San Francisco...maybe the best sushi I've ever had in my life. IThe food served here makes you feel like you should be in a four-star restaurant with waiters crumbing your table. 

We rolled in on Saturday for lunch and tried the omakase menu. We were served about 10 different dishes before we begged for mercy. Each item was unique and delish. Notable mentions: fois-gras sushi, the 1849 - a veritable party in your mouth, jalapeno hamachi, and lobster tail sushi, just to name a few.

It's a drive if you're not in the area, but COMPLETELY worth it.  A word of caution - they're not cheap, but you do get what you pay for.
author: T. B.

description:
I was not impressed with this place at all. I came here about a year ago. Parking around here is the worst. I was running late and joined family who had already ordered and actually eaten too. There menus are trying to be high class; a one sheet menu with a item and a short description, but no price. 

It took a long time to even get myself a menu. And while we were waiting, had a dozen people staring down at us as they were waiting for their tables. The tables and floors wasn't that clean for a restaurant. 

And when the bill came, really overpriced for the quality of the food and service.
author: M C.

description:
Was looking for a decent place to have dinner last week, and thanks to one of Nobu K's hilarious but insightful reviews, gave Kabuto a shot. After a life-changing trip to Japan a year ago, I've been longing for food even half as good as their domestic restaurants, with little success.

Prompt seating for dinner (although they sat a party of two at the bar despite plenty of vacant tables; would have preferred a small table to help with conversation), and a good ratio of servers to customers kept wait times short. The place isn't particularly well decorated to evoke ideals of Japanese cuisine--maybe more like a 60s diner than anything--but I'm no interior designer; I go to eat, not gawk at the walls.

I had a prime seat in front of the senior chef; it was a pleasure to watch his skill and attention to detail. As a proud obsessive-compulsive person, I totally loved watching the chef plate the food, arranging the fish, rolls, or sprigs of greens and then slightly tweaking them to be "just right". Of course the same seat also bolstered my embarrassment whenever my clumsy paws wouldn't pick up or hold onto something quite right. It's no formal place, but I like to respect the chef's artistry just the same. 

All of that is well and good, what really counts is the food. Luckily, Kabuto pleasantly surprised. So many places serve tiny sushi and charge top dollar for it. Not here. The nigiri were full-sized with a plump bit of fresh fish on top; much like I remember overseas. Hamachi wa oishikatta desu; melting in my mouth. A couple of the rolls were fancier (and more slender) than necessary, but delicious just the same. Finishing things off with some inari and tamago was perfect; both good sized and not too sweet (too much syrup and sweetness is common). Didn't scrutinse the bill, but I'm pretty sure the large cups of tea were complimentary. A full meal for two including tax and tip for under 60 bucks; well worth it for the quality.

Service was polite and thorough; everyone including the chefs greet customers as they walk in (irasshaimase!) and thank them when leaving.

Bottom line: A quaint little shop that serves some of the most authentic sushi I've ever had in the states. Healthy portions that might seem a bit higher than average price but worth it for both quantity and quality; attentive service... I will definitely come back for dinner, or even try to check out their lunch offerings.
author: Aaron H.

description:
I have found my favorite japanese restaurant and its here!! KABUTO! This place is amazing. Not only is the presentation pretty, each dish is out of the world! I ate there four times last week. YES, FOUR TIMES!! And mind you, this place isn't cheap either. 

Must get
1. 1849 oysters
2. Toro tartare
3. Sunrise
4. Scott's handroll
5. Ceviche
6. Live scallop
7. Hamachi Kama
8. Katsunagi 


Expect your tummy to thank you and your wallet to cry.
author: Jenny K.

description:
From the outside (and even on the interior) it looks like your generic sushi spot but the food here is AWESOME!
It has become a go-to place for me and my friends and I recommend it to anyone from out of town looking for some authentic sushi. 
I have never had a roll here I didn't like- make sure to try a few from the "specialty menu". The Hamachi Pear is a MUST!
It's a small place so I wouldn't recommend this for parties bigger than 4.
author: Maggie M.

description:
Best Sushi I've had in the bay area by far.  So good.  Words cannot describe.  I would recommend the Chef's choice Kaiseki meal.  You'll get a ton of crazy good sushi you'd probably never try on your own.

Eat here!
author: J B.

description:
Eating at Kabuto is a spiritual experience. There are no words to describe how amazing this sushi is. My favorite is the fire salmon roll and the ceviche. 

The fish is so fresh, and the flavors so amazing that when I leave I am already thinking about the next time that will be going. 

The restaurant is not very big and does get crowded, but if you go when they open for dinner you'll have no problems being seated. The service is good and the staff is very friendly. 

If you are a sushi lover, I highly recommend a trip to Kabuto.
author: Ashley Y.

description:
Hands down, BEST SUSHI RESTAURANT IN THE CITY. Yes, I said it.

Not only is it authentic, the quality of the fish is so fresh, it melts in your mouth like lukewarm butter.  The feeling I get when it travels down my throat and into my stomach is equivalent to a fat kid finally eating his first piece of cake after a long summer of fat camp.  It is seriously THAT good.

Don't be afraid to go crazy and order random items off the menu.  We did and we were not disappointed.  

Enjoy! but don't gasp when you see your bill =/

Oh and parking is atrocious during dinner time.
author: Lisa W.

description: For the first time going to this restaurant I had the worst service!!  The waitress was inadequate. We waited 30min just to get water. After sitting down the waitress had such a bad attitude. We had a mixup the Order that we placed and was pointing in our face lime we were criminals.  The food was thrown at us. I know it was busy but good service should always be given.
author: samuel p.

description: I've been here twice now.  The first experience was mediocre at best.  I gave it another try and loved it!!  The sushi on their specials is where it's at.  You have to try that.  The quality of the fish is fresh and the presentation is great!  Their seared toro with foie gras nigiri was amazing.  But I won't get it again because I read what they do to ducks and felt bad eating it.  It is amazing, but not at the expense of what the poor ducks have to endure so that we can eat this.  I think it should be banned everywhere.  It's horrible!  Anyway, back to the restaurant.  I think it's definitely worth a try and I will be coming back here.
author: M. T.

description:
With the line that went out the door, it's pretty obvious that this is a place where the chef's got the customers in the palm of his sushi-making hands. He knows you'll wait, he knows you'll pay, and he's pretty sure you'll come back eventually.

Anways, for the price and the massive flavor, you really only need 3 or 4 dishes to be completely satisfied. My party went all out, but came back with this consensus.

Ceviche.

1849 oysters.

Alaskan salmon (one of the specials) was BUTTER.

Maybe the foie gras, but I've found that that's not exactly my thing.

and last but not least, Asahi Kuronama Beer.

If you don't want to wait, just come when they open. I've found that to be a pretty good solution for busy restaurants in general. Or you know, make a reservation.
author: Lucia C.

description: I love Kabuto! we got the ceviche, toro roll and also the foie gras sushi. Altogether, a very enjoyable experience. Service was good. the only thing I would say is there wasn't much food for the price, but if you take it as is, it's an awesome mix of flavors.
author: Ellin C.

description:
i havent been here in a few years.  i guess last time i ordered some hot food which isnt as good as their sushi.  their sushi is sooo good.

on their wall is a huge mural that says resume in katagana i think.  before they had a mural that said risen from the dead in kanji.  i heard it was in reference to the old restaurant that they had across the street that didnt do too well.  i am guessing the resume just means to keep doing what theyve been doing.  and they do it well.

we sat at the sushi bar with no wait.  it was fun watching them do their meticulous works of art.  hijiki salad was a bit too salty.  oden was ok.  sushi amazing!  1849 oysters had all their most decadent ingredients on it - quail egg, caviar/tobiko (red, black, orange), gold flakes, uni, ikura.  it was definitely a flavor party in my mouth.  sweet. tasty.  and i dont even like oysters.  abalone sashimi - so good!  live scallop - they did small little nigiris then they made a little mayo thingy with the sides of the scallop.  the ikura was definitely more fresh than most ive had.  they were 'crispy' not soggy.

overall a great great sushi experience.
author: claudia y.

description: I really love this place for their innovative spin on sushi.  Fois gra is a must try!  I do recommend going there at lunch time and be the first so your food comes out first while others are hungrily waiting, hehe!   I would order oysters in a heart beat, just melts in your mouth.  I Can't wait to go back again!
author: Tessa M.

description:
Amazingly fresh fish and terrific "specialty" sushi - such as the delightful hamachi pear and crunchy sushi.  And for patrons who aren't fans of raw fish, their sukiyaki and gyoza and other cooked items are also delicious.

One piece of advice - get a table near the back if you can.  When the front door opens, a cold wind usually blows in and those near the front of this tiny place bear the brunt.
author: Tom B.

description: This place is really authentic and their food is amazing. The only downside to it is that it IS pretty pricey, however, the quality of the food is very up to par. You definitely get what you pay for. When I went, my friends and I ordered a LOT of hamachi dishes, all of which were really good. You should definitely give this place a try if you feel like splurging on something worthwhile.
author: Leslie C.

description: Good quality sushi in a casual environment. Our party of six dined here on a Saturday night and the restaurant was not too crowded but filled up by 8:30pm. Half our table ordered the $65/person taster menu and all seemed to love the items. My sushi/sashimi dinner (not the taster menu) was quite good and filling.  Pretty friendly waitstaff that were helpful and efficient.
author: Kent W.

description: One of the best sushi restaurants in the bay! hands down! Although the price is a bit higher than other restaurants but you just can't beat the quality of the fish/food they serve here. I have been here three times and enjoyed every bite of it. Some of my favorites are - ceviche, hamachi pear, toro and spicy scallop roll.
author: Charlene L.

description: Since their move across the street several years back these guys definitely have a defined art to their food - and you do pay for it. Great for an occasional splurge. Love how this used to be an old little diner found new life as a Japanese eatery. Crazy good but 'spensive  when there/s more than a few others in the neighborhood. What am I saying?!? There's more Japanese eateries than Starbucks out here!
author: Tristan C.

description: I love this place. Don't let appearances fool you (the restaurant exterior looks like an outdated cheap diner). They have such a uniquely creative and tasty selection of sushi, fresh ingredients, and the green tea macha creme brulee is amazing.
author: Amy M.

description:
They have sushi(s) ( i.e ceviche, tuna tartare) here that don't need to be dipped in soy sauce& wasabi and still tasted AMAZING.... that's like MAGIC! I saw a plate of hamachi with pear OMG.... If only I wasn't too full... " I'll be back". 
        BTW.. the pricing for nigri... is PER sushi... not 2 like 99.9% of sushi restaurants... yes, that means you will be racking up a pretty pricey bill. So if you are gonna bring someone here, make sure they are worth it like a REALLY REALLY good friend, or your LOVER! JK....
author: Lisa M.

description:
So after all the hype and hear-say, I finally made it to this place.  Once we walked in, there were 2 open tables, 1 all the way in the back and 1 directly in front of the door on a cold windy night.  Guess which table the waitress told us that's available?  She told us to sit down on the one directly in front of the door.  Really?  Luckily, the other waitress then told us to sit at the other table in the back.  Ok...I'll let that one slide.  After we sat down, they dropped 7 menus on our table: 3 of the regular menu, 2 of the special sushi menu, and 2 of the alcohol menu, so we had a bit of an issue getting the right menus to look at.  10 minutes went by and you would think they would first give you tea, but had to ask for tea.  Another 10 minutes went by and still no tea.  We ordered the fois gras sushi, fire salmon roll, dragon roll, tuna with soft shell crab, and spicy hamachi.  The first dish was the fois gras sushi and it was ok...tried it and wouldn't order it again, because it didn't have the "Wow factor" for me to say "Wow!  I gotta come back and order this next time".  The 2nd dish was the fire salmon roll and this was probably the best salmon roll I've ever had, but had to use my chopsticks to split the rolls into the separate pieces, because the seaweed was still attached between the pieces.  Then came the dragon roll and it was ok and again had to use my chopsticks to fully separate the seaweed between pieces.  The tuna with soft shell crab was not good.  The soft shell crab tasted old and soggy as if it was cooked in the morning and guess what???...had to separate the pieces again.  The spicy hamachi was pretty good and guess what???  No, didn't have to separate the pieces on this one, because these were standing vertically where they had to separate the seaweed.

Conclusion...overall was ok, but the service was terrible and what sushi place doesn't fully separate their rolls???  Even the worst sushi restaurants out there would ensure all the sushi pieces are separated, but for Kabuto to have the seaweed still attached to pretty much all our rolls is a big disappointment and shameful to all sushi owners.  My first impression of this place isn't what all the reviews said it would be and would never ever choose this place for sushi.
author: Hung Wai M.

description:
I mean, seriously. If you like to put slimy things in your mouth, this is the best place in the city to do so.

Doesn't sound appetizing? Then just focus on the freshest fish, carefully and beautifully prepared by a handful of legit sushi chefs. Omakase at $65 is a trip. I prefer to gather my courage and order nigiri à la carte--you get to control what you order in term of $$$$, and can experiment with the special/daily catch side of things.

The final damage was around $100 for two and we were walking a few inches higher off the ground. If you like rolls and other pastiches, save your money and go somewhere else. If you like fresh fish, monkfish liver, uni, and abalone...come here.
author: Giacomo F.

description: This is my favorite sushi place in the city. I have been trying different places, but this place still has the best fresh fish! They have a lot creative, fancy sushi. If you are into that, you have to try the 1849 Oysters. The traditional nigiris offered are my all time favorite. Those nigiris are straight up not fancy, but really really fresh and tasty. The sea urchin just melts in your mouth. Plus, the sushi chefs are very friendly and nice.
author: Sally P.

description:
Good Chinese Sushi Chef.
But,
I got my original Kabuto review removed.
It was 4 star.
But, I tell you this.
This place is really good for Gai-Jin. You can French-kiss inside.
Call me dickhead but I had better. I still like Japanese Sushi Chef's if I gotto pay 50 bucks.
So, I won't go back here again, Why should I? period.

So, Get this. 
The First Female Sushi Chef in the city! 
And she is Japanese. 
But the main chef is Chinese guy who used to work for old Kabuto when Kabuto was cross the street. 
The old Kabuto was owned by a good Japanese sushi chef. But I don't want to talk about the old Kabuto because it's a really sad story. The original Kabuto's sushi chef has been moved and  own a sushi bar up in the Napa or somewhere in north. 
Anyway. 

I ordered, all Nigiri, Shima Aji Katsuo Tataki Bachi Maguro Shime-Saba with thin sliced KonBu was nice touch! Hirame Ika Tamago + a small Yebisu Beer + tax= 43.40.

It's all done by the Non-Japanese Asian Male sushi chef. 
Nice slice, well-prepared Katsuo, Shime-Saba were good. 
Sushi-rice was decent, a bit hard, not a over "sweeted". 
The only thing bothered me was that the size of the Nigiri were a bit too small for me. The means that the place is focus on Non-Japanese customers, Not a hard core Japanese Sushi eaters. 

I still read reviews that girls sayin' too much rice even though the girl has such a big mouth can take 2 BJ at once! 
I was once sat right next to 2 girls ordering Temaki with no rice.
The sushi chef was Japanese asked her back twice "No rice?"
WhatThe FXXX?
The most important part of SUSHI is how to prepare GOOD-Sushi-RICE. and Good Fish. 

And sure enough, there was a white-couple came in, The dude was looked like bold head version of the original Maxwell Smart ( Get Smart ) 40's FiDi kind guy. His date, she had long dirty blond, Tall and ugly, BigRed lips Miss Piggy. Soon after they sat by the counter, they started deep-French-kissing each other. 
Ugh! 
Do the Ugly FXXXin' French-Kiss OUTSIDE! 
FXXXin' idiots!
WHATTHE HELL you think where you are in? 
It's a SUSHI BAR here.
What a ignorant. 

I take SUSHI BAR as be in a shrine. I take be in SUSHI BAR seriously respectful. 
The way the couple using chopsticks was outrage too. I don't want to get into the detail because UGLY AS FXXX.
like....
trying chopsticks to make them even on the table.
trying to get a nigiri but dropped right into soy sauce.
Showin' off when she could pick-up Sashimi and feeding him.
Chewing sushi like a maniac.

If the sushi chef were Japanese, he'll kick them out.

The female chef greeted me with very nice respectful-Japanese. So, I asked her, " Can you do Nigiri?" She replied very politely, " Yes, sometimes, but I only know a little bit of how to cut a fresh whole fish." 
The all conversation was in Japanese. 

Kabuto is 50% Japanese. VERY CLEAN Counter. Nice Oshibori= hot cloth napkin, and I love the Great Big Agari= Hot Japanese tea. Great service too. 
So far, I must say OUT LOUD that one of the BEST Non-Japanese Authentic Sushi Chef in the city. WELL-DONE, Sir. Well-done. I like Kabuto a lot better than the FXXXin' Rude KiSS THE SEA FOOD for sure! 

Non-Japanese-Good-Sushi Chef list. 
1. Kabuto 
2. Okoze 
3. Balboa Sushi House

I forgot to mention, the female Sushi Chef is very pretty. YEAH! Btw, Ken K send me a info that where the old Kabuto Chef now. He is at Vivify, Shasta. http://www.yelp.com/bi...
author: Nobu K.

description:
If you could, you would kick yourself in the face for getting to this tiny sushi restaurant right at dinner time with the rest of San Francisco. But that's definitely a testament to the sushi quality at Kabuto.

After some confusion (their old locale still has a sign up across the street on the north side of Geary), we settled into our seats at the bar at the ridiculously early hour of 5 p.m.

Fish is fresh, richly colored, and presentation seems extra important here. The nigiri (tuna and salmon) were soft and outstanding. 

The rolls are different than other places; almost gourmet. Hamachi Pear Roll with special mustard sauce was as beautiful as it was perfect, with a fantastic blend of flavors I haven't found at any other sushi resto.

The Katsunagi roll came with unagi, avocado, deep-fried shiso, katsu and raspberry miso sauce. (!!!)

My standby Dragon Roll was wider than it was long (that's what she said), but I enjoyed every inch of it (...)

Spicy Tuna Roll was alright.

Standard to above-average sushi prices, running $30-40 each (incl. tip) for the fishies, a large Sapporo and edamame.

Get here early, sit at the bar and knock yourself out.
author: Tara R.

description: best sushi in town.  small space, recommend calling ahead, or just be prepared to wait a little bit. go for something unique on the nigiri / sashimi list - guarantee they will most likely have some type of fish you've not had at another sushi spot.
author: j d.

description:
It really is the best sushi in San Francisco. The amazing uni was topped on rice with the perfect temperature making the experience unforgettable. 
I also recommend the foie gras sushi, 1869 oysters, toro topped with uni and caviar, live scallop, and hamachi pear.
author: Sally P.

description:
Kabuto used to have the best sushi in the city 20-30 years ago.

It's not bad now, but no longer in the top tiers.
author: J M.

description:
I ate there on Friday night, we got in at about 9:20 and was seated about 10 mins later.  Parking really wasn't too bad which was surprising to me considering the location Kabuto's in.  

The food was AMAZING. 
WE had 3 orders of the CeViChe - Halibut and salsa wrapped with deep fried seaweed and served with lime and sea salt. Eaten with no sauce

2 orders of the Baby Main Lobster - Seared lobster with spicy sauce

Crepe Sushi - Salmon - Smoke salmon and cream cheese
wrapped wth Kabuto crepe

Sonoma Duck - Barbeque Duck served with Jpanese
Spicy Mustard

Sammy Roll - Fresh Salmon outside, California inside, topped with Kabuto Curry sauce

Ume Fried Tai - Fried red snapper in U.F.O shaped sushi served with balsamic raspberry sauce

and for dessert we had the green tea creme brulee. . .(the green tea creme brulee didn't do much for me the texture was a bit too grainy for my liking. ) 

Everything else was pretty much delicious except for the sonoma duck the flavors were SO intense after about a min of choking on it i was finally able to swallow it down with the help of some tea.  

PROs: attentive service, reasonable prices 

Cons:  the restaurant is really small so its a tight fit and it can get REALLY loud in there.
author: Elle T.

description: Came in close to 10:00 PM.  It was close to closing.  Service was pleasant and "me" lovely was happy.  The miso with clam was excellent, as was he monkfish liver, softshell crab handroll, the toro and uni.  I eat sushi frequently and highly recommend Kabuto to all sushi lovers:)
author: Olafur G.

description:
We recently went to Kabuto Sushi in the Richmond district.  We knew about the popularity of this place and showed up promptly at opening.  This was the best idea for a nice dinner, as there was a long wait for tables outside.

Kabuto offers a lot of sushi options.  We were reviewing their special sushi menu along with their regular menu.  It took a long time.  I found out later that Kabuto has a link on Menupages.com, and some homework ahead of time can help.

I ordered their Nigiri Ichinin-Mae, their sushi assortment.  It comes with tuna, albacore, shrimp, mackerel, halibut, salmon, hokkigai, smelt roe & tekka maki.  There was even a giant clam nigiri, the first I've seen.  All of it was delicious.  This sushi entree comes with miso soup and house salad.

My husband orders various items.  He starts with the Kai Miso, a miso soup with asari clams.  Neat idea - this is highly recommended!  Next comes a saba nigiri and a dragon roll.  The mackerel is delicious and always garners respect from the sushi chef/waitstaff anywhere we go.  Just an observation.  The dragon roll was pretty good, as the unagi and avocado were delicious, but there was a bit too much rice and the tempura shrimp seemed small.

But the highlight for us was off the special sushi menu -- the Katsunagi.  This is unagi, avocado and shiso deep fried as katsu (coated with bread crumbs & fried) and served with kabuto raspberry miso sauce.  The sauce looked like "country gravy" which seemed odd at first.  But combined with the katsu it became a nice flavorful dish.  Awesome!

We tried our luck at dessert, but ended up underwhelmed.  We each had the tempura green tea ice cream and the macha creme brulee.  Both could have been sweeter in taste.  They are probably trying out new ideas for execution and presentation of desserts.  But for next time, we will skip it.

Kabuto is some of the best sushi I have had in a long time.
author: Janet H.

description:
Tempted to give Kabuto 2 stars due to some of the horrible service I experienced, but I give them 3 stars because they're OK.  I had high expectations and convinced the GF to join me on an "expedition" to the Outer Richmond. 

Had an 8pm reservation, wasn't acknowledged until 830pm (several others with 8pm reservations also weren't acknowledged), and wasn't seated until 845pm at the sushi bar.  The waitress barely paid attention to us after we sat and the staff didn't manage the diners very well despite the fact that they are definitely adequately staffed. 

Food was OK - fish was generally tasty though not the freshest I've had.  They definitely have some interesting rolls, though some are smaller than you might expect.  Not worth going back to.
author: Elad C.

description:
Lived in the neighborhood and driven by this place hundreds of time. Definitely a place that you cannot judge by it's cover. I assumed it was a hole in the wall place that served your basic rolls, some "special" & "unique", and teriyaki bowls or plates BUT always crowded and at times a wait outside. Boy was I pleasantly surprised!

Read all the yelp reviews and saw all the pictures posted. Order a lot of the interested dishes that people recommended and posted numerous times and was definitely not disappointed.

Though hole in the wall by exterior appearances the inside was simple and clean. As soon as you walked in, I felt like I was in Japan where all the employees greeted you and waitresses seemed shy but attentive.

Ordered (** highly recommend)
Hamachi Pear ** (so good we ordered it twice)
Toro tartare **
1849 Oysters ** (so many intricate details & flavors combined)
Fois Gras Sushi **
Ceviche **
Spicy Hamachi (not bad but basic when it comes to the other special rolls)
Spicy Scallop (tasty and fresh but again not as amazing unique as the others)
Sun Rise (unique but not as flavorful as the others, the quail egg definite a plus)

All this and our bill was about $72. Most worth it for extremely fresh sashimi and special unique flavors.

Definitely listen to the waitresses when they say no soy sauce. If you're unsure, take half a bite and then try the other half with light bit of soy sauce like we did.

A new favorite, we'll definitely be back!!!
author: Jane T.

description: A nice, chill place for Japanese grub. The wait's not too crazy, and the food is pretty good. The fish is sufficiently fresh, and the service is sufficiently solid.
author: Guillermo K.

description:
Good sushi with fresh ingredients.

Heard from people that the side dishes were okay but not what Kabuto was known for.  Pretty much had an all sushi dinner there.  It was good sushi with great fresh ingredients.

Particular sushi I choose when evaluating a sushi place are one of the tuna, ikura (salmon eggs), and saba (mackeral).

Toro = firm fish with even taste.  Not old, mealy, oily, or disguised with heavy wasabi to mask age.  The toro was good, not the best I have had, but in the top and would order again.

Ikura = Th eggs were firm, bright orange, with good flavor.  The eggs were not over salted, discolored, slimy, or with poor turgor.  I have had ikura with more flavor, but this was one of the better quality ikura I have in awhile.

Saba = The saba was excellent.  The fish was firm, tasty, and did not overpower with vinegar.  The saba was served with a piece of some type of wakame on it, presumably to cut the vinegar taste.  It worked well the vinegar was just a hint but not too strong like some saba.  The flesh was still firm, unlike some places where it is starting to fall apart.  This was one of the best sabas I have had in a long time.

The sushi-su is also an integral part of the sushi.  With bad su a meal can be ruined.  With good su the rice is tasty and provides a great palette to highlight the fish and other ingredients.  The su at Kabuto was tasty and light, it provided an underscore to the fish without distracting from the fish as it created a good firm bed for the nigiri.

I would eat here multiple times.  Ranks in my top 10 sushi places I have eaten at.
author: Jason N.

description:
Okay, those special sushi here are not authentic but they are sure trendy and tasty.

I can always count on coming here and get a satisfied sushi meal. The fishes are always fresh and there are couple unique sushi that I really enjoyed.

My all time favorites:
- 1849 oysters,
- hirame jerry,
- hamachi pear,
- anago,
- akamutsu.

My biggest complaints:
- expensive!
- difficult to find parking,
- long wait line.

The way they combine various ingredients to make those innovative sushi always amaze me.

If you are a purist, you might not like Kabuto. But if you are open to something different, it's worth checking this place out.
author: Stephen L.

description:
I think I am in love.  If I could afford to have kabuto 4-5 times a week, i would do it without hesitation!  Don't let the ambiance of the restaurant fool you, they serve some fresh and amazing sushi.

Here are my favorites/MUST HAVES:
-scott's handroll (their spicy tuna is the best i've had)
-toro tar tar
-cevichi
-hamachi pear
-foie gras
-sunrise
-1849 oyster... $7.50 a pop, but OMG TOO GOOD
-dragon roll
-this grilled fish thing is really good (sorry forgot the name)

i've tried a lot on their menu and with the items listed above, you can't go wrong!

omg i'm salivating as i am writing this.  if that doesn't convince you how amazingly delicious kabuto is, i don't know what will.

note to self: must make a trip to kabuto immediately after finals.
author: Cee L.

description:
Went to Kabuto twice so far. One was for Father's Day dinner. Both times I loved it. Fresh fish, "modern" sushi style, and interesting tastes. Bad thing though, a bit pricey. Bill for 4 was around $120, w/o tax/tip. Mostly ordered sashimi, sushi plates (2 pieces/plate), chirashi (sp?). And to fill us up a bit, we also ordered soba.
We left satisfied (not super full).
Great place to come to eat sushi, and man, do I love sushi... Top 5 of sushi/sashimi restaurants that I have tried in SF.
author: Ali S.

description:
One of the best sushi restaurants in San Francisco - from fusion sushi with pear, ponzu jelly, lamb, foie gras and chocolate sauce, monkfish liver etc., to incredibly fresh fish nigiri from the whiteboard list of Specials.

Those specials are very pricey and turned out to be the only negative point of the night: we asked the waitress twice what were their prices approximately, but in a fashion more befitting a restaurant actually IN Japan, she did not understand our questions and replied something completely irrelevant, so we just ordered.  Whether that sublime toro or live scallop is worth it in the end only depends on the condition of your wallet.
author: Sasha M.

description:
If you want good Sushi and willing to pay for it, then this is a good place to start. Presentation is creative, and the food taste fresh. Went here on a whim and cant wait to come back. 

Quality over quantity for sure here, but well worth a visit.
author: Lisa D.

description:
We finally tried Kabuto several months ago after years of a friend's ranting/raving.  I admit I may have assumed there wasn't any "authentic" and really good Japanese restaurants left in this part of SF, as I am a total food snob cause I just really love food & enjoying a great meal...price is never an issue as long as the tummy is happy =)  

I am incredibly particular about quality, freshness, and consistency when it comes to Japanese food, which is hard to find in SF--Osaka has been my go to spot for years as it never disappoints

But I have been missing out as I came to realize after my first experience at Kabuto...TO DIE FOR FRESHNESS, incredibly unique sushi/sashimi offering, and awesome presentation for a local Richmond neighborhood restaurant.  Now I rant & rave, as this has definitely become a new SF favorite which is far & few in terms of quality and impeccably fresh Japanese cuisine.    

Top 5 favs:
-ceviche
-hamachi jalepeno
-live scallop
-lobster roll
-mirugai (hard to find in SF)
author: C L.

description:
Seriously had multiple foodgasms, eyes rolled back and all. So good I nearly cried. I wanted a cigarette afterwards and I don't even smoke. 

MUST TRY:

-Foie Gras Sushi (when it was still available)
-Hamachi Pear (now that there's no foie gras, you gotta come for this)
-Live Scallop (prepared 2 ways)
-Sweet Shrimp (also two ways)
-Uni
-1849 Oyster

Didn't use any soy sauce, just dabbed a little freshly grated wasabi and cleansed the palate with ginger in between fish. Advice: savor each bite and enjoy the sweetness of fresh fish. Simply delicious.

All washed down with a some sake and Asahi BLACK..so smooth! Best sushi meal by far.
author: Lina S.

description: A bit pricey and small portion sizes. Really fresh and delicious sushi. Not sure i'll try it again though.
author: Oge c.

description:
Sweet little spot in the Outer Richmond. Make sure to look at your directions if you're not a local, because when I was looking for the place I saw what was the OLD location (closed) just across the street, which got me all worried that I had just driven an hour to this place for nothing! Finally, I got my wits about me and found it. It's so small you might miss it.

Anyway, my boyfriend and I tried two of their specialty sushis, the Crunchy (spelled "Cruchy" on the menu) roll, which has tempura halibut and light yellow curry sauce. The texture was wonderful, but the sauce left me wanting more of a stronger curry taste. One sushi you have to try is the ceviche. It had a nice clean flavor to it. 

We also ordered the tuna sashimi sampler which was right on. Fresh, soft pieces of fish. Just a really good platter of sashimi.

If you're a sushi traditionalist and you want to experience some unconventional rolls, try this place. I do want to come back and try some of their other specialty rolls.
author: Monica N.

description:
my fav sushi in sf!!
i experiences this place the first time years back, and i think they keep getting better. amazing fresh fish!!!
before the foise gras ban in sf, kabuto had all kinds of yummy foie gras dishes, mixed with unagi etc. 
i always get the monk fish liver, and the oyster special with uni on top. but all of their dishes are excellent and the quality is outstanding. the service could be a lil bit friendlier, but after you been with them a few times and they start to recognize you, they get much nicer.
author: Nicole L.

description:
NOM NOM NOM NOM

Alright, if you're stalking me and/or J-To, you'll either find us here or across the street at Shabu House on any given day. If you're looking for some seriously fresh and elegantly prepared sushi, this is where it's at.

You'll find some of the most creative sushi rolls in SF here, and their menu is endless. They've also got an extensive yakimono (grilled), agemono (fried), and hot and cold a la carte menu. Make sure you check out the specials on the board behind the bar, as there is always something that is a must try. Highly recommended: hamachi pear roll, ceviche roll and miso eggplant. If you're a fan of foie gras, they also have an amazing foie gras roll served with balsamic raspberry sauce. 

Make reservations if you can, the place is tiny -- the sushi bar sits about 12 and there are maybe 8 tables inside.
author: Connie C.

description: Ask for recommendations on their special sushi menu. The cerviche roll will make your knees weak...
author: Jessica T.

description:
This place tries so hard to be unique that it forgets that sushi should allow you to savor the flavor of the fish. 

Carrots, curry and capers are just three of many C's that do not belong in sushi but manage to make an appearance in Kabutos. 

I had clams in their shell taking a hot bath in my Miso soup. Strange. 

Oh, and all of this for about a third again what you would pay elsewhere... and no hot tea served to us? 

Maybe next time I want to drown my sushi in something that starts with the letter C I will come here but C is for cookie and that doesn't go with fish!
author: Drue C.

description:
The fish is fresh.  It's a bit pricey though as even with the promotion coupon ($25 for $50), that the net cost could still be high as you may end up around $40+, which you can have a very fulfilling meal at a good restaurant in Japan town.  I would have consider it for about 3-4 stars overall. 

So why am I giving 1 star then?  It's because one thing happened at the end.  After I gave out tips, their senior waiter actually questioned me that I didn't pay enough tips in front of other customers.  In reality, some people would pay more tips, and some would pay less, and that's just the way that tips goes as it should be what the customer feel like giving base on various factors, more or less.  But under no circumstance, that even if you feel that the customer didn't pay the standard that you expected, you don't say that to customer. It's just inappropriate/rude to tell the customer that he/she didn't pay enough tips for you in front of others, and asked for more.  We have been to so many Japanese restaurants and this was the first time ever happened to us in a such award experience. .
author: Alex D.

description:
Had dinner there last night. We showed up at 6 which was right before the rush. The sushi was fresh and the service was great. Here are a few recommendations of things to order:
off the special sushi menu:
hamachi pear
ceviche
hotapple

off the dinner menu:
marinated grilled seabass
salmon mushiyaki
author: Jonathan G.

description: Only the hardcore sushi fans should come here. Don't be afraid to try anything on the menu
author: Andres G.

description:
I found the majority of the sushi here to be average and the service was just so-so.  The restaurant is very small so it has kind of a claustrophobic feeling to it.

However I give it four stars for the following:
AMAZINGLY tasty Escolar (aka, Butterfish)

And, they had Monkfish liver on the menu, which I haven't had since I lived in LA.  YUMMERS!

Not to mention the really tasty ceviche appetizer which is featured on the menu.  Oy, so GOOD!

I'd go back strictly for those three things.  For sure!
author: Kate R.

description:
I had the pleasure of dining at Kabuto the other night with a fantastic group of ladies and it was nothing short of fabulous.

Reservations are a good idea, since it gets very busy on any given night. We were immediately seated and brought tea and menus. Because we all love to eat (it's no secret), we went ahead and ordered a good portion of the menu. We went with the spider roll, the hamachi pear roll (lovely), the spider roll, the veggie tempura roll, and the foie gras sushi (yes, it was spectacular!), the vegetable tempura and the creamy eggplant appetizer.

My favs were easily the eggplant and the spider roll, but then again, the spider roll always seems to be my fav. For dessert, we had the green tea creme brulee and the tempura ice cream. The creme brulee was made with macha and it was absolutely fabulous and had a great flavor.

The bill was very reasonable.. The service prompt.. and the food was lovely. I'll definitely be back. This place gives Red Box in the Tenderloin a run for their $$.
author: Katie A.

description:
who would have thought to serve foie gras nigiri?  kabuto certainly did and it was heavenly.  their eclectic dishes and unique flavors gives a "wow" factor that most japanese restaurants do NOT possess.

this place is all quality and not quantity, but well worth it.  I definitely recommend kabuto for a intimate date but it will cost a pretty penny to impress the lady. =)
author: Alexander H.

description: Service was great (female server was friendly & attentive), food however was only ok (not memorable), but the odd thing was when my sister took out her credit card for payment, the server asked for her ID and then walked off with it. I can understand wanting to verify that the picture matches the name, but why the need to walk off with it. Sorry, but with so much identity theft nowadays, this was disconcerting to me. If this is a restaurant policy, they should stop. If it's just that one server, she should stop. Either way, server or no server, the food was not memorable or tasty enough for me to go back.
author: Wendy L.

description:
One of the member on Yelp had great review on this place so I had to try! I was in SF with my girl and I wanted her to taste some great and fresh sushi. If you drive by this place, you would think it's a mom and pop shack but when you walk in it's pretty cozy. It's pretty small, bigger compare to Ino Sushi. Somehow all the good sushi joints in SF is all small for some reason? It's cool though, we sat at the bar. 

We ordered the Toro Tartar, Sashimi Dinner special, and Spicy Tuna Roll. The Spicy Tuna roll had some spicy sauce on top of it, I don't know what it's call but damn it's sooo good. It's a litle spicy and the taste was indescribable but it's taste so good when you put it in your mouth. The Toro Tartar was something new, never had it before. When you put it in your mouth it almost just melt and dissolve and it's really good as well. mMmM. The Sashimi was fresh, almost like it's pop out of the ocean and they slice and serve you the fish. 

I'm definitely coming back here to get that spicy tuna roll and toro tartar and try new things as well. My mouth is drooling right now just thinking about it. Great service, great sushi place, definitely recommend.
author: Thanh T.

description: Fresh sea food and great innovative sushi. yumm will def be back!
author: Fabiola R.

description:
I am treated so well.  After torturing the boyfriend with literally a full day of nonstop being dragged from girly store to store, he surprised me with a sushi restaurant he had yelped beforehand to take me to!  We made reservations about 30 min in advance and headed over.  Parking was a neat trick aka difficult, but once we arrived I was so pleased with the menu.  We got the sashimi teishoku which had a great selection of different fish + roe + octopus.  Additionally, we tried the monkfish liver w/ponzu (since the iron chef made it on Anthony Bourdain, heart Anthony) the uni, and butterfish sashimi.

Most memorable/different: salmon roe and uni.  The uni was so cold, creamy, and delicious.  The monkfish liver, although I thought would be scary, was actually masked a lot by the seaweed it was wrapped in.  And I gotta say, the sashimi, overall, is fantastically cut- great texture!

Presentation is also fantastic.  Cute place for a date.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I brought my bf here to celebrate his birthday few months ago.
I made a reservation for  so I only wait for like 15 mins.
Service was good.
Food was awesome to me, but my bf prefer more simple, traditional japanese sushi, plus he visited japan often so the japanese food here will never be great to him. (The review below is only represent me, forget about my picky boyfriend :p)
We ordered
1.hamachi pear --- 3 stars, not a huge fan of this one.
2. foie gras sushi - 6 stars!!!!! omg, Im willing to eat this everyday until the day I die. 
3.uni --- 4 stars, just a regular buttery uni but it taste really good too.
4.toro tartar ----- 6 stars again!!!! omgomgomgomgomg.............OMG.
5.1849 oysters ----3.5 stars .well, even tho a lot of ppl recommend this on yelp but I think the oysters are too pricey and doesn't taste that great.
6. CeViChe ---- 4 stars, pretty tasty.
7. salmon sashimi ------ 4 stars, pretty fresh. 

I think we ordered a little bit more other sashimi but I forgot what it was already and the bill was around $180. I'll go back during some other anniversary but it would be a little too pricey for a regualr dinner.
author: Niko L.

description:
I like this place. 

And yes, it's two steps from my apartment. And YES, I'm lazy. But that's not why. 

Now, it's by no means authentic. But there are traces of the authentic that remain, and the innovations they've made are interesting. And for the most part, they work. 

They serve up some decent cuts of sashimi. Their ankimo is always superb, though the last time I went they were out and that just SERIOUSLY put me in a foul mood... They make a "ceviche nigiri" that actually works, quite well. Normally that's the kind of sushi-revisionist attempt I'd shrug off, but they seem to know what they're doing.

The presentation of everything is always outstanding.

And, their sushi chef is just about the coolest-looking dude EVAR. I think he also lives in the neighborhood. Because I've seen him walking down the street, and I'm every bit as mesmerized by him in the "real world" as I am behind the sushi bar... Long white hair, little wire-rimmed spectacles on the end of his nose, one steel earring... And he always has a bandanna on. 

He is just one badass mo' fo' sushi man.

The second they start deep-frying and slathering mayo on their shit, though, I'm outtie...
author: Lisa T.

description:
One sexy sushi spot. 

Voluptuous fried eggplant, scooped right out of the shell, miso soup involving wee little mushrooms, and melt in your mouth sushi choices. Mmm. 

We had both the hamachi pear and foie gras, as well as some veggie and tempura rolls... probably a bad idea, but they all made me want to take a to go box back to Atlanta.

Now while the sushi is sexy, the actual space is 200% "hole in the wall-we are authentic- you may or may not find a seat" kind of space. Also the service is a bit hectic, but if the urge tempts you to get frustrated for waiting for your precious rolls to arrive, calm yourself by ordering the Green tea creme brulee and tempura ice cream!
author: Deanna J.

description: Good sushi but had better ones. I really like the foei gras and the oyster special was very tasting. I'm giving this place 2 stars because the lady that waited on our table had a very negative attitude... she was very pushy and walked away as i was talking to her!! very rude.
author: Lola J.

description: Feasted here on New Year's Eve and had another magnificent meal.  Yes, even with reservations we waited, but it was well worth it.  I am in love with the Crispy and Ceviche rolls and all of the sashimi that was on the "specials" list.   The only problem with eating here is that I want one of everything and it is hard to pick and choose what to order.
author: Katharine A.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi restaurants in the city.  The ceviche sushi is a must!  The fish is fresh, the service is excellent and the prices are good considering the high quality of the fish.  I also love the green tea ice cream,
author: Sarah K.

description:
I absolutely love Kabuto!  I visited here three times within a one month period.  The first time I celebrated my birthday here with a group of friends during the Christmas season.  The second visit was when I returned from my trip to Asia.  The last visit was right before I had to leave San Francisco to get back to my life in San Diego.  

After tasting my first piece of toro tuna tartar I said "Wow, I'm in love!!!!"  Now don't get me wrong, I wouldn't say I loved all the sushi.  However, I could eat the toro tuna tartar and ceviche sushi allllll niiiiiight looong!  Like I told my friends when I took that first bite of the ceviche sushi, "It's like a nice surprise in your mouth!"  So with that advertisement, my guy friends were excited to try the "nice surprise" in their mouths.  It met their expectations.  I heard "OH...mmmmmm!!!!"  They were pretty excited - as excited as a person can get from eating sushi.

We were about 10 people on my first visit to that small mom 'n pop restaurant.  The food came a bit slow but all the dishes/sushi were excellent quality.  On the second visit I noticed the food still coming slow despite it was only the two of us.  During the last visit I was introduced to the unagi nigiri.  I can say that was the best piece of unagi I've ever had!  The sushi delivery to our tables quickened a little.  Because the sushi is OH SO DELICIOUS, it felt like forever until I could place another "nice surprise in my mouth"!

So...if you are impatient...if you don't like looking for parking...if you can't imagine waiting an hour for a table, then Kabuto is not for you. BUT if you LOVE food and SUSHI you'll try this joint in spite of these things.  Make sure you order the ones I recommended.  You'll love the "nice surprise in your mouth"!  Kabuto's is one of those places that you want to remember.  It's one of those places where you wish you had around the corner from your home.  My birthday wish was to transplant Kabuto to San Diego.
author: Angie K.

description:
Just because people line up to eat your food doesn't give you the right to treat them poorly. This place is the classic example of a restaurant that acts like you are lucky to be there, and if you don't think so, it doesn't matter because there will be someone else in your seat as soon as you get up. I have had issues with the service here in the past, but my terrible experience here last night guarantees that I will spend my $$ elsewhere from now on. And its not like I am some guy with an office job that doesn't know the first thing about restaurants and how they work; I have been in the restaurant business for 20 years and currently wait tables at a high-end place downtown. I am well aware of the importance of customer service-- it pays my bills!
I made a reservation last night so that I didn't have to deal with the sign-up sheet and the line that is always inevitably there, but it didn't seem to matter one bit that I had the foresight to call ahead. We arrived at 8 for our reservation, but were TOTALLY AND COMPLETELY IGNORED for 20 minutes while we just stood there in the doorway. The two waitresses WOULDN'T EVEN MAKE EYE CONTACT WITH US. It was ridiculous. When I finally lost patience and was able to corner the younger of the two waitresses to inform her that we had a reservation, she acted like I may as well have been from Mars, and bustled off to do something else. When I then asked the old waitress if we could have a seat at one of the MANY AVAILABLE TABLES, she said that they were "for another reservation". When a couple of seats then opened up at the sushi bar, the old waitress then sat some other people that were behind us. And all of this without so much as a "sorry" or "it will just be a moment" or ANYTHING!!!!
At this point, I would have been a total and complete idiot to stay here and give them my money. So my wife and I went down the street and spent a couple hundred dollars at a place that welcomed us when we opened the door, and seemed happy that we were there. 
I will tell anyone who asks and probably lots of folks that don't to NEVER EVER COME TO KABUTO. Horrendous customer service does not compensate for fresh fish!
author: Doctor S.

description:
Have you ever been separated from an ex-love for years, then suddenly find yourself reconnecting in that magical way that makes you question why you ever split-up?  Further you end up regretting all of the attempts you had at trying to find a replacement.  Maybe as the years went by you found semblances of replaceable parts, but when you got a taste of that once pure goodness, the fallacy that was your post separation/rebound replacement crumbled like a wall in Germany.

Kabuto, you are that lost love. I am sorry for dulling my memory of you and for forcing myself to try to forget you.  Last night we reconnected after 4 years and I must say, you were better than ever.  Gone were the things that annoyed me (big crowds, cramped spaces, long lines, people holding the door open on cold nights because as they suffer through "the-wait," we eaters must feel their coldness too).  Gone for the night was the excuse that I live in Berkeley, which broke up the romance in the first place.  

Last night was a perfect flashback.  Absolutely perfect nigiri (Ono, Dungeness crab, Bonito in a sauce to die for, Unagi to end all unagis, an Aji (with its bones fried on the side) that makes you want to be a predatory fish, etc. etc.).  Then came the fun stuff, a live scallop nigiri that on the side had spoonfuls of the "guts" from the scallop in a cream and wine sauce that was devilishly scrumptious.  Next up was the hammachi with a slice of crisp pear and a topping of fruity mustard.  So simple, so clean, yet shockingly good.  Ah, I forgot you had this move Kabuto, no one else has ever done it like you.

When I was feeling the love come back, you dropped the haymaker on me with the Valentine - That smoky sweet mix of unagi, seared liver, squash cubes under a blanket of balsamic-coco sauce that all foodies must have to have once before dying.  If fish could be had for desert, this would be my order.  

Even in its simplicity, Kabuto you know how to wow me.  Your spicy tuna roll should be a simple offering.  Yet yours has a hint of shiso (which usually I hate, but was the perfect note), and is under sauce that is both spicy but deeply flavorful.  A basic roll, but no one does it like you.  Once again you've ruined me.

Kabuto, I apreciate your special little details.  The little cranberries that are on most plates that cleanse the palate and are just damn yummy to munch.  The near candy like fresh roasted Japanese Pumpkin nigiri that are a MUST HAVE even if your not a vegetarian.  I got a double order.  The aforementioned Aji bones that should be bagged and sold in supermarkets, which you happily serve up with an order of nigiri.

Finally, your ankimo.  Ah ankimo, that silky smooth pate of the sea that still blows my mind as to what sushi can elevate is self into.  Other places put on a nice showing, but Kabuto, your ankimo appetizer was divine.  Softer, smoother, better tasting than all the rest.  Oh, how you know you're the best.

Kabuto, I know distance separates us, but our love is so strong I refuse to let mileage be an excuse to keep us apart.  You gave me a perfect tasting of that old sweet loving and I'm hooked on you once again.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I like both traditional and Westernized takes on Japanese cuisine. This place is wayyy out of the box I would even go so far as to call it Japanese fusion. They make some really interesting dishes and the owners ARE Japanese, so don't you start complaining that they are destroying tradition! They can and do serve what they want! I've never had a dish here i didn't enjoy. Some of them are orgasmically tasty.

The fish selection is really good, exotic at times, and everything is super fresh. I've taken dates here, friends from out of town, I'm a repeat customer.

Yes I will admit the service is a bit slow sometimes (the place gets very busy and its fairly small, I hope they expand to a larger building eventually). It's worth it to call ahead and get a reservation. I like the fact that the servers are Japanese and have accents. How could reviewers complain about authentic servers?? It adds to the appeal for me. And they will tell you "don't put soy sauce on this, it's already served with a sauce, you silly american!" I think that's righteous. Tell me how to eat the dish you prepared for me. Would you put ketchup on a Fillet Mignon?

It isn't really that expensive. It's up there, but if you want a REALLY nice sushi dinner for two, you could walk out of there for less than $100, and you could likely get some drinks too for that price.

If you are a sushi nazi and only like traditional sushi, skip this one you will be offended.. If you are into Japanese "fusion" and you have a refined pallete for super fresh fish, this place knocks it out of the park. I like that they aren't cheesy like some of the other Westernized sushi places, they don't dump spicy mayo on everything, and they don't deep fry that many of their rolls. Thanks Kabuto!
author: Zack D.

description:
R.I.P. Sachio Kojima's wonderful creativity and freshness with anything sushi and his incredible energy and vital "IRRASHAIMASE".

(The new owners don't have quite the right touch. Boohoo.)

the previous owners, Ayako and  Sachio. To quote the SF Chronicle, "http://www.sfgate.com/cg... 

Sept. 1 [2005] will be a sad day for fans of chef Sachio Kojima of Kabuto A&S Sushi (5121 Geary Blvd., near 16th Avenue) in the Richmond District. He has sold the business to Jinsoo Kim and Eric Cho, who own Ariake Japanese Restaurant, just a block away at 5041 Geary Blvd. (at 14th Avenue). Until Aug. 31, Kojima will be training Kim's and Cho's chefs in his style. 
Last year Kojima gave up his lease at his popular Japanese restaurant and moved it across the street to a smaller space. The idea was to downscale and operate the new place with his wife and children. Now Kojima plans to move about five hours north of San Francisco, near Mount Shasta. He said his wife, Ayako, who has cancer, needs to drink pure water, and that that area has it in abundance.
author: miriam b.

description: Such great sushi! Seriously - one of the best sushi experiences I have ever had. We sat the sushi bar - so fun because you watch them make everything - and ordered a bunch of items from their specials for the day. I recommend the Fire Salmon roll, and the cecviche as well. SO GOOD.
author: Gina M.

description:
Usually I would not write a review when a restaurant already has so many but I feel compelled to give a non-conforming review based on my experience.

There is no doubt this is a good restaurant for those who want Japanese. They offer some unique sushi, blending new and old flavors culminating a taste that will leave an impression. The Scott's handroll is tasty (basically a spicy tuna handroll topped with a quail's egg) as well as their raw oyster (1849?) topped with a myriad of additional flavors such as quail's egg, tobiko, cavier and foie gras if I'm not mistaken. Either way, it was a delectable delight however not cheap... 2 pieces for $16. We also order one of their sashimi platter dinners and the fish was fresh but the quality of fish is not top tier given the prices I'm paying. Along with this, we also ordered Uni nigiri which was a HUGE disappointment. It was not particularly very fresh. I do understand that Uni is not something that stay fresh for an extended period even stored properly, but with a restaurant that is so highly touted, I expect more and that they should know when their Uni is not fresh as to avoid serving it. Lastly I had their Amaebi which is good, but not as sweet as other premium Japanese sushi restaurants I've been to.

This place has a loyal following and we all have our personal tastes. I just don't feel the place really deserves anything higher than 3.5 stars based on their higher prices, overall average sashimi and somewhat rushed service. The servers looked stressed out and didn't smile very often, we even sat at the counter and the sushi chef barely responded to conversations we were trying to have with him about the food unless we asked "what is this called?" 

If you're looking for a place that has some nice fusion sushi and you're willing to spend some money, then be sure to make reservations in advance. However for those who are more discerning sushi lovers, you can skip this place without regrets... trust me, your money is better spent elsewhere.
author: Andrew L.

description: The sushi ain't cheap, but it sure is good!  Finally put my $25 for $50 Yelp deal to use.  My bf and I ordered a bunch of sushi from their Specials Menu and from the board.  We were not disappointed!  I'll go ahead and echo what most people have mentioned on here already.  To name a few of the best ones, we had the CeViche, Crunchy Sushi, Foie Grais Sushi, Katsuangi, Toro Tartar and a few others.  The Aji and Toro nigiri were fresh.  This place is all about creativity and quality, not quantity.  The presentation of their food is remarkable.  I wanted to photograph every dish that came out.  The restaurant itself is tiny, so I could imagine that this place gets filled up rather quickly.  Not a good place for big groups, so bring a date and leave the others at home.
author: C E.

description: This has been my favorite Japanese restaurant in SF for the past 5 years. It was, to my knowledge, the first in the Bay to combine sashimi and fruits and citrus. Innovative rolls and offerings, I love taking people here on dates to impress them, and they always are. Favorites of mine include the escolar, the ceviche, the hamachi pear, the ono grape and the Maine lobster.
author: Muy Y.

description:
I have to start out by saying this place is slightly expensive. And it's not the most traditional sushi you'll have. You might say that Kabuto serves a modern style of sushi with a hint of Californian Cuisine. I'll tell you that's not a bad thing because they pull it off well. And one time I did leave kind of hungry. That's usually a no-no for me. But if you can get past all that you'll be in to enjoy some of the more fresh and tasty sashimi you can find around here. There are many inventive nigiri and rolls that are exclusive to Kabuto's. You won't find Lamb Apple Sushi anywhere else. The attention to detail in their clean presentation is evident and adds to the experience. I've been there a few times, dented my wallet, but I'll keep going back. Maybe I can entice you with some of what they call their "special sushi,"

- Lamb Apple Sushi
- Baby Maine Lobster Sushi
- Foie Gras Sushi
- Hot Apple Sushi
- Hamachi Pear Sushi
- S.F. Wave Tsunami
author: Al L.

description:
went last week, and was so disappointed. used to like this place for its sashimi.

this time the quality of the meat was just not there, and the rolls we ordered, was literally a huge rice ball, on a piece of unagi on top. very much like a cheapo fast food sushi place....
author: Danielle A.

description: I am a bit of a sushi snob, and this place is fantastic - one of the best in the city.  Great quality fish prepared expertly, for a reasonable price.  The hamachi pear special is especially good.  Other than that I tend to stick to standard nigiri & maki.
author: James B.

description:
This was quite simply the best sushi I've ever had. I came alone since I was on a business trip. The place is much bigger than you would expect and has a great vibe inside. I was seated at the sushi bar. The sushi chef that I worked with was incredible. He was a true artist. I asked for a 5 piece sashimi of his choice. When he presented it to me he explained what each piece was. It was all highly excellent.
I'm sorry that I don't remember what kind of roll I had but it was the best I've ever had. Fantastic place but be prepared to spend some money. I can't wait to go back next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Byron P.

description:
UPDATE (4/18/07):
Though not the best sushi in the city, I'm happy to have other people believe it. Sushi is tasty. Interesting inventions. Pricey for what you get... or don't get. The service is pretty good unless it's really crowded, which is 80% of the time, at which point orders can be forgotten.

Worst seat in the house is the "butt-crack" seat or "windy-way." It's the seat closest to the door. When crowds start to hang at the door waiting for their table, they're practically sitting ON your table. When the door opens, especially on a gusty day, you'll think you were sitting on a chairlift at Kirkwood or Sugarbowl. 

But every time I go weird things happen. One night a guy tried to bring his mountain bike into the joint. The space is smaller than a Taco Bell which is totally unsuitable for a bike.  Another time a drunk lady kept asking me while pointing to MY BROTHER, "Where's your date? Is he your date? I hope your date puts out." Nice.

Trivia: Kabuto is the former location of a place called Rancho Mr. Hot Dog. 

Sit at the bar to experience Kabuto at it's best. 
________________________________________________________________

Small place. Everybody's happy. Mostly hoodies who live around Geary B. coming back from their jobs fresh of the dreary thirty-eight. Better to get there a little later to miss the crowds. Order some hot sake or an Asahi Dry. Then browse the menu. Maybe pick two or three of the interesting rolls (Dragon Roll or Spicey Tuna), and 3-4 Nigiri, it's all fresh. The place is a mini-me version of Blowfish without all the LAishflash & 'tude and about 1/8th the space.  A good regular spot for the regulars.
author: Johnny C.

description:
Awesome.  Best sushi I have had to date.  You sit and the first thing that happens is that you're handed a (clean) warm damp towel, which was a pleasant surprise.  

The sushi was absolutely fantastic.  Had the ceviche and toro tartar which were beyond delicious.  Also had some spicy tuna and escolar which was also excellent.

All that and some beer brought my lunch total to $40, which is a bit much.  But the price is pretty comparable (and definitely worth it for what you get).  And it's kind of out there in city terms but again, it's worth the trek.
author: sara r.

description:
If you're looking for a place that serves sushi like no other, this is the spot! 

I was searching for a place that was unique and distinctive from all the other gazillion sushi places in the city. I can honestly say that this is it right here. 

After viewing the Yelp pictures, I decided to take a plunge with the gf. 

I was a little fearful that the place would be super packed on the Wednesday before Thanksgiving even with reservations since the place was claimed to be small. A 7:30 reservation proved not to be a problem since the restaurant was only halfway full. Though the place got increasingly packed and when we did leave, there were actually two people that were waiting. 

The 1849 oysters are to die for with the lovely combination of quail egg, uni, tobiko, and yes fish eggs. yummm.

Sunrise was good on presentation, two pieces of salmon wrapped around a ball of rice, with a quail egg to top off.

There was one roll (forget what its called) but it had smoked salmon and it was soooo good, mainy cuz smoked salmon is good in and of itself.

Ceviche roll is a must try, do it without the soy sauce. It's already got a sour tang to it. 

Toro Tartare was uber good (would have preferred without the black pepper but it was still all good!)

You may want to order 4-5 plates a person if you actually want to get full. Almost everything comes in pairs. 

It's all very pricey when you're rollin out $3 a piece as opposed to say $1.50, but it's definitely worth a try at least occasionally as chances are you won't see anything else like it in 95% of the other sushi places. It's alll very worth it and it's not even like it's a pretentious place with fancy decor or anything. Just a modern setup with one of a kind sushi. 

Funny thing is, during the end of our meal, the couple sitting next to us was talking about Yelp and I only caught snippets of the conversation. Like how people talk about parking on Yelp and how it's stupid cuz people should know by now that parking is always tough in the city. Haha, in honor of that, I shall say that parking is rough but one can usually find parking near the park presidio side streets area =P
author: David N.

description: Best eggplant miso I've ever had. Other meals we ordered were outstanding as well. Space is incredibly cramped and loud, but food is absolutely awesome!!!
author: Sasha L.

description:
Kabuto's fish is great. Prices are very fair. But, the service sucks so much that I don't think I can ever go back. I'm not willing to subject myself to more crappy service to become a recognized regular to get treated respectfully.

My girlfriend and I visited for the second time Sunday, 11/30. The first time we made reservations and had a great experience.  This time, no reservation, but got the last two-top in the front corner.  Everything seemed to be going fine and, then, my friend who'd ordered a la carte got most of her order right away. And, then... we... waited... for... 25... more... minutes for my sashimi-sushi plate I'd ordered from the menu.

Even after I saw my order sitting on the counter for god knows how long, the girl *still* didn't bring it to the table for several minutes.  Barely an apology. No offer of a dessert or drink. No discounted bill.  Nothing.

So, that's what she got for a tip... nothing.

It sucks going out for a meal and leaving upset and angry, instead of serene and satisfied.

Good food does not offset total crap service.
author: Lydia S.

description:
OK...Gotta give credit where credit is due...Dan B. (who has yet to write a review on Yelp) highly recommended this sushi joint and man are we glad he did.  Hubby and I got here at about 6pm on a Friday and we were accommodated immediately at the sushi bar.  However, literally within 20 minutes or so there was quite a wait for a seat.  Once you're seated be prepared to wait for your sushi...but wow it is so worth the wait.
For food we thoroughly enjoyed the sashimi moriawase, toro tartare (OMG...that was amazing), the tempura is like something we've never had before (that good) and of course freshly cracked dungeness crab nigiri.  We thought the price was reasonable and the quality and freshness superb...definitely a keeper...
author: Karen B.

description:
The food was really good.  The flavors were all nice and delicate and the presentation was really impressive.  The courses came out set by set, plate by plate.  The one that didn't impress me was the tako.  It was rubbery.  And they smeared this dark sauce thing on it.  

This was very different from regular sushi.  The flavors were balanced in most of the dishes.  But my gripe is that everything was so small.  We ate everything we ordered and that wasn't enough so we had to order some more.  So we ended up spending a lot of money for ordinary fish, done in a very pretty, fragrant way.  But as Nobu K. has said, sauce and flavors usually hide.  And if the fish were really really nice, one wouldn't want to flavor and dress it.  

In the future, if I come back, I'll plan a hamburger after the meal.
author: Christina C.

description:
I am not the type to write reviews on restaurants, but I just had to say something about this place.  I just ate here tonight and this place sucks.  You can take my word for it and stop reading, or if you're the type who needs proof, read the lengthy summary below.  

It's highly over-rated and customer service is non-existent.  I'll admit that the quality of the food definitely does matter, but if the service sucks, that will no doubt ruin my enjoyment of the meal.   And believe me, I've tried many different flavors of restaurants in my time - from small mom&pop hole-in-the-walls to extravagant fine dining and have had better treatment at my local Taco Bell.  

I'm not going to go over every single detail but just touch on a few of the problems that got to me the most.  First of all we had made reservations for 5 people ahead of time and  they really only provided seating for 4, with the 5th seat sticking out at the end of the table back-to-back with a seat from the bar.  We sat down, and during the meal one of the waitresses kept telling me to move because I was in the way.  Why do they seat me someplace where I'm going to be in the way and then they tell me to move but no location to move to?  Don't tell me to just get out of the way - give me a place to move to!  I had to be pressed up against the table so the waitresses had enough space to walk behind me.  Fools. 

The food was decent, and by the time we got the check, we had a $200 gift certificate to pay for the meal, only having used $120 of.  They said we cannot get any change back, which was fine, but when we tried to order more food to take home they said we couldn't.  Then we offered to pay for another couple's meal with the remaining $80 which was shot down as well.  The owner said, "you just can't pay for someone else's meal like that," whatever that's supposed to mean.  I guess he doesn't know the meaning of altruism.

I finally asked the owner "how can we use the remaining $80," and he had no answer - which meant to leave it as tip.  Seriously dude, WTF.  They could have been at least a little more accomodating and understanding if the owner actually cared about something called "customer loyalty."
author: Scott T.

description: One of the best sushi place I've been to. Small but cute. We tried 4 different rolls, Sammy Roll, Crunchy Roll, Dragon Roll, and a special roll that was on the board. All were really good but I really liked the Crunchy Roll: Tempura halibut with special curry sauce. Sooo good. Green tea creme brulee to end the night.
author: Juliane N.

description:
4.5 stars really. There are reviews under the name Kabuto A&S, which is the right name. I think the name stands for the previous owners, Ayako and  Sachio. To quote the SF Chronicle, "http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2005/07/27/FDGQDDRCHK1.DTL

Sept. 1 [2005] will be a sad day for fans of chef Sachio Kojima of Kabuto A&S Sushi (5121 Geary Blvd., near 16th Avenue) in the Richmond District. He has sold the business to Jinsoo Kim and Eric Cho, who own Ariake Japanese Restaurant, just a block away at 5041 Geary Blvd. (at 14th Avenue). Until Aug. 31, Kojima will be training Kim's and Cho's chefs in his style.
Last year Kojima gave up his lease at his popular Japanese restaurant and moved it across the street to a smaller space. The idea was to downscale and operate the new place with his wife and children. Now Kojima plans to move about five hours north of San Francisco, near Mount Shasta. He said his wife, Ayako, who has cancer, needs to drink pure water, and that that area has it in abundance.

In the early 20th century, travelers came to the region to "take the waters" from the many springs. Kojima plans to open a small sushi bar there. Kim, one of Kabuto's new owners, is an experienced sushi chef, having worked for seven years at Ebisu in the Sunset. He also has cooked French and Japanese cuisine for many years. He says the partners plan to close the restaurant for just a short time, reopening in early September and keeping Kojima's style.

Dinner will be served nightly except Sunday; lunch might be added later. Currently, Kabuto is open for lunch and dinner Thursday through Tuesday." I managed to eat at Kabuto on Aug. 31, 2005. :) Had to wait about an hour and a half though. I haven't been back since the ownership change, and according to other reviews, it's not the same. Things I liked: the tofu miso soup, the pira-kara nasu, the chawan mushi, the fried baby octopus, the sea escargot, the uni sushi, and the ogura cream anmitsu (not often seen outside Japan in the US). I also liked the white tuna topped with flying-fish roe and a raw quail egg nestled in the middle.
author: Hao L.

description:
Hands down one of my favorite sushi restaurants I've been to...and I've been around.

I found this lovely place on Yelp!  I wanted good sushi, for a decent price, without the long wait time.  This place was IT.

I live in LA but go to SF frequently.  I try to eat here any chance I get.

I highly recommend the special sushi menu.  And yes, get TWO ceviche sushi orders.  Your taste buds will love you.

I have tried almost everything on the menu and I will be honest.  I don't love EVERY item, but that is because I'm particular about the types of fish I like.  I did venture out and tried some items, and don't get me wrong.  They were tasty, but not for me.  

The one thing that I love about this place is their creativity.  Their special sushi items are very sophisticated.  The taste variations make you feel like you are doing a tasting for Top Chef.  The other winning factor especially coming from LA is this is the only place that serves fresh toro sushi for about $5.  FIVE DOLLARS!!!  That is insane.  Also, you can order one piece of sushi instead of the typical 2 pieces they serve at other places.  I like this because I don't get too full and can try more plates.

I've never been disappointed at this place.  The service is very good.  And you aren't breaking the bank too much, especially for a sushi joint.  

The place is really small so I suggest groups of 4 or less.  Try as much as you can because it's worth it.

Lastly, they have a Jelly Fish salad which I am dying to try but it's seasonal.  I'm flying up this weekend so wish me luck so I can add it to this review!!
author: Cathy C.

description:
Oh man, this place is the shit. fois gras with raspberry sauce nigiri. That's right, fois gras. The shit.  (see photo 11!!)

There's a really nice variety of contemporary takes on sushi. Everything we had was delicious. I would highly recommend this restaurant to anyone who is looking for something outside of the box.

Oh yeah, and try the spicy tuna with quail egg hand roll. Scott roll I think it's called. That was f'ing good.
author: Annie T.

description:
I'm a little bit peeved at myself because I've been on a food porn binge lately taking pictures of my food conquests like any Hong Kong celebrity would. Logically I brought my camera here for the fantastic presentation only to realize that I left the memory card at my friend's apartment so now everyone misses out on the eye candy. :(
