Kabuto Sushi met my expectations, I really enjoyed how the menu was different than most traditional sushi places but didn't have to slather everything in mayo to make it more appealing to none sashimi eaters. It is a rather small restaurant and I was cramped up next to the faux fireplace but hey fobby accents like that make the place more authentic. We got there on a Saturday night and it took about 15 minutes to get seated for two, but it would be hard to get a large party seated here.

I can't remember exactly what I had but I recommend the Tazmanian salmon whole heartedly, if salmon had a toro equivalent, this would be it. It was fresh and buttery and tasted just right. We also had the halibut ceviche which was different but tasty. I thought it might be too sour to complement the sushi rice and nori but it was perfect. The butter fish (escolar)  was also amazing and super fresh as all the fish was. Lastly we had the toro tartar which was served with a mint leaf of some sort, it was also highly recommended. I'm not sure what was in it, but all I saw was the words "toro" and I was sold. I really do appreciate the fact that they put their entire menu online so you can salivate and plan before you get there.

They also remind you when not to eat something with soy sauce which I find amusing, and they have a female sushi chef  with cute hair, you know the important things. The presentation here is pretty awesome and it wasn't too hard on the wallet. I thought we'd spend at least $50 a person, but when the tab came out it was about $35 before tip. Not too shabby. I would give it 4.5 because I thought the croquette, and sweet shrimp were just average, along with the cramped quarters, but it gets five for creativity and presentation. Plus it's right down the block from where I usually stay. Oh also, love that they have a tea selection.
author: Crystal T.

description: small unique Japanese restaurant. Try the Fresh oysters with caviar, uni, roe, raw egg, and gold flakes. Also, I love the Mini lobster tail sushi. You get what you paid for, it's worth it. The green tea brulee isn't as good as expected, so I will probably try other desserts next time.
author: Sandy L.

description:
My dinner companion and I walked in around 7ish and we got seated that bar. We were given the menus to browse through and oshiboris to wipe our hands with. Their sashimi was fresh and wonderful that it basically melted in your mouth. 

We had ordered the hamachi kama, a platter of assorted sashimi, a few specialty items:ceviche wrapped in crispy seaweed and drizzled with lime and sea salt, Hamachi pear & Toro Tartare. I had also ordered a scallop sushi but that didn't appeal to me. Everything else so so yummy, that we had to top the evening off with another order of the ceviche. 

Definitely will go back again.
author: Trina C.

description: The scallop on a shell looking thing was delish........ Ceviche was slamming too, no soy sauce needed.  Small and intimate setting....... Gotta scavenge for parking.
author: BENADICK F.

description:
4.3 or so. This place is really, really good.

I realized today that sometimes, having a hangover is beneficial. The odd hours, random spontaneous appetites can work in your favor. Witness today, New Year's Day 2009. We rolled out of bed well after noon, and ended up in the Outer Richmond around 4:30 when our first hunger pangs kicked in. Kabuto opened at 5. Perfect.

We got in and scored a seat at the bar, which was quite open. 1.5 hours later, when we left, the place was packed and a fierce mob had gathered outside, waiting to get in.

Service was polite and efficient. Atmosphere is, well, it's probably the only element you can really knock the place for. It's not bad, it's just not a factor, really.

But the food is outstanding. We ordered the Hamachi Pear and Katsunagi off the special rolls menu. Hamachi Pear was what it sounds like, topped with a dollop of Kabuto's special mustard sauce. We tried this without soy sauce. It provided an odd delight to the taste buds. Good stuff. The Katsunagi, well, we can't remember what was in it. Unagi, presumably. There was some tempura-ing going on, and it was all rolled up hand-roll style. Delicious.

We also got a Dragon Roll, which I can only say was solid and so, so good, and a spicy tuna roll, which was average.

Nigiri was ordered a little late, after the restaurant got packed, so it took a little too long, but that's understood.

Overall, I'd rate this place up there with Shimo as best sushi in the Richmond.
author: Jeff H.

description:
After walking by too many times saying "we need to check this place out" a couple Saturdays ago we finally did. Although it was packed, we were sat comfortably at the bar, and ordered a beer and a glass of cold sake (big and strong enough to share). 

We ordered a few of the more traditional dishes (nigiri assortment and a few rolls) which were good, and a few dishes off the specials menu, which were excellent. My favorite was the Toro Tartar, which is two pieces of chopped raw tuna mixed with avocado, deep fried seaweed, and onion. Another favorite was the Ceviche, which consists of halibut and salsa wrapped with deep fried seaweed and served with lime and sea salt. Honorable mention goes to the Katsunagi: unagi, avocado, deep fried seaweed with raspberry miso sauce. Very creative but balanced flavors. 

Dishes were presented beautifully; it was nice mix of a traditional and gourmet sushi eating experience. Prices are higher than your typical local sushi joint, although it's definitely worth the splurge to stick to the specials.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Update: The chef has since left, haven't tried it with the new chef yet.

Innovative and fresh.  This small space on Geary serves excellent quality fish.  Best tuna and toro ever.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Chawan Mushi: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chawan_Mushi

I love it, love it, love it!!!  So far I have only been able to get it here.  The sushi is also fantastic.  If you want to try UNI for the first time then this is the place.  The uni was so fresh it tasted sweet with just a hint of sea but not fishy at all.  I love this place but don't be starving when you arrive.  Keep in mind this won't be a quick dinner if they are busy.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Went here last night for the first time. I really enjoyed myself. It was a Sunday night, not too crowded, and the best thing very fresh fish. I had been craving sushi for awhile so it was a special treat for a Sunday. 

The menu and presentation was both diverse and creative. Also, there was never any looking around wondering if we could order more. Our waitress was great. 

There was fired salmon, jalapeo hamachi (fantastic) and really nice little tasty treats that just melted together in your mouth. - I am thinking of the Toro tartar. 

Now all we need to find is somewhere after we can go for dessert- Like an Ice Cream Parlour!
author: Danielle V.

description:
Kabuto is all about blending flavors and textures in perfection! 

This was my 3rd visit to this small sushi joint and it was the 3rd time I left this place happy and satisfied. 
The decor is minimalistic but still has a little flair here and there, the sushi speaks for itself. There are two menus, the white menu has innovative special rolls.  Don't forget to check out the weekly specials on the board. Right now they have a jalapeno hamachi dish that just melts in your mouth combined with the texture of the jalapeno (not to mention a little kick) make a perfect union in your mouth.

Must order:
The foie gras sushi...a must try,  the savory foie gras and the tartness of the raspberry blend together to make a unique burst of flavor that makes you want to keep it in your mouth forever.

I liked the Anmitsu dessert: I thought the flavors were light, fruity and the green tea ice cream goes well with the sweet red bean paste. I prefer Asian desserts because they are lighter and for some reason, make it seem more healthy. Hey, works for me. 

3/21/07 update:
4th time here and i still love this place! a new thing try on the specials board: 1849 Oyster - oyster + uni + salmon roe + tobiko + raw quail egg + a drizzle of ponzu sauce = extreme mouthgasm!
author: Kristina L.

description:
Just checking in to reaffirm that this place is excellent.  Went on a Saturday at about 7pm and didn't have to wait long at all to be seated.  

As I said last time, you should only order from the daily specials board and the "special sushi" menu.  Highly recommend the "U.F.T." (so good we got a second order!) and the "CeViChe".  Boyfriend got the duck sushi and LOVED it.  We were less sold on the "Sushi Mozarella": nice concept but disappointingly bland execution -- if you want this done well go to Sushi Zone in the Castro and order the baked bass.

Overall, very pleased.  This may be my second-favourite sushi restaurant in SF, behind Sushi Zone -- and has a considerably shorter wait time.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I've been eating at Kabuto for over 10 years now (it used to be located across the street) and I will never stop eating here.  Kabuto is hands down the best sushi I have ever had in the United States.  It is small and looks kind of cheap from the street, but it is so eff-ing good that you won't know what hit you.  Their specialty Nigiri, if you could call it that, ranges from Duck to Ceviche, both of which are on my top 5 list of favorite foods.  

The wine list is decent, with a solid range of various sakes, but no sushi meal is complete without the large Sapporo.   The service is very friendly and the sushi chefs speak more than one langauge. (The younger guy spoke to me in Spanish. It confused the hell out of me)  The one thing you might complain about is the price, but it is worth every cent (especially when our fish stocks are being depleted so quickly that there won't be any sushi left by 2050).  

Perfect for a date, an anniversary, or a small group outing (no more than four).
author: Charley B.

description:
This is going to be one of my favorite sushi places in the city!  The menu choices are impressive, and they've got some great special rolls.  Some of my favorites were the  CeViChe roll, the Hamachi pear roll, and the Mozzarella roll.  I've never had anything like them!
 The only negatives were a long wait for a table on a Sunday night, despite having a reservation.  And we were surprised by how small the portions were, not the place for a big appetite, although our bill was also surprisingly small.  But the free beer we got since it was the chefs birthday made all that easily forgotten.
author: Rochelle J.

description:
Tried Kabuto for the first time and the first thing that comes to mind is that their fish is super fresh and buttery.  Everything is really simple and clean.  There is no doubt that the sushi chefs put a love into the dishes.

My boyfriend and I ordered:
~ Apple Lamb Sushi: OMG!! Love the lamb and grilled apple combo!
~ Crunchy Sushi: the halibut tempura was fried to perfection...very light and moist and the curry sauce was delicious!
~ Sammy Roll: another roll with the delicious curry sauce...this one was a lighter since it has salmon on the outside and was basically a California roll inside.
~ Spicy California Roll: loved that they use fresh crab instead of surimi and no mayo. Their spicy sauce is a little on the tangy side and not the usual spicy mayo that most sushi places use.
~ Roll with Tuna outside and Soft Shell Crab inside: most disappointing dish we had...soft shell crab was over-fried and tasted a little burnt
~ Matcha Creme Brulee: first time I've ever had green tea creme brulee...you definitely taste the matcha in it.  The custard could have been smoother but very yummy nonetheless =)

Their portions are super small and neither of us were full afterward.  The bill came to be about $60 after tax and tip...a little too expensive even though the quality was outstanding.

The service could have been better though.  The waitress never bothered to refill our water =/
author: Katelynn L.

description:
I heard of the restaurant from many of my friends and finally made it here. It changed my sushi restaurant  rating in San Francisco!

We orderd Asari sakamushi, Maguro Nuta, and Tsubo yaki, as appetizers. These traditional Japanese plates are great.  Their unique sushi looked good but we went for traditonal sushi as we expected high quality. That was great. Unfortunately we came in a little late Saturday night and they were running out of some of my favorite fish but it was still great.  

Their service is a bit slow but the servers/chefs are nice. $100 for 2 people are still reasonable  I would love to go back here anytime   =)
author: Yoko S.

description: Quite possibly one of the worst sushi experiences.... the sushi quality rivaled those found at your local seafood buffet.  I had higher hopes given the consistent lines at this Richmond neighborhood restaurant.  We ordered the Chef's tasting menu ready to go all out as Ino-san of Ino Sushi was on vacation.  The omakase is heavy on hamachi... Hamachi is not only for novice sushi eaters but it was your B-quality hamachi (mmm... maybe C).  Most of the fish served have no flavor.  Kabuto has also attempted to fancy up their sashimi dishes ala Nobu-style. Sadly, it falls flat.  Just b/c you place a jalapeño and a small slice of Asian pear with yuzu sauce will not make it good unless you use high-grade hamachi.  A few diners next to us kept raving about the food.  That and the the people waiting for a table belie the fact how average sushi can still be a good business model in the Richmond...  Sad but understandable.  Not all dishes fell flat.  Out of the 10 dishes that came out, two had interesting flavor profiles yet low quality fish tempered what could have been.  The only highlight was the wait staff.  Eager, hardworking young Korean girls despite their confusion and mixing up the orders.  I would not be so disappointed if the final tab was 1/2 of higher quality Japanese restaurants.  Alas, it was about the same.  Sorry to be so hard on this place but this place would fail in Japan.  No experienced sushi eater should come here.  If you are ok with their sushi, just go to Isobune in Japantown where it is served on a boat.  At least you get a little Disney experience along with your sushi...
author: Laurence H.

description:
They have a great selection of fresh fish and an assortment of unique sushi pieces that are each a work of art.  In fact, most of the special have distinct flavors and the server instructed us not to eat them with soy sauce.  The presentation and quality of the food go hand in hand at this place and won't disappoint.  

Highlights:
- The 1849 Oysters
- Hamachi Pear 
- Scallop Sushi
- Poke 
- Foie Gras Sushi
author: Wei K.

description: This place is really small. Sushi here is ok..maybe just a tad beyond ok but that is it. I do give them props for foie gra sushi and other ones i can't find anywhere else. Their sushi is actually pretty expensive. I would rather pay that kind of money at Shimo sushi on clement. But if you never tried this place, do try them out then you be the judge.
author: Sophie L.

description:
Say it with me, "Green Tea Creme Brulee, ....Green Tea Creme Brulee."  

The portions for its entrees are actually quite small.  My friend had a pork katsu that was like an appetizer dish.  My tempura was your normal, typical tempura.  

The spicy tuna roll definitely had kick to it.  They use some kind of special spicy sauce that was quite good.

But definitely the dish that sealed the deal was the Green Tea Creme Brulee.  

I might even recommend just going to Kabuto just for the creme brulee.
author: Alan T.

description: Nice folks, excellent sushi. What more could you ask for?
author: Joe M.

description:
Every now & then, we love trying to discover a sushi place that other Yelpers are enjoying...To add to our rotisserie of fav Sushi joints...So we gave this a shot based not only on volume of reviews but the quality of them.

First thing you learn that while it's outer as opposed to inner Richmond, parking is still a real pain

Second thing you learn is that the restaurant at one point or another was situated almost exactly across the street from where it's presently located on Geary...We learned this because some listings still include their old address but more importantly their old sign is still at the old location (And more prominent than the new one)...Strange.

Seating...It's a small location with roughly 10 or 11 tables and a dozen seats at the sushi bar from where the chefs operate...We had reservations and arrived on time but that didn't seem to matter too much...For a restaurant that we later learned was pretty organized, the seating/hosting aspect of it left a lot to be desired, IMHO...There seemed to be confusion from the moment we arrived...3 tables had just left and 3 different parties arrived nearly simultaneously...We were seated even before we got a chance to mention we had a reservation.

Decor/Location...Nothing memorable and again it's small but not particularly noisy either...Very casual atmosphere and you pretty much won't stick out even if you came in a t shirt and jeans.

Food/Menu...Everyone's sushi experience is different for different reasons...We're primarily sashimi kind of sushi eaters but will mix it up with some rolls (Especially if they sound creative)...Sometimes you want a place for both the 'scene' and the food and sometimes you just want some quality sashimi etc. regardless of how things appear...Tonight we just felt like some quality sashimi....You'll notice that they have two different menus (A bit confusing and overwhelming, IMHO)...One is a specials menu (Which is not a short menu) and the other appears to be their main menu...The specials menu had a section that included items that sounded like very complicated entree dishes but actually turned out to be two pieces or so of sashimi that were prepared in rather unique ways....Not sure if this is a traditional sort of Japanese presentation or not but I hadn't really seen that before.

The other thing that pops out is that there aren't a lot of rolls which was fine for us...If we wanted the 'cute' rolls we could always head back to Blowfish or something...We ordered a couple of different varieties of sashimi as well as a jalapeno Hamachi kind of appetizer...It was fantastic...The fish itself was as impressive a quality as I can ever recall having and the jalapeno flavoring to it was a perfect compliment...From that moment on, we knew we were in for a treat...We kinda just tried different items but unfortunately we only tried a couple of things from the 'Specials' menu that included the much written about ceviche....Really amazing and very glad we got a chance to try that....Next time around, we're going to get more from that menu.

Overall, it was a terrific experience in terms of the quality of the fish and the different preparations.

From a service standpoint, very polite and helpful but also not very pushy...We never felt rushed while never feeling like we had to chase someone down...The staff, actually, did a great job at recommending some items over others too.

Downsides...It still does bother me when we roll into a sushi joint and see them serving endangered species...At some point (Hopefully soon), this has to stop...I wasn't crazy about the decor or how small the place is on the inside but that wouldn't keep me from not coming back...It's not cheap but it's also not the most expensive in town...I think if it were about 15-20% cheaper, it'd be ideal but already it is one of my top two places in town to go now...I really was won over and look forward to coming back.

Immediately after leaving, I called anyone I could to let them know, you GOTTA try this place out.
author: Barca F.

description:
I love fish :-)!

The wait can be long and the prices are high, but the food is well worth it. The sushi chefs are incredible and created beautiful sushi plates. Tonight, I had the fresh Tasmanian King Salmon ($4 each), Tuna Sampler that included blue fin, big eye, yellow fin and albacore sashimi, and the Halibut Ceviche with salsa. The fish were fresh and delectable. 

Miso soup was okay, plain tasting, but very salty with little seaweed. Make sure to drink some Asahi Black (rich and smooth tasting) with your meal because it goes very well with raw fish. Be careful with the tea because the cup is burning hot! 

Kabuto has so many other things on their menu that I want to try so I would definitely go back here again.
author: Celeste M.

description:
I went here a few years ago with a good buddy because he said this was the best sushi in the city.  I was also interested in going all those years ago because Kabuto had recently been featured in article in a men's magazine as the best sushi in the country.  (It was Details ok...but the GQ wannabe Details, not the frat version of Details.  Oh the shame!)  That meal was awesome.  Then the place closed down.  My buddy told me that the chef owner had decided to hang up the skates and call it a career.  Then about 4 months ago, I noticed that Kabuto seemed to be open again.

The girlfriend and I were going to a movie at the Bridge, so we decided to grab something relatively close.  I suggested that we try the new Kabuto.  We got there around 5:15 and the place was empty.  We timed it well, because about 10 minutes after we sat down, the place filled up like Bonds' head after a session with Greg Anderson.  We were jammed in between two other couples in the small doubles table.  I hate that.  Whenever I get sardined that way, I feel a need to lower my voice to an almost inaudible level because I am afraid of disturbing my neighbors.  

There were two menus, one of "special" items and the other of more traditional fare.  We quickly tossed the special menu because I remembered that the special items were small and weird...like the mozzerella sushi.  We went for the Dragon Roll, toro roll, spicy tuna, and hamachi.  They had aji nigiri on their special menu, but the very nice waitress informed us they were out.  Damn it all to Hell!

I really enjoyed the spicy tuna.  They made it spicy by plopping some kind of hot sauce on top.  I think that is cheating, but I iked it anyway.  The Dragon Roll stood out among the sushi that we ordered.  I enjoyed.  The girfriend did not.  We started the meal with some seaweed salad.  Kabuto does not serve what I am used to when I order wakame salad.  Kabuto's was a regular green salad with much bigger seaweed.  The dressing was excellent, but I was not too keen on the seaweed.

When it comes down to it, the new Kabuto did not measure up to the old Kabuto.  Good, but not great.  Give it a try.
author: Chris I.

description:
This is a place I only tell people I really, really like.  I made the mistake of going on a casual date here once and then ran into the guy taking some other girl here a few months later!  

Kabuto sushi is my favorite sushi place in the city.  It's very small so not appropriate for groups larger than 4.  The fish here is extremely fresh, and they have a wide variety of traditional sushi or more modern takes like fois gras sushi with a raspberry reduction, and my personal favorite, the ceviche roll.  The ceviche roll comes with specific instructions to not use any soy sauce with it.  and they are nazis about that!  I also recommend the gold rush oysters.  They are oysters on a half shell served with uni, salmon roe, raw quail egg and bits of real gold leaf!  

The prices are a bit on the higher side, but if you want cheap sushi go to No Name sushi or We be sushi in the mission instead.
author: Jade L.

description:
Don't misjudge by unimpressive window into one of the best new age style sushi joints in the San Francisco. We made a reservation which I always think is a plus considering many great places take no reservations. We sat at the sushi bar and began to order almost every special off the white erase board as well a sushi specials off the menu. Wow, this is a wonderful new age style sushi joint that impressed me with every dish and left me feeling euphoric. Expensive but well worth skipping a few crappy meals out for one great meal at Kabuto. My husband and I are hard to impress when it come to sushi and we were not disappointed. We have worked at quite a few fine sushi joints for the past 10 years, one of them being Ozumo...we know our stuff and we felt very impressed about the creativity in the dishes as well as the super fresh fish. Great service with a wide range of delicious dishes. 

Some of our dishes- the ceviche was beyond unique, not at all what I would consider ceviche but I loved the super crisp nori and bits of sea salt. The toro tartar was mouthwatering served perfectly on little bits of sushi rice topped with delicious caviar. I love foie gras, so foie as sushi was delightful, topped with a half raspberry and a tiny piece of chive...I wanted another order but I had to limit myself so I could try as many things as possible. Fresh sea scallops were one of the highlights from the evening served two ways- sashimi and a scallop amuse bouche. 1894 oysters were outrageous they were topped with buttery uni, a silky quail egg, black and red caviar and then topped with flecks of gold to impress. Hamachi with jalapenos is something I have had at many places but Kabuto's was delightful with large, thick slices of hamachi.  Round off the evening with 4 orders of ono sashimi to satisfied my tropical tastes. Living in Florida for many years I have become spoiled with fresh ono at almost every meal.  I cannot wait to go again next month! Absolutely, not your typical sushi place but if you like creativity and new style sushi you must try.
author: Cheryl T.

description:
If you aren't sure what you like or don't this is a great place to try.  The owner is very helpful, he can tell you what was flown in that day - but don't be scared of the prices, you can try everything BY THE PIECE!!! It's perfect, because you get to try so much - but you won't spend a fortune to find what you like.

The owner recommended butter fish, and oh my! am I glad he did!  It was amazing.  We have brought many friends here since being introduced - can't imagine it will be topped for some time to come!

Parking can be a challenge in the area, go for side streets!
author: Alicia W.

description: We really enjoy going to Kabuto especially if you have family or friends in town. The dishes are very creative and delicious!!
author: Susan R.

description:
small place so i reccomend you make reservations...the place gets packed fast

very unique sushi (first thought i thought these were apperitzers, but didn't even realize that all this was on top of a piece of rice)

CeViChe Halibut and salsa wrapped with deep
fried seaweed and served with lime 
and sea salt. (fresh and flavorful)

Hamachi Pear Yellowtail sushi topped with sliced pear 
and kabuto fruity mustard sauce (2nd fav dish, the pear goes perfect with the fish and the mustard...to die for)

Hirame "Yuzu" Halibut Sushi with pickled shisonomi topped with Yuzu-Kosho Paste (my 2nd least fav, but still good and my friend says takes like what yuzu is suppose to taste like)

Shrimp & Crab 
Tartar sushi Chopped shrimp and crab mixed with Kabuto tartar sauce served with egg yolk, capers, anchovy, cilantro, 
and grape (i didn't like this, they give u a lot more pieces, but just didn't wow me at all, nothing special)

Spicy Scallop Scallop sushi served with kabuto fruity mustard sauce (yummy)

Hamachi Kama Yellowtail collar served with 
grated radish and ponzu sauce (excellent)

Foie Gras Sushi Seard marinated goose liver served
with balsamic raspberry sauce (my favorite. just melts in ur mouth. not a fan of rasberries, but it goes so well together. i could just eat of bunch of these)

salmon wontons (a lil burned..nothing special)

stick with all the sushi
author: Karen H.

description:
No wait on a Sunday around 6:30. Finding parking a block away on Geary took just ten minutes. Oh God. Something is wrong, I know it. I'm not picking up the phone if my dentist calls. I know karma when I see it.

The sushi was inventive and very fresh. Great hamachi. The chef looked like an artist with his gray hair and reading glasses perched on his nose and the dishes came out plated beautifully.

The staff kept teasing us by putting down dishes that belonged to other tables then rushing back and taking them away. Was it a ploy or absent-mindedness? Was it a diabolical plan to show us all the things on the menu that we didn't order but could have? Who knows.

BTW, they *do* take reservations, although I'm not sure how valuable they will be when the crowds pour in.
author: Mister X.

description:
yummmmmmmy! Every time I hear the word "kabuto," I start to crave the Ono Grape! Oh my goodness, it's good. Imagine: fresh, raw wahoo strewn across rice, with a massive, plump grapefruit slice draped across the top, and a sauce that fuses both ingredients together into a taste similar to a grape. In plain words, the combination is ineffable. I crave the Ono Grape nigiri.

Oh, and the Saba (Mackerel) is quite good as well. As is the Hamachi.
author: Sally M.

description: I Love this place!!!! Everything is so fresh and yummy!!!! The beef one and the Uni is my FAVORITE!!!! I recommend for date night and friend gathering. Such a romantic and relax place~ and yes! Is a little bit pricy, but trust me!!! everything is worth it!!!!
author: Fiona W.

description:
This is hands down my favorite sushi joint in the city which is why I have avoided writing a review until now. Looks like I will have to face the fact that the cats out of the bag and it has been for a while. Its obviously no secret anymore as the tiny restaurant is packed to the gills on a Wednesday night. Well...they do say denial is not just a river in Egypt. 

We started with the seaweed salad which is a different take on the usual mound of bright green seaweed with a few sesame seeds sprinkled on top. It was fresh seaweed atop a mound of greens and garnished with sliced grapes and cherry tomatoes. Yum! 

All of the fish is exceptionally fresh and artfully presented. We enjoyed the hamachi pear, kastunagi, salmon, escolar, amberjack, yellowjack, and unagi. The abalone and king mackerel were fresh but I didn't enjoy the firmness of the mackerel or the crunchy cartilaginous texture of the abalone. It was like a giant clam but crunchy. Ick. 

The sake list is long and the sapporo is flowing. Its a great place to enjoy better than average sushi.
author: Stacy T.

description:
Outstanding sushi.
This isn't your typical roll sushi-this is creative, inspired, californized sushi that just melts in your mouth. I went for my birthday dinner a few weeks ago and was blown away. Years ago I had been to Kabuto when it was across the street and was resistant to trying it again because it didn't overly impressed me. The new version of Kabuto is possibly the best sushi experience I've had in the city. 
Expensive, but worth EVERY penny.
author: Melyss S.

description:
Just came back from Kabuto.  This is a highly recommended sushi place if you can stand the wait.  Basically you cannot make reservations.  Just go there and put your name on the white board at the front door and wait for about 45min.  There are only 7 tables and a sushi bar.  When I left at 9:30p today, there were still people waiting to be seated.

Like other reviewers said, the fish is VERY VERY fresh, and the dishes are very creative and elegantly displayed.  5 star food quality.  However, the table size won't be big enough to accomodate any party larger than 7 people.

Some special sushi I like :  Foie gras sushi, duck breast sushi, crunchy hamachi.

Service was alright, but always lack of serving hands.
author: Alex T.

description:
I've had people tell me this place was one of the best sushi places in the city. I still haven't found good sushi in the city, so I decided to try this place.

I have to admit the creativity of some of their rolls (as well as their wide range of items on their menu) were great! But I also have to say that if you're a fan of the classic sushi (sashimi) meal, you may be disappointed.

Amaebi: Not as sweet (fresh) as I've had at other sushi restaurants. No offer of the amaebi head as well. I never usually eat it, but they should at least offer.

Baby Main Lobster: The sauce was excellent, but the lobster was very dry.

Hamachi Pear: My favorite dish of the night. The pear and hamachi went great together!

Sashimi (Toro, Blue-Fin Tuna, Kampachi, Tuna, Salmon, etc): I was probably the most disappointed in the sashimi. I have to agree with another reviewer on here... you pay good money for good, fresh sushi. Some of the sushi came out like chunks.. and just didn't taste like sushi that was sliced properly.

I guess I'm still in search... anyone have any recommendations?
author: Haw Y.

description:
Many yelpers talk about the creative dishes/rolls here.  I beg to differ.  We tried a few of the creative dishes and all were just ok.  Who needs rice to go with foie gras.  Call me a sushi purist... I appreciate the chef's adventure side, but some things are better in their classical form.  However, this place has really fresh fish.  So order any sashimi and nigiri to your hearts' content.  

Also worthy of mention, the eggplant with miso is a stand out dish. I can eat it everyday.  Overall, the service is quick and attentive.  This place is a great value, I will definitely come back.
author: Karen N.

description:
The service was incredibly horrible.

First, they gave our table to someone else, even though we were next in the waiting list.  The waitress apologized, and said a 'better' table will come up shortly.  I think sitting at a table instead of waiting like 20 more minutes is better right?

Second, it took us over 2 hours to complete our meal.  The food takes forever to come out and it comes out at the most random waves.  At one point, we had to wait an hour to get three orders.  I mean we didn't even eat that much and it took 2 hours.  In fact, after waiting, we built up an appetite, and ate somewhere alse right after leaving this place.

The staff actually seems like they don't care at all.  I can't believe they can stay in business this way.  The staff just hangs out and talks to each other instead of serving people and making food.  I would understand the poor service and the wait time if the place was really busy, but it was about the close and was only half full.

Not once were they perceptive enough to see that i needed more water and more ginger.  I had to ask them each time.

The prices were a bit on the expensive side as well.  I wouldn't really mind spending this much money on food, if the service was good.  It's like it didn't matter to them we were spending our hard earned cash on it.  

Food wise, it was decent.  The bluefin tuna was discolored an unattractive and an unappetizing brown.  

Anyway, I give it a 1 star, because of the incredibly bad service.  This place's staff is incompetant and indifferent to the customer's needs.  I really want to stress that.

We went there for the good zagat reviews, but i think the new ownership doesn't understand how to run a sushi restaurant.
I'm willing to bet it doesn't get high marks from Zagat in 2007.
author: Jung L.

description:
Loved this place. When we went, we just signed up on the clipboard to the left as you enter. An egalitarian queue system that other popular places would be wise to try out.

We sat down at the sushi bar, and instead of ordering a whole bunch of the special rolls, we asked the chef to whip up some nigiri according to what he thought was the best stuff that night. Was not disappointing - our culinary trip went everwhere from toro to Tasmanian salmon. Awesome, melt-in-your mouth fish. Spectacular presentation - one of the sushi chefs used a blowtorch on a special salmon roll to partially cook it right in front of everyone. Plates were simple, and expertly refined with floral garnishes. Definitely a treat for the eyes and the tastebuds.

This place is great for the price, though this isn't somewhere you'd come every week.
author: Derek C.

description:
THIS IS A REVIEW FOR BOTH KABUTO AS IT WAS AND THE NEW KABUTO.

i used to eat at kabuto religiously and almost weekly for years before sachio sold it to eric a few years back, and from there i began to more oft. eat at their family friend's restaurant ryoko's.  i was at first very hesitant to try it again at all, but i did, and 600$ later,  i was very much pleased to see that they are putting much effort into keeping the true spirit of kabuto alive.  there are many embarassing yet delicious sushi's that i still reminisce about, such as their ceviche sushi and toro tartare.
author: christopher a.

description:
From the mouthwatering food to the endearing old Japanese chef/owner behind the sushi bar, this cozy little restaurant in the Richmond district has solidified itself as my favorite Japanese restaurant in San Francisco. 

In a world filled with hip sushi restaurants focused on complicated, over sauced rolls and fancy sake cocktails, the simplicity of Kabuto makes for a refreshing and much welcomed sushi dining experience. Despite having a menu filled with fresh & traditional Japanese sushi/dishes, the 2 things I could never live without here would be the Toro Tartar special sushi and the Ceviche special sushi. 

The Toro Tartar is a melt-in-your-mouth masterpiece of negi-toro and avocado on a bed of rice and crispy seaweed, topped off with a perfectly fried shiso leaf. It's important to remember to eat this sushi as is. The use of soy sauce or wasabi is highly discouraged by the waitresses and the chefs... but for good reason!

When you're done savoring every last bite of the Toro Tartar, clear your palate for the refreshing delicateness of the Ceviche. Served up in 2 piece orders, you'll find yourself ordering in bulk for these light and citrusy halibut sushi pieces. They come to your table looking like little mounds of chopped sashimi goodness on top of a single piece of seaweed, and end up tasting like pure heaven with a dash of lime to keep things unique.

All in all, Kabuto is an amazing restaurant with fresh ingredients, cozy decor and brilliant sushi. If I were you, I'd make your reservation today!
author: Diane C.

description: We had a Groupon special and ordered all the rare and expensive dishes that we normally would not be able to afford.  That was the last time.  With a Groupon special, it was totally worth it, but I would not spend the regular price on the lobster, scallops, and foie gras.  The sushi was ok.  The service was fine.  The space is way too crowded and the wait, a bit too long.
author: Nadine H.

description: SO yummy! The sushi is very fresh and unique. The only reason I'm giving it 4 stars is that the place is very small.
author: Sfgrl P.

description:
I could eat here everyday!   Love the food and the staff.  I've gone so many times, they know me now.  :)   
The sushi here is fresh, great quality, deliciouso, and great presentation.  From their specialty menu, my favourites are foie gras sushi, ceviche (halibut), toro tartar, hamachi pear, hamachi jalapeno (not listed on menu, but on their whiteboard).  If you love sushi, you will not be disappointed with this place.
author: Lina L.

description:
Just when you think you've seen them all, along comes Kabuto Sushi.  I stopped in last week for a visit and was pleasantly surprised by the fare, everything from apple lamb sushi (think sushi sized skewer) to hamachi jalapeno sashimi to halibut and salsa wrapped ceviche kept our taste buds on our toes.  I especially liked the crunchy sushi--tempura halibut served with special curry sauce.

Service was friendly, and despite the short line tailing outside the door, we weren't rushed.  Unfortunately eating this good doesn't come cheap, dinner for two came out to seventy bucks after tax and tip, no drinks.  But unlike other local sushi joints (Drunken Sushi comes to mind) at Kabuto you actually get bang for your buck.
author: Tony L.

description:
Food:  we had sushi for lunch.  the seafood was very fresh.  the sushi chef was very creative. it was kinda fusion of west and japanese. not cheap though, but once in a while is ok.  today, it was $70/person. 
one thing i really don't like was that i think they put MSG in the sauce.  my mouth got super dry afterwards.

Service:  nice.  they will tell you which doesn't need to dip in soy sauce. presentation is very westernized.  the soy sauce bottle was the type that normally use for olive oil.

Parking:  street parking.  urgh.

Recommend?  definitely if you have enough money to spend. 

Revisit?  of course, but once i save up some money

Overall:  sashimi doesn't have sauce.  so, avoid the ones like Tsunami that has tons of sauce.  i would give this restaurant a 3.5 star due to the MSG. but a 3-star won't be fair for them. so i give them a 4 star. the food deserves it except the MSG part.
author: Kay C.

description:
Not as good as before.  The fisrt thing that should have tipped me off was that there was no line on a Friday night as there has been before.  We just walked up and were seated.  No placing our name on the list.  No waiting.  The second red flag was that you can now buy gift cirtificates on restaurant.com.  I don't know if this is a good thing or a bad thing.  Service has always been slow and was expception.  Last time I was here I found a rolled piece of paper in my spider roll. GROSS!  Sushi was decent.  It is however well priced.  All in all I would have to say that I would return with the coupon, but my expectations have definately gone down for this once wonderful gem for sushi.

Why is it that they never have anything on the menu??? Hamachi kama is always out as well as the pampano!!!!
author: Darren I.

description:
I was impressed with their variety of creative dishes and flavor combinations.  I especially enjoyed their tuna sampler (big, fat chunks of melt-in-your-mouth tuna), the ceviche roll (loved the salty-tart combo), and the foie gras roll (served with a delicious raspberry sauce).

My biggest complaint is how uncomfortable it was getting through the meal.  I know it's not a huge space, but they pack people to capacity, which means tables & seats all the way up to the front door...which means terribly uncomfortable gusts of wind whenever someone opens the door.  I'm looking forward to trying this place out again, but perhaps at a less-crowded time and on a much warmer day.  PLEASE, if at all possible, I would suggest building some sort of vestiblue to block the wind because the bone-chilling draft will make you cry.
author: Andrea U.

description:
I love this place. This place is authentically Japanese and offers fresh sushi and a few fusion dishes.

I have been there at least three times and always have had a great meal.  I loved the monk fish liver, Foie Gras Sushi, Hamachi Collar and 1849 oysters.

Positive:  Simple, fresh and authentic Japanese sushi
Con: Croweded, small and the decor needs updating.
author: VIOLA L.

description:
Hands down the best sushi there is in the city!  The sashimi here is very very fresh! And their Special Sushi Rolls are creative and very unique -- not to be found elsewhere!
Try to the Civeche Roll.... one of their greatest!

They do not take reservations and the place is super small and always packed -- be prepared for a wait..but the servers are so nice...it was cold out while we were waiting for a tablw so they even brought out some green tea to warm us up beforehand!
author: Jennie L.

description:
The grilled eggplant with miso is one of my favorite dishes in the city.  They have a flaming conch shell soup if you like theatrics, but the variety  of fresh fish and inventive specialty rolls make this a balanced  modern & traditional sushi bar.   check out the 1849 oyster with quail egg, urchin, salmon roe, caviar, green onion and gold leaf.  visually scary, but tastes crisp and clean once you gulp it.  
There has been a slight drop off with the new owners, but the service seemed more attentive.
author: Christian W.

description: Some of the best sushi I've ever had! Had the usual saba, ikura, hamachi and all were wonderful. The unagi nigiri had such HUGE pieces of unagi I couldn't even believe it! The miso soup was delicious and the seaweed salad was different and so good. Spider roll was so perfect, crispy and full of flavor. The spicy tuna roll was super spicy and delicious! Spicier than usual and I loved it! Also, for the first time I was lucky enough to try monkfish liver sushi and it was really to die for! Drooool! Can't wait to come back!
author: Kristen L.

description:
You'll love this place if you like "creative sushi"!!

The Favs:  My favorite was the "ono grape".  I wasn't sure if I liked the wahoo more or the grapefruit more.  It was unique, creative and two bites of it was just not enough!!  The Sammy roll was also very delicious.  Curry makes the difference!

and.. the downside....The regular sushi was just ok.  Nothing special.  Cuts were thin... The Ikura and uni did not taste fresh.  The wasabi tasted like it from the supermarket.  I'm used to the wasabi with fresh horshradish mixed inside and was really surprised when a restaurant of this creative caliber did not have it.
author: Nutmeg Y.

description: I have been coming to Kabuto Sushi for years and in San Francisco I think that it is absolutely the best sushi I have had.  The fish is always fresh, the chef creative, yet stays true to tradition.  If you are looking for crazy, crappy, cheap sushi do not come here.  I think that the prices are more than reasonable, the staff is professional and attentive.  It is a small, intimate space and they work well within the confines of the space.  I am sad to see so many negative reviews from the generous coupon that kabuto offered.  I hope that those negative people do not return.  The owners and staff of this fabulous restaurant deserve patrons who truly appreciate their creativity, attention to detail and kindness.
author: mi m.

description:
This place was my favorite  a few years ago.  But then i read that the owners moved to mt. shasta.  

3 months ago, i went for dinner.  Maybe it was me but it sooo... wasn't the same that it was disappointing.  It's probably average..   But I couldn't get over how much worse it was than before.

R.I.P. best sushi in town....
author: suckafree c.

description:
Ever since the japanese sushi chef closed his original Kabuto due to his wife's illness (I don't want to quote his name out of resepct, but many of you probably know him if you admired his authenticity), this restaurant is run by a Korean owner. 
And then the whole 'creativity' kicked in the menu.

I really really really miss the original Kabuto.
One of my New Year's ritual was to visit Kabuto, enjoy great sushi, thank the sushi chef, and bring home a little annual diary he gives to customers to celebrate new year. It's not a extravagant gift, but it just showed the kind of person he is. 

The usually quiet and serious sushi master truly showcased what a true sushi master should be. 
He stayed at the new Kabuto shortly after it reopened, but with all the modern decors and colors on the wall, he looked out of place to me, and he disappered after a while.
He's now back to the SF dining scence (hooray!), and I wish the best of luck for him.

Still, this is a fun sushi place. Just don't expect too much of authenticity, if you remember it from the old days.
author: Angie Y.

description:
This is a great restaurant; for those of you who knew it in the old days across the street and have not gone back, try it again; it is very different but has improved from the rocky opening a few years a ago.

First started going to Kabuto in 1985 with friends from work.  It was across the street in the old location, Sachio still owned it and would for another seventeen years or so.   If you didn't eat at the bar they had table service on tatami mats and would bring everything out on huge boards and with sake flowing it was all very festive.

For years my wife and I would go there or I would pick up a to go order on the way out to the Sunset; the waitresses were helpful and delightful and Sachio was always there with a big hello and a loud thank you very much on the way out the door.  The fish was, and still is, as fresh as it can get; three kinds of Maguro regularly, and if you asked what was freshest you'd get the straight read, also drop some freebees on the board when crowded.

The new place is entirely different but the fish is just as good.  Lots of new menu items, things your kids will eat if they can't get behind raw fish.  The atmosphere is not close to being the same without Sachio, but they did have a female sushi chef a while back so that was good to see.  The line is out the door but its worth the wait.  You get what you pay for, a lot of the poorer reviews sound like they come from folks who just don't like sushi; if you do, don't miss Kabuto, even in its reincarnated form.
author: David T.

description: Can't miss sushi.  Always fresh and flavorful.  Fresh Uni on Thursday's is the best thing ever.  Put yourself in the hands of the sushi chefs to notch up the experiience to a new level.
author: Rizwan H.

description:
Kabuto and Ozumo are my favorite Sushi restaurants in SF.  They're completely different in decor and class, but what they have in common is great sushi.  Kabuto is very tiny with only about 6 or 7 tables total.  There is a small sushi bar which seats maybe 6 or 8 additional people.

The fish is the draw here which is very fresh, possibly the freshest in the city.  The selection is extensive with all the standards: tuna, salmon, yellow tail, mackerel, eel, etc.  Plus they have daily specials offering more exotic and unusual fish.   The menu also includes traditional and more "nouveau" raw seafood creations.  For those that don't get into raw seafood, Kabuto also offers standard cooked Japanese items - tempura, katsu, donburis, gyozas, etc.  

The decor is very basic.. sort of a whole in the wall Japanese.  So, if you're looking for a hip, trendy place, go to Ozumo.  

It's very hard to get into this little gem and parking is difficult in C. Richmond.  So arrive before 6 and make a reservations if you can (I believe they only take reservations for 4 people and up).  Expect to pay around $40-$50 per person with a beer and tax.
author: Paul K.

description:
So I admit it. I like fancy sushi. I like atmosphere. This place offers neither. 

If you're a fan of places like Sushi Groove, Blowfish or Tsunami this place probably won't be your slice of hamachi. Definitely low-key, no music, no bar, no fanfare.  Yes, the sushi seemed fresh, (although the spicy tuna was disappointingly bland), the menu extensive and service on-the-mark. And it's definitely less expensive than the aforementioned sushi joints. 

But for me, a dining experience isn't just about the food, it's about the whole package.
author: a p.

description:
This place is small, but the staff is so attentive, and the sushi is so fresh.  
The Monk Fish Liver sushi was delicious, and even the Sea Urchin, which I usually find to be too Sea-ey.   The Fatty Tuna though, mmm......
I also recommend the fresh Salmon.  

The Sushi tasted very fresh, and at least for me, just right.
author: George S.

description:
Definitely my new go-to sushi spot in the city.  I'm sad I hadn't found it sooner.  The fish is super fresh & the rolls are super fly.  I'm usually a straight up sashimi/sushi girl, but their roll combinations are the most unique & tasty I've seen yet.  Though I must warn, this place is not for sushi newbies. All the different sauces, jellys, egg toppings, & pastes can be a bit frightening, but believe me they are delicious & a hell of a lot better than the usual roll ingredients all fried in tempura batter.  

Remember to make reservations... it's super small inside.
author: Jen T.

description:
Never thought I loved foie grass until this place!  I've tried the majority of the special sushi, all were pretty good.  But off the back of my head, the most memorable and unforgettable experiences w/ the sushi that i had are with foie gras (seared plumped piece of buttery foie gras coupled w/ the fresh raspberry and balsamic sauce...it's perfect harmony) and fresh scallop (sweet, tender, juicy and just delicate large pieces of scallop with spoons of cozy scallop chowder).  I can just keep eating those 2 items forever...

Otherwise, hamachi pear, the other scallop, ceviche are also pretty tasty.

(P.S. I took advantage of the coupon from yesterday and probably bought one too many...)
author: Judy C.

description:
When I was checking out an apt for rent literally right around the corner from this place, the first things my roommate advertised was that the room I'd be renting was huge and that there's an awesome sushi place around the corner. A liar she is not. 

One of my favorite places for sushi in the city. I always order a sashimi/nigiri dinner and add on 2-3 other dishes to complete the meal. I'd recommend the skate wing and the salmon kama. The meat on the skate wing is just so delicate and all the vegetables flow perfectly with the broth. The salmon kama has got to be the cheapest, best thing on that menu. For those who have not had the pleasure of tasting salmon collar, it is one of the softest and tastiest parts of the fish. I don't even need to highlight all their special nigiri and rolls. It's creative and and very palate teasing. Only downside I could potentially see is the limited seatings they can accommodate for. It can get quite busy on a weekend evening and a wait can be expected. Other than that. Good food, friendly servers and the most beautiful sushi chef I've ever seen. The female one.
author: Kien L.

description:
What a douche bag!!!

We went on one rainy Sunday and this place was full. The restaurant is tiny and we had nowhere to stand. When we asked how long the wait was and one waitress said "as long as it takes" and pushed us outside the door.  I had high hopes for this restaurant but the attitude of this douche lady was unacceptable. Naturally we went somewhere else......
author: D'Andy C.

description:
this place is such a great sushi joint.

fish is fresh. everything is so tasty & perfect.

we got the following:

gobo salad (burdock root)
salmon sushi
toro sushi
ono sushi
ankimo sushi (monk fish liver)
1849 oysters ( oysters on a shell with quail egg, roe, 24kt gold flakes)

everything was fabulous. service was great. exceeded my expectations.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
Ordered the Sunrise, Hamachi Pear, & Toro Tartar and was not disappointed! The fruity mustard sauce on the hamachi pear was the proverbial cherry on top. Also, didn't know I would like raw quail eggs, but the Sunrise definitely convinced me.

There were other plates, but those three were definitely the most memorable. Prices were reasonable for what it is because you're not going to order a California roll here, right??
author: Anna Y.

description: Very good food, but not worth the exorbitant cost. The saffron soup alone was $40. Be sure to ask the cost of anything on the whiteboard; I wish I did.
author: Doug E.

description: Number 1 on my list of best sushi meals ever.  Made a reservation and still had to wait for a table but you know what who cares when the food is that good!  Stop what you are doing and go eat there.
author: T. L.

description: This is what Japanese food is all about! Inexpensive and delicious. Best Sushi I have had in the US. If you have not gone you better make a reservation before you go, because this place is packed all night.
author: Kai O.

description:
it's a little $$$ but woth it.  Bottom line: you pay for what you get!!  You get the best of both worlds, traditional sushi & fusion sushi.

It was quite busy when I went and they' had 2 waitresses., so the service was just fair.

In any rate, will go again.
author: Jenny C.

description:
My brother and I wondered into Kabuto after our dinner plans downtown were canceled. He lives literally right around the corner from Kabuto but had never been.

We walked in and the place was full. The server asked us to wait five minutes. She was right and we were seated promptly.

We ordered entirely too much sushi and our server told us as much, but we were so eager to try a few of their specials that we went ahead. 

The Monkfish liver and Foie Gras sushi are both outstanding. Their sashimi was fresh and wonderful. Their prices, well, all I can say is thank you! San Francisco is such an expensive city that to find a good spicy tuna roll for $7 is a treat. 

I'm moving to SFO soon and no matter where I live, I'll seek this place out for a great, no nonsense sushi dinner.
author: Zach W.

description: Beyond great.  Just about in a class of their own.  A bit too expensive for my budget or I would be back.
author: Mike K.

description:
It sucks to have to review a sushi restaurant when I had the best sushi of my life just a few weeks ago.  (See my review of Sushi-Gen in Little Tokyo,LA)  That experience changed my view of sushi completely as I will never eat sushi in the same light again.  By this I mean I don't even want to order fancy type rolls anymore as the closest I will come to that is spicy tuna or something simple like that.  I now like my sushi simple which is just the taste of the fish and rice.  

With that said, this was the first time I ordered an all nigiri meal.  I would only do this at renowned places and after reading the reviews here I decided this would be the place to do it.  I sat at the bar and looked at the quality of the fish and it seemed to agree.  So off I went on my sushi journey.  BTW, they have very interesting special rolls which I will definitely try next time.  I just want to judge a place solely on the quality of their fish w/o having it masked by tons of sauces and what not.

I had toro, kampachi, hamachi, hon maguro, akamutsu, and sunazuri.  All were delectable and very tasty.  One thing that I did like is that I could order by piece so that enabled me to try a lot of different fish.  That was awesome.  Usually most places make you order two pieces of nigiri.

As far as service goes, it was good.  It was weird not being able to order through the sushi chef even though I was sitting at the bar.  But whatever, just give me good fish.  And speaking of sushi chef.  I totally fell in love with the female sushi chef.  I've never seen a female one before and she was very, very, cute so that made for a much better experience.  Unfortunately she wasn't the one making my sushi.  I'll definitely be back again for the fish and the sushi chef.
author: Ben M.

description: I love this sushi restaurant.  They have a lot of great rolls.  I would go there again.
author: Chris B.

description: Pricey but their sashimi is top grade and always fresh. The restaurant may be Korean-owned, but the presentation of the dishes and the skill displayed in slicing the fish is all Japanese. If you want to experience quality sashimi or sushi without having to go to Japan, visit Kabuto's.
author: Grace G.

description: Hands down the best sushi in the city.  Not best sushi in the bay area, mind you, but certainly best in the city (which, some would argue, isn't really saying that much).
author: Han L.

description:
Thought I'd had the best sushi before, but I have to slap myself.  Came here tonight for dinner and was completely blown away by everything.  What's everything?

* Ambiance - nice, quiet and doesn't seem commercialized.  CLEAN, from the plates to the cups to the clean table and counters. Hey, I've been to some really janky places.

* Service - Our plates were taken away as soon as we were done with each dish.  Because we were sitting at the sushi bar with limited space, that was greatly appreciated by us.  In addition to being efficient, our servers were very polite and friendly as well.  Always a big plus in Asian restaurants.

* Food - aaaahhh...the best part of the meal, of course.  We had the foie gras sushi and holy crap it was amazing.  The sushi chefs managed to combine two of my favorite things in the world, Foie Gras and Sushi.  Like they sat around, brainstorming on what people like me fantasize about and BAM - they came up with Foie Gras sushi!  Another one of our favorites tonight was the Ceviche.  It was sushi with some kind of fish (it was so yummy, I forgot what kind), to be eaten WITHOUT soy sauce.  I didn't think I could do it at first, but once it hit my tongue, I was in heaven.  The other one we really like is the Valentine, which is Foie Gras and Unagi with sushi rice, served in a Martini glass.  

Thank you, Arlene for such a great dinner!!  =)
author: Selene K.

description: I think this is one of the best sushi places in the city. Don't know why I don't come here more often. The quality of their fish is superior to many other places that get more buzz.  Their nigiri prices are for one piece only, though I don't believe they state that (I could be mistaken).  I assumed that was the case given the price point, but I can imagine some people being confused.
author: Eric C.

description:
Yummy unique tasty sushi!

Presentation, taste, service everything is thumbs up here. I try to come in either early or a little later than the usual dinner crowds so it is not too loud.

Sat at the sushi bar and the chef made us special sushi, it was soo good!

And the price was reasonable too, it came out to 60 bucks for 2 (no alcohol) and usually it costs us around 100.
author: Alissa T.

description:
I'm really  not sure the lamb apple sushi needs to be sushi.  For real, what does the rice add to the dish?

Same with the foie gras sushi.

That said, everything was really tasty and elegantly presented.  I appreciate the effort to make things unusual, so I'm totally on board.  The more traditional nigiri was really yummy and fresh.
author: Marcus C.

description: So, I have come here a dozen times or so.... And if it's a slow night..... I would take your money somewhere else.  The sushi is good but the young lady serving us gave me probably the worst service i have ever had. I kept having to get her attention for everything, like we just werent there. I'd rather spend my top dollar for sushi somewhere else with better more caring wait staff.  Sorry guys. I used to like you.
author: luke b.

description: I love KABUTO!! I love KABUTO!!! I love KABUTO!!! Hubby and I had a lunch date at this cute little place.  Was greeted right away by a little cute Japanese lady. She was so pleasant and explained to us the type of sushi that most people loves. All of her recommendations were absolutely delicious. My absolute favorite is the grilled sea bass, hamachi pear and definitely the macha Creme brûlée.
author: Tess C.

description:
very high quality sushi.  

My sister and I went to town with all their special nigiri's.   We ended up having doubles.    The two of us spent about $80 each for lunch.   We made a pact not to share that information with our hubbies.  

We got there about 30 minutes to closing for lunch.  The sushi chef was wonderfully accomodating, even when we kept having seconds and thirds.  

We had the mirugai-geoduck, clam, 2 kinds of toro, ankimo, etc... everything super fresh and wonderfully presented.   Satisfied all sorts of sushi craving.

Also, their salad was beautiful and tasty!  great dressing!
author: Regi K.

description: Pretty good sushi.  Not as same as before when they were across the street many years ago.  Still very nice....price is reasonable.  Parking is an adventure.  Worth trying.
author: William F.

description: Average. Make sure you make reservation. If you don't, it would be a nightmare because the restaurant is tooooo small and they would serve the people who has reservation first. No matter how long you have wait there already.
author: V L.

description: I've been hearing this place got rated as a top japanese resturant. Though i did go once and it was decent especially liked the chicken teriyaki i just don't think the prices would allow me to be a regular. I also didn't find the waitresses to be very inviting or friendly.
author: Petra S.

description: This is the best sushi I've had in San Francisco. Fairly traditional, super-fresh fish (maybe still moving) and delightful service. The fatty tuna will MELT in your mouth like butter. Let them help you decide and the rest will be history.
author: Stacey C.

description: Exciting,fresh,and inventive.  Fois gras sushi is delightful. Wished I lived closer.
author: Karen R.

description:
So So So Goood!

The fish is FRESH! I've been searching the city for good fresh sushi that won't break my bank and I've finally found it! 

Their menu is CREATIVE and has tons of choices from traditional to fusion-ey!

Their food is YUMMMEEE! Here's what to get--

Sunrise roll: Fresh salmon wrapped around sushi rice and topped with a raw egg yolk and tobiko. Beautiful and deeelicious!

Ceviche: This is not your ordinary ceviche but its so good! It's actually sushi rice, halibut, and a little bit of their "salsa", and you wrap a seasoned piece of nori (seaweed) around it. If you order one thing, order this!

Sonoma Duck- thin slices of tender duck (cooked), served nigiri style (slice ontop of sushi rice). It was good, but not the best. Watch out for the spicy miso hiding under the sushi...it will definitely clear up your sinuses!

Toro Tartar- Doesn't taste like toro to me but it was still very good-- kind of like a normal tuna tartar, but it was REALLY good here. Some places mess up their tartars with fruit and too many flavors, this one was seasoned just enough to let the fish shine through.

Clams in broth- Not your usual MSG soup, very mild. In my opinion could use a little more salt, but still good. 

PRICES- Pretty darn good price for what you get- 3 people, one bottle of sake ($7), $105. 

Downsides- small restaurant (about 7 tables and a sushi bar) and super cramped! Plus we made a reservation but still had to wait 25 mins and got sushi bar seats, not a table. And you feel rushed when you're eating b/c people are waiting outside in the cold for your table!

Altogether-Go here for goood, fresh, creative sushi. But be ready to wait a bit for your table!
author: amy k.

description: I have been waiting to go to this restaurant for a long time since it always seems to have a long line outside and the reviews are also pretty good.  After the first time visit, it's not disappointed at all.  Food wise, this place deserves a 5 stars actually.  I ordered the omakase, and most of the food on the list are impressive.  Some highlights are 1849 Oyster, Ceviche and Hamachi Pear, which are pretty inline with what others recommended in their reviews.  Here is why the one star was dropped off.  First, the menu is a bit dirty.  It's just a piece of paper, why can't they print a new one...Second, the service is a bit rush.  It's not like they have bad attitude, but all the dishes just came out so fast, so we couldn't really pace our dinner and felt kind of rush to finish off the food before the table ran out of space.  I think it's due to that they are kind of in rush to serve the next round since people are waiting outside, which can be understood, but it will be better if they can just slow down a little bit.  Overall, I will still highly recommend this restaurant since I have already started to miss the sushi there the day after.
author: Bryan W.

description:
The first time I went here I was impressed.  Great sushi and we had some type of cooked fish that was excellent.  I went back here again and it was totally different.  The fish was almost unedible.  Hard to eat and some of it had a wierd color. 
-- Update 7/07
I went here when it opened one night when it wasn't crowded and got a seat right by the bar.  I had some really nice fish but the service is pretty bad, make sure you're patient.  It can take very long to get an order in.
author: Mitch A.

description:
Good sushi.  We've been searching for a place to call "home", since Toraya Fillmore closed, last summer.  I like a place that we can linger over fresh fish and beer.  Not so good for lingering because the small space tends to fill up and the atmosphere isn't conducive to interacting with the sushi chefs.

Big plus for the foie gras nigiri!  Nice selection of special, too.
author: Collin W.

description:
Update:
Just went there last nite and it still is as good as the last times..
I mean, SO good!  the Sashimi is incredibly fresh and I just love it for its inventiveness.  Did the ol' Toro sashim test and it passed with flying fish colors..  Fo sho..
Foie Gras nigiri still rocks!


Really great place for inventive and unique sushi which cannot be found elsewhere.  Foie Gras sushi..  nuff said..
Only problem is that it is a tiny place and the wait is incredibly long!
author: Rose C R.

description:
When I lived closer to the City, I loved going here.

Parking can be a hassel and so can the wait.  The wait, however is well worth it.
author: Gene A.

description:
The albacore volcano, Tasmanian salmon sashimi, butter fish sashimi and baby lobster roll are the most amazing things I have ever tasted.

I moved away from SF and although I love where I'm living now, I cry every day that I can't eat Kabuto.

It is the best sushi I've ever had IN MY LIFE. In fact, I believe it's the BEST SUSHI EVER INVENTED BY GOD.

Go here. Eat. You will be brought to tears with the taste of the food.
author: R T.

description:
Awwwwwwwesome!!!!!! 
They have absolutely great fresh sushi in the city and now you should try. Me and my boyfriend always come here at least once or twice in a month we don't even try to go to another sushi place ever since we found here. We love to sit on the sushi bar and let sushi man take care of us not even care to look menu. 

The owner/ sushi man is so creative guy whenever he created a new dish, we became his little guinea pigs...lol 
one of my favorite dish here is fresh oyster, they put more than 3 different type of fish eggs with different colors.... into oyster looks good taste soooo good!!! gulp!!! I am visiting tomorrow
author: Beautee K.

description:
***WARNING***  The restaurant is under new ownership and I hear the food isn't that good anymore.  Unfortunately the original owners (the reason why it was the shit!) had to sell because the wife was strickened with cancer.  I haven't gone since the new ownership change, but I'm leaving 5 stars for what I remember.  See the sf gate article below:
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/01/27/DDG96GT3F51.DTL&hw=kabuto&sn=001&sc=1000



One of the best Sashimi spots you can find in San Francisco.  They have a wide selection of different raw fish to sample and for the non-raw fish eaters, an even wider selection of food to choose from.  I go back at least once a month for my Kabuto fix.  The sea bass and all the raw Hawaiian fish are off the heeze!  Get there early or you'll wait a while.
author: Jason A.

description:
This place is the BOMB!!!    so many fond memories.  Too bad its like an hour away.

Good:  Real tasty food, great rolls, excellent fish

Bad:  parking sucks, long waits, and a far drive

Good prevails over bad once again..hands down my favorite spot
author: MR E.

description: Simply amazing.  As others have mentioned in their own reviews, there's something different about Kabuto.  This is not the place to go if you're looking for the typical spicy tuna or tempura rolls.  While I'm sure they're fantastic, there are so many better, more adventurous things to try on their menu, i.e. the ceviche, hamachi pear and one other that has jalapeno on it.
author: Raja B.

description: The only reason for 4 stars is that service could be spotty. Sushi is better than any other sushi restaurant in San Francisco and Marin. Hamachi pear, Scott Handroll, Tuna Tartar, etc., etc. We dine there once a week and have never had a bad meal.
author: Tatiana C.

description:
Let me preface this review by saying that I am in no way a "foodie," sushi snob or one that likes to complain.

I've been to Kabuto a couple times before, but I probably won't go back again, even though it's only three blocks from my house.  

Part One:

I met my bf there around 9pm on Friday night.  I had put my name on the wait-list and we chilled for a while.  Literally.  It was windy and cold outside and we ended up waiting at least 45 min. for a table.  As I walked inside to check on the wait, another couple waltzed right in and took the next open table.  After asking one of the waitresses why they got a table right away, she explained that they had made a reservation and because of a late flight they couldn't make it on time.  No apology or "sorry for the long wait."

First of all, I don't understand why such a small restaurant has both a reservation system and a wait-list.  It's unfair to those who wait if someone comes an hour late for their reservation and can take a table that someone had waited almost an hour for.

Part Two:

After FINALLY getting a table (the people that were seated there before us had finished eating about 30 min. prior to leaving), my bf ordered some miso soup and tea for himself and I ordered a large Sapporo for us to split.  (Our waitresses wrote it all down and specifically said she would bring two glasses for the beer.) The waitress came back with two bowls of miso soup and nothing else.  We told her that we had only ordered one order of soup.  She asked us about three times if we were sure and then told us she had to go "check in the back" and took both bowls back with her.  She came back with one bowl and then we had to remind her about the rest of our order.  She came back with the Sapporo and ONE glass.  Not off to a good start.

Next, we got a bowl of wasabi and ginger with a hair in it.  Had to wait about five minutes to even catch the attention of our waitress.

Here's the sushi we ordered:

- Albacore and salmon nigiri: rice was dense and mushy
- Pear habachi: pretty tasty and loved the mustard sauce
- California roll: didn't look or taste fresh
- Spicy tuna roll: would have been fine except for the odd chili sauce on top
- Unagi and avocado roll: Unagi is normally my absolute favorite sushi roll, but this was way too chewy and flavorless.

We paid our bill, left a 10% tip (which was generous) and didn't get any kind of thank you, have a nice night or even a smile.

We looked at our watches: 11pm.  TWO hours to eat a meal that should have taken half an hour.  Good thing we didn't make plans for after dinner.

In short: 

Having only two waitresses for the entire restaurant (no bussers) slowed everything down.  They also need to work on faster turnover and politely getting people to leave faster (no lingering dinner parties chillin' at the table for an extra 30 min. to chat).

Aside from a couple pretty good rolls, the sushi was not good.  The menu is unique, but they really need to work on their service!
author: Emily H.

description: Came here with the boyfriend and we ordered a variety of things. Among them was Ceviche which was the most tastiest thing I ordered. Also had some tartare and asparagus roll. Bf loves the asparagus roll, I know.. I know asparagus right? its not worth $4 but its one of the best I've ever tasted. However prices are a little high.
author: Lily K.

description:
Updated 6/17/07:
-----------------------
 It was my second visit to Kabuto and I was expecting to have some great sushi like I did on my first visit.  I don't know what happened, this time I was a bit disappointed by both the quality of sushi and service.  The sushi was not bad but it was not that great either.  It was definitely not worth the price.  I don't mind spending some money on sushi but if I do,  I'm expecting some LA quality sushi.  If you've had it,  you know what I mean (see my SoCal list).  And the service...boy o boy,  I did the one finger head scratch a couple of times wondering when I was going to get my check.   I guess I'm on the quest again to finding that go to place in the city.
-----------------------
10/08/2006
Okay...I take back what I said about there not being any good sushi in the city. Kabuto is a solid 4.5 stars!

Last night was my first visit to Kabuto and I was very suprised by how good the sushi was.  The Yellow Tail, Blue Fin, Yellow Fin, Fresh Salmon, Amber Jack, Unagi, Spicy Scallop Handroll, and Tataki Salad were all excellent.  Considering that was everything we ordered, I think it would be pretty safe to order anything on the menu and not be disappointed.  

Thanks to all the other yelpers for helping me find my new favorite sushi in the city.  I'll definitely visit Kabuto again.
author: Steve D.

description:
Hands down, the BEST sushi in SF.  Seriously.  I was taken here for a very special dinner last night.  Never been before.  I absolutely loved it.  We sat at the bar and were served fantastic sushi.  The fish was EXTREMELY good. a million times better than anything else I've had.  The simple nigiri was great.  The more elaborate sushi with sauces were amazing.  They made something in an oyster - very good.  They also have a foie gras sushi with chocolate raspberry sauce - delicious.  The tuna tartare - awesome.  Also, the ceviche was delicious too.  My absolute fave was the swordfish nigiri.  Just fish and rice. Excellent.

The sushi chefs were great.  They shared beer and sake with us.  Such  a perfect evening.

Sit at the bar.  Oh, and it's well worth the wait.
author: Angie C.

description:
I've always had good sushi here, but I think there was a change in management a while ago and thereafter the reviews declined. I'm not sure though....

It is pricey but I love the ceviche roll (the lime juice in the rice really sends my taste buds into la-la land. I usually need a few minutes to savor the taste before taking any other bites).
author: S. P.

description:
I am not a sushi connoisseur.  That being said, this place is good.  This isn't your usual sushi place, they have a few "specialty" dishes aka fusion rolls.  WAIT.  Not the bland-slap-stuff-together-and-charge-an-arm-and-a-leg type roll, but carefully crafted rolls of wonderfully explosive flavors.  Hamachi Pear, Toro tartar, Halibut ceviche.. I could go on...

I don't remember all the names, but I liked it.  Be adventurous and order all the crazy stuff.  I added some 'regular' rolls for filler, because if you've got an appetite like me, I could not afford a meal exclusively on specialty rolls.  Make sure you get a beer and throw a quail egg in it for kicks.  It can get pretty busy, so be prepared to put your name on a waiting list.  

On my Spongebob Awesomeness scale this gets 5 krabby patties.  A place for true Goofy Goobers.
author: Ronald M.

description:
I've been eating here for quite awhile, but I don't want to review it since all it will do is increase my wait time! That being said, I guess I owe them at least  a few words:
Uni
Katsunagi
Nasu Dengaku
Toro Tartar

That's all you need to know. :)
author: Matthew H.

description: OMG how did I miss this place! I had to come up with a place near my hood for a lunch meeting. My business colleague was running late and our lunch was moved to 1:30.  Most places near by close for lunch at around 2 - 2:30. Kabuto is open till 3. So that worked in my favor. The nigiri and sashimi were stunning. We ordered the scott hand roll with the quail egg. Delish! The ankimo was a heaven. A great find in the inner richmond.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
