it's so easy to spend a buck or duckets here especially for the love of sushi. had the pleasure of dining here last night. my favorites of the night were the hamachi pear, hamachi jalapeno, crunchy sushi with japanese curry and the miso albacore. tried the duck foie gras, toro, and the ceviche. 

everything was exceptionally creative and delicious. 

we had personal service and she was very informative and helpful. definitely need to come back again!

this may be one of the best sushi restaurants in the city!
author: Mika D.

description: This is an amazing sushi place!  The best in town.  Sun that works there is really friendly!  The place can be crowded fast so go there early.
author: Audrey C.

description:
I wish YELP has 1/2 points because this would've been a 3.5 star place.  Its only 2 blocks away from our house so we''ve been here a few times for dinner and its excellent and would be a 4 star place, but their lunch menu takes it to 3 star.  Its not very extensive and they only have 2 bento (i think) options to choose from..  and last i recall both costs over $13.  I just looked at their online menu to confirm, but they only have dinner menu.

Their sushi is fresh and melts in your mouth.   I wouldnt go there for lunch, but will continue to go there for dinner.
author: Marcia B.

description:
Quality food and sashimi. Not the best

Great service. The unfortunate by-product is a long wait during peak time.

Another minus is parking can be tough at times. Like I've said before the good old 38 is highly recommended. Or if you are coming from the Sunset take the 28.

It's number three on my personal list of favorite sushi places.
author: Eugene L.

description:
Toro Tartare and Sushi Mozzarella.  *drool*

I can't wait to go back!  It's expensive, but worth it.  Kabuto is a small and cozy restaurant, with a nice, bright, and clean interior.  Staff is friendly and attentive.  

My foodie friend and I shared two sashimi plates and the above appetizers - fresh fish, unique combinations - ultimately, a very satisfying meal,  but I was still left wanting more in terms of quantity.
author: Kalista W.

description:
I love this place. I hadn't been back in 2 years, since it's "far" from my apartment. I don't know why.  It was better than I remembered. Wonderful eggplant hot appetizer to start. A beautiful plate of sashimi. So fresh, like butter. Artfully plated. A few of the "inventive" sushi pieces are a must. Pear/hamachi was a killer combo. Finished off with tempura green tea ice cream. What I love is that you can do your more traditional sushi dinner and it will be great, but if you're in the mood for some adventure and creativity, they'll give that to you too.

And I don't think agree with it being too expensive, given the quality, freshness and inventiveness, it is well worth it. For 3, including beer and dessert, it was $80 w/o tip. Not bad for how awesome it was.

I am only kicking myself that I haven't come back sooner.

Plus one star for a female sushi chef-how often do you see that?
author: Nima K.

description:
Really 3.5 stars.

Truly excellent selection of creative rolls and an incredibly extensive menu. They have it all - fresh fish, grilled items, fried items, lots of vegetable items, etc, etc. It's not the best choice for a simple, classic sushi meal, but I happen to love all the creativity in flavor and texture combinations. Warning: it tends to get PACKED!!!

Side note: Myself and some other Seattle transplants (including Japanese and Korean friends) are on a hunt for sushi as good as we got in the Emerald City and Vancouver, B.C. Who knew we were so spoiled? Our search is still in its infancy, so I'm sure there are some fabulous gems left for us to discover. The group has a vast array of tastes (from uni to toro, tempura california rolls to steamed or grilled fish, classic rolls to nouveau panasian creative rolls, etc), and so we want to find a vast array of sushi restaurants to satisfy each of our palates. If any fellow Yelpers have recommendations, please shoot me a quick message! Thanks!
author: Veronica L.

description:
Do I think it's good?  Well, my fiancee and I have been going to Kabuto at least once a week for the past year- I guess that gives you a good idea.  

The fish is fresh and very tasty.  The creations are innovative and progressive.  I can run down a list of what we order but to tell you the truth, it's ALL good.  Our dining experience is nothing but the best.  The atmosphere is super friendly and delightful.  Hands down, my favorite sushi restaurant.

Honestly, it's not about portions or cost, but about the taste and freshness of the fish.  If you want portions, go to Costco.  If you're worried about cost, go to Long John Silvers.  Sayin'.
author: Todd S.

description: Currently my favorite sushi place in the city. Fusion sushi at it's best. Excellent quality, super-fresh, and creative presentation. Service impeccable and fast. The 5 stars are for the food not the ambiance.
author: Wolfgang S.

description: Very nice atmosphere. Clean. Casual. Beautiful plating and presentation. Great variety. Yet, I wouldn't say this would be one of the best ones I had. But definitely deserve a try ;)
author: RB B.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night and had to wait quite a while to get seats for 2. The place is pretty tiny. But it was totally worth it! 

The hamachi with pear was amazing - it comes with a house mustard sauce thing and all the flavours are so subtle but so harmoniously delicious. If heaven existed I bet this is what people up there would be eating. All the nigiri we had was great too, in particular I liked the shima aji and the hotate a lot. The cooked dishes we had (hamachi kama and lamb) were also good, but I would suggest passing on the dish with the cheese over rice (totally forget what it was called).

Probably the best sushi I've had (not that I'm much of a connoisseur). We ordered way too much food and the bill came up to about $50 per person. Sushi is one of the few food things I'm willing to pay for, so this was a great deal in my opinion!
author: Bingying L.

description: Great San Fran sushi. I would definitely recomend over the one near The ACT Theatre.......
author: S P.

description: This is a nice date spot.  But its a date killer when the first smell you get is stinky, old fish.  They need to disinfect this place with some deodorant.  You only need to order two things here.  The Fois Gras sushi and the Uni Nigiri.  The Fois melts in yo mouth like butta.  Its freakin fatty ass good.  The uni was very fresh.  Everything else here pretty much sucks.  The chicken karaage is garbage.  No fat person should eat this.  The yellowjack kama was decent but nothing special.  Pretty much just order the fois gras sushi and go home happy.  $9 for two piece is a steal!
author: Fatty A.

description:
Kabuto has the largest selection of sashimi items I have seen yet in a San Francisco sushi establishment. Seriously, there were fish I had never heard of on there. 

The first time I went there the quality of the sushi was evident, especially compared to my local sushi joint. My friend and I split a 'live scallop' which is prised out of the shell, sliced, garnished, and handed over the counter still quivering. It was delicious, with a soft, creamy, yielding-but-firm texture. I haven't eaten a seared scallop since then. 

The toro is very nice as well. The unagi is prepared perfectly with a crispy outer skin and delicate flesh. I would go more if it wasn't so far away.

The sake list is nice, with a nice range of styles and prices. The prices are a bit high for the offerings, but how often do you drink sake anyway (answer: less often than me) ?  Pick something off the list and you'll probably be ok with it. Dewazakura is always a good choice for beginners.
author: Michael H.

description:
Hard to explain.

Very small spot. Lots of character. Fantastic sushi. Awesome staff. I've been here a few times with my friends. It's a blast. Every time.

An interesting item to try is the sting ray. It has an odd, squishy consistency to it, but still worth a shot.
author: Immunity B.

description:
The fish was fresh, with many varities that you don't get at other local sushi places. The rolls were unique, but the menu was a little overwhelming and unclear on what was nigiri or maki.

The service on the other hand left a lot to be desired, the waitresses left us feeling like we were an annoyance, and they could not get our orders right.
author: karine s.

description:
The wait is pretty much ridiculous.. but they were nice enough to offer us hot tea while we stood outside. 

The sushi is pricey for the modest portions, usually only two pieces for six bucks. The best marinated pieces of hamachi. The sashimi platter was delicious. And we ended on a yummy sweet note, green tea creme brulee, which deserved a whole STAR.
author: Sara D.

description:
They really hit the bull's eye with their sushi creations, soft, original, creative

They miss the mark because their sushi creations are a little bit too pricey

Now it's up to you!
author: Alex A.

description:
Friend's friend insisted that this is his favorite restaurant in the Bay Area.  He drives in from the East Bay every month to have dinner.

We decided to leave the ordering up to the chef and was treated to an amazing feast.  As we gave him feedback after each piece (my friend doesn't like seaweed!), he customized the next order with what we liked.  The flavors ranged from subtle (fried seaweed) to the unexpected (balsamic raspberry sauce) to the bold (ceviche).

The menu is divided into 3 types: nigiri special, sashimi special (mostly w/interesting sauces), and fusion sushi (such as foie grais or roasted duck).  Most of the regulars ordered the sashimi specials.

My favorite Japanese place is still Uzen in Oakland (I trek across the Bay the other way), but it's good to know an innovative sushi place in the City.

Street parking is easy right at 6pm.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Kabuto will be annoying to the purists because they offer post modern sushi. I happen to like the post modern menu quite a bit, along with their sake selection which I think is great.

Yes, they are expensive. But if I can go to a restaurant absolutely knowing every time that I will be consistently pleased with the service, the selection, the freshness and the preparation, I am happy to pay a premium. I am also particularly sensitive to places with lots of ambient noise, and that is not a problem here.
author: Phil W.

description:
Good enough to go back (I've been about 5 times) but wouldn't bother to wait too long if there's a line out the door. I give them credit for their uniqueness in sushi. 

Some of my favorites are: ankimo sushi, Crunchy, and Hamachi & Pear. I've tried some of their cooked appetizers and wasn't all that impressed. In my opinion, I would stick with the sushi. It's pretty fresh.
author: lisa m.

description:
I went to Kabuto because my mother-in-law wanted to try it, so we did. I really don't know much about the place or why people like it so much. 

I was wowed by their food presentation and creativity. I thought the sushi was right in between the traditional and extravaganza. So what ever your preference is in regards to this cuisine they will be met. And everything else (service, cleanliness, restroom, etc.) was done pretty well. 

I've been eating sushi for a long time and I've tried everything from sriracha hot sauce to mayonnaise on it. At this time my personal preference is traditional. I feel sushi is sushi, it shouldn't be priced at 4 stars restaurant prices. Food in a restaurant at these prices needs a full bar with specialty drinks, a matre'd, a receptionist, career servers, etc.
author: Bebe L.

description:
Tonight I died and went to sushi heaven.  I have only one word: UNAGI.  If you thought you had unagi before or if you're not even a fan, you will LOVE it here.  I would come here for that alone.  Who knew such a slimy scary sea creature would be so delectable?  On our first round of sushi, the three of us ordered 2 pieces each, but had to order 5 more pieces bc it was just that good.  It's a perfect balance of sweetness, flakiness, melt-in-your mouth buttery-ness.  We also ordered shitake rolls (yum), crunchy sushi (unmemorable), dragon roll (delicious but small), yams (not bad), spicy tuna roll (excellent), and soft shell crab with salmon (wonderful).  

We had reservations at 7 but were late.  They didn't seem to mind too much.  In a place that seats only 35, be prepared to wait.  The service is painfully slow, but the food is definitely worth every agonizing minute.  We also saw a curious uni shot being made...cold sake, quail egg, uni, fish eggs, other colorful stuff, topped with a gold leaflet.  It was quite a show and not in the menu.  I'm not brave enough for that though. Everything is beautifully presented.  The place is extremely busy.  Parking stinks.  But I'm giving it 5 stars bc the food is amazing.
author: Kristen N.

description:
I wouldn't go to Kabuto's for traditional sushi.

Yes they do have a menu with traditional entrees, but I love Kabuto Sushi for their sushi menu. 

A lot of their own-creation sushi is so unique; they use different flavors like fois gras sushi, or lamb & apple sushi. Yes, these creations are a bit pricey, but worth it. They're delicious :)

The only bad thing is that the location is small, so if you go for dinner, you're either waiting a while for a table, or it's difficult to get attention from your waitor/waitress without having to ask several times. 

Other than that, I love Kabuto Sushi and I'd definitely go back again :)
author: Shelley A.

description: Kabuto is fantastic sushi.  Always fresh and clean and inventive, as well.  Expensive, but you get what you pay for!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Best sushi I've had in SF after eating at many of the cities sushi establishments during my 11years here. The Ceviche and Toro Tartar were my favs. Will be coming back here regularly for sure
author: Fred E.

description:
best sushi in town. 
We did not look at the menu and ask the Chef to prepare something outstanding. It was incredible. 10-15 plates, almost all of them were extremely good. I now send there every person visiting San Francisco and so far, none have been disappointed. 

the restaurant does not look outstanding (street view, location, design), but the cusine is excellent.
author: Henri M.

description: I must have gone on the wrong day.  I had very high hopes for this place.  It's Japanese-owned and gets rave reviews on yelp.  But my server was grumpy, the sashimi was not fresh, and the unagi makimono we got had a sugary/not very good syrup globbed all over it.  Why is that I found several places in the Boston area (check out my review of Oga's below as one example) with incredibly fresh sushi but am struggling to find such a place in SF?  The only good/authentic thing about this place was the hot/wet hand towel put on the table before the meal.
author: John W.

description: Really good quality fish. Chef has infused many flavors to create some interesting small dishes. Try fire salmon roll, aburi toro. The yakinasu was presented quite nicely for such a casual and simple dish.  A bit out there (location) for me and they seem to be inconsistent these days.  I would try again if I'm in the area.
author: Susan Y.

description:
Kabuto is certainly one of the better sushi restaurants in San Francisco. 

If you begin with Miso soup, you will notice that this restaurant has somewhat of a soup variety. You can order Miso soup with wofu, mushrooms, clams, or a combination of the three. 

Kabuto's rolls and raw fish are flavorful.

With regard to dinner entrées, I recommend either the "Salmon Mushiyaki" or "New York" steak; both are flavorful and covered in a unique sauce. 

Dessert is good, but portions are small

The staff are very friendly. Whether dine-in or takeout -- the staff have always seem attentive to your needs.

Entrée prices are less than $25. Most of the sushi and rolls are below $10.

Additional Notes: 

- If in need for parking, there is a parking garage where the Rite Aid and Walgreens are -- on Geary and 16th Ave.
author: A B.

description: so goodddddddddddddd.... can't wait to have a pre-fixe meal there again...
author: Y L.

description: Nice and pretty presentation on the food arrangements, however, its a bit pricey of a place if you are looking for a restaurant to get your belly fulled. They do have some not so common pieces you should try.
author: Linh D.

description:
My dad has a rule about Italian places:   never go anywhere where the menu is too long. Kabuto proves the rule holds for Japanese restaurants, too. 

Sushi and sashimi + extensive grilled menu + lots of hot and cold appetizers, noodles, rice dishes and a few things involving a blowtorch are all on K's menu. Plus, lots of out-there sushi involving foie gras, mustard, you name it. These items seem very popular, reading other reviews, but I like raw fish and seafood, thank you. So that is pretty much what we ordered. Bad move.  

Everything was 5 degrees too cold:  hotate, uni, ama ebi. We even ordered hot sake and a spider roll, once we figured out that this wasn't our kind of place. Too cold. And, that soft-shell crab was fried in oil that tasted as if it had been re-used for a few days running. 

Good tea, and not expensive, I suppose. But I will not be back.
author: J P.

description:
Mmmm, mmmm good!  

But DON'T spread the word - I don't want to have to wait 2 hours for a table.
author: Aila L.

description:
Okay, so I have to set the record straight -- this place is NOT overly expensive.  And, the fish really is some of the freshest I've tasted in SF. Not only do they have unique sushi options and some hard-to-find fish, but they also do a great job on the standard fare.

It's really about the food here - the service is just 'eh and they don't time anything, so you just get your food in the order it comes out (e.g. the miso soup came after one of the rolls, and my friend who ordered the soba soup didn't get it until everyone else was eating something for 10 min).

Some highlights from the meal:
The tea (free) is flavorful
Seaweed Salad - at $5 and filling, a great starter
Fatty Tuna (Toro) pieces - pretty amazing and worth the $5 per piece
Crispy Roll - perfect texture and subtle chipotle flavor
Salmon/Mozzarella thing - tasted great (baked cheese!) but the fish was hard to find
The green tea creme brulee is huge, and has a very potent green tea taste, so only get it if you love green tea.

The place is really small, so get reservations or expect to wait.
author: Simmi M.

description:
I enjoyed dining here last night but I felt something was missing. YES, authenticity! 

Kabuto has a good variety on their menu and we ordered over 10 different items for the sake of impartial review. Some of the items:

Chicken Karaage- 5 tiny pieces of squares on a bed of vegetable. Tasted pretty good but portion too small.

SF Tsunami- Cooked tuna wrapped like a crepe ( 2"x2")  with some sauce and some other decorations (kinda edible). Not sure how to describe my experience because I cannot fit it into any category, french? Japanese fusion I guess. 

UFT- Fried snapper in spring roll. Pretty strange, lacking in taste and one order you will get two little spring rolls, 2.5"x 1".

Hamachi Kama- Well, at last, something we did not regret ordering. Good portion, well grilled. 

Sunrise- Salmon sashimi wrapped around some rice with an egg yolk in the middle. The egg further elaborates the freshness.Another winner of the table! This is highly recommended but on the pricey side.

Spider Roll- Not too bad but nothing special.

Pencil Sushi- The waitress said "sorry I forgot to tell you it's out".

I remembered eating some other stuff but maybe I have amnesia or maybe the taste just not too significant for me to remember. If you are searching for a different kind of Japanese cuisine, maybe Kabuto is right for you. But to me, I'm definitely looking forward to a satisfied stomach and the freshness that stays on my taste buds even after gulping some piping hot green tea.
author: Gary T.

description: The best Japanese restraurant/sushi bar in town.  Reasonable prices for such wonderful food.
author: Robert K.

description: This place is awesome. If you go here, go for the sushi. its awesomely fresh. Toro tartare, and the katsu unagi are probably the best things to ever land on my mouth. ITS GREAT. The fresh fish is addicting and you can get carried away ordering several pieces of nigiri and then your bill is crazy expensive.
author: Robert A.

description: ok.......I was a bit apprehensive about going to another Japanese Restaurant, but damn this place was GREAT!!!! We had Seaweed Salad, Various sushi, Kanpachi Kama, Yaki Nasu, Maguro Poke and Miso. Everything was GREAT. I could have had just the Seaweed salad and Kanpachi Kama and would have been happy. The atmosphere was good, the space between each dish was good.....it turned out to be one awesome date.....I will definitely be going back!!!!
author: Troy H.

description: I prefer to stick with the basics - great sashimi.  The menu here was too much for my liking with too much 'fusion' like rolls and plates.  We came on a  warm day and it was hot inside and the fish wasn't served cold enough and didn't seem to have very much flavor.   The wasabi and soy sauce was way too watered down and had no taste.  The fact that they served it in the same bowl as the ginger (which is wet) was a bad idea.  I don't like that they charge for green tea since that seems to be a very basic thing to provide at a Japanese restaurant.  Maybe I just take it for granted at other restaurants?  The place is small and it feels like they're trying to cram too many people in one place.  Service is average and the waitress who took our order pushed way too hard to try us to order more food, naming alot of plates that she said were popular/good.
author: Irene C.

description: The wait is kinda long, but you get sake while you wait. Its really small inside, but once you're in, its pretty good. The unagi was AWESOME!! the grilled and smokey flavor really caught me off guard. It's a fanicer sushi place, but won't be a regular for me since its kind of pricey.
author: Nancy T.

description:
Came here on a yelp 25/50 deal.  

The pros:

- The sushi was absolutely excellent - very fresh and tasty
- Very creative sushi - the toro tartar and a hamachi jalapeno special were standouts
- Again the sushi was very very good

The cons:

- They clearly use the term "reservation" very loosely.  More means that you get to sit earlier than if you just show up but not really at the time you have reserved
- While most of the staff was friendly, our specific waitress was anything but.  She did the job as far getting us our food, but was we felt like we were imposing
- the place is tiny, packed with no waiting area resulting in folks standing over you while you eat, or the cold coming in the door, or both
- Pricey considering the abundance of stellar sushi.

Overall was very good, but given all the sushi options probably wont be visiting that often.  The actual sushi was outstanding, but for the price would expect a better overall experience.
author: Robert U.

description:
Seating at the Bar is a must.  The fine attention to detail, and meticulous crafty work these sushi chefs prepare are amazing.  The fish is consistently super fresh.  Quite possibly one of the best sushi experiences I've had since the memorable meal at Sushi Roku in Hollywood.  The saba is carefully prepared and always a delight to eat.  I'm not sure where they get their toro, but man, its the best in the city so far.  Some of the specialty pieces weren't memorable, and didn't do much for me.  I usually stick with the traditional menu.  The head sushi chef moves with a zen-like attitude; calm, precise, and authoritative.

The tamago was most enjoyable.  I was trained with the understanding that a tamago is the last skill the sushi chef is taught and first to be judged upon his skill set.  The tamago takes skill to make, and every sushi chef has their style.  In this case, I love the style of the tamago here, with the traces of green seaweed embedded in the egg mixture. A delight of a morsel that must be had.

Ordering straight to the sushi chef is what I usually do, and getting info on the specials and products, but these guys don't really take orders directly from the customer.  They seem really concentrated on the work, and not wanting to be bothered. Orders given to them are usually relayed to the waitress and punched into the tickets.  I guess its their way of keeping sanity.  The guy in the middle seems to move like he's on speed. His slices come out uneven, which irks me. Maybe he doesn't want to be buried by the tickets.  The anti-social wall defeats the purpose of having a good time at the bar, but hey, not every great sushi chef does the mingling.  

Still, the plates are beautiful, the portions are generous and the quality of the food hits the yummy mark.  Stick with the traditional pieces, as a few of the specials mask the flavor of the fish.  The hamachi pear was most memorable of the specials i've tried, and the rest I don't even remember.  The fish can be pricey, but worth the quality and work put into it.  I have no problem having a meal here anyday.  This is sushi done right.
author: Phat Hippo L.

description:
This place is really under-hyped. Been coming here since the previous owners, across the street location. this is my stalwart sushi restaurant in the city. Having lived in Japan three years as an expat, and traveling there on business frequently, i have a refined sushi palate.  This is where I bring my Japanese friends, casual and business, who visit from Japan. It is extremely high quality and very reliable. It is a casual, lively place.
Although they stray from a purist sushi experience with some innovative dishes, they do so in a refreshing and tasteful manner. 

Besides a great experience in the restaurant, you can also take out and they cater parties. I had them cater a party for 100 people and they did a tremendous job (although I had to provide my own platters--but hey, that's a step I won't have to take next time). My only complaint is that they not sell shochu, but they make up for it somewhat with a solid sake selection.

My typical order:

Hamachi Jalepeno ($17, but worth it)
Mentaiko shiso maki
Ikura
Uni
Ceviche
Saba
Awabi
Toro
Hirame
Ika
Tai
Sake: Mu Junmai Daiginjo
If I am still hungry I sometimes order oden as well which is always great.

Enjoy, but don't even think about taking my seat.
author: John D.

description:
I friggin love this place.  I do often forget about it, thankfully.  If I didnt I would have to move to a smaller place to afford Kabuto.  I love the food here.  Whenever a certain friend of mine is in town we go here and drop a pile of cash on some of the best sushi around sf.
 If you are gonna bring someone make sure they really love sushi.  If you were thinking of Kitaro and were gonna bring someone here instead forget it!  This place should only be shared with those who appreciate and love some kick ass sushi.
author: Tony B.

description:
some of the best sushi i have ever had. $90 for three of us (including 4beers!!!) and tons of incredible, high quality sashimi. they were able to add an extra piece of each to the plates so we could each try them too, so it's an even better deal than you might think!

if people complain about this being to expensive, you're crazy. this is one of the best deals around.

the hibachi pear (yellowfin, pear, mustard sauce) was one of the most unique combinations i've seen at a sushi restaurant. 

these aren't the epic rolls you might find, fried & stuffed with all things under the sun... it's MUCH better.

we went at 9:00 on a wednesday night, so it was totally empty, with great customer service. 

you have to try this place.
author: leslie b.

description:
I drive at least 40 min just to come and eat here. Every time, it has been a great experience. This is the place for some of the most amazing special sushi I have  had.  We always end up ordering more and repeats, and they have some classics such as ceviche, Toro tartar, hamachi pear, "fire salmon" etc.  I also love their grilled yakimono and ippnryouri.  We have tried their nigiri and sashimi and are good, but always stick to the specials. 

The fish is  very fresh and the presentation beautiful. Servers and the chefs are very nice. If you are looking for an affordable nigiri, there are other restaurants. If you want an amazing experience, and fantastic tastes with special sushis and hot dishes, this is the place... My favourite japanese restaurant in the bay area.
author: RR R.

description: This place is very under-rated given the quality of the fish at the very reasonable price. This is a definite stand by when I visit my family in San Francisco. There halibt ceviche and hamachi jalapeno are my favorites. Although not mentioned in many of the reviews the tuna belly hand roll is another really good choice. The place alternates between being completely packed and somewhat empty over the course of the eight or nine times I have been here so making a reservation can't hurt if your group is bigger than two. Total cost for three people including severa beers is about $140.
author: Procter F.

description: We loved the sushi, and the dishes. Our favorite was actually the cooked dishes - the seabass just melted in your mouth like butter and the wild himachi kama was succulent and perfectly seasoned. Everything else that came out from the miso soup to the sashimi to the uni shell was spectacular. We had a wonderful meal - spent two hours eating - and we can't wait to go back there again.
author: Vincent K.

description: It's where art meets craft. It's where you dare to taste different. Kabuto is true love in a roll.
author: Alex H.

description: Favorite sushi place in the city.  Make sure to check out the specials board before you order.
author: Chris L.

description: Reasonable prices, no-frills interior, acceptable service, reasonable portions. What else to say?
author: John B.

description:
I'm native Japanese and decided to give reviews on Japanese restaurants in SF. My first review is on Kabuto. I went there with my friend, and we ordered, 2 nigiri, Hamachi kama, kinpira, and 2 special roles. The total came out to be around $70 and with tips, it'll be $40 to $45 dollars per person. I was pretty full by the time I left so most people wont spend that much at Kabuto.

Price and Volume:
Charges avg price for sushi but some smaller home made dishes are too expensive for its volume.

Service:
Slow, slow, slow!! 1 waitress was always standing at the back doing nothing while the restaurant was filled with customers.

Ambiance:
Very small and you might find it uncomfortable since you will be surrounded by other customers. Table near the door should be removed as well because it's annoying.

Notes:
Overall, you will be satisfied for your dine at Kabuto. But since you have to wait a bit to get your food, you have to be patient. Avoid early hours and come by after 8pm or so. It'll be less busier and you will be served much faster.
author: Shumi S.

description:
Every menu item is interesting, tasty, and expensive.  A great place to take friends who have not progressed beyond "Sashimi Combo A".  Just order one of each item until you're full and smug.

Kabuto gets five stars (from a base of three) because I treat friends here as a reward for their years of loyalty.
author: Amanibhavam K.

description:
I've got to say the flavors and the quality of the food was great.  This is like a Japanese Tapas bar (lots of options).  At first glance the prices seem reasonable too, but when you get the food it's like 'that's all i get for 60 bucks?'  If you come here hungry be prepared to dole out major greenbacks, but yes, everything we had (most non-traditional appetizers and rolls) was great.  If money is not an issue this place can be lots of fun!  

Can't really comment on the sushi since we didn't have it.
author: NB B.

description:
Good Food
The overall restaurant "Atmosphere" is a little bit of a greasy spoon, but the food far exceeds the lack of decor.
Enjoy
author: Blair E.

description: AMAZING!!! Wish I still lived in the Bay Area as I would frequent this place often. Went with some friends while in town and did the Omakase menu at the bar. We had about 12 items come out which were absolutely amazing. I will be back!!
author: Sarah J.

description: this is one favorite japanese restaurant in the bay area and it's the closest I can find to the taste in japan. they have over 20 plus fishes and traditional japanese cooking. I highly recommended their clam miso  soup.
author: Leah C.

description: Booo Kabuto! This review ain't about the food 'cause I never got to try it. Service was AWFUL though. Went with a fairly large party for this tiny space (6 of us), but they said "no problem, 15 minutes!" We were starving and super stoked. For the first 30 minutes. Went in, checked, "sure, juuuust about ready." So we waited. And we got to that point where you've invested so much time you're like "damn, we can't quit now." So we didn't, and it was a foolish mistake. After waiting for another 30 minutes (remember, she told us 15 minutes, now we're an hour in), she FINALLY came out and told us she had two tables. Across the dining room from one another. Given all 6 of us had planned to all have dinner together, that just wasn't going to work. Honesty is always the best policy, and frankly, we wouldn't have been upset if they were upfront with us to begin with.
author: Brian G.

description: Innovative sushi. Too bad the foie gras sushi is no longer available.
author: Joseph Y.

description:
I cannot rave enough about Kabuto!  This is the freshest fish I have ever eaten, and Eric the sushi chef behind the bar is extremely creative with his rolls and nigiri.  Don't be affraid to try everything on the menu, also ask for chef reccomendations or try off the specials menu.  Or don't even look at the menu at all, and order just by watching what is being made behind the bar.  
By far the best sushi I've eaten ANYWHERE!  Ate until we were stuffed, but then Eric breaks out a blow torch and starts searing a Maine lobster nigiri(A MUST HAVE).
You must try Kabuto, I reccomend going during the week to get a good seat at the bar.  Don't try going on the weekend without reservations.
author: Joe H.

description:
Money leaves my pocket as amazingly beautiful sushi dishes cover my table. There is no regret in this experience. 

My only wish is that the had a bit more of an interesting eating environment to augment the beauty of what the sushi chefs create. Though a small detail, this quality ends up getting blinded as I enjoy my fourth unfiltered sake with a plethora of fresh fish.

Getting here early is key as sushi aficionados have this place on lock down.
author: Mario G.

description: Come early and hungry. This is the best sushi in the city IMHO.  You can get creative or just enjoy some simple, uber-fresh fish.
author: Michelle C.

description: Wow, Kabuto is great. I know all sushi lovers know what "the best sushi ever is" but after trying several places this place stands out. There's a lot on the menu to try and for us it was all really a wonderful experience. The sashimi platter is $25 for 17 pieces of generously sliced fresh fish. It's cozy and the service is quick. I love Kabuto and my g/f who lived in Japan for 4 years absolutely loves this place. Ignore any naysaying and enjoy Kabuto if you want truly creative and elegant sushi at a good price.
author: M H.

description:
most often, you get what you pay for, especially when it comes to fresh fish.  if you're down to spend a moderate chunk of change on phenomenal sushi, this is the spot!  the sushi is really fresh and they have interesting flavor combinations that work.  i highly recommend the scallop and tuna tartare sushi.  they even excel at non-fish entrees.  we tried the braised lamb short ribs, and we found ourselves  gnawing on the bones, it was so good.

the restaurant is quite small.  even with a reservation, we had to wait an extra 30 min. for our table...but it was all worth the wait!
author: t L.

description: I was craving for sushi and Kabuto did not disappoint.  Last night was my second time there and I think this is now one of my new favorite sushi restaurants in SF!  I'm a pretty picky eater and I LOVE sushi and the best sushi I've had was at the Tsukiji Fish Market in Tokyo.  Back to Kabuto, everything we had last night was so fresh and not fishy at all!  We ordered kobe beef sushi and it was melt in your mouth and did not require any chewing, it almost tasted like fish if we didn't know it was beef.  Other highlights were ankimo sushi, saba, hamachi pear, toro, hamachi belly, uni, ceviche suchi, 1849 oysters, spicy mussels and anago.  We had to order another anago because it was so good, the fish was crunchy on top and it was lightly sauced and there were no bones.  Of course the bill was impressive as well but I think it was worth it.  There were only two sushi chefs and three wait staff but we didn't wait long for the food and the wait staff was very friendly and professional!  I'll be back for sure and not for long!
author: winnie l.

description: This is my favorite Japanese restaurant in San Francisco. It's good quality fish--fresh, good japanese flavors, and priced right. I think I've tried everything on the menu. I don't really care for the hot food. But the sushi is awesome. Traditional japanese flavors with quality fish and good presentation. honestly the 5 star is just for the sushi. I would give the hot food maybe 3.
author: Jess Y.

description: This restaurant defines what it means to be a sushi restaurant today. From the perspective of a sushi traditionalist, the fish is some of the best I've had in the states. At the same time, plates such as the 1894 Oyster (oyster, caviar, uni, roe) and the Toro Tartare (I know some of you are cringing right now but it's amazing) demonstrate to me the desire and ability to innovate in a city where the standards for good traditional sushi are astronomically high. This is as good as it gets, imho.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Kabuto serves the most unique sushi I've ever had, ever. My boyfriend and I tried this place for the first time the other night and we enjoyed everything we ordered. We had the sashimi plate (I'm a huge fan of sashimi so I'm being biased here) and with a touch of sweet soy sauce it tasted great and fresh. A must try is the Ceviche--it's not your run-of-the-mill ceviche folks--this is halibut w/ a dollop of salsa and lime sitting on fried seaweed. We loved this one so much we ordered a second one. We were told by a patron sitting next to us to let the ceviche sit for a few minutes so that the lime juice can run down and infuse the halibut and rice. I would go back just to have this and the sashimi again.

The menu is by far the most unique I've ever seen in a sushi bar but I warn you, when it comes to sushi I'm a neophyte. I was never a fan of sushi before I came to live in SF. I was really impressed with the presentation and service. It's a great date place or for a special occasion w/ 2-4 friends.

I docked a star b/c I was surprised at the portions (small compared to other sushi places I've frequented) and the prices.  I would not recommend going after 7 PM or if you're going with a party of more than 4. The place is super small (typical of outer Richmond restaurants). We were sitting near the entrance and at around 7 PM people/groups started rolling in and were told to wait, even if they had reservations. We went around 6 PM and were seated right away.
author: Les R.

description: Yum. How did I not know about this place before? Great, creative, beautifully presented sushi and exquisitely fresh fish. It's my new favorite sushi place.
author: Kate T.

description:
I am usually not a big fan of sushi.   But Kabuto is one of my favorite sushi restaurant for the variety of unique sushi.  The best are the hamachi pear, ceviche, and foie gras sushi.    The staffs are friendly and welcoming.   And each of the dish is prepared like a piece of art!

The price is a bit on the expensive side, but it is worth it.   The restaurant is small too and to avoid having to wait in line, I usually go on weekdays.   Definitely a must try!
author: Maggie L.

description: Hands down the best sushi I've had in the city and quite possibly in the Bay Area. That's a lofty claim coming from someone who is a die-hard sushi fan, but this is the real deal. Don't get confused like did with the old sign across the street. This space is really small and the wait will usually be ridiculous on a weekend, but the quality of the service and freshness of the fish is hard to beat. We pretty much just ordered the nigiri throughout the night, and everything was amazing. We ordered so much that I simply forget all of the varieties that we ate. However, the toro tuna, and the tobiko and quail eggs- were the true stand outs for me. The toro tuna melts in your mouth and literally makes you blush- that good. Everything was just buttery and ocean- fresh, and so much attention paid to the delicate presentation...I can't wait to go back.
author: NaNa M.

description:
while other places offer you a free glass of wine or a cup of coffee, kabuto was nice enough to give their patrons waiting outside the restaurant a cup of tea. it was just perfect  on that chilly night two weeks ago.

looking from the outside, the space of the dining room with their tiny bar made me already uncomfortable, though the nicely presentation of the food made me want to stay and made me feel excited to have a taste of it.

we went here for a light dinner, so we only ordered a few items.

we had the **agedashi tofu**, which they don't do the "green onions" stuff, but instead they used a grilled chili green pepper and no bonito flakes.  this appetizer plate was average. i still rather have it with green onions, tons of it and of course with bonito flakes.

the **unagi with avocado roll** was flavorful. we were asked by the waitress if we want the avocado in or out of the roll and the same thing was asked about the unagi. to me it really doesn't matter which one is in or out. both divine goodness will go the same way...into the mouth. i thought that was a silly question.

two pieces of my favorite bites, the **potato croquette** drizzled with bottled tonkatsu sauce was definitely  NOT the best for six expensive dollars. i had better and cheaper.

the satisfactory **salmon skin roll** was very enjoyable. nicely crisped and it didn't have that strong fish taste.

the standard **tempura shrimp roll** was decently made, but they skimped on the shrimp...boo!

and we ordered this exclusive  sushi  that we saved for last that certainly made our dinner pleasant.....**the foie gras**!

these two miniscule slivers of ambrosial excellency of that seared marinated goose liver pate certainly made our dinning experience wonderful.
it was beautifully complemented with a balsamic raspberry sauce and tease of fresh tiny raspberry.

in general, kabuto serves satisfying & tasty sushi and the sashimi are still to be savored next time. yes, there's still a next time for us, for we were really entertained by the awesome presentation and grooved on the food as well.
author: Nelle A.

description:
i thought i had died, i said DIED!!!! and went to heaven when i came to kabuto for the first time.  that was 361 days ago for my birthday.  and apparently, IT IS possible to die more than once AND go to heaven when you've tastedteded sushi THIS good!  

*pinch myself - "OWWW!  but still here!"

let's see if i can remember everlleythingg i ate that night....

sea shad and pencil fish - i would have never ordered it, but the waitress recommended it so we thought to give it a try.  it was something different, not bad....

the pencil fish brings back some good ole memories that i had when i was in bora bora.  one of which included: kidnapping a poor little fishy from ashore, scooped some water into my purse and brought him back into my room.  how did i get a hold of one a these small and swifty little fishies you ask?  by feeding bread stuck between my boobies.  YES.  feeding via this method was quite effective, it essentially freed up both hands and allowed my hands to be more efficient.  this picture will be in a box filled with things i WILL share with my grandchildren - caption: this was when grandma's boobs did not touch her toes.

the uni was oh so yummy and fresh, it melted in my mouth.  mmm....mmm....good.  i could seriously eat ten servings of it.  ANYONE want to have a uni eating contest with me?  i'ma gonna kick your butt to the north pole!!!!!!!

the tasmanian sea salmon sashimi was spectacular.  i thought the ones i caught, with my creative fishing skills, out in the bay were fresh, but this one was 100 times better!

the nameko miso soup with baby mushrooms was 
ThE. BeSt. MiSo. SoUp.                                 EVAR!!!!      
(you can spank me if it doesn't taste good, but only after you've ran up and down geary street twice, NAKED, wearing a tiara, singing "i am beautiful" by christina aguilera)

the hamachi pear with a fruity mustard sauce was actually quite tastay.  the flavors blended very well together.  definitely opened up my palate to try more....

the foie gras sushi with a heavenly raspberry sauce was absolutely divine.  if i was a penguin, this is one item i will NOT regurgitate to feed my younguns.     
i.   inhaled.   it.  

the toro tartar and the ceviche were the two dishes you eat with no sauce (otherwise the sauce will drown out the flavors).  another brilliant blend of flavors.  

the uni, foie gras and tasmanian sea salmon was so freakin' awesome, we had another order of each of those again.  

this is one of the few japanese sushi restaurants in the city that is run by japanese.  it's the only place (i know of) that doesn't put your individual sashimi orders all on one long dish - each order is garnished and displayed like a piece of art.  the staff were so nice and made sure our tea glass was always filled.  the restaurant is clean (including the bathroom) and inviting.  there were two sushi chefs behind the bar.  special note:  one of them is a HAWT japanese girl.  this space is great for two, four, or small groups.  there was ample parking at 5:30 p.m. as we were lucky to have found parking right outside!!!

$120.  
two orgasmic experiences.  
two happy tummies.  
two elated human beings.  
totally worth it!   

KABUTO is the place to go....
friendly service
fresh and   d e l i s h   sashimi
AND 
if you want to indulge in the ultimate, most intense orgasmic experience that'll leave you wanting more....

ps. 
they are also open for lunch from 11:30 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.
author: Paulina C.

description: This place is amazing.  I always make reservations before coming to this place, but because it's always packed, they don't really honor the reservation.  Word of advice Yelpers - if you want to try this place, go for lunch - there's very little wait if any.  But I must say that the food here really makes up for the wait.  Everytime I come here I spend at around $200-300 between me and my hubby.  Because it's that good!  Too bad foie gras is no longer sold in CA, cause their foie gras sushi was to die for!  Their 1849 oysters are amazing.  If it wasn't for the fact that this place is so pricy, I would be coming here every weekend.  Would come again.
author: shirley h.

description:
the katsunagi was my favorite.
and the soft shell roll, duuuuuuude...
tako sunomono had a great vinaigrette.
we ordered sooo much, and i suck with names, but every hamachi, tuna, salmon, shima aji, fishy flesh was excellent!

besides the slightly difficult to understand accents, service was impeccable.  very polite and attentive.
wow, lady sushi chef, quite a rarity.  and yes, very pretty like other reviewers mentioned.  azumi, anybody?  8)
author: Ethan L.

description: this place is pretty good, it is sort of small though, its my boyfriend's favorite sushi place, the service is good, it is a bit pricey though :/
author: Bailey L.

description: Kabuto is probably one of the freshest sushi places I've ever been to. Every dish we had was nicely plated and delicious, that I forget which one was my favorite. The restaurant itself was small and crowded, so not a good place for large groups of people. But overall, great service, nice vibe, fresh and affordable sushi, and nice presentation makes this a great place to go.
author: Vivian H.

description:
i love this place! my favorite in SF!!! ok, if you're gonna come here i suggest ordering from their specialty menu- their signature stuff is the bomb! you can get the other stuff anywhere.
the ceviche rolls were yum yum yummyyyyyyyyyy, there was another roll i tried that had pear and it was delicious. their rolls are not meant to be soaked in soy sauce, it might actually be insulting and will definitely kill the taste, these rolls have their own special sauce. 
the waitresses are cute and i liked the chefs, they were pretty cool. 
the sea urchin tasted like UGH^&*%!!! i almost barfed it, it tasted like a rotten ocean and the texture- ugh, its a taste thing. but yeah this place is rocks the house. oh yeah and it gets crowded so good luck.
author: Osiris Z.

description: Wow really people I only went here cause I got a coupon offer from yelp you pay $25 and they cover up to $50 of food.  I eat a lot of sushi it's my favorite.  I like good sushi some of the odd selections and pairings here were gross.  For instance I had their himachi pear happened to have a drop of the most disgusting spicy mustard I've ever put in my mouth.  I was enjoying my dragon roll but after I took one bite for the first time ever I thought I was going to yak inside the restaurant.  The worst part about my experience was the worst service in my life.  I think because I used this coupon they decided to completely not wait on me I waited 10 minutes then finially put my jacket on, then I waited 5 more minutes for a check and eventually got up and chased the server down (only like 3 other tables were full). In addition I never once got asked if I would like to order more or have my water refilled.  Also for the first time in my life I tipped under 10 % which is very hard for me to do.  Save your money and pass this place up even they're regular rolls tasted like something I made at home not a fan at all, and don't put a coupon online and treat someone like a piece of crap cause they decided to use it.
author: Nirea S.

description: This was the best sushi I'd ever had in my life, and I'd been to Japan.  Okay, so there's a caveat: when in Japan, we could not afford the good expensive sushi restaurants, so we only ate at the kaitan (conveyor belt) sushi bars.  But seriously, the sushi here at Kabuto was phenomenal.  I don't normally like tuna, but the blue fin tuna here was mild (not fishy) and so melt-in-your-mouth good.  We also tried the butter fish; a seared toro (fatty tuna seared by a blow torch); a ceviche that comes on small seaweed paper; escolar (super white tuna); a salmon from Tasmania (normally salmon is my favorite but this was too bland IMO--a disappointment); sea urchin (which melted like saltwater on our tongues); yellowtail dressed with pear and hot mustard (the pear and mustard combo was really palatable but I thought it overwhelmed the yellowtail so was not a good complement); foie gras sushi (a slab of foie gras atop sushi rice with a little raspberry on top--this was so creative and delicious); and bits of eel that came dressed in chocolate and bits of pear and foie gras all in a mini martini glass (also very creative and delicious--the chocolate made for a good substitute for the normally sweet eel sauce that comes on unagi--but the presentation seemed a bit forced when inside a martini glass).  All in all, this was a good mix of the classically delicious with the interestingly creative sushi.  Loved every bite.  The three of us ate all of the above and shared a large Sapporo, and the bill came out to be $180, making each sushi somewhere between $4 and $8.  Not what I'd normally pay, but we were on vacation, and anything goes.  So worth it for a splurge, especially if it was the best sushi I'd ever had.
author: Christine H.

description: Fresh, fresh FRESH sashimi.  The uni here is perfection!  Yummy.  I enjoyed the different rolls they had, I was just a little sad that most of the special rolls came only in 2 pieces, so I had to order a lot to get full.  They are very inventive and have great combinations.  My favorite is the Crunchy special sushi (i forget if that's the real name, but it's tempura halibut), fire salmon roll, sammy roll, and the hamachi pear.  Mmmmm.  Definitely coming back here.
author: Cheryl L.

description: This place, for what? the last 20 years, has been one of the purist sushi places in town. Top quality, real sushi in a neighborhood setting. Rock 'n roll attitude and spicy mayo rawness left at the door for the most part. Hard to rate or comment on any particular slice of fish on any particular night b/c sushi changes day to day, y'all. But this place does rate right up there with the better places in LA - and dat's sayin' alot.
author: A. P.

description:
Very creative in the combinations chef puts together, as in hamachi pear with fruity mustard!

We called ahead and secured reservations...and if you don't make a reservation you will be standing in line on the street looking through the window and salivating as you watch tables being served great things!
author: David B.

description: Yum...so glad that we found a place near us that is mellow and delicious! fish tasted so fresh. we had a few rolls, yellowfish, salmon...don't remember everything..but a $75 lunch was well worth it!
author: Bing B.

description:
Just had a dinner here.. overall, i enjoyed it!! the range of sushi rolls are unique  they're definitely different than other normal sushi place! this restaurant can be categorized as tapaz.. small portions, fullfilling people's desire of wanting to try as many kinds as possible..
Remarkable dishes:
- Foie Gras sushi.. omg... it juz melts in your mouth!!
- Valentine.. the chocolate sauce is not as overwhelming as i thought...
- Sunrise.. fr salmon sashimi lovers!!
- saikyo - slurpp

the "just- OK" dishes, WON'T order again next time, i guess:
- ankimo.. why eat this when u can eat foie gras?
- hamachi pear.. not remarkable.. despite the fresh fish
- toro tartar
- crunchy

Well, I'll definitely come back to try their other menus.. it woudl be great if you make reservations beforehand, so u don't have to wait so long while being packed inside this tiny restaurant!
author: Cherish S.

description: HOLY COW...or fish, as it may be.  EXCELLENT sushi.  So unique.  So tasty.  We had quite a few of their specialties...the ceviche was excellent, as was the hamachi collar which was grilled to perfection.  Yum.  Cannot wait to have an excuse to go back there.
author: Melinna G.

description: We took my parents there last Thursday night for an impromptu dinner in the avenues.   I remembered the restaurant from the days when there were lines around the corner.   Not Thursday though, we walked in and sat down immediately.   My concerns were soon alleviated when the otoro ($7 per) arrived.   Then the hamachi belly ($3 per).    And everything afterward (including a apple scallop concoction).   Simply perfect thick slices of sashimi and sushi.    We left full and very satisfied - all for a reasonable price.
author: Roger B.

description:
Their ceviche is to-die-for.  I like their grilled bass and scallops.  I was expecting a spider roll but the crab came by itself.

This is our 2nd visit if not third.  I like the variety but I also would prefer some more staples.  

Dinner doesn't fill me but it is quite tasty.
author: Mona B.

description: Been going to this place for years.  I really miss the old location though...  I definately don't come to this new location as often as I did with the old location.    The new owners pretty much threw everything out the door.  At the old location, you would see Japanese business men going out of their way to come here, not anymore. I still reccomended it though.
author: Demanding T.

description: Fluctuating quality.  Used to be more consistently good.  Had a piece of dried out tuna there recently.  Sometimes size of piece is a way to overcome less than exceptional quality.  Still go sometimes.  But it's not a planned special occasion anymore.
author: jennifer j.

description: Kabuto use to be one of favorite japanese restaurants in SF.  After Chef Sachio Kojima sold the place last August I decided to give the new owners a couple months before trying it again.  Last night I went back for the first time and was thoroughly disappointed.  Taste-wise, everything was a little off...from the items on the "unique sushi" menu to the special cuts of tasmanian king salmon and escolar.  Also it's pretty clear that the new owners are skimping on quality ingredients and portion sizes to improve margins - boo on you.  First-timers may like this place (there was still a crowd at the door).  But for anyone who has tasted the original, it's not worth the trip back.
author: Stephen C.

description: Yes, 43+ reviews can't be wrong. The staff can be spotty at times, but the sashimi was the best I've had in months. Brings me back to the Japanese fishing village days. Like butta.
author: I Love Beef C.

description: Very original.  The food in general is not bad, but ever since they moved I feel as if the price has gone up and everything else has stayed the same.  Try some of their special crudo/roll dishes they are unique and interesting.  However, I believe their sister restaurant Ariake down the block seems to be more of a go to place for me.
author: Cory C.

description: Came here for the first time last night, I'll definitely be back!  Kabuto Sushi has a pretty extensive menu with some of my japanese non-sushi favorites (maguro natto, mekabu, shishito...)  We had nigiri - the kanpachi and uni were especially fresh and yummy.  Nice casual, friendly, unpretentious atmosphere and service here too.  No wait either at 9:30pm on a Saturday night.  I'm gonna come back to try all the other dishes from home that I crave.  I'd give this place 4.5 stars if I could... and hope to make it a 5 after I try everything on the menu!!
author: Haru K.

description:
It was my second time at Kabuton last nite and once again I was impressed with their food.  The Valentine -foie gras, unagi sushi with some chocolate flavor sauce, served in a martini glass was my favorite of the night.  Also the tuna tartar sushi and the this other shrimp and crab sushi  as well as the Hirame Jerry were really good.  They have a special sushi menu and a regular sushi menu.  I have tried most of the items on the special sushi menu and I am impressed with all of them.  I have also tried many regular sushi menu items yesterday and all of them were really fresh, especially Escolar.  Overall Im fully satisfied with their food.  
Here are a few downside about this place.  This place is usually really crowded.  Full house at 8:30pm on a Tues night, but with only 2 waitresses.  The food were really slow.  Also this place can be very pricey.   We had 3 people, ordered a few bottles of beer and sushis on the special and the regular menu and the total was about $350 including tips.  Although it is totally worth the price, but it is not a place where I can come regularly to satisfy my constant hunger for sushi.  The last con about this place is this place is really hard to find parking on Geary.

But overall, this place is highly recommend and I am a fan.  Make sure to try all the items on the special sushi menu!
author: Kuankii N.

description:
Just had lunch here.  The most beautiful sushi I've seen in San Francisco.  Everything was fresh and a couple of notches above most of the best sushi joints in the city.  The ebi tasted as if it was an actual fresh shrimp that was cooked on site rather than the regular frozen pre-cooked stuff most places stick on a glob of rice.  The spider roll was also distinctly different, tasting more "crabby" and less of tempura.  

Love it.  It is pricey though... so be prepared for that.
author: Mike P.

description: Quite refreshing that the best sushi around is also free of the attitude and expense. Sure, sometimes its fun sitting in a large decked out sushi joint with chefs on display, as well as most of the customers, but I'll take Kabuto's quaintness any day. After indulging in the ingenious collection of specials, great Sake selections, and the bountiful regulars; mmm, tuna sampler; I always expect my personal bill to greatly exceed100$. So far it's hovered in the 50$ range, no matter how gluttonous I am. The only problem I have about writing this review is that it might attract more people. But hey, might as well share the yelpth.
author: Chris W.

description: Best sushi in SF. We ordered the ceviche, hamachi pear, fire salmon, foie gras  roll, and a spicy salmon roll. Yum!
author: danielle r.

description:
The sushi here is unique, fresh, and oh so good!! The presentation is wonderful!!! The menu is absolutely extensive.. a little overhelming. The sushi list is amazing!! Very unique! The foie gras sushi was delicious!!! Fresh seared foie gras on top of sushi rice. My other favorite was the baby lobster roll!! Yummy!!! Fresh lobster over rice and it was seared with a real torch in front of us! It was topped with cream lobster sauce. I highly recommend this one. The Scott handroll was really good as well.. fresh tuna roll topped with quail egg. Loved it! We also had spicy scallop, shrimp and crab tartar.. both were okay. Overall, really different from the normal rolls you see. Only reason why it didn't get 5 stars was the price. It was quit expensive. Each roll was about $9-$12 dollars.. I thought it was typical, but you ONLY get two pieces!!!! (not the usual 6!!) So in order for us to get full, we ordered about a total of 6 rolls!!!! Between two people, I only had 6 pieces....
I definitely want to go back to try the entrees and small plates..
author: Denise L.

description:
Fantastic experience! 

I finally ate at Kabuto and I am still glowing from last night's meal. I did my research on Yelp and ordered all the favorites and one after another, they did not disappoint. And my bill was only $50 due to the fact that I only drank 1 beer and 1 glass of Saki. 

The servers were gorgeous and the service was friendly and efficient. 

The ambiance was electric. I appreciated the visual things that enhanced my experience. From the dusk lighting looking out the window to the bright orange and green colors of the logo. We sat at the bar in front of the very cute sushi preparer. 

I shall return. 

Dupree
author: Rob D.

description:
*drool*

hamachi with green onion
toro nigiri
ceviche
boiled black seaweed
sake chazuke

It's super expensive but totally worth it. We paper, rock'd, scissors for the bill and I won! Free dinner! 

PS There are three sushi chefs and one of them is waaaay hot. I wish I could look like her.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
i am a ruiner of restaurants. i was afraid that kabuto might have suffered the over-hyped phenomenon. if my friends rave about a place for years on end, inevitably, when i get around to going, it sucks.

kabuto did not suck. it lived up to nearly all my expectations. the fish was amazingly fresh. in the midwest we suffer from 'jet-fresh' seafood. the selection was stellar and the flavor combinations were clever and inventive. the problem is, clever and inventive don't always work for me. some of the combos were just too overpowering and rich. the sunrise was WAAAAAY over the top for me. an entire quail egg does not belong atop one lone piece of sushi; it's far too much for one bite. the nigiri was fabulous though, and the chef's choice worked out well for us.

oh, and it seems like kabuto is in a bit of a cab wasteland, so if you make the trip, i recommend driving.
author: Rachel P.

description: Yes, Kabuto, you are and will be surely missed !  Have been going here for years and discovered last night that it is under new ownership. Same 2 crazy waitresses.  We've put up with them in the past just to get to the corner for Kabuto but I must say, with my sadness, that the new chefs are not worth the wait, the waitresses, the noise, and the prices.  $98 for 2 people for 2 star sushi after a drive across town and 45 minute wait - yikes !  We didn't see Kabuto through the window and had a feeling they were gone but gave the new people a try anyway ... won't be going it again.
author: Beautiful B.

description: Nice slices of fish but quite popular.  Seems to be a solid fave of all my sushi eating friends.  I've only been twice, but wanna go back soon.  Need a refresher and to update this review.... mmm fish
author: Gene X.

description: Sushi is okay, but the appetizers are great - the grilled eggplant is my fave!  The wait is terrible thou... i waited for almost an hour last time, and it's very hard to find parking in the neighborhood...
author: Mandy C.

description: Have eaten here twice.  Probably the most creative, inventive and fresh sushi in the city.
author: Pug P.

description:
Very tasty meal... everything we ate was amazing.  The fish was all remarkably fresh and delicious.  Stick with the specials, even though it can get pretty expensive if you are hungry!  We were a bit shocked when we got the bill.  That said, every bite of food was outstanding, so it was worth it.  

Hard to point out specific fav's, but here are a few:

Burri Toro (we called burritos)
Hamachi with jalapeno
Spicey scallops (had nigir and then hand roll)
Dragon Roll

Soo many other great ones, you can't go wrong, but be adventurous!

One bit of warning, you should order a lot at the beginning, they bring out one plate at a time, so if you wait and order more, you will have some serious lag time between orders.
author: Brad G.

description:
Wow...came here for the first time friday night and boy did I have a good time and a happy tummy.  We had a party of 8 and didn't want to get separated so we waited for a table to accomodate us.  It was definitely worth the wait.  They kept apologizing for waiting too.  We tried a lot of items on the menu.

Albacore Volcano-it was good...had some kind of green sauce on it...looked something like pesto.
Anago-I didn't get to try this one so can't comment on it.
Baby Main Lobster-At $6 a pop it was really really good....great recommendation from my buddy Spence.
Ceviche-we ordered 12 of these....halibut and salsa on deep fried seaweed...lol your server will tell you no sauce.  This is one of my faves.
Crepe sushi albacore-This was also very good.....yummy.
Crunchy sushi-this was very yummy.
Dragon roll-as anny dragon roll can be...I liked that the pieces weren't huge.
Fire salmon-not bad.....I definitely liked watching them torch the roll.
Grilled Lamb-I don't eat lamb so didn't try it.
Grilled spicy mussels-We had 3 orders of it....not too spicy for those that can't eat spicy.
Gyoza-pretty good we squeezed lemon juicce over it.
Ono-this was one of their specials..yummies.
Toro tartar-This I also really liked...then again I like tartar anything....it was really pretty too.
Unagi and avocado-nothing special...but it was good too.
Uni-I must have gotten spoiled but this was good too.
Macha creme brulee...definitely interesting my first time eating this....not too bad.

I defintely had a great time here and will come back.  I do want to try other things on the menu.  But I definitely will be ordering baby main lobster, ceviche and toro tartar again....I really liked those.  We had over 80 items with everything that we ordered including drinks and desserts.  You might have to wait a bit for a table but definitely worth the wait.
author: Allison T.

description:
kabuto is the cadillac of sushi this side of divisadero.

the only problem with these rolls is that they may be just too pretty to eat.  but if you dare, the flavors are just as brilliant as the appearance.

the space is small, and there's always a wait. the prices aren't for the weak hearted or light walleted either so beware.

but there are plenty of people who will sacrifice a long wait and a big bill for an excellent meal.
author: Ameer N.

description:
it's been said many times before and i'll say it again, Kabuto A & S is amazing and, i find, almost maddeningly consistent. an SF institution really. it's not in the center of Japantown but it's worth the drive after filling up your tote bag with $1 Japanese goodies at Ichiban Kan. 

respect the toro tartare and lamb apple roll. this is the master menu.  hundreds of standard fare options (which aren't really standard at all) and a specialty menu that makes you slap yo mama every time. this place is serious.  don't order a basic california roll... you'll be sad when you see what everybody else got. 

i love taking friends and family here (especially new yorkers). i watched as my tight etiquette new york mother-in-law practically licked her plate after enjoying her scallops in chardonnay sauce. this place turns foodies who love sushi into junkies. slam it down with some of their high-end sake (the organic one made in berkeley is damn good with the chirashi zushi).

Better to be safe than sorry with this zagat rated gem, make a reservation sillies!  But it's even worth the wait outside in the cold (come on people!).
author: M M.

description: Awesome find for Japanese/Sushi cuisine.  The sushi chefs has a great mind for creativity but using great quality fish.  My favorite all time dish is the Raw Oyster with Uni, Tobiko and 14K gold flakes!  Their rolls are also delicious and unique.  Try the ones with foie gras or the Seared Salmon.
author: Alice H.

description: Good place and I agree with many of the positive comments.  If you order take-away they will not make any of the "special sushi's" for you so many of the specific dishes mentioned are not available.
author: Kevin F.

description: I think this is both the best and most consistent sushi restaurant in SF.  Yes, it's a ridiculous drive from downtown to get there, and yes, getting a table often requires a lot of patience, as the restaurant is very small.  But when it's time to eat, Kabuto delivers.  With sushi, there are a lot of places that focus on the staples, and there are some places focus on "special" rolls.  Kabuto gets it right with both the basics and the you'll-only-find-it-here rolls, such as foie gras, lamb, and CeViChe, all of which are fantastic.  I could spend all day eating there (which may explain why none of my clothes fit), and the prices are a bargain relative to the quality.  Service is harried, but very friendly.  It's restaurants like Kabuto that make SF a special place to live.
author: Ty D.

description:
i used to come here all the time when the original owners were there and their restaurant was across the street.  i've always thought their sushi was the best in sf, until i went there a few nights ago.

i found the sushi not to be the same as when the old owners were there. and i know good sushi when i taste it.  we ordered a couple of appetizers like the hamachi kama, spicy musse, and gyoza. they are bomb; i think better than the sushi.

i'm use to easily spending $150 -$200 bucks here with a date just because i eat a lot of sushi. but after the other night, i don't ever see myself paying that much for the quality of food. maybe $100  -$125 for my meal would've been more reasonable.
author: Cedric F.

description: Kabuto is a quiet restaurant and the food is very different because the way they make their sushi is different from other japanese restaurants. The way they plate their sushi makes it look exotic and also just looks creative. The prices for this restaurant is kind of pricey but it depends what you order to make it worth the money you spend. Also. the textures of the sushi has a wide spread of selections. Also it would be a good place to go at lunch because at night it gets really crowded especially on saturdays.
author: Ky P.

description: We can all argue over the "best" sushi restaurant in the area. It is a waste of time, grasshopper. Go here. eat here. Enjoy some of the best food on the planet. Smile as your waitress tells you "yes, we have fresh toro", then savour the luscious buttery love handles of the tuna fish. I see that some folks think this place is inexpensive. It is not. Figure $50/person for a great meal including beer or sake. But it's worth every yen.
author: Don W.

description: This is the best sushi I've had in the country, other than in LA's Sushi Nozawa (for under 100$).  They have an unmatched variety of just about every fish you've ever heard of and haven't, of specialty nigiri and rolls (that have their own menu), and all are incredibly fresh and tasty.  It is crazy to me that this place is rated lower on Yelp than some of the much more inferior sushi bars.  I can only conclude that it is backlash from Kabuto's high and well-deserved rating.
author: anna k.

description:
i'd give this place 5 stars, except that it was about 20% more expensive than the places we normally go. 

that said, the sushi was really good and very very very creative (asparagus toro roll in a miso fois gras reduction). i ordered 3 cucumber/avo rolls and they made them in multiple forms so that the presentation wouldn't be boring (2 of the rolls were inside out with the avocado on top like you'd see a rainbow roll would have the fish on top). 

the veggie tempura appetizer was plentiful unlike appetizers at other places, and they were nice enough to do all green veggies instead of starches. it was great, super fresh asparagus.

i'd go again for sure, but i might be a little more careful ordering so the bill wouldn't be so high.
author: lisa w.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi places in the city.  Definitely fresh, and definitely got it's own special twist to Japanese cuisine.  the Asari soup, Dobin mushi (mushroom soup served in a cute teapot with sake cups to drink the delicious broth with), and all the special sushi's are amazing.  The foie gras, baby lobster, and sonoma duck sushi are among my favorites.  Try out chilled sake with uni, ikura, chives, tobiko, and gold flake as a garnish.  It is SO SO good.  And oh yea, the sushi chefs rock too, always sending out a complimentary dish or some shot of nice chilled sake. Always a plus.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Amazing quality, unique menu options - I really love Kabuto.  I could eat nothing but the foie gras sushi for an entire meal, even with my girlfriend's increasingly intense look disapproval at the ethics of my food choices.   The fruit & sushi combinations are novel and quite tasty as well - why do so few sushi places in the Bay Area do this?
author: Jason M.

description: It was good, but I wasn't impressed.  Portions seemed a bit small for the price.  The interior was a bit  cramped and you definitely had to make eye contact with somebody to get service.  I liked how they had different versions of miso but essentially they all tasted the same. 2 misos, 2 rolls and one hamachi was roughly $70.  If I were in the area, I might consider it, but I definitely wouldn't go out of my way to find it.
author: Rachelle G.

description: I've been coming here for years, even when they used to be located across the street.  The original owner/chef, Sachio, who made this place what is is, has since left and moved up to Mt. Shasta (he's opened a restaurant up there too -- must make a trip there someday..), but the new owners who run it now have done a great job keeping up everything.  Kabuto has the finest selection of fresh fish and sushi creations you won't find anywhere else. My most absolute favorite is the Ceviche sushi, I can eat hundreds of those!
author: Crys L.

description: We did not have the sashimi or nigiri (which really tells you how fresh the fish is) so I cannot attest to the quality or freshness of the fish.  However, we had several rolls, which were just average.  The presentation is beautiful though and the seaweed salad is probably the best I've had (wide seaweed, not the traditional light-green kind).
author: Mitzi C.

description: The rumors are true: this place provides the perfect sushi experience, from a great sake selection to friendly service to inventive sushi appetizers and quality fish.  They tend to favor the flame thrower modified sushi rolls, which I'm not crazy about.  And the location isn't the best for me.  But, if you care about good sushi more than ambiance, Kabuto is for you.
author: Chad W.

description:
One of the best sushi bars in San Francisco.  I don't think that I've seen the same selection of sushi or sashimi in any other Japanese restaurant in San Francisco.  

I've eaten there a few times and have always been impressed by the freshness of the fish.  I even eat the fresh salmon - which I never do in most other sushi places.  

Their special rolls are worth investigating.  The one roll I remember had pear in it.   Now, I've eaten at a number of Sushi places and have never had pear in any.  So, a plus for creativity.  

They have a variety of miso soups - at least 3, if I remember correctly - which all taste subtly different from each other.  Other places just have one type of miso soup.  

I've taken my kids there a couple of times and the waitstaff have always been very helpful.  This was the first sushi place that I took the kids too - and the first time that they tried sushi (ikura, which they now love).  

I like their collection of sakes - I've tried the regular hot house sake (a good way to get a quick buzz) and have also tried a couple of their cold sakes, which were good.  

It is in the Richmond which could be a downside depending on where you live in the city.  Also, it isn't the hippest place in the world - very simple, basic decor.  However the food is truly wonderful, so that trumps everything.

2/8/2014 update
- went there with family this past weekend. Still the best sushi, in my opinion. Tried lots of things but the pièce de résistance was the live uni! Mmm, mmm, mmm - and they bring it out with the shell, which makes for interesting conversation.
author: Nick K.

description: My friend suggested this place and reading the reviews, it looked like a decent place but I was a bit disappointed. We ordered entrees but maybe we should've went a la carte. Could've been a mistake on our part but who knows. I just didn't think the sushi was very fresh...We did order hamachi kama and that was really tasty.
author: Michelle H.

description: Kabuto combines fresh fish with creativity.  The sushi are beautifully plated individually unlike most restaurant would combine your whole sushi order on the same plate.  This tells me that they take pride in their food presentation which translate also in the quality of food they serve there.  The toro tartar was one of my favorite.  Price is very reasonable too.
author: Amelia H.

description: We've been going to Kabuto since it was on the either side of Geary.  This place is really different from other sushi places in the area--many unique items on the menu and great execution.
