You can get the traditional items like chawan mushi but also try new dishes they've created.  A definite fan.
author: Mae O.

description: The company was great, yet I think we ordered the wrong things.  The tofu business in the broth was great, and we had this big platter of sashimi, yet the tuna was as smooth as it could have been.  A bit chewy if you will.  But the fire roll was great.  Not positive I would be back, yet the ladies who worked there are very attentive.  Tempura looked killer, yet I was not in the ordering seat.  So there you have it.
author: Nicole F.

description:
As a vegetarian, japanese restaurants are really hit and miss. In general veggie sushi consists of boiled vegetables coupled with cucumber and/or avocado. 

But Kabuto. Mmm, Kabuto.  They have a variety of nigiri veggie sushi that really floats my boat. The japanese pumpkin is lightly roasted. The enoki mushrooms are slightly crunchy. Lots of choices and so well done. All the pieces I've tried have been wonderful. And the price for the veggie nigiri is super reasonable ($1.25 - $2.50/ piece)

Their dengaku (broiled eggplant with miso sauce) comes out hot, with the smooth texture and sweetness of the miso matching so well with the eggplant. Man. delicious. 

Go here even if you don't eat fish!
author: C M.

description:
I was really excited to come here because my friend kept raving about how pretty the sushi was . She was right !! But boy was I disappointed .. looks can be deceiving !! The taste didn't match up to the looks ! I came here just yesterday with three friends . We ordered the baby main lobster , toro tartar , sushi mozzarella , and the crepe sushi . The baby main lobster seemed to lack flavor , the toro tartar was too salty & overpowered with flavor . I don't remember regarding the sushi mozzarella and crepe sushi but they obviously weren't that good either because the taste didn't leave an impression on me . The 1849 oysters were okay but too salty and overpowered with flavor . At first I thought the gold stuff was not edible so I picked it out but later on , my friend told me it was edible ): . The grilled spicy mussel SUCKED . It was a total miss ! The sauce that it was made in didn't even taste good !! It was not creamy one bit ! The jalapeno yellowtail was pretty good . I like the sauce on the plate that it came with . My favorite was this one dish with four pieces sashimi ( I forgot what it was but it's white ) and it's dipped in some kind of green sauce . It was very tasty !! We ordered a lot of different kinds of  sashimi which tasted okay . The green tea creme brulee was okay but too sweet . I really want to give this place 4 stars .. 3 for the so-so food and 1 extra one for the creativity and presentation of the food because it takes a lot of effort & time to make each dish pretty but I can't . Why ? Because :

1) The glass cups had a dish cleaner taste to it when I was drinking their beer
2) The special sushi was expensive .. $ 5 - 8 for only two pieces that didn't even taste all that great ! So what if it looks pretty ! Looks aren't everything !!
3) After ordering and eating ALL that crap above , I was still not even close to being fulll ! Note that only me & one of my other friends was eating .
I guess this is a nice alternative to dessert and nice if you haven't seen their special rolls before but I would not recommend coming here for dinner if you're hungry or have cravings for sushi .
author: Eileen L.

description: Kabuto has been our favorite sushi place in SF for more than 15 years.  The menu has gotten fancier over the years.  To me, what excel in this restaurant is the quality of their ingredients and how they handle them.  Both of the master sushi chefs before and present are some of the best in the country.  5 stars for the sushi and 3.5 stars for the fancy creations.
author: Terry W.

description: This place is sooooo amazing, I can't put it into words.  I keep a running list of my top 10 favorite sushi restaurants anywhere.  Kabuto is always in the top 5, approaching top 3.  And it is a box.  A little hole in the wall.  Perfect fresh fish.  Creative dishes.  The only negative I can say is that it is pricey, but...you get what you pay for...
author: Jason T.

description: I agree with what people say here about the rolls being creative and the ingredients being fresh.  But the problem with this place is that the portions were just too small I just didn't feel good about shelling out all that dough for small portions at a japanese restaurant.  If it was like a "wow" experience but because expectations were high I was disappointed.  I mean it was good but not great and not great for its prices.
author: Stevezee C.

description: I bought two yelp deals when it was available thinking - "Hey, its a good deal.  You can't go wrong at this price for Japanese food."  After eating here two times, I am forced to re-evaluate.  Really nothing to write home about.  The food was on par with what you find at the mall.  After the first time, I thought it was just a bad night.  But when we had the same experience the second time around, I'm convinced that our first visit was no aberration.  Food was average and the service was mediocre.  This was the first time where I thought we received lesser service because they knew in advance that we were using a yelp deal.  Will not go back again.
author: Will L.

description:
okay, seriously, why have your restaurant in such a small spot when you could just move into a bigger spot right across the street???  i mean, there's already a sign on that building with the exact name as your restaurant.  what are the chances? 

it didn't help that there were 2 people taking up 4 spots at the sushi bar.  okay, so you walk in and you see 4 seats, and you and your partner decide to take the MIDDLE 2 seats even though the place is packed?  screw you!  i don't CARE if you're on a date, and i don't care if you think your purse deserves a seat of its own!!!  have some consideration!  i hope you got a bad piece of fish just for that!  

the food was pretty good.  the croquette's were a little mushy, but he gyoza was really good.  the sea bass was good, although a bit chewy in some spots.  my dining partner liked her tuna.  quite a selection of food.  i think i'm coming back and giving this place another chance though, as i think it has some promise....
author: Miss P.

description:
i ate dinner next to harold (of harold and kumar fame) here!
this place has a stellar galactic reputation, among sushi snobs and foodies.
they do not disappoint.  they keep their supply stocked with great quality choices from standard to exotic, so everytime you come back you will be tempted to try something new.
my favorites are the ceviche, the oysters, all the scallop offerings, and the hamachi with jalapeno.

of course i came here with my mama one day, and all that newfangled stuff might as well have been english to her, so she got the tuna plate.  Sure it was good, but with all they offer, why go for that, unless you are an old fashioned japanese lady?

I have gotten soba here with tenpura, and it's fine.
anyway, harold barely talked with his fiancee!
it gets expensive of course, but its worth it as a treat.
author: yayoi s.

description:
I loved the "special" rolls including ceviche, sonoma duck and the hamachi pear.  Everything was unique, fresh and good flavors.  I don't tend to order the other rolls, but stick to hamachi/nigiri which showcases the freshness/quality of the fish. 

Want to try  tuna tartare.
author: around town e.

description: The first time I went I was impressed by the Fois Gras negiri, but I went this last weekend and was bummed. It took forever to get a table. My date and I decided to move to the table next to us.. closer to the wall and it was all down hill from there. ( i think they were pissed) The rolls were small. Everthing took forever to arrive. They forgot my Unagi and nobody forgets my Unagi. I am on a big salmon kick and it was drab as well. There's is too much great sushi in this city to settle.
author: Claudia O.

description:
very creative. i had high expectations after word of mouth & comparing it to koo. everything was really good, some better than others, but i think koo really gets me (esp that spoonful of happiness & the chocolate cake). the menu was like reading a book, page after page of interesting things, & makes me want to go back & try more!

EAT: ~the FOIE GRAS SUSHI made me really happy. interesting use of berries & fruit (cran, ras, apple) throughout all the dishes. i was stunned to realize @ the end of the meal that i didn't use any shoyu whatsoever b/c everything was designed to eat as is, how refreshing! 

~the grilled miso butterfish (black cod) was good but really small portion. i liked the super japanesey presentation tho. 

~seared lobster was a little too spicy, but the lobster was very appealing. 

~i didn't know the toro tartare was nigiri-style, but i liked taste & presentation. just too small portion again; i expect tartare to last more than 2 seconds. it's also hard to impress w/tuna these days since so common. 

~live scallop was really good as is, love the texture, but accompanying sauce way overpowered--i could be dipping squid or rubber & it'd all taste the same. 

~tried bonito nigiri & 1849 oyster on a fellow diner's recommendation. bonito was pretty interesting w/lemongrass for aroma & crunch. 1849 oyster is served w/24k gold flakes on top, good but more of a novelty, & i turned right back around & told her she needed to get a spoonful of happiness from koo. 

UPDATE:
~GET THE INAYAKI: baked scallop in custard (not really custardy) will have u licking the shell clean. fan-freaking-tastic!

~i appreciated the 1849 oyster more this time b/c i wasn't comparing it to koo. very fresh oyster tasting, but the other ingredients (uni, quail egg) did almost seem superfluous.

~ahi tartare roll was good. shrimp & crab roll wasn't really.

~chawan mushi rocks here! very very very good.

~don't get the somen noodle salad. it's blah.

~the special roll w/the apple/pear was good. different yet still very japanesey.

~ankimo was very disappointing.

SERVICE: was fine. expected worst after reading yelp, but they were decently paced & no attitude whatsoever. we waited 20+ min to be seated despite having a reservation, altho we were 15 min late, but other ppl were seated before us! whatever.

DECOR: neighborhood joint. servers actually wear collar & tie, so i think the only thing incongruous w/the level of food is the decor.

BATHROOM: 1 private stall, but never too much of a line.

OVERALL: feast & expose urself to many wonderful, new flavors. i feel daring here. portions are too small. i guess that way u get to try lots of different things, but the portioning & pricing of the food is out of line w/the decor.
author: miss b.

description: Amazing presentation and very exotic choices.  Be ready to wait in line, regradless of the time because it's VERY popular.  I still think that it's not too widely known but it's busier and busier every time I go.  Try one of the special rolls for the evening, it's always interesting.
author: Jared F.

description:
kabuto has a hook-up for fresh fish that no one else seems to have. i fear  their secret is a dark one: black-market mermaid flesh. it really is that magical. i don't understand it. 

kirala in berkeley gets five stars too, but to kabuto goes 5 magic stars, especially when comparing the two place's grilled eggplant in miso- a MUST ORDER at kabuto. it's like lapping up sunshine and gooey clouds.

i know some people claim the oldie was the goodie, and i can't compare because i never went there. i'm just glad their old bootleg sign and dark store front  across the street are there to throw people off. but, to be nice i'll share that tuesday after 8 is a good time to go.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
i dont get this place.

the pieces of sushi are tasty as hell and inventive. cuts and portions turn out larger than youd expect for the price. wonderful decor and friendly personnel. very reasonable prices for what you end up receiving. 

it just doesnt add up - theres supposed to be a give and take, pay less, worse quality or something, but this place just doesnt make sense. fair prices for quality and unique food. only drawback i can think of is that youre going to need a reservation every day of the week if you want to enter and sit right down.

for sure try the:
hamachi pear
ceviche
author: Darrell L.

description: Their sushi is the one worth dying for. But you will be dead usually before you get into their teeny tiny restaurant. =) BUT...if you are in the right mood(can handle long waiting), this is the place will make you satisfied.
author: Yina M.

description:
amazing.  this place is delish.  on the multiple times i've been here, it has been worth the wait.  service could be better, but you can't have it all.

the maki rolls are very simple.  it's the fancy "special sushi" that you've got to try.  i recommend:

- ceviche.  in fact, just get 2 orders right off the bat.  i promise you'll love it
 - hamachi pear
 - crepe sushi albacore
 - crunchy sushi
 - spicy scallop

i swear, this 'hood has the best food.  if the weather didn't suck and it wasn't so far away from work, i'd totally move here.
author: Natalie H.

description: i love kabuto!  its one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  we usually order off the special menu.  the hamachi pear and ceviche are my two faves.  we also had the toro tartare, the salmon kama (great for the price and very good), grilled eggplant with the miso sauce, the scallop with custard (love) and the foie gras sushi to name a few.  the foie gras was so good that i had 2 pieces but it along with some of the other food was so rich that it did me in - i did not feel good the next day, but not b/c it was bad, its b/c i was bad and ate too many rich foods, boo :(  but i'm still a fan!
author: Vic S.

description:
kabuto sushi rocks my world!!!!! 

5 stars for the creative and innovative sushi that pleases the palette and the pudge. favorites include- the ceviche, toro tartar, and hamachi pear. who ever thought the combination of fish and pear could be this yummy? this place even has sushi pieces that have foie gras, lamb, and duck that's pretty damn tasty too.

beautiful presentation of the food, quality fish, smooth sake, and attentive service. the nigiri is oishii sugoi as well, especially the butter fish and escolar. mmmmmmm, i can't help but drool uncontrollably when i think of going to kabuto's.

it's quite expensive though so i usually only come here once in a while. the bill always comes out to over $100 for the 2 of us but it's well worth it if u have the moola. 

oishii sugoi!!!!!!
author: Jenni B.

description: This is my #1 sushi spot in the city. It's a small place, and there's usually a line later on in the week (no reservations), but they serve you tea while you're waiting. There's TONS of great sake and everything is pretty inexpensive.
author: Nicole S.

description: Can easily spend $50 w. drinks.  Their daily specials are fresh and written on a chalk board outside.  Cold sake selection better than their warm selection.  There's always a line but the good thing is that they serve late.  I think this is one of the best 'boutique' sushi places in SF if exists such a thing.  One other thing: owners are not Japanese but Korean. I heard them talking!
author: Susan K.

description: Is it possible that this is the best sushi in San Francisco? Yes, it is quite possible. Everything was incredibly fresh, beautifully prepared and the service was perfect. The only thing that wasn't so perfect was the price but that's a sacrifice I'm willing to make for sushi like this. It fills up pretty quickly...obviously other people are aware of it's fabulousness...so get there early. Unbelievable...it has given me hope that great sushi still exists in San Francisco!
author: Pagely T.

description: Sometimes the wait can be excruciatingly long, but it is worth it if you like your sushi fresh. (Exceptionally high grade fish.) The 1849 Oyster was sublime & the Sonoma Duck was excellent. Extra points for presentation, French influence (foie sushi anyone?) & the sake selection. Recommend getting there early or dining late.
author: Michael N.

description: Interesting, modern Japanese food. Great presentation and creative flavor mix. Five stars for creativity and three and half stars for flavor.
author: Joanne X.

description: I came here a few months ago so this review cannot be too detailed. I just remembered that they had the best oysters. Must try the oysters. I think it was called 1849 Oysters? Idont know something with a date. I remembered trying the dragon roll. THat was really delicious too. And the Udon noodles are REALLY good too. The bad side about this restaurant is that it is soooo tiny. One time I had to wait 30 min. But regardless, I will always come back here.
author: Amy X.

description: This is definitely the most authentic and fresh sushi i've had in SF. There is this pear, tuna, mustard seed, nigiri that is amazing! Normally I don't order off a handwritten 'Specials' board at sushi places but it is a must in this little gem. Little being the operative word, you'll definitely wait for a table and I wouldn't go here w/ a group.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
Kabuto

Overall 4.5: Fresh and delicious food and decent service. Definitely coming back often.
Food 4.5
Service 3.5
Ambiance/Décor 1

Food 4.5
Sushi was fresh!!! Very innovative flavors that work. They have the classics and the fusions. Both deliciously prepared.
-----
Yes's
HAMACHI TARTARE: Must order. It was a party in my mouth. No soy sauce needed.
FOIE GRAS NIGIRI: Foie gras lovers should order. It's a pretty solid dish. It's pair with the usual sweet citrus glaze. However, the second time I ordered this they skimped on the size of the foie gras, but it was still delicious. $9 for two bites. Your call if it's worth it to you.
TORO TARTARE: Not as flavorful as the hamachi tartare, but almost as good and is more mellow in flavor.
HAMACHI PEAR MUSTARD: It was like a wonderful light pear mustard salad. A little tang from the mustard, a little sweetness from the hamachi, a little texture from the pear.
SASHIMI COMBO PLATE: very affordable ~$23, very fresh fish. What more can you ask for. One order can fill up my guy friends.
-----
No's
SALMON CALI ROLL W CURRY SAUCE: Sounded yummy, but flavors just didn't work. Give them points for using real crab however it wasn't fresh.


Service 3.5
Allow for reservations is a big plus. A rather small restaurant to fit parties any bigger than 2's 4's and maybe one 6-8. Friendly service. Not extra attentive. But polite when called on. When ordering nigiri rolls, note they do come out one by one, so not super fast if you're starving.

Ambiance/Décor 1
It's a very clean restaurant, but it's rather bright and unpleasant to the eye. Bright orange and yellow splashed onto the walls. Weird electrical meter jutting out in the middle of a wall. Front tables rather cold from the draft by the door. But all said and done, food is way delicious, I can overlook what the restaurant looks like as long as they are clean.
author: Lily V.

description: This was my husband's and my favorite restaurant when we lived in San Francisco.  The sushi is the best I've had.  There is a nice aquarium and the sushi chef was always very friendly and innovative.  We used to know him by name - it's been a long time.  We went there a couple of years ago and it was still great, although the outside was covered with graffiti and was kind of dirty.  It holds great sentimental for me because we went there so often when we were courting.  :^}
author: Merry P.

description: Consistently a great sushi place with innovative nigiri.  Favorites are the lobster nigiri special, the Sunrise and oyster special (1849?)...mmm.  Not too pricey either for what you're getting.
author: Jenny d.

description:
You will be surpised to find to find your money missing since you won't remember being at a classy place.

But the food IS good. The sushi stands out, esp. their specials which are innovative. It feels very contemporary Japanese. Yuzu hirame, hamachi jalapeno, and yes, foie gras sushi.

Make sure you look at the non-sushi menu as well. Beef kushiaki, salads, it was hard to order something we didn't like.

For sushi, this is basically my first choice in SF.
author: Asdf A.

description: Friendly, with good food. But, if you have MSG sensitivity --- they use it. I even brought my own soy sauce, so it must have been in one of the ingredients. Nevertheless, I had a reaction.
author: Geri J.

description: Awesome place to go for sushi.  Kabuto does a good job on presentation and everything I had was very fresh and tasty.  I definately recommend the Sweet Potato Nigiri Sushi and the Shishitou Appetizer.
author: Shiho F.

description: Quality and freshness are the best I've found.  You pay for it, but as much as you would for mediocre sushi in the Marina (my old hood).   I LOVED the Hamachi Jalapeno sashimi special and the tasmanian salmon nigiri.  I didn't try the exotic stuff like rolls with Foie Gras, but, given such a great first experience, may later.  P.S. I hesitated to write this review as the small location is already tough to get into, but felt I had to be fair to my fellow yelpers.
author: Leslie R.

description: Okay this place looks like a whole in the wall.  Its super small and very few tables.  But the sushi is amazing!  They have some of those delicious gourmet rolls and of course the standard traditional sushi.  Its just so fresh.  I'm not gonna lie, it is a bit pricey, but so many sushi places are.  Its worth it though!
author: Lauren M.

description:
cubbie and i came here for our official first date.  don't come here looking for the authentic old school sushi fare... they definitely exercise creative license here at kabuto...

... but as long as you know that coming in, your meal will be pretty darn good.  the pairings are things you wouldn't think of... foie gras and the sush? OUTSTANDING! barbeque sonoma duck?  pretty darn good too.

i wouldn't call it a sushi joint as much as i would a sushi-fusion joint.  but delicious nonetheless.  and all the reviews complaining about price... honestly, for what you're getting, i don't know what you're talking about.  i can take issue with spending money in the outer richmond, but seriously, it's not that expensive and about in line with what you would expect.
author: Steven C.

description: Came here for a low-key graduation lunch with family. The fish  was so fresh and delicious.
author: Mark T.

description: This is by far my favorite sushi spot in San Francisco. Their menu is creative, but does not deviate too sharply from the traditional. The fish is always very fresh and their sushi/sashi plate is one of the best deals in town. The service is exceptional and the owner is one of the nicest guys I've ever met. If you haven't already noticed, I'm completely retarded for this place. Try the Valentine, the Hamachi Pear, and the Dragon Roll. I guarantee that you will not be disappointed.
author: j t.

description: Their authentic Japanese style sushi is all fantastic. It reminds me of travels in Nara and Osaka. They also have some crazy-flavorful (as others have mentioned) options. I have actually dreamt about the crunchy sushi, tempura halibut with curry sauce, and seared albacore in lettuce with a miso sauce. Amazing. Gets a bit crowded, but don't blame them for being so great they're in demand...
author: Lorae K.

description: Pricey, but it is sooo good. i have to say, this is one of the best sushi restaurant ive ever been to. they have enough varieties and they are all really unique. you cannot find it anywhere else. everything is really fresh there where it literally melt in your mouth. definitely try the lobster roll and the spicy scallop roll, theyre the best. i dont have a big stomach, but i still wasnt absolutely full after ordering $150 worth of food for two. dont come here and expect to be full unless youre willing to pay $100+ per person.
author: Anita C.

description: This is my secret place - best sushi in the city. Best. Long wait, though. Very long wait. But worth is - unless you're starving and going to pass out before being seated.
author: Jennifer B.

description: This is the best sushi I've ever had in the states. So good. Really fresh, amazing stuff and their rolls are really unique and well executed. My favorite is the sunrise roll. Salmon wrapped around sushi rice topped with tobiko and a raw quail egg. Don't be squeamish about the raw egg, it really ties everything together. The place has a long wait though so try to get there right when it opens.
author: Cathy T.

description: Some of the best sushi I've had ... if you've never been, I'd recommend their special sushi menu first.  All are well presented and most are better than most upper scale sushi establishments.  A few of them are mediocre considering the high prices.  Also, try their unagi if you are a fan.  The best unagi I've had anywhere.  Good selection of beer and saki.  Warning:  Stay away from their 1849 oyster special.  It's been there a while and my friend and I have both bet that the reason that it's called 1849 is that it's the number of times people have vomited trying to partake of this "special" sushi consisting of oyster, various roe, sea urchin, gold flake, and some mysterious "fishy juice" that is tough to keep down.  Mediocre service.  Cramped ... atmosphere is practically nonexistant.
author: Art C.

description: Kabuto has some damn fine sushi! I had trouble finishing my sashimi-sushi combo deal because they give you complimentary salad and miso soup. Can't complain with that! Salad was delish - loved the dressing. Cute little place. I had no problem getting in on a weekday.
author: Susan L.

description: We got there late (9-ish) on a Thursday so there weren't too many people there, and service was prompt. I got the chirashi sushi and I was blown away by the freshness (clarity?) of the sashimi. You can taste the difference between this place and your standard run-of-the-mill sushi purveyor. 4 stars so far, and I'm looking forward to my next visit.
author: John C.

description: Very good fish quality... everything my gf and I sampled tasted fantastic and fresh (toro, hamachi, tai, kotaku, maguro, unagi, etc...). Some of the unique sushi creations (hamachi pear) were quite unexpected and very tasty (but next time I think I'll pass on the foie gras "sushi"). Prices were fair. One of the better sushi joints I've been to in the city (and I've been to a lot).
author: Sunny Y.

description: Get here early, long line+no reservations.  It's worth the wait, though. Don't come if you're on a budget, though.  Between alcohol choices and all the tasty menu items, you'll lose track quickly.  I applaud the creative menu and the opportunity to try some "exotic" things I'd never had before.  At some point why do "regular" places even bother printing an entire menu full of "hamachi nigiri, maguro nigiri," etc?
author: Ken B.

description: Went on a friend's recommendation. Believe it when they said this place is not for kids as it's pretty small and the "crowd" is more suited for single people and dates. As for the food, the sushi is definitely fresh but can get kind of pricey when you add it all up. This is definitely the place to go if you are in the mood for experimenting. I must admit they had a pretty awesome fusion type menu. Along with normal sashimi dishes we ordered a bunch of foie gras dishes as well as the ankimo and although I rarely eat liver these were pretty good. 4 stars for the single folk, but alas I am a family man. 8)
author: John C.

description: They get 4 stars for food but -3 stars for service.  I've been going to Kabuto since they were on the north side of Geary Blvd.  But the last time I was there in their current location, I had the WORST service I've ever experienced.  My girlfriend and I waited forever to order.  I noticed at least two other tables, who ordered after we did, receive their orders before us.  We ordered enough sushi to require three separate deliveries.  Each dish seemed to take longer than the next.  The waitress never asked how we were doing or apologize for the delay.  I'll never step foot in Kabuto again.  Thank goodness in SF we have plenty of other sushi options.
author: David I.

description: HANDS DOWN THE BEST SUSHI IN TOWN!  This is a hidden gem since it is out in the avenues and most hipsters don't go west of Divis...but this place honestly has the most beautiful and FRESH sushi we've had. My husband and I started coming when I was pregnant with my first  baby(obviously limiting for me)-- but the wonderful service and "works of art" they created made us frequent fliers here. Those in the hood know it and the line is pretty crazy after 6pm (not the least expensive place in town)-- but this place is worth the wait & price.
author: Monica F.

description: Went to a friend's birthday party at this restaurant because of the "ratings".  Ordered the tempera soba and that was the nastiest food I ever had.  The broth was like salt water.   My girlfriend ordered the udon and that tasted like paste.  Couple of my friends ordered the "special sushi" and it was running with some kind of liquid.  So disgusting.  Will never go there again.
author: Stalone H.

description: Editing my review.  I had given this restaurant 4 stars but I think the prices blinded me.  The sushi here is so inexpensive.  Yes it is a great deal, the rolls are really large but it isn't really that fantastic.  The fish isn't that fresh and the rolls aren't that special.
author: Diane R.

description: I think it's the best sushi in the City (although, sadly, SF is just not a really good sushi town).  The fish is really fresh and the selection is out of this world.  They also have some inventive rolls that aren't too strange (I hate mayo or cream cheese in my rolls).  But, they are busy -- expect to wait!
author: Jenn S.

description: Always pass by this place when leaving the Richmond heading downtown on Geary.  Thought finally I'd give it a try.  Heard rave reviews about this place.  As soon as we were seated, my goodness, the prices were SKY high!  Expensive!!! The food is great, and the ambiance is very japanese.  The staff is very greatful for your business.  They thank you every moment they get.  I would not go back, unless they reduce their prices.
author: Christi S.

description: Ultra tiny and discreet space but some of the best sashimi in San Francisco.  They have a couple different salads which were all very good too.  Very reasonably priced.
author: Aileen N.

description: Well designed and presented sushi's with fresh tastes as we sat by the sushi bar watching the masters assemble the pieces together.  My friend and I ordered two specials of the day:  toro tartar which was extradordinary to my taste buds.  The 1849 oyster had gold flakes on it but because i'm a picky oyster lover, i disliked the big shelled ones. The dessert was sub-par:  a slab of green tea ice cream, red bean paste with mini gellies and fruit.
author: Jboogie L.

description: This is my new favorite sushi restaurant. It's soo good. Top quality food. When I first came in, I wanted a table...but none were available (even with a reservation), so we ended up at the sushi bar. Turned out good, cuz we got to see what the chef was making for other people and ordered accordingly. The quality of the food definitely fit the presentation. Order the half shelled raw oyster with all sorts of raw eggs, 'secret sauce' and GOLD flakes! What an experience! I'm coming back.  Not too pricey, but it ain't cheap.
author: Kim D.

description: I came here for the first time this week. It's supposedly usually very crowded. We were lucky and got the last table.  I like eating good sushi, and good sushi they had. Try the halibut ceviche and the poke tuna. I wished they had bigger servings.
author: Tan N.

description: I just ate here last night, and I agree with most other people who say that this is the best sushi in the city.  The toro tartar is absolutely spectacular as well as the lobster. The fish is fresh and this place is crowded on a Tuesday!!!!! Both chefs are really nice and the service is as well. I suggest eating at the sushi bar, cuz the chefs give good suggestions and they definitely appreciate you taking their advice.
author: Tommy Y.

description: I won't restate what others have said previously since I absolutely agree with their assessment on how fantastic this place is. However, I will strongly recommend that upon your visit, to get the Uni, Big Eye Tuna, Blue Fin, and lastly (multiple orders of), TORO!!!  ENJOY!
author: Ben M.

description: Wasn't all that, in my book. I thought it was kind of pricey and not up to par- especially considering how much others rave.It was a special anniversary meal, maybe the disappointment was tinged with the lam-o I was dating. Actually, I'm gonna give it one more shot...stay tuned.
author: Rhubarb M.

description:
Over-hyped!!!

I came to this place after many recommendations from friends, and finally came to this place to try the food. The food was not spectacular, very normal and not bad, but not as good as worth the price they were charging. For that price, I could have thought of at least four or five sushi places I rather be eating at.  Not that much selection in terms of raw fish.. a lot on their "special" board was already gone.. (but we went at like 6:30pm)... so go figures!

Then, there's all the fancy named combo plates you can get... I got the "Valentine" for $8. It was unagi and liver with some chocolate sauce.  It was not that good... especially for tiny bits of food in two martini glasses. It looked nice and good presentation, but where's the food?? I thought I came to eat and not just look!!

So, then there was the Hamachi kama (jawline of the fish) that we ordered that really pissed me off... I have had many, many Hamachi kamas and the one we got was the most burnt kama I have ever seen in my entire life time.  The black burnt parts of the kama could have given me an acute case of cancer.  Naturally, I told the waitress about it, and that waitress ignored my comment and then just went to tell this other older waitress about my comment.  The older waitress came over and said that's how it is. That a kama has to be burnt to be cooked thoroughly. And she insisted in her demanding and not-very-polite tone, "try it, try it"... I thought to myself, I guess you're not going to change our dish.  I proceeded to take out all the burnt parts of the kama and not much was left. I don't cook kama, but having ate kama at so many restaurants where it is cooked the exact same way, you would think there's no argument that the kama I had was pretty burnt. 

So instead of trying the kama and risking cancer as the waitress suggested, I skipped the kama. The owner has the nerve to come by and ask about our dish. I told him what happened, and all he could say was that he'll give us something for free (which turned out to be a small bottle of sake) and said that they had a limited supply of kama. 

That was my service that night. We ordered a lot of food that night, and the bill came out to $120 for three person.. but I can't say there was anything I really enjoyed. 

Two stars for the bad service and LACK of good food.
author: Lilian T.

description: Went back to SF recently and was a bit disappointed.  It has been awhile and I'm not sure I've become more picky with my sushi or the quality has gone down hill a bit.  The sushi overall was good, but not great.  The way they prepare the lamb has changed and it's good, but not great as I remember.  Not sure this one will be back on my list of places to go when I return to SF in the future.  Still a good place, so only reducing to 4 stars, but really not great as I remembered.
author: Rob B.

description:
excellent sushi chefs, cozy atmo and great sake selection.  

i guess you cant really hype this place because its so small.. the first time i went there i was wondering how they could make money with such a small place then i got the check...haha but it was still worth it.  EVERY DOLLAR!!!

this isnt your californiarollfusion places.
author: Doug ..

description: A place that never ceases to amaze with their imaginative creations of sushi combos utilizing fresh fish & fushion recipes. A+ combo is the Halibut ceviche wrapped in crispy seaweed and drizzled with lime and sea salt. Hamachi pear & Toro Tartare are also winners. If you want to stick with simplicity, their negihama handroll doesn't get any better for hamachi lovers. To even out the taste of sushi, try the green tea creme brulee. If you like green tea ice cream, you'll like this one.
author: Mary H.

description: The food was sooooo fresh!! I loved everything we ordered. Very interesting sushi selections and I loved the way how the sushi/nigiri were presented. I wished the service was a bit faster though because I was starving.The most memorable was the ceviche and I ordered the hamachi pear but for some reason it didn't come but I'll order that next time. The escolar sashimi was yummy and so was the jalepeno hamachi. My boyfriend and I spent $140 alone on the food and we were happy and full. I will be back again. My next stop is Koo and then Kiji. Crazy binge for sushi this whole month.
author: A L.

description: Really, really, really good.  There are some very creative things to choose from.  We had the hamachi pear & the U.F.T. from the special sushi, I loved the hamachi pear.  We also ordered some of each of our favorites and everything was awesome.  The sunomono with tako was very good, tho slightly different than most.
author: Emily T.

description:
I Heart Kabuto.  If I have more disposable income I would come here every week.  But I can't, especially since I like to eat about $50+ dollars worth of sushi each time here.  You can't help it, the menu brings tears to my eyes.  I love this place so much my husband and I came here for our two year anniversary.

Why do I love this place so friggin' much?
1) FRESH: you can't get better quality fish than here.  Good test is the uni, I had not-so-fresh-uni once at Ritz Carlton in Hong Kong and I sent it back.  At Kabuto, I order four nigiri pieces each time FOR MYSELF. I'm not sharing =)
2) Fish variety: not just run of the mill maguro and sake here, they have fish you don't find at the average sushi restaurant (e.g. escolar, kanpachi, abalone). 
3) Creativity: they don't just have normal nigiris and rolls, they have very creative ones that don't just involve fish.  My favorite non-fish is the foie-gras nigiri. Seared foie gras on top of sushi rice with a balsamic raspberry sauce top with half a raspberry.  Heavenly ... I order four pieces for myself, and I close my eyes to fully savor each and every piece.  People need to make sure they look at the separate special sushi menu.
4)  Menu: large, and diverse.  There hot food is just as good.  Chawan Mushi is wonderful, udons and other soups are great on a cold day.  They also have a decent amount for vegetarians.  My vegetarian friend can order to her heart's delight here, you can't say that about very many sushi places.  I have had a few vegetable nigiris myself (Japanese pumpkin, enoki) Just as delightful.

Place is small so good chance you'll have to wait for a table.  To avoid that just go earlier or later in the evening.  But it's worth the wait.  If you want to go with a larger group make a reservation.  If it will just be two people, you can probably squeeze in at the sushi bar.
author: Helen C.

description: This place has ruined me for all other sushi places. Very close to my Dad's house, so we come here around once a month or so. Great, original rolls and they do more traditional dishes very well. Family owned by the head sushi chef and his wife works there as well. Both are very friendly every time we stop in. A little pricey but worth it for the fresh, high quality dishes they serve.
author: Carmen C.

description: The only reason it's 4 is the wait. I've been three times, including tonight, Saturday, August 28, 2005. The last night Kabuto is owned/operated by the man and the crew that made this place famous. As was the case the first time we came here, we let the chef choose the sushi we ate. Everything was fantastic, fresh, and amazing. We waited 2 hours, but our friend from LA agreed - it's worth it. Still, that kind of wait must result in less than 5 stars. Still, saying "we'll miss you, Kabuto" is just not enough - there is a hole in Sf's sushi scene. Let's hope the new Kabuto and others fill that void.
author: Scott M.

description: Great sushi restaurant.  The outside of this place on Geary might throw you, but once you sit down and order any of their sushi, you'll be happy with this place.  Really good sushi.  The ceviche is good, all the sashimi is good.  I plan on returning often.
author: Sabrina K.

description: Even without the much missed Sachio-san and Aya-san, Kabuto lives on! Same great fish, same great menu, always fresh. Still one of the best sushi restaurants in San Francisco. Suberashi!!
author: Paul L.

description: Super yummy and fresh.  The orders came out rather inconsistantly, but they were jam packed, so I was just happy to have a steady stream of food coming my way.  The wait is rather long.
author: Lauren M.

description:
I credit Kabuto with solidifying my love for sushi once again after an almost six-year hiatus.  When my first sushi experience ended rather poorly with my dinner, and a handle of Tequila, ending up all over my ex-bf's apartment during my 19th birthday celebration, I vowed I would never eat sushi again.  Then I moved to San Francisco.

What started as a slow ease back into the land of raw fish has now resulted in an almost constant craving for the stuff - particularly, Kabuto.  This place manages to combine that intimate, almost hole-in-the-wall atmosphere with a truly delicious and creative menu.  The presentation flirts with a trip to the MOMA; from the plates of traditional rolls to the specials, it's almost painful to ruin the immaculate work of art before you. However, upon tearing it apart with your chopsticks you taste buds are rewarded with an often unique combination of flavors (enter CeViChe: halibut and salsa wrapped with deep fried seaweed and served with lime and sea salt; and my own personal favorite, Baby Maine Lobster).  The specials are amazing, and the traditional rolls never fail.  You'll pay a bit more for the specials, though it's well worth it.   Writing this is already making me crave my next trip.... yummy.
author: Nicole C.

description:
just okay

increased it a star
after multiple visits, value of sushi is great for everyday fair
author: Peter L.

description: if heaven were a food it would be unagi and avocado stuck together and deep fried.
author: Rachael S.

description:
I've been to Kabuto three times now with 3 different groups of friends.  All of us are very impressed by the artistic arrangement of the food, especially the unique sushi that they offer, and more importantly the taste of the sushi.  
I didn't give it a 5 because a lot of time your sushi will be ready but the servers are too busy to hand them to you.  It becomes a little frustrating when you sit right at the sushi bar and sees that your order is ready and wondering why the sushi chef don't just hand them to you.  
The other blemish is none of their dessert stands out for me.  But I am in love with their unique sushi.  They are also very accomodating on most of the sushi they can make odd number pieces to carter to your group size.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
okay, so i finally got to eat here, and while i am still a bit sour about my reservations experience, this is one of the best sushi places i've been to.

i have to rely on all my friends to tell me how the fish is, because i am allergic, but they have amazing other food, and are always very understanding and friendly.  LAMB SUSHI, btw.

and judging by the big grins, and silent, full mouths of my friends, everything else is killer too.
author: Mishka F.

description: I personally believe that this is one of the best sushi restaurants in San Francisco. Never mind the decor and the cramped space. The food is the star. Creative, imaginative dishes. The best Miso Eggplant dish I have ever tried.  Must try.
author: Samantha K.

description:
Y'know...  I used to love this place.  I hadn't been there in a while - not since the moved across the street to the old Rancho Burger spot.  They're in my hood and i drive past there almost every day.  I see the crowds out front every night of the week waiting for tables or seats at the bar.  I figured they were still hooking folks up with some great sushi.  
Well, I wasn't completely wrong.  The sushi is still good (Blowfish is better), but the service was absolutely HORRIBLE.  We each ordered an appetizer and mine came out almost 20 minutes after my dining companions'.  The arrival of our sushi was so random that I finished my entire meal before his last roll  landed in front of him.  I would have been happy to order more,  and I really wanted to, but I was afraid that it would take so long and I didn't want to risk that.  
I feel bad bashing this old favorite...  but I guess I'd have to say that I'm in no rush to go back anytime soon.
author: Mike M.

description:
be prepared to wait a long time!!!  japanese food is not cheap but when is it ever?  except for yum yum fish.  

i really like their cooked dishes.  the salmon head is good.  i've been wanting to try the hamachi but it always seems to be out of stock.  oh wells, maybe next time.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
Spectacular sashimi AND they had both hamachi and salmon kama that was absolutely divine!  My favorite sushi joint in town!!

But I tend to stay away from the special sushi menu because frankly, it's just not that good.  And also, be prepared for the waitress to ask you to move tables a few times before you actually get to eat.
author: Pinkyton C.

description: My new fave place! New, innovative sushi! Try the pear hamachi and the ceviche sushi! Sounds a little weird, but it's soooooooooo good! The wait is kinda long for dinner on the weekends, but it is well worth it. The staff is great, the sushi chefs are hilarious and fun if you befriend them, and service is good.
author: Mimi T.

description: This place is great. Always packed though... Went on a Thursday kinda late which proved to be an excellent time. We were told we had about an hour or so before we got there so we booked it on over (just a few blocks away) and were seated fast. I'm not crazy when it comes to ordering sushi (no unagi etc) but love the usuals. The one plus I love about this place is that they have wasabi tobiko. I have been to a few places that don't have it and it's such a staple (i.e. tsunami on divis got rid of wasabi tobiko and replaced it with habanero tobiko, ugh). It's also great to watch people try it for the first time (especially those who rarely eat it) and laugh at their facial expressions. anyhoo, come here if you want good sushi
author: Cameron R.

description: Sushi was excellent.  They have a very creative menu on specialty sushi that you will not see anywhere.  All the appetizer dishes were excellent and the fish were all very fresh and beautifully plated.  The place is a little small, but it does feel very cozy in there.  It does get pretty busy though, so make sure to get there early!
author: Lily Y.

description: Still my favorite sushi in the Bay Area, but best of all it's cozy and has that mid-Richmond, neighborhood feel.
author: Michael R.

description: Wow!  Was looking forward to sushi in San Fran and picked this place based on the Yelp reviews.  Got here early, around 6 on a weekday, and it wasn't packed.  Great sushi, ordered the scallop special, foie gras, toro tuna, and a few others off the special menu.  Every piece was incredibly tasty and beautifully prepared, but don't expect to come here without dropping some dough.
author: Isaac B.

description: Awsome Sushi place, small and vabriant and full of life. The sushi chefs are amazing I love seating at the bar to see these guys roll their magic! Looooong wait, but trust me its' worth it.....come check this sushi masterpiece.
author: JC C.

description: This was the best place for traditional sushi in the city but it is a shame about the new owners.  Maybe they will hit their stride soon, I think it is worth checking back in a few months.
author: Glenn P.

description:
Good sushi.  Not remarkable really in any particular way but certainly not bad.

Both of the two servers were functionally adequate.  However, one of them was about the coldest fish I have ever encountered as a waitress.  She was the more attractive of the two and perhaps that is why the owner hired her.  But attractive or not, no matter how hard I tried to get some semblance of humanity out of her by graciously saying thank you whenever she came to the table, it mattered not.  She was like ice, and it was annoying enough that even though the sushi was acceptable, I can't say that I am all that enthusiastic about returning here.
author: Richard P.

description:
i'm stunned this place got as many good reviews as it did.  i thought it was really below average. 

i don't like sushi that has fried stuff in it.  just give me rice and fresh uncooked fish.  when I ordered the salmon roll with crab in it, the roll came out with fried legs sticking out of my roll.  not only that, but the fried legs were cold and chewy, and tasted like they'd been fried 5 hours ago.  to add insult to inury, there were little slivers of carrot (??) in the sushi.  I don't like anything crunchy in my sushi.  Just gross.

Also, the display cases are cloudy and gross, and the fish sitting inside them just doesn't look appetizing or fresh.  we left the restaurant feeling slightly sick to our stomach, and we love sushi.

two stars for the nice staff and the decent miso soup.  other than that, I won't be going back.
author: mazzy r.

description: A great new discovery - Kabuto is now taking reservations! Caution is to specify table if that's what you want, or else you may end up at the sushi bar. Some of the best sushi you can get in SF, plus some interesting creative dishes as well. Yesterday, we tried the Valentine, which is grilled eel with foie gras, topped with some chocolate sauce. It could be creamier, but it's a good blend of tastes. And they serve Yebisu beer and have a great list of sake.
author: Izzy C.

description: One of my favorite places here in San Francisco thus far. Every plate is a piece of art- the sushi is amazing. Be prepared to sample lots of dishes, as the menu is quite appealing. They even have Green Tea Cream Brule!
author: Sandra D.

description: Some of the best, most creative sushi I've had in a long while. The standard offerings were extremely fresh and delicious. The unique items were incredible. That includes kabocha (pumpkin) sushi as well as fish dipped in yuzu (citrus) sauce. Prices, too, were reasonable considering the quality of the food.
author: Ken F.

description: 3.5 Stars. Fun presentation, interesting choices, and nice service. I recommend eating off the board because everything we had off of there was phenomenal. However, the sushi combo we ordered off the menu wasn't too great. I had the WORST piece of maguro ever... (sad)... it was on the verge of foul. The other pieces were A-OK, but it all paled in comparison to the board. We didn't get it but the 1849 oysters looked phenomenal as welll...
author: Jeannette L.

description: The best sushi I have had so far in SF.  I am yet to have a bad experience here. Though, I haven't tried the pink dragon roll that is previously described as disgusting.
author: H K.

description: I tried Kabuto for the first time a couple of years ago and absolutely loved it.  The ingredients are always fresh and there is a great selection of innovative sushi on the special menu, including my favorites:  the ceviche sushi and the crunchy sushi.  The only downside is the long wait on weekends.  I normally try to get there by 7:00pm to avoid having to wait.
author: beatrice m.

description:
Let me start by saying that Kabuto has some really inventive sushi on their special menu.  We had the cruncy sushi (tempura halibut with a curry sauce) and another concoction - avocado, and unagi with raspberry sauce.  The latter wasn't really working for me.  Don't get me wrong - this sushi is artfully presented - almost too pretty too eat.  I understand the price point, but for two pieces of sushi per order, it just doesn't strike me as good value.  We tried a couple rolls from the regular menu as well, and they were just okay.  Our favorite dish was actually the cold soba noodles served with fresh greens and a nice tangy dressing.  We ordered it as an after thought when we realized that two of the special rolls we'd ordered amounted to four  small pieces. 

I think I'm a sushi purist - maybe that's the problem.  I probably won't go rushing back, unless I'm with friends and they say something like, "I'm in the mood for sushi - but not the normal stuff, I want reinvented sushi - sushi with raspberry sauce, sushi with grapefruit!"  Then...I'd have just the place.
author: Steve J.

description: We were not impressed and will not be returning to this place to give it another try. Perhaps they were having an off night but the sushi did not taste good at all. Also, one the sushi chefs sneezed 3 or 4 times in a row and despite the fact that there were at least 5 people sitting in front of him, he did not was his hands-yuck!
author: Maria D.

description:
Everyone has been saying this place has gone down hill. I didn't want to believe it.  Up until the last time I went 1 year ago, I've had the most amazing meals and anyone I took was truly impressed.
My return trip last night not only confirmed that that Kabuto has gone down hill, but shocked and actually disgusted with how far it has fallen. I knew things had gone horribly wrong after we ordered and our waitress brought out the plates and a bowl of wasabi and ginger for our sushi. The wasabi and ginger were all crusted and brown like they had been sitting out for a day and dried a bit. I've never seen this before, even at the dirtiest and cheapest sushi restaurants. The actual meal was more of the same. I think the menu and recipes are the same but the quality of the ingredients has vastly diminished. The fish was not only lower quality but also not fresh. Some pieces also showed some drying from being exposed to air for some time. There were a couple things we ordered that were closer to what I remember of Kabuto but still fell short. The one highlight was a roll one of my diner companions invented, an uni and tako roll, really good.
The other not fun part was a truly rude, loud and annoying table of people beside us. But I understand these things happen and I don't reflect it on the restaurant.
Overall, I don't think I will be returning. Thanks for some good memories. I really do hope things improve.
author: Trevis C.

description:
Amazing sushi.  Creative and delicious.  Shockingly gourmet for a small neighbourhood restaurant.   Take your date here and impress them with your knowledge of the best sushi restaurant in town that isn't barely known outside of the richmond.  Worth driving across town for.  Truly has the freshest fish and the most diverse menu.

One measure of its quality is that the sushi is made so well that the rice and the fish don't require a strip of seaweed to hold it together.  This means you can easily bite off half the sushi without the seaweed pulling the thing to pieces.  Makes ya feel sophisticated I tells ya.  

A filling meal for 2 with many taster dishes cost us $50 without wine.  But the food would have been at home on a $80/person menu.
author: alan b.

description: Kabuto is a great local sushi place. Very friendly service and high qulaity sushi. The takeout menu is a bit more limited. We take out often and eat in to try the more creative sushi specials. It is a consistently high quality sushi experience.
author: roger m.

description:
Come here when you regular sushi place is not what you crave. There are plenty of the usuals like unagi and saba but the special rolls are the best things on the menu. Ceviche comes in deep fried seaweed and Sonoma duck is a juicy piece of duck with Japanese mustard. 

The restaurant has a clean, modern feeling and the service is great.
author: Nadezda K.

description: It took 4 years to get my guy to go to sushi. Now he is in love and seems to want Kabuto weekly!it really was a nudge from a good friend who swears by this place. In the end not only are the staff & owner exceptional, the food is off the scale!
author: johnny b.

description: One of my favorite fusion sushi place in SF. I had the spicy yellowtail and their specials. They have different specials daily. Try them all. Best since Nobu.
author: Helen L.

description: I absolutely love eating at this place. My boyfriend and I come here about once a week for dinner. Their sushi is very creative. There is a bit of a wait on the weekends, so make reservations ahead of time or come early.
author: J W.

description:
Go here for their specials and not their decor.

Their specials are the ones to try!  Very Iron Chef Fusion style.

Presentation is real 4 star style with the taste very delicate and crisp.  Portions will be small as that will not dull the taste buds.

The food after dozens of visits over time has been solidly consistent.

Beware, the locale is small and cramped especially for wheel chair access.  There could also be a wait for a table.
author: JL S.

description: The best sushi in San Francisco. Not your typical sushi place. Lots of unusual dishes on the menu, they're all great. The sushi is good, the hot food from the kitchen is good and the soups are all excellent. I recommend mozukuzu, 1849 oysters and the crunchy sushi. Delicious!
author: Geraldine S.

description:
Finally!  A sushi place in SF that makes me crave for sushi and delivers!  The fish was soooooooo fresh, I was looking for the aquarium.  Beautiful plating, and did I mention fresh delicious fish?  

The only dish that I didn't enjoy was the spider roll which was wrapped in daikon radish...a bit unusual as I'm used to it being wrapped in seaweed.  Left an odd taste in my mouth.

The prices are expensive, but well worth it.  The special sushi was very unusual.  

I just wished that I was able to experience this place under its original owners.  

Oh well...now need to save money for next Kabuto experience.
author: J H.

description: fish was a little overly cold last time i went.
author: Latrice B.

description: This is the best sushi I've found in SF-- fresh, creative, and delicious. The Hamachi Pear and the Halibut Ceviche, in particular, are out of this world. Truly exceptional.
author: L T.

description: Kabuto has the best sushi in the city.  Yes, that's a bold statement but I've tried quite the assortment of sushi joints and this is the place to go.  No major frills, no scenes,  just the freshest fish.  They usually have multiple kinds of tuna...try the sashimi.  They  also have some very interesting rolls which might catch you off you guard but are delicious.  I take a point off because no reservations and sometimes the wait can be rough.
author: dizzle d.

description:
Exceptional sushi.
Fresh, great service, great selection.
Very unique restaurant.
Love it!
author: Jacob C.

description:
I am not sure what really happened to this place. I went there more than a year ago and the sushi was great! 

Over the last several months I have been there a few times and their Sushi wasn't that good. The Nigiri just wasn't as fresh as I had remembered, the prices had gone up, and the rolls were somewhat generic.  Their service seemed to have slipped too.

This strikes me as typical Sushi place catering to American palates and I find it to be not particularly authentic.

Being a Japanese native makes me very picky when it comes to Sushi and unfortunately Kabuto no longer makes the grade.  I'm surprised at the amount of favorable reviews I have read about them and can't understand why they're so popular.

**** updated ****
I just remembered the owner retired in 2006.
That's why their sushi is not as good. 
I really miss him.... :(
author: Lisa M.

description:
This restaurant is a hidden gem! The sushi is so fresh, and it's not your typical sushi restaurant (which I love too!) They have a HUGE selection of fish, and I am all about trying whats recommended by the server. Each dish is given so my time and attention, and is beautiful! It's like a five start restaurant that looks like a hole in the wall, local joint. The service is great... but go there EARLY because a line forms out the door within the first hour of opening, even on the week days. 

Highly recommended!
author: Bell C.

description:
overall I think this may  be the best japanese restaurant in the city... 
great service from polite staff...
author: William W.

description: Watch out - good sushi but reservations are meaningless. We had a reservation at 9 pm on a saturday, when we showed up there were no open tables and a 30 min wait. They never even asked our name for the reservation - got the sense they don't even write them down.
author: Parker C.

description: Easily my favorite sushi bar in SF. Creative, delicious sushi in a cool atmosphere without being pretentious and fun, happy staff who are happy to answer questions and make suggestions.
author: Colin S.

description: drawn to kabuto by the yelp reviews and gotta say i'm slightly disappointed.  the sushi was impeccably presented, but must say that better "creative" sushi/rolls, toro and albacore can be had elsewhere.  it is *not* inexpensive by any means...especially in SF.
author: Vic A.

description: This is the first time I've been back since Sachio-san left, and what a terrible disappointment. I took my boss from Osaka, who is a huge foodie and connoiseur of Japanese food. We were promptly seated at the counter (that should've been a big red flag right there as with the previous owners the place was so packed you had to start lining up outside at 5PM when it opened!). We ordered edamame, a couple small plates, 2 sakes and the toro tartar salad to start. The tartar came out from the sushi bar side in minutes, before we had even gotten our drinks. It was a strange, gooey combination of minced, seared fatty tuna (toro) over some kind of slimey grayish green sauce which we were told was avocado. It was $15 and in my opinion a total waste of the toro. The flavors did not meld together well, and the luxurious taste and texture of the toro were lost. Next the burdock root dish came out, which was mediocre at best. We still had not gotten our drinks (about 15 minutes had passed). I reminded the scatter-brained waitress that we still needed our drinks and edamame (normally always first to come out ) and she replied with a curt semi-nod. No apologies, nothing. I should probably let you know that I'm half Japanese and was speaking to her in Japanese, and it's part of Japanese culture to apologize profusely when one has messed up or forgotten something, especially an "okyaku-san" (customer). Finally our drinks came out (still no edamame), so we were stuck with sake, but no "tsumami" (something to munch on while drinking), another big no-no in Japan. Finally we got so sick of flagging her down and complaining that we just asked for the check (at this point we had only gotten 2 of the 5 or 6 things ordered and our drinks). We were charged for everything we ordered (even what never came out) and 4 glasses of sake! We had to send the bill back TWICE for corrections and finally left disgusted and headed straight to Oyaji on 32nd and Clement where we had wonderful sashimi, sushi and sake. We'll never return to Kabuto again.
author: lani P.

description: Great sushi menu from the standard nigiri's to some very special offerings.  Everything was fresh and cuts were just right, not too big and not too small.  They also had some nigiri that isn't always found, like kohada, pencil fish, multiple types of mackerels.  Also, their pricing is really right on, not cheap and not over the top, especially for the quality.
author: Max Y.

description: Here is the simple skinny - the BEST SUSHI that I have EVER had in my life.  I have traveled throughout Asia and Europe as well as the states - I have had the freshest and most creative - but NOTHING COMPARES when you have something that you swore you would NEVER taste and then when you pop in your mouth, you have that 'Harry Met Sally' moment and others want what you're having!!!  Ask for what's OFF THE menu for some incredible (and that is an understatement!) delight.  I swore that I would NEVER have foie gras.  I did not know that you could even put that in sushi!  But OH-MY-GOD!  I cant' wait to go back!
author: David C.

description: So goddam good you just can't believe it. Order exclusively from the "white menu", this is where they keep all the specialties of the house. The menu for big-nose white people is great too, but the white menu is da bomb! The only problem with Kabuto is that I was so mesmerized by watching the young sushi chef prepare fresh dishes when I sat at the bar, my date actually got a bit jealous that I wasn't paying enough attention to her. I swear to God, next time I'm going to Kabuto alone! The chef works at an almost manic pace, and he has an incredible sense of detail which is evidenced not only in the quality and innovation of his dishes but also in their presentation. The chef artfully uses real gold leaf, orchids, yellow dandelions and quail eggs to add to the beauty and the taste of his dishes. SOme of his dishes he finishes with a giant blowtorch - very godzilla-esque! I would pay money just to watch the Kabuto Iron Chef prepare his dishes for plating. The fish is buttery and tender, and the sauces are original and fresh (try the tataki with house sauce instead of the ponzu for example). Genius!
author: Mike B.

description: The best sushi in San Francisco. Always fresh with great variety, a must is ceviche sushi!
author: Tava S.

description: I have long been a fan of Zushi Puzzle and proclaimed it to have the best quality fish in the bay.  While I remain a supporter of Roger I must admit the creativity, ambiance, and quality of everything I tasted here was superior.  For one you didn't feel like you were in an old laundromat and two there were far more choices.   A great date spot and you could go a la cart and not get a surprise bill for $250.
author: Robert S.

description: Delicious unique sushi and not over priced, too bad it is like eating in a donut shop- they need better decor!
author: K S.

description: A particularly cosmopolitan friend recommended this restaurant to me and claimed that it offered sushi better than any she had had in San Francisco, New York, Los Angeles and Tokyo. Far from a sushi aficionado, I was incredulous and felt that, in general, so long as the fish is fresh, sushi is sushi.  However, one meal at Kabuto proved her right and made me realize that it was possible to have sushi that virtually melted in one's mouth. With its unassuming decor and freakishly reasonable prices, this place manages to evade widespread recognition as a premier sushi establishment while simultaneously earning top marks and vocal praise from those in the know.
author: Eugene P.

description: Mmmmm....i loved this place.  i went here tonight with my husband and our friend Mike (who introduces us to most of the new places we go to- thanks dude).  most special tasty unique sushi we've had in awhile.  here's my recommendations: toro tartar, ceviche, foie gras..pretty much we went with the specials and the special sushi menu and were well rewarded.  sushi was fresh, tasty and interesting.  we were stuffed and drank a decent amount for 50-60/person (inc. tip).  the desert was great, get the zenzai, a red bean soup with rice balls- asian staple and they do it well.  i agree w/ jonhnny c. though- avoid the seats near the door.  the service was good.  the food took awhile to come but once it started there was no stopping it.    they were a little quick to take our plates, the little cherries that were on the pretty pretty plates were tasty but the waitresses (cool black tie wearing ones)  cleared them before you could snatch one.  i didn't try all the different kinds of sushi but am looking forward to coming back.  hear that chad?
author: Ann F.

description: I really like Kabuto. The food is inventive and fresh.  The fish is fantastic.  You can take your own wine, and they charge $10 corkage.  However, the reservations system is a disaster.  Making a reservation is pointless.  Twice I've made reservations, arrived on time, and had no table......for 50 minutes.  The place is small.  There's a sign in sheet for walk ins, but no system to prioritize reservations.  I've eaten here probably ten times for lunch and dinner during the week without having to wait, but Saturday night..............ugh.
author: Grendel B.

description: I've gone here three times in the past few weeks, I know it's been around for awhile but I just had to my 2 cents in. I've had much more expensive sushi, not that this place is a bargin, but for the money this place rocks.  Of course you got to be into not only really fresh traditional sushi, but their fusion stuff is to die for.                                      On my last visit I tried the Butterfish, Tasmanian salmon, adn Blue fin tuna for exotic fish.  Excellent, buttery, smooth, fresh fish taste, and great mouth feel ( for any cantonese) hau gum.  As I observed the hamachi pear sushi is the most popular, and rightly so, fresh hamachi with a thin slice of asian pear, and a dab of a homemade mustard chutney, its really a savory experience.  The toro tartare is to me the value dish, toro tuna with avacado and slightly peppery hint on a sheet of nori on rice, again really good, and only $5 for two pieces.  For the adventurous a lamb sushi that has roasted fuji apple, a rasberry balsamic sauce and nori/rice, great combination of flavors, and comes with a small side of spring salad infused with light balsamic dressing.                                                                                            I would recomend ordering your traditional sushi first before you dive into the exotic fusion offerings.  I usually finish with the fire salmon roll, like it's name has spicy sauce on it so eat it last to finish your meal wih a bang.  Definitely will be a place for me to hang out for awhile, as long as my piggy bank holds up, about 50-60 per person with a few beers, 40 if u go non-alcohlic.  Enjoy, go early, it's a small place and if u wanna sit at the bar there are only about 10 spaces.
author: Michael D.

description: Sit at the counter to get the best view of the cute sushi chef, and definitely order the following: hamachi kama, 1849 oyster (a lot more flavorful than the 'spoonful of happiness' at Koo, minus the sake), ankimo (tastier than the ankimo at Koo), foie gras sushi, and macha creme brulee. To avoid: poke (piss-poor value). Warning: it's cold and drafty, and during busy times it gets kind of loud.
author: A. T.

description: Wow this place sure did surprise me.  I'm usually pretty picky about japanese places because sometimes you go to a restaurant and the food just isnt fresh.  This place has great sushi and definately has fresh fish.  I love everything that I ate.  There were only two things that I thought were "ok".  Definately try their specialty rolls, they're all great and they are so unique...each roll has a twist to it.  My favorites are the ceviche, foie gra sushi and jalapeno hamachi.
author: Julie Z.

description:
delicious...
and the hot chef doesn't hurt either
author: Andrew K.

description: the menu frightened me at first... goose liver pate? but wow... it works! the flavors and the presentation are definitely worth the price.
author: Roman H.

description: I've never heard of the place but Stella C. said she has heard great things about it and wanted to try it so we did.  It is a really tiny restaurant and really stuffy on a hot day because of it.  We were seated right away but the tables next to us were so close to us it was like we were dining with them.  The menu was quite overwhelming, there was so much to choose from and I didn't know what to choose.  I went boring and ordered the chirashi as I always do... Stella totally called what I was going to order since I order the same thing every sushi place we go to... but she urged me to try a specialty roll, so I got the toro tartar roll, which was pretty good... they have a different way of presenting their rolls.  the sushi isn't wrapped around the rice and it is placed flat underneath it so i guess u can grab it and wrap it yourself.  I had also gotten the croquettes, and they were really cute... rolled into balls... I don't really like don katsu sauce usually and they had drizzled it over the croquette, but their katsu sauce wasn't that bad.  The meal was really good.  I don't think the chirashi was that much (usual price for chirashi is about 15-20 and it was in that price range)  but the specialty roll was like 11 bucks and it was the size of a nigiri.  The fish was really fresh and I think that makes it the price you're paying.
author: Kymberli C.

description: Here's the not-so-pretty verdict: I have eaten at four sushi restaurants since moving to SF six weeks ago, and none of them match the quality of the sushi I enjoyed in LA. One sushi place, however, does come close.   Before I go on, let me address my lovely San Franciscan friends: most of you get a little defensive when I make the LA-has-the-best-sushi claim. But hear these things: 1) The food overall is better in SF - better restaurants all around. 2) But LA is King of sushi. 3) My friend, Melissa, who has also had the pleasure of living in both cities, agrees with me. Mel, feel free to jump in here and get my back.   However, before being spoiled by LA sushi, Kabuto Sushi was my favorite. It's also considered SF's top sushi restaurant. I used to love watching Master Chef, Sachio, move in his odd mechanical way as he chopped fish, molded rice and slapped it gently together. And the sushi was to-die for. As my sushi chef friends down south have taught me, it's all about the balance between the rice, fish and sometimes seaweed. Sachio clearly hasn't lost the odd way in which he moves, but in my humble opionion he's now a little unbalanced.  Read more on The Ballyhoo: http://www.ballyhoo.us/restaurants/review.cfm?review=91
author: Baochi N.

description: i thought about giving it 3 stars for the wait, but oh well. the sushi/sashimi is good, but i think the rolls and menu overall is pretty creative. (ie. duck and fois grois sushi?) the green tea creme brulee was also pretty interesting.
author: Shinn Z.

description: i dig this joint. great sushi, not too expensive, awesome tuna salad, and the best unagi nigiri around town. we didn't order the rolls, because the sashimi was just too good not to order a second round. the wait is long unless you arrive right at opening hour, but once you sit down, you won't want to leave. the waitstaff is pretty friendly, and the environment casual.
author: monkey l.

description: sure, the wait can be tortuous and it ain't cheap, but this is love in the form of japanese cuisine.  worth it.
author: Missed F.

description: i know this place is well-reviewed, but i had a mixed experience.  the non-sushi food was great, deep fried soft shell crab was particularly excellent, but the sushi wasn't anything special.  i tried a selection of sashimi and found it to be chewy and lacking flavor.  after the main meal was done, the waitress seemed to forget about us for about a half an hour (even with people waiting for a table!) when we wanted to order dessert.  when we finally got her attention and placed our oder, it took another 30 minutes to get our dessert from the freezer and bring it to us!  to top it all off, she brought one of us a dessert we didn't order.
author: Andrew F.

description: Great sushi restaurant. It's cozy, affordable and tasty. I've been here several times and every time is good. Very interesting pairings (hamachi w/pear) but it works. Small place. probably only seats 20-25 people.
author: Erik B.

description: i was lured into this place cuz i kept hearing how good the foie gras sushi was so i decided to check out the place. the last place i had sushi prior to this was morimotos in new york so my expectations were high. the place was small and a real homey feel to it which i liked. so i finally had the foie sushi and it was good, but not the greatest thing i had that night. maybe it was to hyped up. the hands down winner that night was the KATSUNAGI!!!!!!! deep fried unagi with avocado with a slightly tart sauce to cut the grease mmmmmmmm it was so good i had three orders! it had all the textures. the crunch of the panko, the softness of the rice and the creaminess of the avocado. we had a few other dishes and they were all good. all in all definitely a good place to come if you want to try some unconventional sushi.
author: cj b.

description: authentic japanese restaurant.  not the typical trendy sushi places that compromise on authenticity or freshness.  fine, fresh seafood quality and amazing delicious creations like the foie gras sushi.  fresh good sushi and bottle of sapporo cannot be better.
author: anita c.

description: another one of my faves.  you must try the crispy halibut sushi (i think that's what it's called).  it has a creamy curry sauce, i know it might sound strange but it is good stuff.
author: a g.

description: Somewhat limited roll selection but whatever they serve is good! I took a non-sushi eater here for the first time and he was turned! You might be paying a little more than you receive (portions aren't generous) but definitely a place to add to the sushi-places-to-visit list.
author: Q C.

description: The freshest fish, great selection! Toro is to die for! Uni so good my non-uni-loving friend now is a believer. I was here for my birthday on a visit from Chicago, and loved my birthday dinner. Lovely neighborhood spot with wonderful food and good sake selection. Will keep coming back here every time I visit. (btw, prices very reasonable)
author: Paula R.

description: Not terribly authentic, and the technique is sloppy.  Avoid the mayonnaise-filled rolls.  Lots for food for the money, but I'd rather go for quality than quantity and eat at Oyaji, just a few blocks away.
author: Anonymous M.

description: One of my favourite sushi places in the city!  Go early cos it gets crowded pretty quickly.  Love the Oyster 1849 with the quail egg, uni and tobiko!  Yummilicious!!!  Want something warm?  Go for the Oden (nice, chewy riceballs with fish and broth).  Prices are not cheap but the quality is good.
author: Ai M.

description:
there are enough reviews of this place that i'll keep it simple.

pros:
-competent service -- not overly friendly, but do their job efficiently; this is how i prefer the waitstaff
