-i have been twice.  the first time, i ordered two rounds of kanpachi sashimi.  the first round was melt-in-your-mouth amazing.  second round had thicker pieces, i'm not a fan.  ditto during second visit, but i will say, you get a bang for your buck this way.  much better than the wimpy little sashimi pieces at tsunami.
-piri-kara nasu appetizer: get it.  don't think.  just get it.
-good veggie nigiri options

cons:
-long, looooong wait most nights, esp. weekends
-cramped seating
-limited interesting veggie roll options
author: pitter k.

description:
I have always meant to write a raving review about this restaurant.  It has always been one of our favorite in the city.  

I've always meant to give it 5 stars.  For the type of clientele and market that they cater to, this is an amazing restaurant.  It's fresh, innovative, and absolutely clean and consistent.

Until now.

(Background)
We eat here about twice a month (once every other week), sometimes more if we have guests and want to bring them in for a great sushi experience.  In fact, we're here so much, not only does the entire staff know us, but we've got the menu pretty much memorized; we always order our favorite:  Foie Grois sushi -- the only one I've found of its kind.  Mostly because of the sauce that goes on it.  Keep in mind, we've been going here for over 2 years consistently.

Tonight was a disaster.  We ordered "to go" for the first time, and had my husband pick it up.  Granted, I know sushi ordered "to go" will never be as good because the heat of the sushi rice will eventually heat up the fish (even a little bit).  But the technique and art that comes with their usual sushi was definitely lost tonight.

1.  Foie Grois Sushi-  sauce was still awesome, but the foie grois was definitely burnt.  I understand that they're busy, but at $9.00/order, and it being one of their signature dish, someone better pay attention to their quality.

2.  O-Toro Nigiri (fatty tuna)-  another favorite.  As soon as I opened the box, I knew something didn't look right.  If you've ordered this before, you know it'll look like a very soft smooth fish DRAPED over the rice.  This one came like it was a block chopped from a machine.  Edges were cut very straight, and the slice was VERY thick.  Chefs cut on a bias because there is an even distribution of fat layering you always go for in fishes, especially fatty tunas, which make the fish tender.  The grain on my fish tonight was vertical.  I'm not being a princess about this, but think about it:  As a business owner with very expensive and limited fish, you'd want to make sure that it's being prepared with the best attention.  As a patron, when you pay $10 each piece, then you expect quality.  and if you eat a BLOCK of raw fish, it definitely has a different "taste" than a slice of fish.  The slice of the fish has everything to do with the taste...which is why Sushi chefs take lessons or years to learn how to do it right.

There are usually three sushi chefs behind the bar, and each of them are amazing at what they do.  This leads me to believe that someone else behind the kitchen did the preparation.  

As my husband said, we've eaten there so many times that a bad night is bound to happen.  If this was an off-night in quality or staff courtesy, I would buy it.  The quality is still great, but as with all sushi, the preparation of the dish really makes or breaks it (this is why when we try to make sushi at home, it never "tastes" like they do in the restaurant).

But I'm bringing my review down to 3 stars because it was very irresponsible (as a business) to have someone else (without full training) handle the expensive fishes being served.

Would I recommend it to the next person?
ABSOLUTELY!  Like I said, quality is always great, and we've never had a bad experience when we eat IN the restaurant.
And like I said, the reason I'm knocking stars off my review is because of how they handled a busy night (by giving certain tasks to untrained staff).

If, however, the sushi was prepared by someone behind the bar, then please listen to my review and work on your consistency.
author: ny n.

description: i'm a fan of simple, fresh fish without the extra toppings.  if you like rolls and fusion-type sushi, come here.  i'll have to give this place another try when i'm in the mood for non-traditional sushi.
author: Big e.

description: I don't know what the hype about this place it. It's over priced, the servings are small, even if you do make a reservation it seems like they think it's ok to call you a half an hour before it to tell you it's been postponed an hour AND it's in the Richmond. Now, I haven't had sushi in SF in quite sometime, cuz if I want sushi I go to TGI in Campbell, but apparently they don't give you free miso or salad. When I mentioned this the people I was with said most places in SF don't unless you're in Japantown, which is where I used to go with my gramma when I was a kid. This place isn't worth the effort you have to make to even find parking in the Richmond.
author: Brandi T.

description: Kabuto is the best place for sushi and san francisco.  It's a small place but its worth waiting.  My favorite is the cechive and toro tartar.
author: Annie C.

description: I'm definitely a fan.  The food is delicious.  My only quibbles are that the wait is long (price of popularity?) and the service is a little spacey.  But I reiterate:  the food was great.  The foie gras roll was outta sight.
author: Sophie M.

description:
the reigning champion of san francisco sushi.

amazing marriage of fundamentals and creativity.  the fish is always fresh and full of flavor.  the rice is perfect.  you can't go wrong with just ordering nigiri (kanpachi, katsuo, escalar, 4 types of maguro) or sashimi, but i highly recommend trying some of the items off the special sushi menu.  The hamachi pear, ceviche, toro tartar, ono grape, and jerry are simply amazing.  in addition to the perfectly-matched flavors, the presentation is top-notch.  buy the chefs a beer; they earn it.

this is easily my favorite restaurant in sf right now.  what's really funny is my girlfriend and i recommend it to people all the time, but no one will try it because its on 15th and geary.  there can't be good sushi outside soma or the marina, can there?

thanks to yelp for helping us find this place.
author: alan e.

description: Their food is good, but the it is kinda pricy. myself and 2 other friends went to this place last night. 3 of us order couple dishes and cost us about $130. but over all it was a good, just make sure to bring some money with you when you visit.
author: MF M.

description: Some of the most creative sushi I've ever had.  Some are really funky sounding but I've always had a good meal here.
author: Heidy M.

description: I went here about 3 years ago when they were in the previous location.  I'll be the first to say that the sushi here is REALLY good.  There's not much atmosphere in the new location--quite small, kinda loud, but comfortable.  The only thing I take issue with is their prices.  I went there with a friend, really excited because I remember how great their fish was.  The prices on their menu seemed reasonable--$3-5 for nigiri and anywhere from $5-12 for their rolls.  They have some specialty apps that are also fabulous.  My friend and I ordered a pretty average size meal, maybe 3 orders of nigiri, a couple of rolls, and beer.  The bill came to a whopping $65.  When we asked why it was so high, they told us that the nigiri prices are priced "per piece."  Who does that?  Logically then, if we placed "an order" of nigiri, they should bring us one piece; instead they automatically brought us two, without saying a word.  We didn't argue.  We just paid the bill (with a minimal tip) and decided never to go back.  I don't think they did it maliciously, but they should be crystal clear up front that their pricing is twice as much as most other sushi places in the city.  The fish is good, but not good enough to pay double the average.
author: Melinda G.
